deal_metadata.current_narrative: Chris, We reviewed Intuit?s renewal pricing from Jive. On the initial purchase in 2015, there were a couple of iterations and the final term was one year for $400K.  It allowed for a first renewal at $420K for 10,000 users and then had language indicating another four renewals wouldn?t increase by more than 5% each year.   NPIs top end target was $40/user/year and Intuit improved upon its initial $48/offer when the deal was finalized. NPI didn?t review last year?s renewal.  Per the terms of the contract this second renewal shouldn?t exceed 105% of $420K or $441K.  The renewal is for essentially the identical subscription and set of features.  It now includes Encryption at Rest and Cloud Private Preview which were separately added in mid-2016.  The base cost is $420K a year or $42 per person (10,000 users) plus $25K for Encryption and $15K for Cloud Private Preview.  Jive is likely not exercising its right to increase costs 5% on the core subscription to offset the added costs of Encryption and Private Preview now that the two contracts have merged.  The annualized cost of Encryption was $50K and $15K for Private Preview when NPI did our initial review in 2016.  NPI never learned the outcome of this add-on purchase but it appears a further reduction of Encryption was received since the renewal is at $25K.  NPI is assuming Encryption landed at $25K and Private Preview at $15K and they are also renewing at a flat cost.  The offer of $460K appears to be flat compared to the prior two years.  This is great since we know Jive has the right to at least increase the core subscription by 5%.  NPI wouldn?t expect a reduction in costs on a flat renewal.  While this isn?t the inaugural term for Private Review on another recent renewal for a client with 7000 users, Cloud Private Preview was included at no charge.  However, in this case this was an add-on to the renewal.  Intuit has already contracted for Private Preview so it can be hard to negotiate those costs out.  The site link below provides some good detail about Private Preview.  Intuit could consider making the case that Private Preview strongly helps Jive thrive and expand at Intuit and push back on the $15K spend.  https://community.jivesoftware.com/docs/DOC-180119
deal_metadata.description: Could I get a quick FMV benchmark on Jive?  Much thanks,

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email, see the attached below.  Pricing appeared to be really bad and not in consideration of volume tiers as noted in documentation found online.  Estimating the term.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: So this feedback is less about a benchmark and more about sharing the findings from some research we performed.  While we?ve done a ton of Riverbed hardware and support reviews and a few Riverbed SaaS reviews, none of these involved Aternity.  They?re an Israeli company that Riverbed bought toward the end of 2016.  http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-riverbed-acquires-israeli-saas-co-aternity-for-70m-1001142685  https://www.riverbed.com/press-releases/riverbed-announces-definitive-agreement-to-acquire-leading-end-user-experience-monitoring-provider-aternity.html  The punchline is we believe there?s room for substantial savings.  We found it odd that the one year and three year offers were added together by SoftwareOne and that the multi-year offer didn?t reflect any improved discount.   ?	Elavon?s quotes didn?t include list pricing or provide any indication of the discount being offered ?	In NPIs experience, Riverbed has offered the same discount levels for hardware, software and SaaS subscriptions ?	NPI believes we determined the list price for the primary Part Number ? ATNY-SAAS.  We also believe the other two Parts are zero dollar items.  This is an oddly-constructed set of parts as all three line items seem to just restate the same words just in a different order for the most part.  ?	Part of our efforts were to validate that the two zero dollar items are typically no cost items.  While we found listings on CDW for the ATNY-SAAS product we got no hits at all when searching sites for pricing on the other two products. ?	Additionally, NPI has the attached price list from early 2017.  If you search ATNY-SAAS-PTO you will get only one hit for a zero dollar evaluation license.  If you search LIC-ATNY-SAAS you will get no hits.  If you search ATNY-SAAS you get a plethora of hits. o	The most interesting observation is the clear volume-based tiers offered by Aternity that don?t appear to be reflected in Elavon?s quote.  o	There are 8 volume tiers (they start at 500-999 because the subscription indicates 500 is the minimum quantity you can buy).  The list price at this level is $8.33/mo o	Elavon?s volume of 57,600 (one year volumes multiplied by three) slots into the second highest tier (50,000-99,999) which has a list price of $2.55 o	Elavon?s offer is $6.15.  This is a 26% discount from the lowest tier list price of $8.33. o	In February of 2018, NPI provided another client with a review of a purchase that included SaaS subscriptions.  We were able to validate that several list prices provided in that quote matched the same list price in the Feb 2017 attached price list.  While this doesn?t confirm we have the latest price list it provides some support that it is still valid.   ?	In addition, to the programmatic reduced list price based on volume, in NPIs experience Elavon should also receive a discount off that.  30% would be a solid (not aggressive) discount target.  The caveat is if there?s some reason Riverbed doesn?t discount Aternity subscriptions similar to other SaaS subscriptions (NPIs recent experience was with SteelCentral AppInternals SaaS Core). ?	Elavon should seek a starting price of $2.55.  Software One may get a bit wily and indicate they need to use the annual volume of 19,200 which has a list price of $3.15 (tier is 10,000-29,999).  Additionally, a discount of 25-35% should be offered especially if this is a first-time purchase.  The table below shows these scenarios, the targets and targeted reductions.  These are quite significant.  While NPI admits to not having performed an Aternity-related review in the past we believe there?s enough findings to support Elavon seeking reductions or at least some rock solid explanations if the current offer is truly a good one.  ?	NPI also recommends Elavon take a look at past discounts on any recent/prior Riverbed hardware purchases to see the historical discounts offered by Riverbed as this can support current targets. ?	It would be interesting to see what list price and discount are  being used to come up with the $6.15 offer. While it is possible the other two parts have list prices >$0 that aren?t being shown I?d push for clear evidence of that. ?	Riverbed does not offer the best search tool to find partners and see their level within the ecosystem but SoftwareOne may not be the highest partner with Riverbed and this may be evidenced in their offer. http://partnerlocator.riverbed.com/ Searching in Georgia NPI didn?t see SoftwareOne show up in the list.  An even broader search didn?t find a hit either. The levels were Elite, Premier and Authorized.  Ask S1 if they?re a partner and their level.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Gregg,  Can you please work your magic and see if the three year plan can be any better or if it looks good to you.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAP SuccessFactors for HCM transformation - Global Proposal
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the updated proposal from SAP for a global rollout. As detailed in the previous FMV report, and as compared to other market transactions, NPI still believes there is room for significant improvement in pricing. The pricing for Compensation, Performance and Succession are now in the range of FMV (with room for small improvement). The pricing for Learning and Employee Central, Workforce Analytics & Planning are still above FMV.  Overall, there is still room for improvement of about $3.6M which would bring the total cost over 5 years to $18.2M which is also closer to Oracle?s proposed pricing of $17.8M.  The table below has more details on the FMV price for the global rollout.  In terms of the concessions,  ?	the exchange rights offered are superior to the others we have seen at NPI.   o	SAP routinely offers exchange rights, but these are usually within product families. o	We have seen only one other instance where they offered an exchange right across products.   o	We also see exchange rights capped (usually a certain number of users or a certain % of revenue). In this case, SAP has not subject the exchange rights to any caps. ?	If Aramark runs SAP ERP, there is greater flexibility to save money. There may be scope for more exchange rights with existing on-premise software. ?	The services credit provided is small ($350K) for a $20 M deal. Since SAP will be displacing all the incumbent HCM and learning software, Aramark will incur an additional cost of $3.86M in implementation fees to make this change. Aramark should negotiate additional consulting credit for implementation.
deal_metadata.description: this deal is a competing proposal for Oracle HCM. SAP provided an updated proposal for the Global numbers. Deal-36473 is for the North America numbers only.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI has seen In the recent past, Altify has used the following discount table (for what? Single product?  Bundles?): 0 > 50 = 5% 51 > 150 = 15% 150 > 300 = 25% 300 > 400 = 32.50% 400 > 1500  = 40%  JCI?s pricing picks up from this point but starts at 41%, which NPI considers to be ABOVE FMV (for clarity, pricing is high, discounting is low).  Previously, JCI?s discount from list has largely been at 59% off of list, with the exception of order 2, where JCI rec?d 76% off of list. The matrix laid out in the initial contract for JCI was very aggressive, relative to other clients and yet, JCI was actually priced into the 3rd tier, 3K-5K licenses, despite having a collective license pool of only 1,642 licenses, placing JCI in the 2nd pricing tier.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The lever to be pulled with Altify is that there is growing competition in this space and while their solution may be cutting edge, there are pricing values to be found with other vendors that offer most of the same features that they do. Were JCI to only be increasing the subscription 2-3x, NPI envisions that JCI would top out at discounting between 65-75% or a subscription base of $2.3-$3.3M annually, still an enviable position for most clients.  Based on the 10x license pool that JCI is projecting, (just under 16K licenses), NPI is confident that JCI can push past the discount schedule previously provided to as high as 85-90% off of list. With that type of projected growth, the message to Altify is a concern over being penalized for growing the solution organically.  The believe is that if JCI were purchasing that number of licenses now, you would see significantly better pricing.  Why should you be penalized for growing the solution organically to get up to the 16K licenses.   NOTE: Closing for data cleanup... no final docs.
deal_metadata.description: From: David Mazur [mailto:david.john.mazur@jci.com]  Sent: Thursday, September 14, 2017 5:00 PM To: Chris Vicknair <cvicknair@npifinancial.com> Subject: Altify /TAS Benchmark Request  Hi Chris,   Per our conversation, attached are the agreement components related to our Altify/TAS.  Please review and provide assessment.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposal from Oracle for Hyperion (Oracle Cloud Fusion) Enterprise Planning and Budgeting Cloud Services and Analytics Cloud and found the pricing to be above FMV with room for significant improvement.   Pricing Analysis  Oracle EPBCS  ?	The user Saas fee for Oracle Enterprise Planning and Budgeting Cloud Service is proposed at $175 per user per month.  ?	The EPBCS subscription lists at $250 per user per month.  ?	This translates to a discount of 30%. NPI has seen the market range of discounts for this software vary between 60% and 80% based on the size of the deal and the customer?s leverage.  For a purchase of this size and based on Metlife?s brand, size and spend with Oracle, as well as the (60 month) term of the deal, NPI would expect starting discounts to be 70%. NPI would expect a 30% discount for smaller sized deals of with a 1 year term. ?	NPI would recommend a best-in-class discount target of 80% which would amount to savings of $4.1M for the 60 month contract. ?	NPI would expect the test environment licenses as well as the storage discounts to match the per user EPBCS discount of 80%.   Oracle Analytics Cloud for Finance  ?	Oracle has provided deeper discounts of Oracle Analytics Cloud - Enterprise of 59%.  ?	Monthly subscription price is proposed at $2,460.  ?	The subscription lists at $6000 per month. This translates to a discount of 59%. While this is a good starting point, NPI recommends a target discount between 70% and 80% for the subscriptions in this quote as well ?	Achieving an 80% discount translates to savings of $2,046,265 for this purchase order.   Negotiation Leverage and Strategy  Oracle has siloed sales teams for each family of products which is why Metlife has 2 different quotes even though you are making both purchases at the same time. The sales reps are separately commissioned for the products assigned to them. The sales reps may or may not even know about the other purchases. It is to Oracle?s benefit to keep the sales teams disparate, in order to put a ceiling on the discounts based on the product family.  ?	The term of the subscriptions is a great leverage. Sales reps are compensated immediately based on the size of the deal, so a (larger) 60 month deal is more beneficial to the Oracle sales rep. Oracle also likes longer term deals because it locks in recurring revenue for the term of the contract, and Oracle?s revenue grows based on the customer?s growth over the 60 month term. Threat of reducing the term to 12 months , thus reducing the deal size greatly would incent Oracle to provide deeper discounts for a longer term deal. ?	Ask Oracle to combine the quote (even though it may not be possible) and use the higher combined list price to get greater discount. ?	Use the large HCM Cloud purchase from 2016 which had a discount of 87% to set the discount expectations for these purchases.  Close out comments: Gregg ? that was exactly it, we put some competition into the mix and we were able to execute by the end of the month.  Discount for EPBCS went up from 30 to 38% and Analytics went up from 58% to 68%.
deal_metadata.description: starting Financial Oracle fusion review

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Did not review. Adding deal without contract so data is in the system.

file_info.name: AmFam Adobe ETLA Renewal Agreement Final Partial.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Amfam has done an excellent job negotiating with Adobe on this ETLA renewal.  ?	Amfam has ?rightsized? the deal and optimized the counts for Document Cloud Enterprise ? Std (from 20,831 to 16,500). The savings achieved for this line item is $160K annually and ?$480K over the 3 year term of the ETLA. ?	Amfam has successfully negotiated lower per unit pricing on most of the products despite the reduction in spend/scope of the ETLA. When customers reduce the deal size, Adobe invariably increases the pricing on the products which has not occurred here. ?	Cost reductions achieved including the cost savings from optimizing product count is 21% or $548K for the ETLA. After adjusting for volumes, the savings from reductions in per unit pricing only is 15% or $106K for the term of the ETLA. ?	The final product pricing is within FMV for the size of the deal.  Initial Baseline (including 20831 Acrobat Std licenses) is - $2,552,842. Final Quote is $2,005,176 (16,500 Acrobat licenses).
deal_metadata.description: Ihor,   Can you forward this request to NPI to have them review our pricing with Adobe?  I have attached a spreadsheet that shows our Adobe pricing under our existing contract along with the pricing they gave us as a renewal quote.  I would like to see how our pricing stacks up to what NPI is seeing nationally.   I would also like to see if everyone is experiencing these price increases.   Folks,  Please see attached. Please review and provide your input.  Sincerely,  Ihor Jakymec

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposal from Ivoxy Consulting and finds that although pricing is within FMV, historic pricing seen by Seattle Children?s Hospital in the past lends credibility for an increased discount.                   Pricing Analysis  Current Proposal:   	List Price	Quote	Discount Hardware	$ 398,141	$ 142,679	64.2% Support	$ 117,004	$ 88,243	24.6% Software	$ 714,426	$ 240,176	66.4% Grand Total	$ 1,229,571	$ 471,098	61.7%   Prior SCH Purchase (7/13/15):  7/13/15	List Price	Quote	Discount Hardware	$ 939,638 	$ 235,139 	75% Software	$ 472,300 	$ 104,659 	78% Maintenance	$ 855,123 	$ 161,401 	81% Services	$ 12,000 	$ 12,000 	0% Total	$ 2,279,061 	$ 513,199 	77%  ?	NPI finds the blended hardware discount of 64.2% to be at the lower end of FMV. ?	NPI finds the blended software discount of 66.4% to be at the lower end of FMV. ?	Software pricing should typically fall at 20% of net pricing of hardware and software combined.  This figure, as quoted, is at 23% of net pricing and is above FMV.   Targets   	List Price	Quote	Discount	Target Price	Target Discount	Target Savings HW	$ 398,141	$ 142,679	64.2%	$ 99,535 	75%	$ 43,143  Support	$ 117,004	$ 88,243	24.6%	$ 51,342 		$ 36,902  SW	$ 714,426	$ 240,176	66.4%	$ 157,174 	78%	$ 83,002  Grand Total	$ 1,229,571	$ 471,098	61.7%	$ 308,051	74.9%	$ 163,047  ?	Based on historic discounts received by Seattle Children?s Hospital, NPI sets similar target discounts. ?	NPI acknowledges that these targets are slightly aggressive as the prior SCH deal was a slightly larger deal with ?new logo? potential.   ?	The more aggressive, best in class discount, results in a 74.9% blended discount with a $ 163,047 savings.   ?	A fallback position with a 70% discount on hardware and software will result in a blended 67.4% discount and a $70,574 savings. ?	Discounting off list pricing for the support/maintenance line item can be misleading.  Review final pricing to ensure that support lands at 20% of the final hardware and software costs.    Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	In contrast to the prior negotiation tactics with Ivoxy, NPI recommends that rather than focusing on dollar amounts, SCH should work with Ivoxy and push them for the same discounts as previously received.  Because SCH now has a target discount to strive for, it sets a somewhat innocent target that needs to be met.   ?	NPI would expect a pushback based on the prior deal was ~ 1 million greater in list pricing.  Reality is that after discounts are applied, the differences are within a few hundred thousand and still warrant discount levels greater than the current 64% on hardware and software. ?	?New logo? opportunities help drive discounting a little deeper.  This deeper discounting may have occurred in the prior deal.  The position that SCH should maintain is that ?we can still easily choose to play a dual vendor strategy with our storage solutions if we can?t find the right solution at the right price?. ?	Support is currently quoted at 23% of the combined hardware and software costs.  NPI recommends that SCH target a 20% of net price of hardware and software. ?	NetApp Q3 end is 10/31 and a quarter-end deal will typically allow for the best negotiation power with a promise to close this deal in Q3.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Subsequent overage

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Apttus and found the proposal to be in the range of FMV with scope for improvement. ?	Apttus has proposed pricing of $35.25 for the Enterprise CLM edition.  ?	The pricing appears to be grandfathered from Aramark?s pricing for Contract Wizard which is one of the key functionalities in Enterprise CLM.  ?	Aramark?s current pricing of $39.75 for Contract Wizard for about 800 users represents a discount of 47%. ?	For 1386 users, the discount tier in the 2013 contract is 53% which translates to a price of $35.25 per user per month.  Below is the snapshot of Aramark?s discount tiers in the 2013 MSA.   NPI has seen pricing for Apttus CLM range between $22 and $60. NPI has observed that there is no consistency in pricing and there is large variance in the market. Pricing is not necessarily closely correlated with the purchase volume; it varies based on many factors and depends mainly on the presence of competition (especially at the time of the initial purchase) as well as customer?s requirements and negotiation leverage. NPI recommends target pricing of $33 per user per month for CLM Enterprise. Achieving a target of $33 per user per month translates to savings of $37K annually.  However, the fact that this is largely a renewal and hence there is a lack of competition reduces Aramark?s leverage. NPI also recommends that Aramark ask about tiered pricing and the associated price breaks as well as capped/flat out year pricing. License Type	Qty	Price	Term	Total Annual Price	Total Price	Target Price	Target Annual Price	Annual Savings	Target Total Price	Total Savings Enterprise CLM Edition	786	$35.25 	48	$332,478 	$1,329,912 	$33 	$311,256 	$21,222 	$1,245,024 	$84,888  Enterprise CLM Edition	600	$35.25 	47	$253,800 	$994,050 	$33 	$237,600 	$16,200 	$930,600 	$63,450   Overall, the Enterprise CLM offering is a better value for Aramark (as compared to the current cost of Contract Wizard licenses).  In addition to including Contract Wizard, which is one of the key functions, but not the only key function in the Enterprise CLM offering, it includes the other components that Aramark currently licenses, plus a good amount more which Aramark may find useful.
deal_metadata.description: Note from vendor: In summary, our proposal offers Aramark over 400k in savings on its current deployment, and lowers significantly the overall unit costs for the entire user population. While we have not achieved Steve?s objective of adding 600 users without an increase to the annual cost, our unique set of circumstances leading into the end of October allows us to provide extraordinary value at this time and we encourage you to move forward with our offer.   If we have not achieved your organization?s objectives, I suggest we schedule a call with our systems engineering group and our business value consultant with your key stakeholders to determine if we can identify/quantify the business value for the additional 600 users to help the proposal over the goal line prior to the end of October.

file_info.name: Segment Price Negotiation for CDP - Event Collection Distribution.msg

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Segment Price Negotiation for CDP - Event Collection/Distribution
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Dianne,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  While we have seen other CDP deals, NPI has not seen the volumes that Intuit is purchasing.  The CDP world continues to grow at an amazing pace and is expected to become even more competitive (to the benefit of Intuit).    With that said, NPI would agree that your data leader has done a very good job at both negotiating and documenting the journey.  Based on the Segment deals we have seen and extrapolating a bit on the size of this deal, NPI concludes that this deal appears to be solidly Fair Market Value (FMV).  We believe that Intuit can move forward with confidence on this transaction.
deal_metadata.description: CV:No docs yet... requested quote/proposal from Dianne.  Hope all is well! Thank you again for providing the pricing analysis for Adobe Analytics. I have 2 more requests for next week if your team has the capabilities to analyze market pricing for Segment for CDP- event collection/distribution and Tealium for tag management. I?ll send the Tealium request on another email.   We feel comfortable with the final proposal that we received. Our data leader has done an excellent job with the negotiation. However, we want to get your team?s thoughts if there are any negotiation leverage that we haven?t explored based on your customer?s dealings with Segment. Please see below the price negotiation journey that our leader provided. Please let me know if your team has expertise in analyzing CDP providers and if you have any questions. Thank you!     ? Current FY18 rate: $130K for 3M monthly active identifiers (e.g. cookie or authId). Identifier overages are expensive (we owe $70K and may owe as much as $114K by July). Basic enterprise service level. "Data governance" package not included (schema validation/enforcement, Lambda transformations, more coming). ? Offer 1 (Dec '17 for SBSEG marketing websites): $815K for 50M monthly active identifiers ? Offer 2 (Feb '18): $1.5M for 360M annual identifiers + "data governance" package. Previously Segment only offered monthly plans, and because of our seasonality we pressed for an annual cap instead. However, active identifier pricing is still terrible for planning because we have many anonymous Intuit experiences (marketing websites, invoice payment portal). So we pushed Segment over several conversations to offer annual event volume pricing to meet our needs. ? Offer 3 (Early Mar '18): $1.3M for 50B events + data governance free for 1 year ($300K after) + "gold account" service.  ? Offer 4 (Mid Mar '18) ? Segment is asking for 2 year agreement and deal by Apr 1 for the below: ? 3 mos free + overage debt forgiveness till now + "gold account" service + data governance free for 2 yrs + upcoming CDP profiles/audience product free for 1 year ($400K after) ? $1.05M for 80B events ? $1.2M for 100B events ? $1.3M for 120B events (for comparison, Intuit estimated 120B events will be sent to Adobe Analytics in FY19)   ? I gave some thoughtful reasons in asking for the following concessions: ? $100K cut off the top volume (120B) ? 1 year deal with Aug 1 start date (Segment really wants July 1 at least for the first year for a revenue recognition reason.) ? Exclude "identify" and "group" calls from event volumes (these are for setting user profile info, not really tracking events) ? Overage forgiveness for the rest of FY18 (they had only considered overages up until now) ? After a call with their sales team, this is Offer 5 (Mar 23, 2018) which has 4 options, all which include:  ? 126B events (to cover "identify" and "group" API calls, estimating 5% of calls)  ? Overage debt forgiveness through March (2 options cover the rest of FY18) ? "Gold account" high value customer status ? Data governance package included free for the duration of the term ? Profiles/audience product free through Dec 2018. $233K option to license through end of FY19. For 2 year agreements, $400K option for year 2 (this product will likely be priced $700-800K similar to competitors). 1. July 1 start. 13 months for $1.3M (w/ 10.5B extra events to cover July). Overage forgiveness through June. 2. Aug 1 start. 12 month agreement for $1.25M. (Overage fees assessed Apr-Jul, estimated $50K -- no upside over July 1 start) 3. file_info.name: NPI FMV Report Metlife Oracle Fusion - Oct - 2017.docx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposal from Oracle for Hyperion (Oracle Cloud Fusion) Enterprise Planning and Budgeting Cloud Services and Analytics Cloud and found the pricing to be above FMV with room for significant improvement.   Pricing Analysis  Oracle EPBCS  ?	The user Saas fee for Oracle Enterprise Planning and Budgeting Cloud Service is proposed at $175 per user per month.  ?	The EPBCS subscription lists at $250 per user per month.  ?	This translates to a discount of 30%. NPI has seen the market range of discounts for this software vary between 60% and 80% based on the size of the deal and the customer?s leverage.  For a purchase of this size and based on Metlife?s brand, size and spend with Oracle, as well as the (60 month) term of the deal, NPI would expect starting discounts to be 70%. NPI would expect a 30% discount for smaller sized deals of with a 1 year term. ?	NPI would recommend a best-in-class discount target of 80% which would amount to savings of $4.1M for the 60 month contract. ?	NPI would expect the test environment licenses as well as the storage discounts to match the per user EPBCS discount of 80%.   Oracle Analytics Cloud for Finance  ?	Oracle has provided deeper discounts of Oracle Analytics Cloud - Enterprise of 59%.  ?	Monthly subscription price is proposed at $2,460.  ?	The subscription lists at $6000 per month. This translates to a discount of 59%. While this is a good starting point, NPI recommends a target discount between 70% and 80% for the subscriptions in this quote as well ?	Achieving an 80% discount translates to savings of $2,046,265 for this purchase order.   Negotiation Leverage and Strategy  Oracle has siloed sales teams for each family of products which is why Metlife has 2 different quotes even though you are making both purchases at the same time. The sales reps are separately commissioned for the products assigned to them. The sales reps may or may not even know about the other purchases. It is to Oracle?s benefit to keep the sales teams disparate, in order to put a ceiling on the discounts based on the product family.  ?	The term of the subscriptions is a great leverage. Sales reps are compensated immediately based on the size of the deal, so a (larger) 60 month deal is more beneficial to the Oracle sales rep. Oracle also likes longer term deals because it locks in recurring revenue for the term of the contract, and Oracle?s revenue grows based on the customer?s growth over the 60 month term. Threat of reducing the term to 12 months , thus reducing the deal size greatly would incent Oracle to provide deeper discounts for a longer term deal. ?	Ask Oracle to combine the quote (even though it may not be possible) and use the higher combined list price to get greater discount. ?	Use the large HCM Cloud purchase from 2016 which had a discount of 87% to set the discount expectations for these purchases.  Close out comments: Gregg ? that was exactly it, we put some competition into the mix and we were able to execute by the end of the month.  Discount for EPBCS went up from 30 to 38% and Analytics went up from 58% to 68%.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Amfam has done an excellent job negotiating with Adobe on this ETLA renewal.  ?	Amfam has ?rightsized? the deal and optimized the counts for Document Cloud Enterprise ? Std (from 20,831 to 16,500). The savings achieved for this line item is $160K annually and ?$480K over the 3 year term of the ETLA. ?	Amfam has successfully negotiated lower per unit pricing on most of the products despite the reduction in spend/scope of the ETLA. When customers reduce the deal size, Adobe invariably increases the pricing on the products which has not occurred here. ?	Cost reductions achieved including the cost savings from optimizing product count is 21% or $548K for the ETLA. After adjusting for volumes, the savings from reductions in per unit pricing only is 15% or $106K for the term of the ETLA. ?	The final product pricing is within FMV for the size of the deal.  Initial Baseline (including 20831 Acrobat Std licenses) is - $2,552,842. Final Quote is $2,005,176 (16,500 Acrobat licenses).

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Apttus and found the proposal to be in the range of FMV with scope for improvement. ?	Apttus has proposed pricing of $35.25 for the Enterprise CLM edition.  ?	The pricing appears to be grandfathered from Aramark?s pricing for Contract Wizard which is one of the key functionalities in Enterprise CLM.  ?	Aramark?s current pricing of $39.75 for Contract Wizard for about 800 users represents a discount of 47%. ?	For 1386 users, the discount tier in the 2013 contract is 53% which translates to a price of $35.25 per user per month.  Below is the snapshot of Aramark?s discount tiers in the 2013 MSA.   NPI has seen pricing for Apttus CLM range between $22 and $60. NPI has observed that there is no consistency in pricing and there is large variance in the market. Pricing is not necessarily closely correlated with the purchase volume; it varies based on many factors and depends mainly on the presence of competition (especially at the time of the initial purchase) as well as customer?s requirements and negotiation leverage. NPI recommends target pricing of $33 per user per month for CLM Enterprise. Achieving a target of $33 per user per month translates to savings of $37K annually.  However, the fact that this is largely a renewal and hence there is a lack of competition reduces Aramark?s leverage. NPI also recommends that Aramark ask about tiered pricing and the associated price breaks as well as capped/flat out year pricing. License Type	Qty	Price	Term	Total Annual Price	Total Price	Target Price	Target Annual Price	Annual Savings	Target Total Price	Total Savings Enterprise CLM Edition	786	$35.25 	48	$332,478 	$1,329,912 	$33 	$311,256 	$21,222 	$1,245,024 	$84,888  Enterprise CLM Edition	600	$35.25 	47	$253,800 	$994,050 	$33 	$237,600 	$16,200 	$930,600 	$63,450   Overall, the Enterprise CLM offering is a better value for Aramark (as compared to the current cost of Contract Wizard licenses).  In addition to including Contract Wizard, which is one of the key functions, but not the only key function in the Enterprise CLM offering, it includes the other components that Aramark currently licenses, plus a good amount more which Aramark may find useful.
deal_metadata.description: Note from vendor: In summary, our proposal offers Aramark over 400k in savings on its current deployment, and lowers significantly the overall unit costs for the entire user population. While we have not achieved Steve?s objective of adding 600 users without an increase to the annual cost, our unique set of circumstances leading into the end of October allows us to provide extraordinary value at this time and we encourage you to move forward with our offer.   If we have not achieved your organization?s objectives, I suggest we schedule a call with our systems engineering group and our business value consultant with your key stakeholders to determine if we can identify/quantify the business value for the additional 600 users to help the proposal over the goal line prior to the end of October.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email, see the attached below.  Pricing appeared to be really bad and not in consideration of volume tiers as noted in documentation found online.  Estimating the term.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: So this feedback is less about a benchmark and more about sharing the findings from some research we performed.  While we?ve done a ton of Riverbed hardware and support reviews and a few Riverbed SaaS reviews, none of these involved Aternity.  They?re an Israeli company that Riverbed bought toward the end of 2016.  http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-riverbed-acquires-israeli-saas-co-aternity-for-70m-1001142685  https://www.riverbed.com/press-releases/riverbed-announces-definitive-agreement-to-acquire-leading-end-user-experience-monitoring-provider-aternity.html  The punchline is we believe there?s room for substantial savings.  We found it odd that the one year and three year offers were added together by SoftwareOne and that the multi-year offer didn?t reflect any improved discount.   ?	Elavon?s quotes didn?t include list pricing or provide any indication of the discount being offered ?	In NPIs experience, Riverbed has offered the same discount levels for hardware, software and SaaS subscriptions ?	NPI believes we determined the list price for the primary Part Number ? ATNY-SAAS.  We also believe the other two Parts are zero dollar items.  This is an oddly-constructed set of parts as all three line items seem to just restate the same words just in a different order for the most part.  ?	Part of our efforts were to validate that the two zero dollar items are typically no cost items.  While we found listings on CDW for the ATNY-SAAS product we got no hits at all when searching sites for pricing on the other two products. ?	Additionally, NPI has the attached price list from early 2017.  If you search ATNY-SAAS-PTO you will get only one hit for a zero dollar evaluation license.  If you search LIC-ATNY-SAAS you will get no hits.  If you search ATNY-SAAS you get a plethora of hits. o	The most interesting observation is the clear volume-based tiers offered by Aternity that don?t appear to be reflected in Elavon?s quote.  o	There are 8 volume tiers (they start at 500-999 because the subscription indicates 500 is the minimum quantity you can buy).  The list price at this level is $8.33/mo o	Elavon?s volume of 57,600 (one year volumes multiplied by three) slots into the second highest tier (50,000-99,999) which has a list price of $2.55 o	Elavon?s offer is $6.15.  This is a 26% discount from the lowest tier list price of $8.33. o	In February of 2018, NPI provided another client with a review of a purchase that included SaaS subscriptions.  We were able to validate that several list prices provided in that quote matched the same list price in the Feb 2017 attached price list.  While this doesn?t confirm we have the latest price list it provides some support that it is still valid.   ?	In addition, to the programmatic reduced list price based on volume, in NPIs experience Elavon should also receive a discount off that.  30% would be a solid (not aggressive) discount target.  The caveat is if there?s some reason Riverbed doesn?t discount Aternity subscriptions similar to other SaaS subscriptions (NPIs recent experience was with SteelCentral AppInternals SaaS Core). ?	Elavon should seek a starting price of $2.55.  Software One may get a bit wily and indicate they need to use the annual volume of 19,200 which has a list price of $3.15 (tier is 10,000-29,999).  Additionally, a discount of 25-35% should be offered especially if this is a first-time purchase.  The table below shows these scenarios, the targets and targeted reductions.  These are quite significant.  While NPI admits to not having performed an Aternity-related review in the past we believe there?s enough findings to support Elavon seeking reductions or at least some rock solid explanations if the current offer is truly a good one.  ?	NPI also recommends Elavon take a look at past discounts on any recent/prior Riverbed hardware purchases to see the historical discounts offered by Riverbed as this can support current targets. ?	It would be interesting to see what list price and discount are  being used to come up with the $6.15 offer. While it is possible the other two parts have list prices >$0 that aren?t being shown I?d push for clear evidence of that. ?	Riverbed does not offer the best search tool to find partners and see their level within the ecosystem but SoftwareOne may not be the highest partner with Riverbed and this may be evidenced in their offer. http://partnerlocator.riverbed.com/ Searching in Georgia NPI didn?t see SoftwareOne show up in the list.  An even broader search didn?t find a hit either. The levels were Elite, Premier and Authorized.  Ask S1 if they?re a partner and their level.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Large SAP purchase: IBP, SAP CPQ, SAP Hybris Commerce, Ariba supply chain collaboration
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the SAP products likely to be purchased by Intel. If Intel purchases all of these products together, this will be a very large purchase with a list price value of $5B (Year 1 perpetual license/cloud subscription, Hybris Commerce with a revenue metric). It will be a unique purchase with custom pricing and discounts.   As with other software purchases, the discount range is impacted by historic discounts/pricing, scope of purchase, competition, growth and term commitment.
Did not review. Adding deal without contract so data is in the system.

Most of the guideline recommendations on slide 2 in the VzW deck are basic recommendations that should be implemented. Similar recommendations should be obtained from AT&T for optimization.   For comparisons, it was good to bring in T-Mobile, however, we see most clients using them in limited cases due to coverage issues. Alternatively, NetApp should look at MetTel for comparative quotes. They are an MVNO that can be creative in the servicing of accounts such as this which ultimately drive costs down and create efficiencies. Please ask for further details.  It?s worth noting that the majority of cost savings in the cellular suite of services come from optimization efforts and that the observations below should be used as a guideline.  Discounts ?	For an account of this size, we work to achieve discounts of 22%-23% from Verizon Wireless. They appear to be offering 14%. ?	Similarly, we work toward AT&T discounts of 25% for an account this size. (No ATT proposal was shared.)  Activations Credits ?	For an account of your size, work to get the following activation credits o	AT&T = $150 o	VzW = $125 (in proposal, so OK) ?	Don?t buy accessories from carriers.  For accessories, Verizon offers a 50% discount.  Even so, their discounted prices will be much higher than even standard retail pricing.  Plans (VzW) ?	Business Unlimited data (all device types), we recommend that you push to achieve rates approaching $40 per month. ?	Business Limited could go as low as $30 per month.  Pool optimization ?	Recommend the buffer should be managed to ~10%. ?	One potential issue with the proposed plan distribution is management of the pool. With the amount of plan types being proposed, pool management can be problematic. You can save time, hassle, and cost by reducing the number of plans.  Make sure that the contract terms allow unlimited movement from one pricing plan to another in a given month.   Additional observations ?	We agree that Travel Pass should be added to all international roaming phones, as suggested in the proposal. ?	On the TCO, cell H8, you indicate an AT&T MARC of $6 MM ? does this include a substantial wireline spend?  Otherwise, you will not hit it, so don?t agree to it. ?	For true TCO calculation and proposal analysis, we strongly recommend to perform an independent cost assessment using recent actual data usage (available from the billing portals) by a 3rd party SME. Any time a provider recommends how to pay them less, their analysis should be fully scrutinized.

Maybe they can suggest better way to do TCO and some alternate comparison structure.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pricing Analysis ?	Analysis of a draft version of the JDA Software contract appears to have the initial Guitar Spend defined as:  Standard Software	Qty	License Fees Space Planning Plus	6	$ 53,561  Floor Planning Plus	6	$ 53,561  Space Automation	6	$ 10,043  Intactix Knowledge Base	1	$ 218,562  Intactix Knowledge Base Web Publisher	1	$ 64,274  Space Planning Viewer		$ 0  Floor Planning Viewer		$ 0  Estimated Total Purchase Price		$ 400,000   ?	NPI does not have access to the fully executed agreement, yet viewed in other known JDA Software agreements is an annual escalator clause which allows for JDA to ?increase the Maintenance fee by the lesser of 3%, or the percentage increase in the Employment Cost Index for total compensation, for all civilian workers as published by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics during the 12 months prior to the effective date of the increase?. ?	NPI reviewed the original purchase price and applied the annual increases as per what NPI would normally expect from JDA. ?	Employment Cost Index for total compensation of all civilian workers as published by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics (https://www.bls.gov/web/eci/echistrynaics.pdf) is listed below.    ?	NPI estimates increases did not begin until the end of the 4th year, versus at the end of the 3-year contract. ?	Employing the Q1 ECI-A numbers as the annual basis, NPI applied the expected increases to the original basis and finds the resultant renewal figure to be closely aligned to where it would be expected to be.  Estimated renewal rate falls at $115,228 versus actual renewal rate quoted as $115,682.  Year	Support Cost	Increase	ECI - A 2007	$ 88,000 	3.0%	3.5% 2008	$ 90,640 	3.0%	3.4% 2009	$ 93,359 	2.3%	2.3% 2010	$ 95,506 	1.9%	1.9% 2011	$ 97,321 	2.2%	2.2% 2012	$ 99,462 	2.3%	2.3% 2013	$ 101,750 	2.1%	2.1% 2014	$ 103,887 	2.1%	2.1% 2015	$ 106,068 	3.0%	3.1% 2016	$ 109,250 	2.4%	2.4% 2017	$ 111,872 	3.0%	3.0% 2018	$ 115,228 		  ?	JDA appears to be following its standard policies for annual increases and NPI finds these increases to be in line with expectations and at fair market value (FMV).  Targets ?	NPI recommends targeting a ?freeze? on 2017 pricing at ~$111,872. ?	NPI typically will NOT see a roll-back on pricing, yet will often see a ?freeze? to the prior years? renewal rate. ?	If Guitar Center is willing to consider a multi-year deal, a potential roll-back may be possible. ?	A conservative $110K baseline on a multi-year deal with no annual increase for 3 years will lock in pricing and save an estimated $26,159 using an assumed 3% Y/Y increase (2018: $115,228, 2019: $118,685, 2020: $122,246) ?	The realized savings from reducing the proposed $115,682 spend to a multi-year $110K spend would result in a $26,613 savings in comparison to a business as usual 3% Y/Y increase (shown below).  Year	Adjusted Support	Increase 	 	Savings	 2018	$ 110,000 			$ 5,682 	 2019	$ 110,000 			$ 8,685 	 2020	$ 110,000 	3.0%		$ 12,246 	 2021	$ 113,300 				 					 3 Yr. Savings			$ 26,613 	23%  ?	A very aggressive $106K multi-year baseline would result in the following:  Year	Adjusted Support	Increase 	 	Savings	 2018	$106,000 			$ 9,682 	 2019	$ 106,000 			$ 12,685 	 2020	$ 106,000 	3.0%		$ 16,246 	 2021	$ 109,180 				 					 3 Yr. Savings			$ 38,613 	33%  ?	A multi-year deal will also allow Guitar Center to ?freeze? the annual increases and reset the baseline to 2015 levels.       Negotiation Leverage and Strategy  ?	JDA will lose some incremental revenue with a multi-year deal. ?	Guitar Center will lose options and flexibility to implement new solutions. ?	Yet?  Both JDA and Guitar Center have ?wins? by securing a multi-year deal.  JDA has stability in revenue and Guitar Center has stability in budgeting and pricing. ?	A $106K - $110K is ?fair and reasonable? compromise for both parties. ?	Point out that support costs have increased 31% since the original contract. ?	Both JDA and Guitar Center have acted in good faith in the annual increases of the past.  Yet? The increases over the years have begun to become somewhat of a problematic issue.  A small ?reset and pause? with new commitments from each side are now in order. ?	NPI recommends using ?logic? and pure spreadsheets to argue the need for a potential multi-year proposal.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Appears that JDA agreed to rollback maintenance from the original $115K to $100K on a 1 year deal.  Unsure as to the argument to convince JDA.    Savings, but in Guitar Center thoughts, savings NOT attributed to NPI contribution and tied more to contract changes.  Agreed to write as Savings with no NPI credit.

Bundles?): 0 > 50 = 5% 51 > 150 = 15% 150 > 300 = 25% 300 > 400 = 32.50% 400 > 1500  = 40%  JCI?s pricing picks up from this point but starts at 41%, which NPI considers to be ABOVE FMV (for clarity, pricing is high, discounting is low).  Previously, JCI?s discount from list has largely been at 59% off of list, with the exception of order 2, where JCI rec?d 76% off of list. The matrix laid out in the initial contract for JCI was very aggressive, relative to other clients and yet, JCI was actually priced into the 3rd tier, 3K-5K licenses, despite having a collective license pool of only 1,642 licenses, placing JCI in the 2nd pricing tier.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The lever to be pulled with Altify is that there is growing competition in this space and while their solution may be cutting edge, there are pricing values to be found with other vendors that offer most of the same features that they do. Were JCI to only be increasing the subscription 2-3x, NPI envisions that JCI would top out at discounting between 65-75% or a subscription base of $2.3-$3.3M annually, still an enviable position for most clients.  Based on the 10x license pool that JCI is projecting, (just under 16K licenses), NPI is confident that JCI can push past the discount schedule previously provided to as high as 85-90% off of list. With that type of projected growth, the message to Altify is a concern over being penalized for growing the solution organically.  The believe is that if JCI were purchasing that number of licenses now, you would see significantly better pricing.  Why should you be penalized for growing the solution organically to get up to the 16K licenses.   NOTE: Closing for data cleanup... no final docs.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Did not review. Adding deal without contract so data is in the system.

Most of the guideline recommendations on slide 2 in the VzW deck are basic recommendations that should be implemented. Similar recommendations should be obtained from AT&T for optimization.   For comparisons, it was good to bring in T-Mobile, however, we see most clients using them in limited cases due to coverage issues. Alternatively, NetApp should look at MetTel for comparative quotes. They are an MVNO that can be creative in the servicing of accounts such as this which ultimately drive costs down and create efficiencies. Please ask for further details.  It?s worth noting that the majority of cost savings in the cellular suite of services come from optimization efforts and that the observations below should be used as a guideline.  Discounts ?	For an account of this size, we work to achieve discounts of 22%-23% from Verizon Wireless. They appear to be offering 14%. ?	Similarly, we work toward AT&T discounts of 25% for an account this size. (No ATT proposal was shared.)  Activations Credits ?	For an account of your size, work to get the following activation credits o	AT&T = $150 o	VzW = $125 (in proposal, so OK) ?	Don?t buy accessories from carriers.  For accessories, Verizon offers a 50% discount.  Even so, their discounted prices will be much higher than even standard retail pricing.  Plans (VzW) ?	Business Unlimited data (all device types), we recommend that you push to achieve rates approaching $40 per month. ?	Business Limited could go as low as $30 per month.  Pool optimization ?	Recommend the buffer should be managed to ~10%. ?	One potential issue with the proposed plan distribution is management of the pool. With the amount of plan types being proposed, pool management can be problematic. You can save time, hassle, and cost by reducing the number of plans.  Make sure that the contract terms allow unlimited movement from one pricing plan to another in a given month.   Additional observations ?	We agree that Travel Pass should be added to all international roaming phones, as suggested in the proposal. ?	On the TCO, cell H8, you indicate an AT&T MARC of $6 MM ? does this include a substantial wireline spend?  Otherwise, you will not hit it, so don?t agree to it. ?	For true TCO calculation and proposal analysis, we strongly recommend to perform an independent cost assessment using recent actual data usage (available from the billing portals) by a 3rd party SME. Any time a provider recommends how to pay them less, their analysis should be fully scrutinized.

Maybe they can suggest better way to do TCO and some alternate comparison structure.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Apttus and found the proposal to be in the range of FMV with scope for improvement. ?	Apttus has proposed pricing of $35.25 for the Enterprise CLM edition.  ?	The pricing appears to be grandfathered from Aramark?s pricing for Contract Wizard which is one of the key functionalities in Enterprise CLM.  ?	Aramark?s current pricing of $39.75 for Contract Wizard for about 800 users represents a discount of 47%. ?	For 1386 users, the discount tier in the 2013 contract is 53% which translates to a price of $35.25 per user per month.  Below is the snapshot of Aramark?s discount tiers in the 2013 MSA.   NPI has seen pricing for Apttus CLM range between $22 and $60. NPI has observed that there is no consistency in pricing and there is large variance in the market. Pricing is not necessarily closely correlated with the purchase volume; it varies based on many factors and depends mainly on the presence of competition (especially at the time of the initial purchase) as well as customer?s requirements and negotiation leverage. NPI recommends target pricing of $33 per user per month for CLM Enterprise. Achieving a target of $33 per user per month translates to savings of $37K annually.  However, the fact that this is largely a renewal and hence there is a lack of competition reduces Aramark?s leverage. NPI also recommends that Aramark ask about tiered pricing and the associated price breaks as well as capped/flat out year pricing. License Type	Qty	Price	Term	Total Annual Price	Total Price	Target Price	Target Annual Price	Annual Savings	Target Total Price	Total Savings Enterprise CLM Edition	786	$35.25 	48	$332,478 	$1,329,912 	$33 	$311,256 	$21,222 	$1,245,024 	$84,888  Enterprise CLM Edition	600	$35.25 	47	$253,800 	$994,050 	$33 	$237,600 	$16,200 	$930,600 	$63,450   Overall, the Enterprise CLM offering is a better value for Aramark (as compared to the current cost of Contract Wizard licenses).  In addition to including Contract Wizard, which is one of the key functions, but not the only key function in the Enterprise CLM offering, it includes the other components that Aramark currently licenses, plus a good amount more which Aramark may find useful.
deal_metadata.description: Note from vendor: In summary, our proposal offers Aramark over 400k in savings on its current deployment, and lowers significantly the overall unit costs for the entire user population. While we have not achieved Steve?s objective of adding 600 users without an increase to the annual cost, our unique set of circumstances leading into the end of October allows us to provide extraordinary value at this time and we encourage you to move forward with our offer.   If we have not achieved your organization?s objectives, I suggest we schedule a call with our systems engineering group and our business value consultant with your key stakeholders to determine if we can identify/quantify the business value for the additional 600 users to help the proposal over the goal line prior to the end of October.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: This is 1.0... No data, too small for SME... FMV...  Hey James,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  While we have not seen a ton of Vertiv deals, we HAVE seen a few renewals so we were able to draw some comparisons with your pricing.  To save the suspense, NPI finds the pricing to be at Fair Market Value (FMV).    Our FMV assessment is largely based on the statement in the deal profile, that Vertiv Services has ?reduced pricing to the same dollar values as in 2014.?  Typically we see Vertiv renewals that will have a 3% - 7% increase year over year.  In the Vertiv renewal deals that NPI has reviewed, we have not seen Vertiv offer pricing below the previous renewal or purchase.  Therefore, keeping pricing flat (or same dollar value if equipment has changed) is typically the best result for this type of renewal.  Based on the information that NPI has, we believe this pricing is FMV and SCH could move forward with confidence.
deal_metadata.description: Please review and provide FMV feedback.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposed rates from KPMG and determined that the pricing and rates were above Fair Market Value (FMV), based on the size of the project. with scope for improvement in the pricing. The savings opportunity is about $1.2M for the engagement and translates to 8.2% of the proposed cost.  Pricing Analysis ?	The blended rate for the SOW is $206/hour. Blended rates for similar projects which are based in the US with no offshore component are typically between $195/hour and $225/hour based on the number of offshore hours, mix and seniority of the resources, etc.  NPI recommends a target blended rate no greater than $200/hour. ?	Overall, benchmarking and negotiating rates and volume discounts from the Big 4 consulting firms involve as much art as science because of their organization structure? they are partnership based firms. o Between the 4 firms, there are 10,000 + partners whose annual income is based on revenue/profits from their customers. The partners, therefore, have some degree of autonomy where pricing/billing decisions are concerned.  ?	Some of the firms, like Deloitte, PWC and KPMG, have a standard or list price for the rates that they sometimes reveal to their customers. This sets the ceiling on the rate. Actual (negotiated) rates are discounted off of these rates. Other firms, like E&Y, don?t usually reveal a set of standard rates.  ?	In addition to the rates, volume discounts and tiers are also negotiable and depend on the customer?s leverage. These discounts can be applied in various ways.  1)	A discount is applied upfront to the committed spend in the SOW. If the customer has a number of ongoing projects with the customer, 2)	 credit provided at the end of the year based on the actual spend. This can be in the form of a check (this is rare). 3)	Volume discount is applied to the future spend based on the previous year?s spend.   Targets  NPI has provided the target fair market value rates for all the roles in the attached excel sheet.   ?	The categories/roles which are within FMV are highlighted in green. ?	The rows highlighted in yellow are those where there is scope for improvement in the rates. ?	Achieving these target rates brings the blended rate down to $197.6 per hour and translates to savings of $567K.  ?	NPI also recommends negotiating a volume discount of 5% based on the large spend. NPI has seen KPMG offer a discount of 5% off the negotiated cost of the SOW(s) if the customer commits to large spend volumes. Achieving an additional 5% discount translates to savings of $669K. ?	The PMO effort is rather high as compared to other similar projects. NPI recommends moving 30% of PM hours to other areas.

Analysis of a draft version of the JDA Software contract appears to have the initial Guitar Spend defined as:  Standard Software	Qty	License Fees Space Planning Plus	6	$ 53,561  Floor Planning Plus	6	$ 53,561  Space Automation	6	$ 10,043  Intactix Knowledge Base	1	$ 218,562  Intactix Knowledge Base Web Publisher	1	$ 64,274  Space Planning Viewer		$ 0  Floor Planning Viewer		$ 0  Estimated Total Purchase Price		$ 400,000   ?	NPI does not have access to the fully executed agreement, yet viewed in other known JDA Software agreements is an annual escalator clause which allows for JDA to ?increase the Maintenance fee by the lesser of 3%, or the percentage increase in the Employment Cost Index for total compensation, for all civilian workers as published by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics during the 12 months prior to the effective date of the increase?. ?	NPI reviewed the original purchase price and applied the annual increases as per what NPI would normally expect from JDA. ?	Employment Cost Index for total compensation of all civilian workers as published by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics (https://www.bls.gov/web/eci/echistrynaics.pdf) is listed below.    ?	NPI estimates increases did not begin until the end of the 4th year, versus at the end of the 3-year contract. ?	Employing the Q1 ECI-A numbers as the annual basis, NPI applied the expected increases to the original basis and finds the resultant renewal figure to be closely aligned to where it would be expected to be.  Estimated renewal rate falls at $115,228 versus actual renewal rate quoted as $115,682. JDA appears to be following its standard policies for annual increases and NPI finds these increases to be in line with expectations and at fair market value (FMV).  Targets ?	NPI recommends targeting a ?freeze? on 2017 pricing at ~$111,872. ?	NPI typically will NOT see a roll-back on pricing, yet will often see a ?freeze? to the prior years? renewal rate. ?	If Guitar Center is willing to consider a multi-year deal, a potential roll-back may be possible. ?	A conservative $110K baseline on a multi-year deal with no annual increase for 3 years will lock in pricing and save an estimated $26,159 using an assumed 3% Y/Y increase (2018: $115,228, 2019: $118,685, 2020: $122,246) ? Savings			$ 38,613 	33%  ?	A multi-year deal will also allow Guitar Center to ?freeze? the annual increases and reset the baseline to 2015 levels.       Negotiation Leverage and Strategy  ?	JDA will lose some incremental revenue with a multi-year deal. ?	Guitar Center will lose options and flexibility to implement new solutions. ?	Yet?  Both JDA and Guitar Center have ?wins? by securing a multi-year deal.  JDA has stability in revenue and Guitar Center has stability in budgeting and pricing. ?	A $106K - $110K is ?fair and reasonable? compromise for both parties. ?	Point out that support costs have increased 31% since the original contract. ?	Both JDA and Guitar Center have acted in good faith in the annual increases of the past.  Yet? The increases over the years have begun to become somewhat of a problematic issue. deal_metadata.current_narrative: This is 1.0... No data, too small for SME... FMV...  Hey James,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  While we have not seen a ton of Vertiv deals, we HAVE seen a few renewals so we were able to draw some comparisons with your pricing.  To save the suspense, NPI finds the pricing to be at Fair Market Value (FMV).    Our FMV assessment is largely based on the statement in the deal profile, that Vertiv Services has ?reduced pricing to the same dollar values as in 2014.?  Typically we see Vertiv renewals that will have a 3% - 7% increase year over year.  In the Vertiv renewal deals that NPI has reviewed, we have not seen Vertiv offer pricing below the previous renewal or purchase.  Therefore, keeping pricing flat (or same dollar value if equipment has changed) is typically the best result for this type of renewal.  Based on the information that NPI has, we believe this pricing is FMV and SCH could move forward with confidence.
deal_metadata.description: Please review and provide FMV feedback.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI has seen In the recent past, Altify has used the following discount table (for what? Single product?  Bundles?): 0 > 50 = 5% 51 > 150 = 15% 150 > 300 = 25% 300 > 400 = 32.50% 400 > 1500  = 40%  JCI?s pricing picks up from this point but starts at 41%, which NPI considers to be ABOVE FMV (for clarity, pricing is high, discounting is low).  Previously, JCI?s discount from list has largely been at 59% off of list, with the exception of order 2, where JCI rec?d 76% off of list. The matrix laid out in the initial contract for JCI was very aggressive, relative to other clients and yet, JCI was actually priced into the 3rd tier, 3K-5K licenses, despite having a collective license pool of only 1,642 licenses, placing JCI in the 2nd pricing tier.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The lever to be pulled with Altify is that there is growing competition in this space and while their solution may be cutting edge, there are pricing values to be found with other vendors that offer most of the same features that they do. Were JCI to only be increasing the subscription 2-3x, NPI envisions that JCI would top out at discounting between 65-75% or a subscription base of $2.3-$3.3M annually, still an enviable position for most clients.  Based on the 10x license pool that JCI is projecting, (just under 16K licenses), NPI is confident that JCI can push past the discount schedule previously provided to as high as 85-90% off of list. With that type of projected growth, the message to Altify is a concern over being penalized for growing the solution organically.  The believe is that if JCI were purchasing that number of licenses now, you would see significantly better pricing.  Why should you be penalized for growing the solution organically to get up to the 16K licenses.   NOTE: Closing for data cleanup... no final docs.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Synactive?s Liquid UI is a niche product, and NPI has seen only a couple of these types of transactions for comparison.  There is also very little competition ? primary competitors are UX consultants who customize SAP? often through GuiXT.      However, with the shift to SAP Cloud, NPI believes this product may be nearing end of life.   Synactive Inc. has not been very active from a marketing perspective.  Very little  ?current? news is available During 2016, their marketing appeared to go dark ? per their website, no press releases were published During this year 2017, one press release which highlighted a customer implementation The Liquid UI facebook page has not been updated in over a year; last update was June 2, 2016   Price Analysis In the few deals that we have seen, 18% for support seems to be the standard rate for GuiXT. We have seen the Developer Suite priced as low as $10,200,  REI?s $10,943 price is within Fair Market Value (FMV). We have seen Desktop Suite priced as low as $175 per license, REI?s $150.68 for 1600 licenses is slightly below what we have seen.   So there are lower prices that REI could have paid for licenses and hence, lower support costs, but even with the lowest license pricing that NPI has seen, the total cost of this renewal would reduce by only $1,100.   Overall, this renewal is largely within FMV with room for very small improvement.  Considering that these renewals have happened for years with little or no increase, it is unlikely that Synactive would come down on this pricing.
deal_metadata.description: We are renewing our GuiXT WS support for SAP for another year from Synactive.  We have been looking to move off of this platform but that will have to wait until next year.  Attached is the new quote for 2018.  The support has been steady at 18% for a number of years now.  We looked at a multi-year contract last year but their only option was a pre-paid deal so we have stuck with a one year deal.      Let me know if these fees are in line with what you have in your records.    Thanks Trevor

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Original feedback via email... followed up with FMV report.  Hey Jack,    I have finally been able to go through the purchase docs you provided and reconcile as much as I could with the maintenance contract you are currently under.  I am sure it is no surprise that your pricing across all of your add-on purchases has been all-over-the-place: ? In the six purchases you sent over (ranging from 2008 ? 2013), discounting on the License product (71000383) ranges between 35% (2011) down to 10% (2012).  When taken alone, where each transaction is below $100K, 35% discounting would be at the low end of Fair Market Value (FMV) ? for clarity, pricing is a little high, discounting is a little below what we would expect. ? The support for the licenses in these six purchases ? as a percentage of the net license cost ? range from 17% of the net license (2012) to 25% of the net license cost (2011).  Once again, taken as stand-alone <$100K purchases, 20% of net license cost is FMV.  In the six deals you sent over, the average discount on the licenses is ~26% and support is an average 22% of the net license cost.  If we apply these numbers to your annual $375,978 maintenance renewal, this would mean that you have purchased ~$1.7M in Software ($2.3M list price at 26% discounting) from McKesson over the years.  This brings NPI to two thoughts: ? If you were spending $1.7M with McKesson in a single purchase, NPI would recommend targeting discounts on licenses between 65% - 75% and support costs should be between 15% - 20% of the net license cost. ? While we would not expect you hit 65% - 75% discounting on these smaller purchases over time, NPI does not believe that Evergreen Health should be penalized for growing the solution organically the way that you have.  You are paying a very high premium for this amount of support.  Caveat: The above analysis is based off of the small sample of deals that you sent over.  It is possible that Evergreen received better discounting and better support percentages on some of the other deals that NPI has not seen ? it is also possible that you received worse discounts and less favorable discount percentages.  The challenge comes with the 2-year agreement that you are currently in.  You _are_ pretty much locked in to that and McKesson won?t be anxious to renegotiate this mid-term, especially since you will want to significantly reduce it (NPI believes the target cost for this maintenance should be ~$162K).  In order to get McKesson to rework this agreement midway through, you will probably have to agree to a longer term deal, or make a sizable new purchase with them.
deal_metadata.description: All,  We have several contracts with McKesson (now Change Healthcare) for software related to their homecare application. We signed a two year agreement last year that froze maintenance increases through 2018.  These contracts generally renew in January.  We have been highly dissatisfied with their support, the software stability, and feature functionality delivered.  Last year, we sent them a RFI informing them we would be shopping for a potential replacement to their software.  The timing of that replacement was moved to 2018.  I wanted to check to see if this would be a candidate for NPI services, or whether the attached amendment puts Evergreen is a difficult negotiating position.  Let me know your thoughts.  Thanks!

deal_metadata.current_narrative: They are discounting you at 45% which is nothing exciting.  A 42% discount is the standard Gold Partner discount which is basically the minimum discount anyone receives, so you are not much more than that.  I do not know your historical discounts with Cisco which could be leverage if you have seen higher than this.  We see discounting on products like these ranging between 47-60%.  The higher discounts are for much larger deals ($1M+) so 50% is not unreasonable at all, I would even aim a bit higher and see what they will do.    The key to this is to discuss it with your Cisco rep if you can.  Presidio only makes 3-4% of the list price, so my assumption is that Presidio got a 48-49% discount and passed the 45% to you.  The Cisco rep needs to extend more discounting to pass through Presidio for you.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the renewal from Adobe and found the renewal pricing to be at Fair Market Value (FMV).   Adobe Analytics  ?	Given the volume of calls per month, for the Standard Analytics (primary), our Fair Market Value (FMV) range for 250 - 400 Million Server Calls per Month is $100 - $187. Pricing varies based on volumes but also on the mix of marketing cloud products being purchased and total spend size. REI is getting great pricing which is at the low end of the range of FMV because REI is purchasing Adobe Target. The expanding volumes also added leverage to lower pricing. ?	The overall market range for Analytics (primary) varies between $25 and $1,100 based on volume and term.  ?	A three-year term with no early termination is now the standard from Adobe.  It wasn?t always this way.  In the past AEs were only paid on first year subscription value and so they were fine doing one-year deals but now they are comped on the whole term so of course three years has become the de facto norm. REI has a 2-year option, but if REI is willing to sign up for a 3-year term, they add to the negotiation leverage to get an additional 5% -10% off of current pricing. ?	In the past, Adobe would charge more for overages but they?ve moved away from this and it is now typically flat unless the volume is increasing y-o-y in which case they will reduce the pricing (which is the case with REI). ?	Cost of Adobe analytics secondary calls is invariably 50% of Analytics Primary rates and this is FMV.  Additional Concessions  ?	We?ve seen Adobe provide these additional concessions for Analytics ?	Net 45 days payment instead of the standard net 30 ?	Having a three-year bucket of server calls that allows you to essentially rollover your calls vs. use each year.  This is a rare concession.  Generally, clients grow and this presents another sale for Adobe and clients leave calls on the table from earlier parts of their contract.  This would be a great risk mitigator for REI but is rarely approved.    Adobe Target Premium  ?	The overall market range for Adobe Target Premium varies between $35 and $1,100 based on volume and term.  ?	For a volume of around 1500, $268 - $256 is within FMV.

NO financials - just rate card review.While some of the individual rates are at FMV, others are at the high end of the range with room for improvement. In summary, NPI believes that there is potential for savings averaging about 4% for the roles in the rate card.  Consulting Rates in the Enterprise Data Management solutions space (including Data Management and Data governance etc.) command a premium. Niche companies such as Utopia, WCI, SAS, T/DG and several others provide consulting services specific to this area. Larger Consulting companies like the Big 4 as well as Accenture also provide these services, but their blended rate is 5% ? 20% higher based on the project. Global IT consultants such as TCS, Infosys etc. typically bill a much lower hourly rate for their consultants (sub $150 per hour for onshore rates).

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  You mentioned that you needed this last week, but with the other deals that NPI was reviewing for Intuit, we were only able to get to this review this week.  I hope this information is still useful for you.  NPI reviewed Intuit?s Elastic purchase last year and we found the pricing to be ABOVE Fair market Value (FMV).  The pricing was initially offered with a 45% discounting and ultimately wound up at 61% discounting, or $2,886/node.  However, the discounting is misleading because the list price changed from $5,500 in the initial quotes to $7,400 in the final pricing.  Now in this year?s proposal, the list price is $4,400.  From what NPI can tell, all of this pricing has been for the same Gold level Subscription product.  Intuit may want to inquire as to why the list price has had such variation between these proposals.  In last year?s feedback, NPI recommended targeting $2,200 per node on a 3-year commitment and that recommendation holds true for the current purchase.  A 1-year renewal should see per node pricing closer to $2,500/node.  This puts NPI?s recommended targets at $100K for a 40-node, 1-year renewal, and $220K/year for a 100-node, 3-year renewal.  The current offer has a 3-year commitment at $2,156/node and NPI would consider that to be FMV.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Original feedback via email... followed up with FMV report.  Hey Jack,    I have finally been able to go through the purchase docs you provided and reconcile as much as I could with the maintenance contract you are currently under.  I am sure it is no surprise that your pricing across all of your add-on purchases has been all-over-the-place: ? In the six purchases you sent over (ranging from 2008 ? 2013), discounting on the License product (71000383) ranges between 35% (2011) down to 10% (2012).  When taken alone, where each transaction is below $100K, 35% discounting would be at the low end of Fair Market Value (FMV) ? for clarity, pricing is a little high, discounting is a little below what we would expect. ? The support for the licenses in these six purchases ? as a percentage of the net license cost ? range from 17% of the net license (2012) to 25% of the net license cost (2011).  Once again, taken as stand-alone <$100K purchases, 20% of net license cost is FMV.  In the six deals you sent over, the average discount on the licenses is ~26% and support is an average 22% of the net license cost.  If we apply these numbers to your annual $375,978 maintenance renewal, this would mean that you have purchased ~$1.7M in Software ($2.3M list price at 26% discounting) from McKesson over the years.  This brings NPI to two thoughts: ? If you were spending $1.7M with McKesson in a single purchase, NPI would recommend targeting discounts on licenses between 65% - 75% and support costs should be between 15% - 20% of the net license cost. ? While we would not expect you hit 65% - 75% discounting on these smaller purchases over time, NPI does not believe that Evergreen Health should be penalized for growing the solution organically the way that you have.  You are paying a very high premium for this amount of support.  Caveat: The above analysis is based off of the small sample of deals that you sent over.  It is possible that Evergreen received better discounting and better support percentages on some of the other deals that NPI has not seen ? it is also possible that you received worse discounts and less favorable discount percentages.  The challenge comes with the 2-year agreement that you are currently in.  You _are_ pretty much locked in to that and McKesson won?t be anxious to renegotiate this mid-term, especially since you will want to significantly reduce it (NPI believes the target cost for this maintenance should be ~$162K).  In order to get McKesson to rework this agreement midway through, you will probably have to agree to a longer term deal, or make a sizable new purchase with them.
deal_metadata.description: All,  We have several contracts with McKesson (now Change Healthcare) for software related to their homecare application. We signed a two year agreement last year that froze maintenance increases through 2018.  These contracts generally renew in January.  We have been highly dissatisfied with their support, the software stability, and feature functionality delivered.  Last year, we sent them a RFI informing them we would be shopping for a potential replacement to their software.  The timing of that replacement was moved to 2018.  I wanted to check to see if this would be a candidate for NPI services, or whether the attached amendment puts Evergreen is a difficult negotiating position.  Let me know your thoughts.  Thanks!

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NO financials - just rate card review.While some of the individual rates are at FMV, others are at the high end of the range with room for improvement. In summary, NPI believes that there is potential for savings averaging about 4% for the roles in the rate card.  Consulting Rates in the Enterprise Data Management solutions space (including Data Management and Data governance etc.) command a premium. Niche companies such as Utopia, WCI, SAS, T/DG and several others provide consulting services specific to this area. Larger Consulting companies like the Big 4 as well as Accenture also provide these services, but their blended rate is 5% ? 20% higher based on the project. Global IT consultants such as TCS, Infosys etc. typically bill a much lower hourly rate for their consultants (sub $150 per hour for onshore rates).
