The rates listed under the Oct ?17 was a proposal they provided to conduct a Data Health Assessment.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  You mentioned that you needed this last week, but with the other deals that NPI was reviewing for Intuit, we were only able to get to this review this week.  I hope this information is still useful for you.  NPI reviewed Intuit?s Elastic purchase last year and we found the pricing to be ABOVE Fair market Value (FMV).  The pricing was initially offered with a 45% discounting and ultimately wound up at 61% discounting, or $2,886/node.  However, the discounting is misleading because the list price changed from $5,500 in the initial quotes to $7,400 in the final pricing.  Now in this year?s proposal, the list price is $4,400.  From what NPI can tell, all of this pricing has been for the same Gold level Subscription product.  Intuit may want to inquire as to why the list price has had such variation between these proposals.  In last year?s feedback, NPI recommended targeting $2,200 per node on a 3-year commitment and that recommendation holds true for the current purchase.  A 1-year renewal should see per node pricing closer to $2,500/node.  This puts NPI?s recommended targets at $100K for a 40-node, 1-year renewal, and $220K/year for a 100-node, 3-year renewal.  The current offer has a 3-year commitment at $2,156/node and NPI would consider that to be FMV.
deal_metadata.description: Please see enclosed quote for an Elastic search function subscription.  If you could get this back by Wednesday morning, it would be greatly appreciated.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the proposal from Ivoxy Consulting and finds that although pricing is within FMV, historic pricing seen by Seattle Children?s Hospital in the past lends credibility for an increased discount.                   Pricing Analysis  Current Proposal:   	List Price	Quote	Discount Hardware	$ 398,141	$ 142,679	64.2% Support	$ 117,004	$ 88,243	24.6% Software	$ 714,426	$ 240,176	66.4% Grand Total	$ 1,229,571	$ 471,098	61.7%   Prior SCH Purchase (7/13/15):  7/13/15	List Price	Quote	Discount Hardware	$ 939,638 	$ 235,139 	75% Software	$ 472,300 	$ 104,659 	78% Maintenance	$ 855,123 	$ 161,401 	81% Services	$ 12,000 	$ 12,000 	0% Total	$ 2,279,061 	$ 513,199 	77%  ?	NPI finds the blended hardware discount of 64.2% to be at the lower end of FMV. ?	NPI finds the blended software discount of 66.4% to be at the lower end of FMV. ?	Software pricing should typically fall at 20% of net pricing of hardware and software combined.  This figure, as quoted, is at 23% of net pricing and is above FMV.   Targets   	List Price	Quote	Discount	Target Price	Target Discount	Target Savings HW	$ 398,141	$ 142,679	64.2%	$ 99,535 	75%	$ 43,143  Support	$ 117,004	$ 88,243	24.6%	$ 51,342 		$ 36,902  SW	$ 714,426	$ 240,176	66.4%	$ 157,174 	78%	$ 83,002  Grand Total	$ 1,229,571	$ 471,098	61.7%	$ 308,051	74.9%	$ 163,047  ?	Based on historic discounts received by Seattle Children?s Hospital, NPI sets similar target discounts. ?	NPI acknowledges that these targets are slightly aggressive as the prior SCH deal was a slightly larger deal with ?new logo? potential.   ?	The more aggressive, best in class discount, results in a 74.9% blended discount with a $ 163,047 savings.   ?	A fallback position with a 70% discount on hardware and software will result in a blended 67.4% discount and a $70,574 savings. ?	Discounting off list pricing for the support/maintenance line item can be misleading.  Review final pricing to ensure that support lands at 20% of the final hardware and software costs.    Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	In contrast to the prior negotiation tactics with Ivoxy, NPI recommends that rather than focusing on dollar amounts, SCH should work with Ivoxy and push them for the same discounts as previously received.  Because SCH now has a target discount to strive for, it sets a somewhat innocent target that needs to be met.   ?	NPI would expect a pushback based on the prior deal was ~ 1 million greater in list pricing.  Reality is that after discounts are applied, the differences are within a few hundred thousand and still warrant discount levels greater than the current 64% on hardware and software. ?	?New logo? opportunities help drive discounting a little deeper.  This deeper discounting may have occurred in the prior deal.  The position that SCH should maintain is that ?we can still easily choose to play a dual vendor strategy with our storage solutions if we can?t find the right solution at the right price?. ?	Support is currently quoted at 23% of the combined hardware and software costs.  NPI recommends that SCH target a 20% of net price of hardware and software. ?	NetApp Q3 end is 10/31 and a quarter-end deal will typically allow for the best negotiation power with a promise to close this deal in Q3.

Hi Kathleen,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  NPI reviewed Intuit?s LivePerson agreement last year ? as it turns out, this was a post-mortem and the deal had already been completed.  I?ve attached the review we did last year, and our feedback is similar this year.  From what NPI has seen on somewhat smaller LivePerson deals, this pricing is highly-negotiable.  We believe that the proposed $.80 per engagement for the 1.5M tier is at the very upper edge of Fair Market Value (FMV).   Last year, NPI recommended targeting $.60 per engagement for a deal of that size (2M+ engagements).  Considering the reduction in scope, as well as a partial, 9-month term, our recommended target for a this transaction would be between $.75 - $.81.  So we believe that the current pricing on the 1.5M tier is at the very upper edge of FMV with room for improvement.  Customer Success, however, is well over-priced on a deal of this size.  We typically see CSO offered at 25% - 30% of the platform cost.  LivePerson has left CSO at $37,600/month which totals 36% of the platform cost.  Intuit will want to push hard to get the CSO costs down closer to $300K/yr (25% of platform cost).
deal_metadata.description: see email attached from Kathleen

deal_metadata.description: No actual quote, details provided via email:  Hi Stuart,  I do not have an actual quote. In fact I have not even told Hortonworks (HW) that they have won the bid on our project.  The pricing is from the Account Rep at HW.    The F (Chirs) column is current quoting .  The G (Sam) column was a special pricing last year only because we bundled it with a Renewal which had an overall discount of 27% actually.  Chris states he cannot give the 50% because that was a bundle with a renewal and the best his CFO will allow is 35% off list.   Technically Hortonworks only allows upfront payments and 32 month terms to get the 35% discount.  2 year is 25% and 1 year is 15%.   We are aware of HW financial risk and have been watching them so we are not keen on paying up front and are in process of amending their contract with this purchase to pay annually/quarterly/monthly but not all 32 months up front.   They may not grant the 35% if I tell them that, but I am waiting to drop all of my demands on them at once- still waiting for the contract amendment to be complete by our legal.  I am also leveraging another vendor called Softpath, but have not talked to them yet.     Do you have any other customers who use Hortonworks?  Thanks, Elena

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Roy, Smita is OOO until Friday so I went through her recent effort to try and provide some feedback on this add-on subscription.  I can definitely confirm the SKU consolidation noted by Oracle. They have a document called their Fusion Cloud Service Descriptions document and the latest one clearly indicates the merging that you describe.  I?m assuming this is in addition to the review that Smita just provided. Let?s encapsulate that one: ?	$5.2M in list costs over five years or $1,036,000 a year ?	$2.5M in net costs over five years or $500K a year ?	52% discount on each line item ?	61% targeted discount suggested by NPI ?	B67272 is the SKU that absorbed B67270.  These had respective list prices of $40 and $5 per month in 2015 and now that they?re combined the new list is still $40 for 67272.  Equifax got a 38% discount in 2015 and the current offer that we reviewed was at 52%.  The volume went up considerably from 300 to 1950 and the term lengthened from 3 years to 5 years. ?	There were two other products that comprised only 10% of the quote and had the same 52% discount and 61% target.  The renewal summarizes as follows: ?	$1.2M in list costs over five years or $240K a year ?	$674,655 in net costs over five years or ~$135K a year ?	B75289 used to list for $400.  It now includes B69716 which listed for $50.  Together they increased the new B75289 to a sizable $650/mo which is 44% more than the combined $400+$50.  NPI hasn?t done a comparison of the capabilities of the software before and after but we certainly hope Oracle can articulate the reason behind the sizable increase. o	Offered at $346.77 per month that?s a 46.7% discount.  This is less than the 52% offer on the other part of this renewal NPI recently reviewed.  In addition, compared to the combined total of the prior list prices of $450 it is a paltry 23% discount.  Of course, Oracle can highlight you only got a 25% discount in 2015 and now you?re at 46.7% (of course they raised prices 44%!) o	NPI can see that the final outcomes in 2015 of $299 and $37 total $336 for these two SKUs and the $347.77 is 3% more than this.  Numbers can really get your head spinning of course.  A 3% increase seems reasonable in the Oracle ecosphere. o	More important to NPI the fact that Equifax is signing up for 5 years not 3 and expanding your extended list subscription costs from $1,071,000 over three years to about $6.5M over five years.  That?s a HUGE increase. This is enough of a change to get this repriced vs. accepting a 3% increase.  (Caveat: NPI is assuming the review from several weeks ago is in addition to this subscription) ?	B69730 used to list for $150 and B69731 listed for $50.  You?d expect the newly-reconstituted B69730 to have increased in price but it is still at $150. o	The $103 offer is a 31% discount.  The quote 2 weeks ago had each line item the same. That is often the case with Oracle Fusion quotes but this quote has one at 46.7% and one at 31%. o	NPI can see that total net price was $100 in 2015 and $103 is a 3% increase.  These were discounted 50% in 2015.  This one dropped from 50% to 31%. A bit unusual for Oracle. o	The blended discount is 44%.   Assuming, this is in addition to the prior review NPI sees no reason to not repeat our 61% discount target across the board.  The term and list spend has increases a lot and Equifax is a huge Oracle client.  You deserve top tier pricing. This does represent a sizable $200K cost reduction which is tough to get from Oracle on a renewal that is mid quarter and can only be attained by leveraging the other renewal?s growth. Standalone a blended 44% could be considered FMV with a blended target of 50%.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: From Roy: My apologies for my late response.   The second half only included Oracle Fusion Product Hub. We were able to remove Oracle Fusion Revenue Management as we determined that it wasn't in use ($520,155.00 savings).  Here are the details:  Term of Agreement: 5 years 10% Discount (we reduced the deal by 77% when Fusion Revenue Management was dropped) 2% cap increase for the next renewal Price hold for additional capacity during the agreement term Total: $202,500.00
deal_metadata.description: Could you please provide market price for the following Oracle Cloud products?    B75289 - Oracle Fusion Revenue Management Cloud Service ? Hosted Named user B69730 - Oracle Fusion Product Hub Cloud Service - Hosted 1,000 Records  This is part of the 2015 purchase you provided feedback a couple of weeks ago. Oracle has confirmed that the two original Business intelligence part numbers included in the 2015 ordering document along with all its functionality for each have been consolidated into their respective base product. So original part number B69731 is now included as part of B69730, and B69716 is now part of B75289.  Below is Oracle?s current offer. They added together the pricing from the original deal, and then added a 3% increase.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: 1.0...  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  This is a below the minimum dollar threshold for deals that NPI will typically review for Intuit (threshold is $100K).  However, I have a bit of Preemptive data and I did a quick analysis of this quote.  First, any type of unlimited license is very difficult to benchmark without expected usage rates.  Based on the comparative data that NPI has, $9K for an unlimited license appears to be within Fair Market Value (FMV); however, the true FMV for this will depend on how many users actually use the system.  The 12 Dotfuscator build licenses are pro-rated for 12-month (and longer) terms.  By NPI?s math, each build license has an annual cost of around $1.2K, and they are prorated out for the extended term.  Overall, this is within FMV.  NPI has seen Dotfuscator licenses offered slightly lower on larger deals, but we would consider this to be FMV.  Overall, for a deal of this size, NPI considers this pricing to be within FMV and Intuit can move forward.
deal_metadata.description: Can you please check the attached proposal for benchmarking analysis? There will be additional 8 licenses and possibly a site license.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Infor is the preferred vendor in part because they were involved with Zumiez POS (trying to protect that information). While license costs for Infor and Kronos are comparable, the implementation from Infor's partner Axsium is more than 5x WFCs for the Kronos solution.  Other scoped implementations have fallen in a middle range of the extremes.  5/16 Received the final Subscription.  We will bill for that and wait on services.  They are looking at other PS firms to validate Axsium scope before committing.   Gregg asked KT about discounts and this is the reply that was worth capturing: We weren?t able to determine the discount, but we also haven?t received final docs or any formal Infor quote yet.  While it?s not a discount, we did see them drop pricing from $307k per year to an anticipated $265k (still waiting on the exact final number for the subscription portion, but this was communicated verbally to Zumiez as the projected price).  That?d imply an additional discount of 14%.    The implementer also discounted labor rates from $175 -> $155, an 11% drop.  Not exactly discounts but that?s what we have so far.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The wide gap in implementation costs could mean Infor knows they are preferred and are trying to inflate costs.  Despite this, Zumiez is happy with most of Axsium's work so far.  Protecting information around Infor as the definite choice will be crucial in preserving leverage.
deal_metadata.description: Zumiez has engaged NPI on a review of their open bid around a new WFM solution.  After an open RFP, Zumiez down selected to Infor & Kronos (included Tanda very briefly after NPI involvement).  Each vendor also has a partner SI with implementation costs, Axsium for Infor and WFC for Kronos.

The information below did not lend itself to a more formal FMV report, but if you need a formal document, I can create one for you.  It appears this maintenance renewal is priced within Fair Market Value (FMV).    Quest software maintenance is typically priced at ~15% of the software license cost.  Based on NPI?s knowledge of the VRanger product, it appears that this renewal is priced at ~17%, so this is in the range of FMV.    If COUNTRY wanted to push a bit, you could request that this pricing get below $12.5K in order to meet operating budget numbers.  Based on the size of this deal, there may not be much leverage.  COUNTRY could point to potential growth in the future and express that the current pricing may stifle growth of the VRanger solution.

Worked with Graham on pricing targets and strategies. ?	Current discounting is at the low end of FMV ?	Coupa can provide more aggressive discounting if they feel they need to in order to win the business.  Details are in the table below. ?	There is no real overhead associated with setting up the Test Sandbox, so Coupa can provide this at no or minimal cost. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP not allow Coupa to bind your license fees to the license metrics provided.  If they go up they charge you more.  If they go up they charge you more, If they go down they won't reduce your annual number.  They audit you or charge you the annual increase, etc. to get back to that number.  Protect against that now before you sign the contract.   After saying NO multiple times Coupa finally came down to 890K and threw in Analytics.when it got closer to the end of the quarter
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends that CHOP begin the negotiations with KPMG or other implementation provider.  CHOP should have a serious conversation about the true cost to enable the expected number of vendors in the Coupa system.  You will want to ensure you have a solid understanding of what your implementation costs will be, as that will provide negotiation leverage in your discussions with Coupa. ?	Coupa will ask you to talk to their references which is an attempt to divert from reducing their fees. ?	If Basware / Verian is a viable option (NOTE: it does not have to be a perfect solution, just as long as Coupa believes they are a real threat), CHOP can indicate that preliminary pricing looks VERY good from Verian. ?	Ask for List pricing to be frozen for the term of the agreement and to agree on a discount % for that time.  Preferably at the same level ?	Push to include 10k worth of incremental storage as a one-time concession to be used during the term of the agreement.  ?	Request to remove the 2% late penalty fee. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP negotiate to get the total cost of the solution down to $800,000 and not try to discuss individual discounts.  CHOP can let Coupa know that budgets are tight and Coupa needs to get much more aggressive in order to get this project approved and moving this month which is the end of Coupa?s Q3.  Without these concessions, there could be a significant delay or CHOP my look further at alternatives. ?	Negotiate SLAs similar to that of Workday ?	Coupa's CEO is a marketing guy so be prepared to offer marketing rights, videos, references, etc., in exchange for concessions.  The more CHOP will agree to, the more concessions you will get. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP ask for licensing protection language in their agreement to cover feature(s) shifting from one module to another.  Coupa is known to take features out of a module you have license rights to and shift or move it to another module that you don?t have license rights to.  Then trying to charge you an incremental fee.    Also recommended getting the Analytics thrown in at no additional cost.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Tableau, unlike many other vendors, tends to sell their products at list price without offering large discounts.  With organizations that have large footprints, NPI has seen discounts range from 7% - 25% (depending heavily on the size of the footprint).    One of Tableau?s co-founders is also a co-founder of Pixar (and a Stanford professor), and he is a big reason for Tableau?s push for outstanding visualizations and intuitiveness. Tableau invests heavily in R&D and support, which adds to their reasoning against discounting.  Although NPI has seen only a single example where Tableau offered discounts of 25% on a new purchase, we have been recently seeing deeper and more frequent discounts being offered.  It is NPI?s belief that although they remain the leader in the Gartner quadrant, Microsoft?s Power BI may be starting to slowly gain ground and thereby forcing Tableau to be a little more generous in discounting.  Tableau maintenance fees are calculated as a flat 25% of the license price.    Pricing Analysis  2016 Renewal						 Product Name	Term Start	Term End	Quantity	Unit Price	Adjusted Unit Price	Total Desktop - Professional User - Maintenance Renewal	8/28/2016	11/16/2017	5	$ 400 	$ 489 	$ 2,445  Desktop - Professional User - Maintenance Renewal	11/17/2016	11/16/2017	46	$ 400 	$ 400 	$ 18,400  Server - Core Commercial Maintenance Renewal	11/17/2016	11/16/2017	20	$ 5,000 	$ 5,000 	$ 100,000  						$ 120,845  						 2017 Renewal						 Product Name	Term Start	Term End	Quantity	Unit Price	Adjusted Unit Price	Total Desktop - Professional User - Maintenance Renewal	11/17/2017	12/31/2018	51	$ 400 	$ 449 	$ 22,899  Desktop - Professional - License Renewal (Term)		12/31/2018	1	$ 840 	$ 483 	$ 483  Desktop - Personal User - Maintenance Renewal		12/31/2018	1	$ 200 	$ 233 	$ 233  Server - Core Commercial Maintenance Renewal	11/17/2017	12/31/2018	20	$ 5,000 	$ 5,616 	$ 112,320  						$ 135,935    ?	NPI has reviewed the Tableau renewal and validates discounts.  Fair market value pricing for Tableau support renewals is 25% of list price on perpetual licensing. ?	NPI recommends that validation of actual use/consumption of the 51 perpetual licenses.  Best practices would have the 51 users validated annually at renewal and forecast for growth can be discussed once a year at renewal. ?	CSAA is renewing a single term license.  If the validation of the 51 seats requires a 52nd seat, the term license should be renewed.  If there are unused perpetual licenses, the term license should be cancelled and the user should be migrated to a perpetual seat.  NPI acknowledges that although the dollar amount may be insignificant, NPI?s goal is to always recommend best practices to avoid waste and maximize profitability. ?	NPI recommends that CSAA request that support timeframes be added to the current proposal for documentation purposes and clarity on exact support end dates. ?	NPI recommends that CSAA can confidently proceed with the support renewal after a quick validation of perpetual license users.

ADDING PRICE LIST THAT SME SHARED DEC 2017.  We iterated in mid Nov.  Worked with Sme again and might've found list pricing. NEver got a quote from MS.  See attached email with her follow on request and my feedback.   No quote and asked a number of clarifying questions.  Ended up sharing feedback before hearing back. Some assumptions were not correct.  See attached email with questions and feedback.  Hi Lara, I hadn?t heard back about some of my initial questions but I made some progress on our review that I thought would be helpful as you progress.  Our feedback lent itself to bullets. ?	It is not crystal clear but it appears the current $153K run rate is being co-termed to the start of this upgrade for a term of 3 months.  That equates to $38,250 ($153,000 / 4).  I?m not clear on really what the upgrade means vis-à-vis what you own. The metric in your original MSA was CPU and the product was Alfresco Enterprise Network not Enterprise One.  I?m assuming you?re really just buy the new platform at renewal time. ?	Over the past year they?ve basically just rebranded Alfresco One Enterprise to be replaced by Digital Business Platform which appears to be a simple rebranding, not a capability upgrade. ?	They have two masthead customers ? Cisco and Nike.   o	Cisco uses it for their salesforce.  People had created content on personal drives and team drives and they estimated they were losing 100K+ hours in productivity a year.  Alfresco doesn?t force you to rethink where you store stuff.  It crawls the network, puts documents in its own storage system and indexes it all for you (NOTE: there will be plenty of Azure or AWS costs to support this storage.  Alfresco will facilitate this and provide a recommended architecture).  They bring your content to you is what they say.  If you want to add business processes  and design your own work flows in drag and drop fashion that?s their BPM Activiti offering. o	Nike does all their digital media storage in Alfresco. ?	While the quote pasted below isn?t crystal clear this is how NPI views step 1 in the analysis (determine the list price)  o	$38,250 - Existing footprint support co-termed to 8/31/17 o	$125,000 ? Digital Platform.  NPI has a price list from just before the new rebranding happened.  No pricing is published on their website  - https://www.alfresco.com/platform/pricing.   This covers the first 1000 Named Users and Content Services, Governance Services and Process Services.  ?	NPIs overarching feedback is to push Alfresco to share a quote with clearer pricing including pricing by product, showing the first 1000 and the add-ons to get to 2,500 Named Users.  They can and will provide this if pushed. ?	Even though Process Services are included this is not the full blown BPM Activiti product.  It is a lite version ? as an analogy think Notepad functionality (what?s included) vs. Word (the separate offering)  o	$187,500 ? additional 1,500 Named Users of the Platform.  List has been $12,500 per 100.  MS needs 15 more of these [(2,500 ? 1,000) / 100] o	$60,000 ? ($20K x 3) - Indexing has been and remains a separate subscription. In the recent past the name was Index Server not Alfresco Index Engine.  Each Index Server costs $20K list and comes with 4 cores running on a single CPU.  ?	The base platform comes with rudimentary indexing (believe that?s the Governance piece which has basic Records Management) but this more robust version is typically needed. o	$70,000 ? ($25,000 + $3K * 15) Content Encryption lists for $25,000 for up to 1,000 Named Users.  Additional Named Users are $3K per 100.  o	$480,750 is NPIs List Price estimate.  There?s certainly a chance we?d want to amend this if we got further clarity on our prior questions and learned of any list price changes that came with the recent rebranding but if the prices went up I?d push hard to find out what?s different from the prior Alfresco One product that listed for $125K a year.  ?	Morgan Stanley?s offer of $422,375 does not reflect an acceptable discount at just over 12%.  My advisor sold for Alfresco as recently as a year ago and indicated AEs had a fair amount of leeway. He?d often lead with a 60-65% discount.  Of course, we?d want to validate NPIs list price estimate but this should start to set Morgan Stanely?s expectations that 60%+ is attainable. ?	There are few seven figure deals within Alfresco so this is a sizable opportunity for them.  Morgan Stanley would likely become a top 5-10% customer. ?	Anecdotally NPI has heard a VC is looking at buying Alfresco. That can be good or bad of course but it does reflect uncertainty that may lend itself to a negotiation nugget. ?	If you do a multi-year deal expect 3-5% increases being offered.  Their sales team loves multi-year deals as they get paid upfront on those which is not the case with many software companies. ?	Some competitors in this space are noted below. Morgan Stanley is a HUGE Adobe customer so that could be a leverage point.  o	Sharepoint is #1 o	FileNet (IBM) o	Documentum (EMC) o	Appian o	Exterro o	Nuxeo o	Adobe Experience Manager   Please share updates as you get them or answers to prior questions when you get a chance to review. Thanks   SUMMARY OUTCOME (NO DOCS):  Hi Gregg,    For Alfresco the best we could agree was the $396k for 2,500 users for a 1 year subscription plus a 10% flex allowance getting us to the true number of 2,750 users for the $396k fee. This unit cost is now at $158.74 but we have agreed a tiered discount for future purchases where the unit cost will go down gradually. If we reach the 9,500-10,000 user level, the unit cost goes down to $98.25 per user per year.    I hope that helps and I apologize for the delay!
deal_metadata.customer_comments: not crystal clear what comprises the final outcome.  Is it just the platform that lists for $232.5K for 1000 users plus 209K for 1000 more and then 5x 23.3K to get to 2500 users?  Later, 2020, doing an Amfam review I saw their users were concurrent.  One table Lara shared at end wasn't crystal clear but appeared to be named user. I asked her to clarify. her reply:They are for individual users, definitely not concurrent.

Alfresco One Enterprise  ?	Term: 30 Jun 2017 ? 30 Aug 2017 2.	Alfresco Digital Business Platform Enterprise - (Up to 1,000 Named Users)  ?	Term: 31 Aug 2017 ? 30 Aug 2018  ?	Alfresco Content Services Enterprise ?	Alfresco Governance Services Enterprise ?	Alfresco Process Services (Powered by Activiti) - Enterprise 3.	Alfresco Index Engine x 3  ? deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI had reviewed this subscription for a client pre-acquisition.  At that time it was priced around $1.25 per employee and they offered up discounts in the 15-25% range.  BJCs offer works out to $4.00 for the two subscriptions or $3.33 for the main PolicyTech one.  That?s a sizable 2-3X price increase over the past couple years.  It is not clear if this reflects a discount as they don?t publish a price list but it feels like list and even looks like list.  This is a good-sized deal for Navex.  The quote doesn?t talk much about future year pricing and historically they haven?t raised prices much but that may not be true anymore.  Push for clarity and for flat renewal pricing.  While the new pricing may be the new reality it may behoove BJC to be ready to indicate through your own research and other employees seeing this at other firms have seen PolicyTech closer to $1.25 per employee and while you know this is a better solution post-acquisition the increase seems too steep.  This is where you?d also share a number that you are willing to pay based on Compliance360 historical pricing and budget.  NPIs target is $75K for this main subscription and $10-15K for the Workflow module.  Paying $85K for these is fair and reflects a $35K reduction per year.  NPI has previously seen the PolicyTech setup shown with a list of $3K and discounted to $2500.  Interesting you?re offer looks like it lists for $2500.  They have historically discounted this about 15% so why not target that.  They may counter that the Workflow setup fee is at no charge.  I?d counter that you?re used to their being minimal set up fees when you?re buying six figures of a SaaS subscription.   Continuing along this line, Navex has been known to nickel and dime customers as evidenced also by the User Import and Gateway Assistance items. These are cheap at a total of $2K.  We?ve seen Gateway fees waived and the Import fee discounted 50%.  Achieving these targets saves about $1500 a year.  The Quickstart feels expensive at $25K.  My SME suggested you push for a sizable reduction to $12,500.  This is to help you fine tune and be able to self-manage.  Reading the description, it doesn?t feel like a $25K effort. You are signing up for 3 years after all and many providers deeply discount the one-time fees when you do a multi-year SaaS contract.  A challenge could be that they see services as a low margin business that hits a separate P&L within Navex which can present challenges when you push for sizable discounts.  Achieving a $5-10K reduction would be a nice outcome.  On the SLA front they?ve gotten stingier.  We?ve seen 25 second for average speed to answer with an 80% goal which speaks to the first and third items above which had worse targets.  Have seen abandon rate due to wait time of longer than 25 seconds targeting 96% or more.  You?ve got 30 seconds and the target is 95%+.  Availability has improved from 99% to 99.5%.     Note from another client on their outcome sent to BJC:  We got the vendor to increase our employee count to 18,000 at the same cost and reduce some of the Initial Fees.  Also, locked in costs for additional employees at the same rate as the initial purchase.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: still on hold per Adam as of 6/18/18
deal_metadata.description: PolicyTech & Workflow Unlimited Licenses, Quick Start (Competing product proposed to replace Compliance 360) PolicyTech is designed to provide instant access to Client's policies and procedures, job descriptions, templates, and compliance documentation. Client can use the software to create, review, approve, and archive Client documents. Email reminders ensure that documents stay up-to-date and that all employees have read and signed-off on required documentation. Client can also configure and organize documents according to Client's compliance standards.  As of March 2018 it is not finalized yet.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Tableau, unlike many other vendors, tends to sell their products at list price without offering large discounts.  With organizations that have large footprints, NPI has seen discounts range from 7% - 25% (depending heavily on the size of the footprint).    One of Tableau?s co-founders is also a co-founder of Pixar (and a Stanford professor), and he is a big reason for Tableau?s push for outstanding visualizations and intuitiveness. Tableau invests heavily in R&D and support, which adds to their reasoning against discounting.  Although NPI has seen only a single example where Tableau offered discounts of 25% on a new purchase, we have been recently seeing deeper and more frequent discounts being offered.  It is NPI?s belief that although they remain the leader in the Gartner quadrant, Microsoft?s Power BI may be starting to slowly gain ground and thereby forcing Tableau to be a little more generous in discounting.  Tableau maintenance fees are calculated as a flat 25% of the license price. deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Illumio?s proposal to BNYM and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV), but with some important caveats.  NPI believes BNYM?s potential spend with the vendor represents one of their top accounts, and certainly the most important in the region.  Illumio?s needs this deal immensely, as NPI is aware of several recent implementations in large financial service institutions that have gone awry.  NPI does caution that one of the major issues with these other implementations is around deployment concerns in which several comparable spends saw less than 50% of committed licenses in use by the end of the term, along with a few with usage below 25%.  NPI suggests checking usage of the existing and proposed deployments, as we do see this as a recurring issue.   NPI views the base pricing in this deal to be towards the top of the range in terms of the vendor?s discounting, but BNYM has a significant amount of leverage in this spend due to its importance to Illumio.  Alignment with the vendor?s fiscal quarter end in April further improves BNYM?s position, and any credible doubt that Illumio can create suggesting this transaction could lag into May due to cost pressures will help your position immensely.  NPI cannot emphasize enough how strategic the success of BNYM?s relationship is to Illumio?s wider organization.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends BNYM first confirm your internal usage forecasts and to push Illumio to apply the 74% discount base to the lowest purchase tier.  BNYM should phrase any messaging around these requests as ?necessary to stay within cost parameters and maintain an April timeframe for the deal.? ?	NPI highly recommends not mentioning any specific discounts or information provided by any benchmarking activities, and to instead focus Illumio on a $4.65M price target that maintains a  o	NPI suggests confirming usage first, and to focus messaging on a high-level TCO figure that may be even lower than the $4.65M target applied to this full proposal.   ?	BNYM should feel confident in considering more aggressive discounts if a purchase above 25k new licenses is determined to be within demand forecasts.  While these are the FMV targets in line with what NPI observes in comparable deals, BNYM is in custom territory due to the importance of this deal to the vendor.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: poor client execution, no savings.    BNYM is reviewing an add-on purchase to Illumio?s Adaptive Security Platform that includes a co-term for existing subscriptions.

Worked with Graham on pricing targets and strategies. ?	Current discounting is at the low end of FMV ?	Coupa can provide more aggressive discounting if they feel they need to in order to win the business.  Details are in the table below. ?	There is no real overhead associated with setting up the Test Sandbox, so Coupa can provide this at no or minimal cost. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP not allow Coupa to bind your license fees to the license metrics provided.  If they go up they charge you more.  If they go up they charge you more, If they go down they won't reduce your annual number.  They audit you or charge you the annual increase, etc. to get back to that number.  Protect against that now before you sign the contract.   After saying NO multiple times Coupa finally came down to 890K and threw in Analytics.when it got closer to the end of the quarter
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends that CHOP begin the negotiations with KPMG or other implementation provider.  CHOP should have a serious conversation about the true cost to enable the expected number of vendors in the Coupa system.  You will want to ensure you have a solid understanding of what your implementation costs will be, as that will provide negotiation leverage in your discussions with Coupa. ?	Coupa will ask you to talk to their references which is an attempt to divert from reducing their fees. ?	If Basware / Verian is a viable option (NOTE: it does not have to be a perfect solution, just as long as Coupa believes they are a real threat), CHOP can indicate that preliminary pricing looks VERY good from Verian. ?	Ask for List pricing to be frozen for the term of the agreement and to agree on a discount % for that time.  Preferably at the same level ?	Push to include 10k worth of incremental storage as a one-time concession to be used during the term of the agreement.  ?	Request to remove the 2% late penalty fee. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP negotiate to get the total cost of the solution down to $800,000 and not try to discuss individual discounts.  CHOP can let Coupa know that budgets are tight and Coupa needs to get much more aggressive in order to get this project approved and moving this month which is the end of Coupa?s Q3.  Without these concessions, there could be a significant delay or CHOP my look further at alternatives. ?	Negotiate SLAs similar to that of Workday ?	Coupa's CEO is a marketing guy so be prepared to offer marketing rights, videos, references, etc., in exchange for concessions.  The more CHOP will agree to, the more concessions you will get. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP ask for licensing protection language in their agreement to cover feature(s) shifting from one module to another.  Coupa is known to take features out of a module you have license rights to and shift or move it to another module that you don?t have license rights to.  Then trying to charge you an incremental fee.    Also recommended getting the Analytics thrown in at no additional cost.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Amfam facing ?forced? upgrade from SA (SA retired, no longer available to renew as of July 1, 2017) to SWM.  Past discount was well above FMV at 58%. New offer is SWM at 45%.  Seeing big increase due to Citrix ?packaging? additional features/services into a new support model ?> no longer a-la-carte. ?	Previously -- Software updates and support were purchased separately ?	New model ? Advertised as ?Customer Support Services?; combines software updates and support, while also expanding and creating a new baseline support tier system o	3 Tier structure created ? 1. Select, 2. Priority, 3. Priority Plus ?	Priority Plus appears to have advantages similar to a TRM ?	Recommend to negotiate price based on an increase due to packaging support features not previously purchased inflating the new baseline price.   No change observed for TRM engagement ? pricing consistent ?	However, the Priority Plus tier may become a reasonable alternative  Closed - FINAL RESULT; feedback from Citrix below....also confirmed no concessions on TRM - holding true to what we typically see...  Thank you for taking the time to express American Family?s concerns with Citrix Maintenance pricing as well as the requirement to have an active agreement in place. We value your business and have voiced your concerns internally to see what can be done to help your organization transition to our new Customer Success Services offering.    Renewal Pricing:    As you?re aware, American Family has not made a qualifying purchase to maintain their ELA-6 discount causing contractual pricing to reduce to the ELA-2 discount of 25%. However, given the relationship with American Family and the change in our program, the Citrix team acted in good faith by agreeing to honor the 45% discount on the initial renewal quote.  The additional good news is that we raised your current concerns internally and have secured a concession to temporarily increase American Family?s renewal discount to 53% if a renewal is transacted on-time by 12/27/17.   *Note: This concession is granted for this transaction only and will not permanently change American Family?s maintenance price on future renewals. While you didn?t express an interest in a multiyear commitment, this concession CAN also be utilized if an upfront payment is made. Considering the savings, it may be something to consider.    Summary:   We have attached a full quote that includes both Software and Hardware at the concession price. While we understand that all of your requests were not fulfilled,  this is the best and final that Citrix can offer. We also feel confident that American Family will see the value of our new Customer Success Services offering after you have had a chance to utilize the many new features. I am available to work with you on whatever option you decide so please reach out after you have had a chance to review internally.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Good improvement.    Xen Desktop Platinum:  NPI recommended 50% would be good, shoot for 55% to settle in the middle  Citrix came back at 53% - with a rate of $35.25 >>> rounding discount up from fractional percent, actual @$300k is closer to $35.29  Negligible, about $300 difference for a $300,000 line item Citrix NetScaler SDX 11500 Appliance ? This was not included in the original quote NPI did not provide a recommendation  Quick research, renewing at the previous rate that AmFam received ($8,910 Gold, $4,950 Bronze) ? no change.  Remains at past discount of 45% Additional hardware maintenance not provided to NPI for review includes:  Citrix NetScaler SDX 11515 Appliance ? Gold $7,567.40 Citrix NetScaler MPX 8200 Platinum Edition ? Gold $3,917.96 SW and HW TRM ? provided feedback that it is rare to see movement, have seen AmFam receive a one off 10% discount in the past  Citrix renewal is at list  Additional feedback in response could include:  For a purchase of this size any reference to ELA-2 is a bit disingenuous as NPI does not typically see a major enterprise the size of AmFam come in at 25% on a maintenance renewal. In the past we?d expect 25% off Subscription Advantage but this is for an upgraded level of support so that doesn?t apply anymore in our opinion..  The movement from a 45% discount to a 53% is a good deal ? if executed then congratulations this is a savings of $53,515. In preparing for your next renewal (2019), track the conversation and progress regarding movement to Customer Success Services during 2018 ? any history that you can maintain and capture regarding any pain points with this migration will be beneficial to bring up during your next renewal cycle.
deal_metadata.description: As attached.  Your thoughts are greatly appreciated. (Citrix renewal SA and TRM)

CHOP should have a serious conversation about the true cost to enable the expected number of vendors in the Coupa system.  You will want to ensure you have a solid understanding of what your implementation costs will be, as that will provide negotiation leverage in your discussions with Coupa. ?	Coupa will ask you to talk to their references which is an attempt to divert from reducing their fees. ?	If Basware / Verian is a viable option (NOTE: it does not have to be a perfect solution, just as long as Coupa believes they are a real threat), CHOP can indicate that preliminary pricing looks VERY good from Verian. ?	Ask for List pricing to be frozen for the term of the agreement and to agree on a discount % for that time.  Preferably at the same level ?	Push to include 10k worth of incremental storage as a one-time concession to be used during the term of the agreement.  ?	Request to remove the 2% late penalty fee. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP negotiate to get the total cost of the solution down to $800,000 and not try to discuss individual discounts.  CHOP can let Coupa know that budgets are tight and Coupa needs to get much more aggressive in order to get this project approved and moving this month which is the end of Coupa?s Q3.  Without these concessions, there could be a significant delay or CHOP my look further at alternatives. ?	Negotiate SLAs similar to that of Workday ?	Coupa's CEO is a marketing guy so be prepared to offer marketing rights, videos, references, etc., in exchange for concessions.  The more CHOP will agree to, the more concessions you will get. ?	NPI recommends that CHOP ask for licensing protection language in their agreement to cover feature(s) shifting from one module to another.  Coupa is known to take features out of a module you have license rights to and shift or move it to another module that you don?t have license rights to.  Then trying to charge you an incremental fee.    Also recommended getting the Analytics thrown in at no additional cost.
deal_metadata.description: CHOP just completed a deal with Workday and now looking at Coupa P2O and ultimately P2P.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We do have quite a bit of BMC data for comparison and considering your urgency, see our feedback below (in lieu of a more formal FMV report).  BMC has several flavors of its Control-M automation software.  We have a couple of BMC price lists, but without part numbers, we are unable to calculate a discount percentage.  We strongly recommend that you push back on BMC and ask for a revised quote that shows the list price for this purchase (preferably by line-item).  Here is what we think we know: ? The quote says that support is included for the first year.  We know that BMC support is almost always 20% of the net license purchase so the $148,500 likely breaks down this way:  o $123,750 for licensing o $24,750 for support  We have seen that BMC will get very aggressive with discounting.  On a recent $250K renewal (similar Control-M products), another NPI client saw 80% discounting.  In another deal where BMC won in a competitive take-out over CA, a similar sized deal was discounted at 88%.  So, once Trinity receives a list price quote for this purchase, you will want to ensure that you are seeing discounting in the 75% - 85% range.  Incidentally, the client who was moving away from CA and bought Control-M ? that effort is failing.  Our client is scrambling to crawl back to CA and extend the support on the product they were going to drop.  They are leaving a bunch of failed services spend with BMC in the dust and not going with Control M.  Trinity should mention to BMC that you have heard some stories from the industry about failed implementations ? use the FUD (Fear Uncertainty, & Doubt) to create more leverage.  NOTE: NPI is vendor agnostic, we do not recommend one product/vendor over another.  The above is shared only as a means to gain additional leverage in your negotiations with BMC.   UPDATE: Received add'l info from Belli on List price... sent Jim an update:  Hey Jim,   I wanted to follow-up with a bit more info that I?ve learned.  I was able to get some feedback from one of NPI?s mainframe experts and we believe that we may have figured out list pricing.  If we are correct, the Control-M Platform has a list price of $250/task.  Control-M Base ? Enterprise has a list price of $25K.  If we do the math, $250 * 500 + $25000 * 1 + 20% of licensing for support, the list price for your proposal is $180,000.  Which would mean that you are only receiving a 17.5% discount on this proposal.  NPI considers this pricing to be egregiously overpriced.  As I mentioned before, we have seen these types of purchases reach 75% - 85% discounting.  We recommend that you reach out to BMC and let them know that your market research shows you have meager discounting and this pricing is a non-starter.  This $148K quote should be closer to $50K.
deal_metadata.description: Can you give us a quick FMV for this BMC support? Their fiscal year end is today and I have them at $140K for 500 units. Do you have any FMV intel on BMC?

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Amfam facing ?forced? upgrade from SA (SA retired, no longer available to renew as of July 1, 2017) to SWM.  Past discount was well above FMV at 58%. New offer is SWM at 45%.  Seeing big increase due to Citrix ?packaging? additional features/services into a new support model ?> no longer a-la-carte. ?	Previously -- Software updates and support were purchased separately ?	New model ? Advertised as ?Customer Support Services?; combines software updates and support, while also expanding and creating a new baseline support tier system o	3 Tier structure created ? 1. Select, 2. Priority, 3. Priority Plus ?	Priority Plus appears to have advantages similar to a TRM ?	Recommend to negotiate price based on an increase due to packaging support features not previously purchased inflating the new baseline price.   No change observed for TRM engagement ? pricing consistent ?	However, the Priority Plus tier may become a reasonable alternative  Closed - FINAL RESULT; feedback from Citrix below....also confirmed no concessions on TRM - holding true to what we typically see...  Thank you for taking the time to express American Family?s concerns with Citrix Maintenance pricing as well as the requirement to have an active agreement in place. We value your business and have voiced your concerns internally to see what can be done to help your organization transition to our new Customer Success Services offering.    Renewal Pricing:    As you?re aware, American Family has not made a qualifying purchase to maintain their ELA-6 discount causing contractual pricing to reduce to the ELA-2 discount of 25%. However, given the relationship with American Family and the change in our program, the Citrix team acted in good faith by agreeing to honor the 45% discount on the initial renewal quote.  The additional good news is that we raised your current concerns internally and have secured a concession to temporarily increase American Family?s renewal discount to 53% if a renewal is transacted on-time by 12/27/17.   *Note: This concession is granted for this transaction only and will not permanently change American Family?s maintenance price on future renewals. While you didn?t express an interest in a multiyear commitment, this concession CAN also be utilized if an upfront payment is made. Considering the savings, it may be something to consider.    Summary:   We have attached a full quote that includes both Software and Hardware at the concession price. While we understand that all of your requests were not fulfilled,  this is the best and final that Citrix can offer. We also feel confident that American Family will see the value of our new Customer Success Services offering after you have had a chance to utilize the many new features. I am available to work with you on whatever option you decide so please reach out after you have had a chance to review internally.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Good improvement.    Xen Desktop Platinum:  NPI recommended 50% would be good, shoot for 55% to settle in the middle  Citrix came back at 53% - with a rate of $35.25 >>> rounding discount up from fractional percent, actual @$300k is closer to $35.29  Negligible, about $300 difference for a $300,000 line item Citrix NetScaler SDX 11500 Appliance ? This was not included in the original quote NPI did not provide a recommendation  Quick research, renewing at the previous rate that AmFam received ($8,910 Gold, $4,950 Bronze) ? no change.  Remains at past discount of 45% Additional hardware maintenance not provided to NPI for review includes:  Citrix NetScaler SDX 11515 Appliance ? Gold $7,567.40 Citrix NetScaler MPX 8200 Platinum Edition ? Gold $3,917.96 SW and HW TRM ? provided feedback that it is rare to see movement, have seen AmFam receive a one off 10% discount in the past  Citrix renewal is at list  Additional feedback in response could include:  For a purchase of this size any reference to ELA-2 is a bit disingenuous as NPI does not typically see a major enterprise the size of AmFam come in at 25% on a maintenance renewal. In the past we?d expect 25% off Subscription Advantage but this is for an upgraded level of support so that doesn?t apply anymore in our opinion..  The movement from a 45% discount to a 53% is a good deal ? if executed then congratulations this is a savings of $53,515. In preparing for your next renewal (2019), track the conversation and progress regarding movement to Customer Success Services during 2018 ? any history that you can maintain and capture regarding any pain points with this migration will be beneficial to bring up during your next renewal cycle.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Illumio?s proposal to BNYM and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV), but with some important caveats.  NPI believes BNYM?s potential spend with the vendor represents one of their top accounts, and certainly the most important in the region.  Illumio?s needs this deal immensely, as NPI is aware of several recent implementations in large financial service institutions that have gone awry.  NPI does caution that one of the major issues with these other implementations is around deployment concerns in which several comparable spends saw less than 50% of committed licenses in use by the end of the term, along with a few with usage below 25%.  NPI suggests checking usage of the existing and proposed deployments, as we do see this as a recurring issue.   NPI views the base pricing in this deal to be towards the top of the range in terms of the vendor?s discounting, but BNYM has a significant amount of leverage in this spend due to its importance to Illumio.  Alignment with the vendor?s fiscal quarter end in April further improves BNYM?s position, and any credible doubt that Illumio can create suggesting this transaction could lag into May due to cost pressures will help your position immensely.  NPI cannot emphasize enough how strategic the success of BNYM?s relationship is to Illumio?s wider organization.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends BNYM first confirm your internal usage forecasts and to push Illumio to apply the 74% discount base to the lowest purchase tier.  BNYM should phrase any messaging around these requests as ?necessary to stay within cost parameters and maintain an April timeframe for the deal.? ?	NPI highly recommends not mentioning any specific discounts or information provided by any benchmarking activities, and to instead focus Illumio on a $4.65M price target that maintains a  o	NPI suggests confirming usage first, and to focus messaging on a high-level TCO figure that may be even lower than the $4.65M target applied to this full proposal.   ?	BNYM should feel confident in considering more aggressive discounts if a purchase above 25k new licenses is determined to be within demand forecasts.  While these are the FMV targets in line with what NPI observes in comparable deals, BNYM is in custom territory due to the importance of this deal to the vendor.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: poor client execution, no savings.    BNYM is reviewing an add-on purchase to Illumio?s Adaptive Security Platform that includes a co-term for existing subscriptions.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: FMOL inherited this contract from a hospital acquisition and the deal was not right-sized so there is a large true-up.  In order to get an on time renewal I was able to negotiate concessions on the true-up.  Waiting on FMOL to get it done
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Subsequent overage

deal_metadata.current_narrative: SAS renewals are a bit of a challenge because they aren?t typically benchmarked like other vendors.  We have seen a number of SAS deals and renewals so I was able to do some comparisons on the Software you are renewing.  When we break your renewal cost down to a per user price, your pricing is similar to the pricing we have seen on other SAS renewals.    For example: We have seen SAS Analytics Pro renewal pricing range from $1,437 per user (31 users) to $2,850 per user (1 user).  REI?s SAS Analysis Pro renewal is priced at $2,790 for 2 users.  So by comparison, your pricing is FMV.  Having said that, NPI typically benchmarks a SAS renewal year fees (RYF) based on the first year fees (FYF).  Depending on the size of the initial purchase, discounting can range wildly from 25% up to 70%?s & low 80%?s.  NPI generally advises that RYFs should remain between 27% - 35% of FYFs.  REI should review initial year fees for the products in this renewal to insure that you are in that 27% - 35% range.  If you are, then NPI would consider this pricing to be largely Fair Market Value (FMV).  If you are above 35%, you should point this out to SAS and explain that your finance team has taken notice of it and is holding up this renewal.
deal_metadata.description: I?ve got a couple of quotes here from SAS on licensing support. We will likely drop ODBC and Oracle Components, Concurrent seats from 15 to 7, and Mining to 1.  Can you run these through the FMV Echasketch and see what comes up?

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Discounting was sort of all over the place but not that bad for this volume above a 20% blend.  I do believe they could target a $35k net to shave ~$4k off if they lead with that as the needed figure to accommodate an April deal.
deal_metadata.description: Urgent deal, needed it same day

deal_metadata.current_narrative: This was 1.0 ... hoping for QGenda docs from Evergreen but they did not come.  Significant scope change... counts were reduced and unit-pricing (per staff) appears to have gone up.  Closing with no savings.  Thanks for sending over your QGenda pricing for NPI to review.  QGenda isn?t one of our strongest vendors, so I had to reach out to one of NPI?s SME?s in our Advisor Network and also gathered some additional information from another NPI hospital client, thanks for your patience while I gathered the additional data.  Overall, NPI finds this pricing to be slightly ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) and we recommend that Springfield target reductions in this pricing.  Upfront Costs Beginning with the Upfront fees, these amount to 25% and 31% (26% blended) of the subscription fees.  NPI has typically seen that upfront fees on QGenda implementations are typically 18% - 20% of the net total cost of the licenses.  We recommend targeting 20% of the final license cost.   License Fees The difference in the license fees between the Hospital based staff members and the Float pool are due to additional functionality for the Hospital Based staff members ?Time Tracking and Compensation Management modules. ? Hospital based employees have a recurring annual cost of $324 per staff member, and the Float Pool has a recurring cost of $240 per staff member. ? NPI has seen the base Schedule Automation module priced lower, between $210 - $220 per staff member. ? For the Hospital based staff, the recurring charge is $84 more per year per staff member.  NPI finds this increase for the Time Tracking and Comp Management modules to be FMV.  However, the pricing for the hospital staff should still come down to ~$290 per staff member to account for the slightly overpriced base scheduling fees.  If we are able to achieve $215 base scheduling fees and the upfront charges at 20% of the net license cost, the total first year price tag will be closer to $50K - $51K.  NPI recommends that the messaging to QGenda should focus around budget and potential growth: ?Thank you for sending over this proposal for our review.   Unfortunately in its current form, it may not be executable for us because we just haven?t put this much money into the budget for this project.  I am sure you are aware of the budget issues that Springfield clinic has with the state of Illinois.  Every dollar we spend is going through intense scrutiny and adding funds to a budget line-item is difficult ? if not impossible.   The $12,875 in upfront charges that will come out of our Capital budget is well above the $8,750 that we had expected when we budgeted for this.  Additionally, the $48,000 in recurring license fees have given the finance team a bit of pause.  At these prices, there is concern over the cost of the potential growth of this solution.  I have gained verbal approval for a recurring annual fee of $41,250.  If QGenda is able to meet us at these budgetary numbers, I believe I can get this pushed through by the end of this month, otherwise we may need to wait until the next budgeting cycle later in the year.?    RESPONSE to updated quotes: Hi Arvinder,  Thanks for sending these over.  The Overall pricing is the same as the original quotes that NPI reviewed.  However, they have broken out the Hospital staff cost for the extra Time/Compensation module.  Unfortunately, this actually raises additional questions, such as, why is the base scheduling module charged differently between the two groups?  The recurring annual charge for Hospital staff is $252/user/year, but the Float Pool staff recurring annual fees are $240/user/year.   Springfield may want to question this discrepancy as a side-note to the overall negotiation.  Overall, NPI?s feedback is materially the same as below.  We have seen the scheduling module offered at a lower price and we recommend Springfield use the budget and growth leverage mentioned in the write-up below.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Chris, can you please review the attached. Thanks, Arvinder   UPDATE: after I sent feedback, Arvinder sent updated quotes... response to updated quotes below.

file_info.name: BNYM - FMV - Illumio April 2018 v2 Redline.docx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Illumio?s proposal to BNYM and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV), but with some important caveats.  NPI believes BNYM?s potential spend with the vendor represents one of their top accounts, and certainly the most important in the region.  Illumio?s needs this deal immensely, as NPI is aware of several recent implementations in large financial service institutions that have gone awry.  NPI does caution that one of the major issues with these other implementations is around deployment concerns in which several comparable spends saw less than 50% of committed licenses in use by the end of the term, along with a few with usage below 25%.  NPI suggests checking usage of the existing and proposed deployments, as we do see this as a recurring issue.   NPI views the base pricing in this deal to be towards the top of the range in terms of the vendor?s discounting, but BNYM has a significant amount of leverage in this spend due to its importance to Illumio.  Alignment with the vendor?s fiscal quarter end in April further improves BNYM?s position, and any credible doubt that Illumio can create suggesting this transaction could lag into May due to cost pressures will help your position immensely.  NPI cannot emphasize enough how strategic the success of BNYM?s relationship is to Illumio?s wider organization.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends BNYM first confirm your internal usage forecasts and to push Illumio to apply the 74% discount base to the lowest purchase tier.  BNYM should phrase any messaging around these requests as ?necessary to stay within cost parameters and maintain an April timeframe for the deal.? ?	NPI highly recommends not mentioning any specific discounts or information provided by any benchmarking activities, and to instead focus Illumio on a $4.65M price target that maintains a  o	NPI suggests confirming usage first, and to focus messaging on a high-level TCO figure that may be even lower than the $4.65M target applied to this full proposal.   ?	BNYM should feel confident in considering more aggressive discounts if a purchase above 25k new licenses is determined to be within demand forecasts.  While these are the FMV targets in line with what NPI observes in comparable deals, BNYM is in custom territory due to the importance of this deal to the vendor.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: This was 1.0 ... hoping for QGenda docs from Evergreen but they did not come.  Significant scope change... counts were reduced and unit-pricing (per staff) appears to have gone up.  Closing with no savings.  Thanks for sending over your QGenda pricing for NPI to review.  QGenda isn?t one of our strongest vendors, so I had to reach out to one of NPI?s SME?s in our Advisor Network and also gathered some additional information from another NPI hospital client, thanks for your patience while I gathered the additional data.  Overall, NPI finds this pricing to be slightly ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) and we recommend that Springfield target reductions in this pricing.  Upfront Costs Beginning with the Upfront fees, these amount to 25% and 31% (26% blended) of the subscription fees.  NPI has typically seen that upfront fees on QGenda implementations are typically 18% - 20% of the net total cost of the licenses.  We recommend targeting 20% of the final license cost.   License Fees The difference in the license fees between the Hospital based staff members and the Float pool are due to additional functionality for the Hospital Based staff members ?Time Tracking and Compensation Management modules. ? Hospital based employees have a recurring annual cost of $324 per staff member, and the Float Pool has a recurring cost of $240 per staff member. ? NPI has seen the base Schedule Automation module priced lower, between $210 - $220 per staff member. ? For the Hospital based staff, the recurring charge is $84 more per year per staff member.  NPI finds this increase for the Time Tracking and Comp Management modules to be FMV.  However, the pricing for the hospital staff should still come down to ~$290 per staff member to account for the slightly overpriced base scheduling fees.  If we are able to achieve $215 base scheduling fees and the upfront charges at 20% of the net license cost, the total first year price tag will be closer to $50K - $51K.  NPI recommends that the messaging to QGenda should focus around budget and potential growth: ?Thank you for sending over this proposal for our review.   Unfortunately in its current form, it may not be executable for us because we just haven?t put this much money into the budget for this project.  I am sure you are aware of the budget issues that Springfield clinic has with the state of Illinois.  Every dollar we spend is going through intense scrutiny and adding funds to a budget line-item is difficult ? if not impossible.   The $12,875 in upfront charges that will come out of our Capital budget is well above the $8,750 that we had expected when we budgeted for this.  Additionally, the $48,000 in recurring license fees have given the finance team a bit of pause.  At these prices, there is concern over the cost of the potential growth of this solution.  I have gained verbal approval for a recurring annual fee of $41,250.  If QGenda is able to meet us at these budgetary numbers, I believe I can get this pushed through by the end of this month, otherwise we may need to wait until the next budgeting cycle later in the year.?    RESPONSE to updated quotes: Hi Arvinder,  Thanks for sending these over.  The Overall pricing is the same as the original quotes that NPI reviewed.  However, they have broken out the Hospital staff cost for the extra Time/Compensation module.  Unfortunately, this actually raises additional questions, such as, why is the base scheduling module charged differently between the two groups?  The recurring annual charge for Hospital staff is $252/user/year, but the Float Pool staff recurring annual fees are $240/user/year.   Springfield may want to question this discrepancy as a side-note to the overall negotiation.  Overall, NPI?s feedback is materially the same as below.  We have seen the scheduling module offered at a lower price and we recommend Springfield use the budget and growth leverage mentioned in the write-up below.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Chris, can you please review the attached. Thanks, Arvinder   UPDATE: after I sent feedback, Arvinder sent updated quotes... response to updated quotes below.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: The proposed price for the Technical Account Manager is $65,000 which is at the high end of the range of Fair Market value (FMV).  The Technical Account TAM is a dedicated but not exclusive resource. Each TAM typically handles 4 or 5 accounts.  There may be customers that require more support time depending on the size/complexity of the organization etc. NPI has seen the price for TAM varying between $45,000 and $65,000 based on the TAM usage.  If REI does not use the TAM extensively, they could negotiate a lower pricing on the TAM and achieve savings up to $20K.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Had a few comps on our own.  Matt B shared a couple as well.  Hi Christina, We validated the list price for this product that has product code - SPDVCP990.   The Spectrum products are almost a commodity and CA has given clients high discounts.  With the total spend MS does with CA, the discounts should reflect consideration of your ELA and ELA pricing.  We?ve seen discounts at this volume no less than 54% and on one occasion exceeding 80%.  A client with a much smaller overall CA footprint bought 1100 recently and landed at 54%.  CA is not selling a lot of Spectrum.  There are lots of competitors that can monitor network devices.    MS should get discounts in the 64% to 70% range.  Minimum discount would be 60%.  If CA does not want to discount more, then MS should look at other competitors. While you could make the argument that the FMV targets should be the same since across all three options the net license spend is a narrow $205K-$275K (i.e., the capacity shouldn?t affect the discount), here?s our FMV targets for all three options. ?	2000 ? 60-66% - target 64% ?	2500 ? 62-68% - target 66% ?	3000 ? 64-70% - target 68%  20% maintenance is typical and it appears the year 2 maintenance involves co-terming as it is for 11 months (i.e., when I adjust for 12 months it equates exactly to 20%).  Any savings on support will be indirect and based on the licensing reductions.  Does MS currently use Spectrum?   Is MS replacing another vendor with Spectrum?
deal_metadata.description: Hi Gregg,  This is in the works for year-end.  Our ELA w/ CA guarantees a minimum 50% discount off list for all distributed software, which is where they?re at for QTY 2000.  At this point the BU only needs 2000.  Looking to understand: 1.	What?s an attractive year-end discount? 2.	What is a favorable discount as we grow ? i.e. @3000 users we should be at X% off list, etc.   Bounced off of Matt B.  Was helpful.  Cancelled; Thank you for the below.  This is no longer tracking as a y/e 2017 deal. The BU will revisit in 1Q 2018, in line with CA?s fiscal y/e.  When we revisit this it?s worth considering that 2017 YTD we?ve spend an additional $2M on distributed software and about $2.7M on mainframe.   This is in addition to the ELA we paid in Nov 2016.
