deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s 3-year offer from GitLab and found pricing to be above fair market value (FMV) for the combined spend.  BNYM?s demand is significant, as the vendor does not have an excessive amount of accounts with 10,000 or more users, and especially not many of those under a 3-year commitment.  GitLab has decent margins on this product even if support call volumes are high, and the long-term agreement would see good incentives passed to the sales team.  The vendor appears to be pushing hard for a decision on this agreement before their fiscal quarter end this month, and terms indicate that this includes a full prepayment of the term.  Even with a limited timeline for negotiations, NPI recommends BNYM create doubt in the sales team?s mind that this deal can proceed in its current form.  NPI sees the DevOps market as fiercely competitive at the moment, and if GitLab?s deal team believes the deal?s health is in question, they will bring their case before the executives in the sales organization for consideration.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends focusing messaging on a $4.0M even target presented to GitLab as the level at which BNYM can maintain the current deal timeline.   ?	NPI highly recommends not mentioning specific discount amounts or benchmarking tied to this deal at all, and instead focus GitLab on the larger annual and full-term costs.  If the GitLab sales team hears messaging that requests specific discounts, their internal systems often interpret this as a ?buy? signal and prevent them from authorizing further concessions.  Conversations focused on net and per user costs do not trigger these alerts, and NPI sees a much greater degree of success when that tract is followed without mentioning discount amounts.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: $375k savings reported for 3-year agreement.    BNYM is reviewing a new 3-year agreement for GitLab Premium direct from the vendor.

file_info.name: SignNow Supplement 56 for MetLife signatue 12.29.2017 Fully Executed.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Had a few iterations.   ?	As I always tell clients -- SAS is tough.  It is tough from NPIs perspective because they don?t publish a list price, limit their pricing transparency and their stuff can get complicated. ?	There?s some GSA pricing out there that we?ve started leveraging to help understand client pricing but it is never complete enough. ?	I always encourage clients to push for SAS to show their Standard pricing (list) and make discounts transparent. ?	I figured I?d start looking at your expiring Supplement to see what could be learned.  I believe your discount on your expiring Supplement was somewhere in the 30% range.   o	My two anecdotes for this conclusion is miraculously I was able to validate that $272,700 is the Standard Price (i.e., List) for Enterprise Miner 16 cores.  You actually have your priced for this exact item spelled out in Supplement 53 p.3.  Your first year fees (FYF) is $191,318.  This is just under a 30% discount.   o	SAS Contextual Analysis is another item with a standalone price in Supp 53.  This has an estimated 35% discount.   o	Supp 53 was just under $1M.  30-40% is a fine outcome for that spend.  Your second year fees (recurring year fees -RYFs) were 28-29% of FYFs.  The target is 27-35% so those were fine.  Your third year fee is 3% more than year 2.  That is typical.  We sometimes see a 5% increase and 3% is always our target. ?	Now the new proposal doesn?t share any line item pricing by product.   It also combined some Processor-driven products (40 cores) and some PC licenses. They also muddy slide 7 by showing VIYA?s value.  NPI is unable to determine the aggregated Standard Price for all the products.  While we may be able to come close it would be an inefficient and inaccurate exercise.  ?	If you include VIYA?s price and compare the $5,161,240 subtotal to the Net price of $1,911,978 that works out to almost exactly a 63% discount.  On a $5M deal that would be a very strong outcome.  We?d target 55-65%; however, if MetLife doesn?t care about VIYA then the $1.9M is only a 42% discount from what may be the list price (to be validated) of $3.274M.  On this size deal that is a bit light.  50% would be a solid landing spot for that price.  50% off non-VIYA licenses would drive about $280K in year 1 reductions. ?	RYF in year 2 is 28% exactly.  That?s fine and within FMV but if the FYF drops then this needs to stay at the same 28% level.   ?	RFY in year 3 is 3% more than year 2. That?s FMV. ?	Interestingly Option 1 in the prior proposal actually used the word discount implying the $1.315M in that offer was list price (i.e., Standard pricing) and that was a weak but not unexpected 26.5% discount.  Perhaps that means the first row of numbers in each proposal is list pricing. I actually don?t understand why the recurring year fees increases compared to year 1 and weren?t 27-35% of year 1 so I?m glad that option is off the table. Oddly Option 2 in that Proposal v.3 had this same approach which we never see.  I?m closing that file right now. ?	NPI suggests pushing SAS to show that list price detail or confirm that?s the offer.  At least it does appear they?re increasing the discount compared to Supplement 53 which makes sense as the price is 3x the size.  ?	As a side note, there?s also a propensity to discount basic tools like Office Analytics and Access less than what I?d call their Solution-based licenses. Less discounts, less flexibility and a drive to just keep it simpler within SAS. This stuff is well entrenched and people that use it really like it and don?t stop using it.  Because of that they just don?t feel obligated to aggressively discount it.  Because this comprises some of this quote that could be a little downward pressure on discounting but doesn?t need to.  It is their fiscal year end this month.  See attached email for second volley
deal_metadata.description: First request: Attached is a proposal (PowerPoint deck) from SAS and we wanted to get your feedback on their proposal. I have also included the current contract that is in effect until August 2018 that we are looking to update as well as our requirements (Word document) that we provided to SAS.  Note that SAS has indicated that they have accounted for the 3rd year fees of Supplement into their proposal. Lastly, we are interested in Option 2 (without Model Manager) just because of the VIYA inclusion as a nice to have. However at the end of the day, if they remove VIYA we are OK. The key is needing licenses as global and we can go down to 15 Desktop if need be.  This is anticipated to be a year-end effort and our LOB wants this transaction to be at $2.9M. Please let us know when you think NPI can provide their feedback  Sent a review. Shared feedback.  Tried to gauge prior discounts and current ones with a spot check.  Gave discount targets.  SAS came back with this story:  Per our discussion today, SAS? pricing for this type of a deal structure is based on the total number of cores and maximum number of environments allowed. Based on the strategic nature of this deal we were able to get permission to use a more favorable ?maximum number of environments? quantity to help drive the overall price down.  These would be the standard fees that would be applicable under normal circumstances.?  On the second round of feedback I suggested they push for list pricing.  She simply asked him if it was list pricing and he said YES.  Told her she let him off the hook.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Had a few comps on our own.  Matt B shared a couple as well.  Hi Christina, We validated the list price for this product that has product code - SPDVCP990.   The Spectrum products are almost a commodity and CA has given clients high discounts.  With the total spend MS does with CA, the discounts should reflect consideration of your ELA and ELA pricing.  We?ve seen discounts at this volume no less than 54% and on one occasion exceeding 80%.  A client with a much smaller overall CA footprint bought 1100 recently and landed at 54%.  CA is not selling a lot of Spectrum.  There are lots of competitors that can monitor network devices.    MS should get discounts in the 64% to 70% range.  Minimum discount would be 60%.  If CA does not want to discount more, then MS should look at other competitors. While you could make the argument that the FMV targets should be the same since across all three options the net license spend is a narrow $205K-$275K (i.e., the capacity shouldn?t affect the discount), here?s our FMV targets for all three options. ?	2000 ? 60-66% - target 64% ?	2500 ? 62-68% - target 66% ?	3000 ? 64-70% - target 68%  20% maintenance is typical and it appears the year 2 maintenance involves co-terming as it is for 11 months (i.e., when I adjust for 12 months it equates exactly to 20%).  Any savings on support will be indirect and based on the licensing reductions.  Does MS currently use Spectrum?   Is MS replacing another vendor with Spectrum?

What?s an attractive year-end discount? 2.	What is a favorable discount as we grow ? i.e. @3000 users we should be at X% off list, etc.   Bounced off of Matt B.  Was helpful.  Cancelled; Thank you for the below.  This is no longer tracking as a y/e 2017 deal. The BU will revisit in 1Q 2018, in line with CA?s fiscal y/e.  When we revisit this it?s worth considering that 2017 YTD we?ve spend an additional $2M on distributed software and about $2.7M on mainframe.   This is in addition to the ELA we paid in Nov 2016.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: This was 1.0 ... hoping for QGenda docs from Evergreen but they did not come.  Significant scope change... counts were reduced and unit-pricing (per staff) appears to have gone up.  Closing with no savings.  Thanks for sending over your QGenda pricing for NPI to review.  QGenda isn?t one of our strongest vendors, so I had to reach out to one of NPI?s SME?s in our Advisor Network and also gathered some additional information from another NPI hospital client, thanks for your patience while I gathered the additional data.  Overall, NPI finds this pricing to be slightly ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) and we recommend that Springfield target reductions in this pricing.  Upfront Costs Beginning with the Upfront fees, these amount to 25% and 31% (26% blended) of the subscription fees.  NPI has typically seen that upfront fees on QGenda implementations are typically 18% - 20% of the net total cost of the licenses.  We recommend targeting 20% of the final license cost.   License Fees The difference in the license fees between the Hospital based staff members and the Float pool are due to additional functionality for the Hospital Based staff members ?Time Tracking and Compensation Management modules. ? Hospital based employees have a recurring annual cost of $324 per staff member, and the Float Pool has a recurring cost of $240 per staff member. ? NPI has seen the base Schedule Automation module priced lower, between $210 - $220 per staff member. ? For the Hospital based staff, the recurring charge is $84 more per year per staff member.  NPI finds this increase for the Time Tracking and Comp Management modules to be FMV.  However, the pricing for the hospital staff should still come down to ~$290 per staff member to account for the slightly overpriced base scheduling fees.  If we are able to achieve $215 base scheduling fees and the upfront charges at 20% of the net license cost, the total first year price tag will be closer to $50K - $51K.  NPI recommends that the messaging to QGenda should focus around budget and potential growth: ?Thank you for sending over this proposal for our review.   Unfortunately in its current form, it may not be executable for us because we just haven?t put this much money into the budget for this project.  I am sure you are aware of the budget issues that Springfield clinic has with the state of Illinois.  Every dollar we spend is going through intense scrutiny and adding funds to a budget line-item is difficult ? if not impossible.   The $12,875 in upfront charges that will come out of our Capital budget is well above the $8,750 that we had expected when we budgeted for this.  Additionally, the $48,000 in recurring license fees have given the finance team a bit of pause.  At these prices, there is concern over the cost of the potential growth of this solution.  I have gained verbal approval for a recurring annual fee of $41,250.  If QGenda is able to meet us at these budgetary numbers, I believe I can get this pushed through by the end of this month, otherwise we may need to wait until the next budgeting cycle later in the year.?    RESPONSE to updated quotes: Hi Arvinder,  Thanks for sending these over.  The Overall pricing is the same as the original quotes that NPI reviewed.  However, they have broken out the Hospital staff cost for the extra Time/Compensation module.  Unfortunately, this actually raises additional questions, such as, why is the base scheduling module charged differently between the two groups?  The recurring annual charge for Hospital staff is $252/user/year, but the Float Pool staff recurring annual fees are $240/user/year.   Springfield may want to question this discrepancy as a side-note to the overall negotiation.  Overall, NPI?s feedback is materially the same as below.  We have seen the scheduling module offered at a lower price and we recommend Springfield use the budget and growth leverage mentioned in the write-up below.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s 3-year offer from GitLab and found pricing to be above fair market value (FMV) for the combined spend.  BNYM?s demand is significant, as the vendor does not have an excessive amount of accounts with 10,000 or more users, and especially not many of those under a 3-year commitment.  GitLab has decent margins on this product even if support call volumes are high, and the long-term agreement would see good incentives passed to the sales team.  The vendor appears to be pushing hard for a decision on this agreement before their fiscal quarter end this month, and terms indicate that this includes a full prepayment of the term.  Even with a limited timeline for negotiations, NPI recommends BNYM create doubt in the sales team?s mind that this deal can proceed in its current form.  NPI sees the DevOps market as fiercely competitive at the moment, and if GitLab?s deal team believes the deal?s health is in question, they will bring their case before the executives in the sales organization for consideration.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends focusing messaging on a $4.0M even target presented to GitLab as the level at which BNYM can maintain the current deal timeline.   ?	NPI highly recommends not mentioning specific discount amounts or benchmarking tied to this deal at all, and instead focus GitLab on the larger annual and full-term costs.  If the GitLab sales team hears messaging that requests specific discounts, their internal systems often interpret this as a ?buy? signal and prevent them from authorizing further concessions.  Conversations focused on net and per user costs do not trigger these alerts, and NPI sees a much greater degree of success when that tract is followed without mentioning discount amounts.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: $375k savings reported for 3-year agreement.    BNYM is reviewing a new 3-year agreement for GitLab Premium direct from the vendor.

file_info.name: RE  Intuit Price Benchmarking - Antivirus RFP .msg

deal_metadata.current_narrative: No financials because this was a review of 3-vendors....   Hi Lucy,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.   I can appreciate the urgency and we tried to get you some information as quickly as we can.  We get a number of requests from Intuit and based on NPI?s contract with Intuit, our turnaround times are typically 4 to 5 business days.  We always strive to respond quicker, but 4 to 5 days is where most reviews will end up.  If we get too many urgent requests that jump the line, it can affect the turnaround times on other reviews we are doing for Intuit and other clients.  For future reviews, it would be best to prepare for a 4 - 5 day turnaround time for feedback from NPI.  This is a bit different than the type of reviews NPI typically does.  Intuit is seeking guidance to subscribe to licensing as an MSP or distributor, rather than as the consumer of a product or service themselves. While this is not the 1st time that we have done such a review for Intuit, and specifically for one of these three vendors, Symantec, this is not a type of transaction that we see often.  We have looked at this review in terms of the pure numbers, but the pricing model may be slightly different, so Intuit should keep that in mind as you review the information below.  Almost a year ago, Intuit asked NPI to review a renewal of Quick Online Backup Services. At that time, Intuit was comparing numerous vendors, including Symantec, for the sole purpose of Intuit buying online backup service wholesale from Norton (Symantec) and selling it to users of Intuit Online.   At the time, NPI offered Intuit the following advice, beyond the hard data surrounding market information on storage pricing:     Fast forward to this moment in time and again Norton (Symantec) is in the mix, this time pitted against Bitdefender and McAfee. While Bitdefender has been in business for 15 years, they have not had much success penetrating NPI?s client base and NPI has relatively small data by comparison to our Symantec and McAfee experience.  NPI was a bit surprised by McAfee?s attempt by to bolster their proposal with 5 pages of data that is all immediately accessible on their website:     In fact, the only truly compelling information provided, unless Intuit is strongly considering becoming a reseller or distributor for McAfee, is found on page 7. On page 7, we find the pricing information that shows that the offer from McAfee, based on a one year model represents an 89% discount from their MSRP for a single instance of their software. The 3 year annually paid offer improves this position to 91% off of MSRP and finally the 3 year pre-paid offer is almost 94% off of MSRP.  Comparing these price points from Symantec and McAfee, to those of the MSP model Bitdefender proposal, we find a mixed bag of higher and lower positions, based on time committed to and consumed licenses.  Both the offers from Bitdefender and McAfee appear to be far more competitively priced by comparison to the Symantec offer at a minimum of $13.99 per subscription, however, Symantec already has a presence within Intuit and Intuit?s Quickbook offering and, as such is probably expected to perform more favorably. At an 86% discount from list, Symantec?s discount is aggressive, but if compared to similarly sized transactions from Symantec, it falls a bit short of the 94% best-in-class discounting that NPI has seen in the past. If we take the simplest of views, NPI could apply the 100K licensing model to Symantec?s pricing, and produce a list price of $9.99M and a discounted price of $1.39M, or 86%. The target discount of 94% would result in net price of $600,000 or a reduction of almost $700K and furthermore, would bring the per license costs in-line with the other two provider proposals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Sony?s Netskope proposal and found pricing to be above fair market value (FMV). Cloud access security broker (CASB) solutions are a newer but expanding technology. The major players in the space are entering a growth phase with a focus on maximizing market share. This atmosphere presents opportunities for purchasing teams, as many deals NPI reviews are put on hold while the technology is still being evaluated. The presence of an existing CASB solution at Sony, Cisco?s Cloudlock, means that even though there?s a desire to switch to a new product, Netskope?s team will be wary of the remote possibility that you could stay with Cisco. NPI does see cases where Netskope has the more complete solution and is the technical preference, but Cisco wins the business due to massive price cuts. There have also been cases where Cisco?s status as a major OEM places them as a preapproved vendor, and internal controls have steered clients towards Cloudlock merely because of the much smaller size of Netskope with its less than 450 employees. This is in no way intended to ca doubt on Netskope?s operational capability or product quality (NPI hears Sony?s technical preference for Netskope echoed in many other competitive CASB deals), but it does give insight into issues that the sales teams and resellers encounter. The potential for uncertainty can provide a good deal of leverage to Sony to target further reductions over the 3-year term, or even better pricing around a 1 ? 2-year agreement.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The opportunity to displace Cloudlock makes this a strategic deal for Netskope with a significant brand name.  While there?s already been some reductions in the 3-year deal, FMV net pricing for this would be in the $450,000 - $500,000 range, amounting to a combined user cost of $50 per subscription per year for the term separate support.   NPI sees a wide range of prices offered for this solution, with higher volumes achieving as low as $20 per user per year for Netskope?s entire platform.    NPI sees Netskope restricting the number of sanctioned cloud applications in some proposals, with additional applications adding to per-user costs. This deal?s unlimited allowance for the cloud services Netskope covers has a positive influence on the FMV assessment.   It could take some time to deploy, fully train, and gain full value out of the total 2,700 user subscriptions. To accommodate for a 1 ? 2+ month lead time, Sony could push for a small proration discount in the first year to balance this shelfware risk.   Timing that aligns with vendor/reseller fiscal calendars could help build leverage. With Cloudlock as an existing solution, it would be credible to Optiv and Netskope that this deal could lag into or past December.
deal_metadata.description: Sony has a proposal for Netskope's CASB platform, a potential move away from Cisco's Cloudlock solution.

file_info.name: RE  Feedback   Intuit Price Benchmarking - YotaScale.msg

deal_metadata.current_narrative: As always, thank you for reaching out to NPI concerning the migration from CloudHealth to YotaScale. Apologies for not getting back you yesterday. I hope this information is still useful and relevant.  Unfortunately, for as much information as NPI has about cloud services in general and AWS services and other iAAS providers, we simply don?t have that much data when it comes to YotaScale.  This should not come as a surprise, considering that they have only 24 employees listed on LinkedIn, several of which are board members and advisors, and they have only been in business since 2015. In fact, YotaScale is largely still living on funding, not revenue, and is still largely a fledgling company:   YotaScale, Inc. is a Silicon Valley startup that is defining infrastructure performance management for the cloud. It is funded by Pelion Venture Partners and Engineering Capital.  YotaScale rec?d $3.6M in funding just over one year ago. From a late 2017 Diginomica article, I gleaned the following excerpt:   As public cloud use proliferates and grows more comprehensive among large enterprises, the difficulty of tracking resource usage, spending and performance is an opportunity for software intelligence and automation. Vendors have cost management services like AWS Cost Explorer. However, these can flood users with data and don?t do a solid job of summarizing it by application, project or department, nor do they provide much help in identifying usage anomalies or their cause. These are just the sorts of insights software from YotaScale, a quasi-stealth startup, seeks to provide by applying machine learning to cloud workload and cost analysis as part of what co-founder and CEO Asim Razzaq calls ?AI-enhanced Infrastructure Performance Management.?  One thing that I can tell you is that the Waterfall pricing method that they are offering is likely receiving push back from clients other than Intuit. This idea that your initial investment continues to be penalized borders on the absurd. There is little incentive to grow your consumption (which Intuit certainly will) under this model. Intuit should push back and either invite YotaScale to lower the cost per EC2 instance to the $1/per offered in the 40K tier, or to change the terms such that when Intuit reaches the next volume tier all of the consumption is repriced to the next tier up.   Intuit does not often prepay for services, but in this particular case, given the commitment of less than $0.5M/year, and the ability to offset the cost of this service, if Intuit offered the cash hungry YotaScale a 3-year prepayment, you could likely push the offer from 15% to 20% and then gain an add?l 5-10% as a referenceable account.  Has Intuit conducted a POC with YotaScale, and if so, NPI assumes it was successful?  In closing, if Intuit is committed to the start-up tech that YotaScale offers, offering a 3-year deal at $1M may carry a lot of weight to company that is certainly hungry for a notable win.

deal_metadata.description: I?m looking for a price benchmark for the enclosed proposal.  We currently use CloudHealth and the annual cost is about $200k, including support.  The team is currently doing an evaluation of Yotascale and is interested in using them because of their anomaly detection feature.  If we could get something back by Tuesday, it would be greatly appreciated.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Chris, NPI has completed our review.  We?ve seen quite a bit of Nutanix of late. We?ve seen some clear discount ranges across hardware, software and support and have seen them flex within that range depending on all the usual purchase factors (i.e., leverage with budget, timing, competition).  Springfield?s quote has a list price of just over $1M and a net offer of $587K.  Our line item breakdown by spend category is as follows: ?	Hardware ? line item discount is 40.5%.  Comprising about 70% of the quote.  NPIs FMV discount range is 40-60% so they?re right at the bottom of our range.  The mid to high 50s is probably more in line with a bit bigger purchases so we believe 50% is the right target. ?	Support is discounted 21%.  This is a typical discount.  A second way NPI views this is the support cost per node.  If you take the support costs and divide it by the license quantity of each piece of hardware you arrive at ~$11,800 for both the 8235s and 8135.  NPIs target is $10K for this as $12K is the upper part of our FMV range. ?	Licenses often come with sizable discounts.  Both licenses have a line item discount of 47.3%.  On sizable purchases above $2M list we?ve seen discounts approach 80%.  For this size purchase NPIs FMV range is 50-65%.  We?ve established a 60% target based on the net license spend totaling under $100K. ?	Services are rarely discounted and NPI doesn?t see much opportunity there. ?	NPI re-ran the numbers using 50% for HW, 60% for SW and Support at $10K/mode (attached file) o	Our target total calculates to $536K o	Springfield?s line item offer is $639K which would be a $103K further reduction BUT?. o	There?s also a $52K one-time discount which cuts that in half; therefore, o	NPIs adjusted savings target is another $51K.  The attached Excel file reflects the offer and NPIs FMV targets.  It is set up to print to one page.
deal_metadata.description: Attached is the Nutanix quote based on our discussion yesterday. This include basic rack/stack and configuration services, but no data migration or integration work into your current environment. We are finishing up the data migration Statement of Work and will have that over to you ASAP.   One thing we would like to note on this quote is that Nutanix has different support levels than the EMC levels you?re accustomed to. The support level quoted is 24x7 support with Next Business Day hardware replacement, which we see most of our customer select. Nutanix does offer a level with 4 hour part replacement at an additional cost if you feel that is necessary.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Jim, Here?s our thinking. This required more creative analysis mixed with some benchmarking.  In sum, I don?t think this pricing is good enough considering your expansion.  When checking our data it was clear that basically all of our prior Flexera reviews were for perpetual license deals.  We had some data points on 2012 list pricing and 2014 list pricing.  Neither price list had a Suite price but there were some interesting learnings that may apply.  ?	In the perpetual license reviews the total quantity always applied to FlexNet Manager Platform.  The total for all the ?connector? licenses e.g., for Servicenow, or for Adobe would then sum to that same Platform count.  While I?m not sure how this works in the Cloud it would lead me to conclude MetLife really has 62,500 platform (or suite) licenses and you can use them for 62,500 various connectors and you don?t have 62,500 connectors to Adobe and 62,500 connectors to Microsoft.  Is that the case and how you interpret that?  ?	While there?s clearly value in having the flexibility of the Suite which is noted in this attached article - http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/flexera-software-enhances-flexnet-manager-suite-on-demand-providing-broadest-software-1875394.htm this was a key observation as NPI did some creative analysis ?	Flexera doesn?t publish a list price but NPI has two sets of price lists.  One from a detailed GSA document in 2012 and some abbreviated pricing from a client?s 2014 offer.  One key observation was it appeared that Flexera had some HUGE price increases between 2012 and 2014.  NPI decided to use our view of 2014 list pricing to analyze your current pricing.  This fits because you executed your current deal around that time. ?	To note again, we don?t have Cloud list pricing now or from 2014.  Flexera has a number of tiers based on volume for all the perpetual licenses. o	There?s a number of ways to cut it but from a perpetual license POV for these volumes I estimate the list price for the Platform and one connector (of which you have 62,500) is $18.50.  o	At these volumes we?d expect a discount near 40% for a net price of around $11.   o	There?s likely five ways to think about how you can compare a perpetual license cost to a Cloud option.  For example with Splunk if a perpetual license costs $100, then a term license is 40% of that or $40 and a Cloud license is 1.33 times that or about $53.  So the Cloud works out to 50% of the perpetual cost.  The inflection point is often at 2.5-3.5 years where the TCOs intersect.  Perpetual will have annual support as well. o	To simplify, if the net target for the perpetual license is $11 then if that?s 2.5 the cost of a Cloud option the target would be $4.50.   o	MetLife?s current contract works out to $11.80. That?s the $2.95M all-in total which is $737.5K a year divided by 62,500. o	If you allow for a bit lower discounts since Cloud usually experiences that vs. perpetual, and if I round up wherever I could in my analysis then maybe I end up at $7-8. ?	In sum, I don?t have a perfect benchmark for the cost of Cloud FlexNet Manager Suite at your volumes but using the data at hand and analyzing a perpetual license purchase and using a reasonable conversion approach I conclude there?s a good amount of room to improve this price as you seek a global footprint. ?	Consider asking them for a quote with list pricing for both perpetual and Cloud.  Let them know you are aware there are significant reductions to list price based on tiers and review those.   In perpetual license model the tiers at the high end have been 50000-74999; 75000-99999; 100000-149999; 150000-199999; 200000-249999 and they keep going.  Sometime we don?t see tiers with Cloud but if you surface your knowledge of tiers with perpetual licenses then you can raise the expectation that as Cloud tiers increase the price should go down.  In the high volumes each tier has a 3-8% drop in the respective list price.  Can talk you through this more but this should get the general message across.    Jim shared this vendor message: Jim,  Spoke to my management team.  Went through the normal questions around why the contractually agreed upon rate wasn?t good for this final year add-on.  What I can offer amounts to 9% additional discount for the 15k endpoints with a confirmation it will close by EOY.  Budgetary Estimate:  Contractually ? 15k endpoints for one year at $11.80 or $177,700 Concession for EOY - 15k endpoints for one year at $10.74 or $161,100  Know this is not what you were looking for yet what I could get approved.  and then Jim said: "FYI.. don?t think I will be able to further reduce the fees."

I learned during my last Flexera review that they?ve got 2-3 different product lines.  One is Corporate Software Inspector.  Not much data there. Then there?s the traditional software asset mgt stuff.  I bet that?s what this is.  Can you share the last purchase/contract that shows all the descriptions and details? I know it feels like a real straightforward request but we?re a bit busy (including a few in process reviews for MetLife + today?s QBR) and with Flexera we always have to warm our brains back up since we don?t see them that much (but we definitely have a number of data points). deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s 3-year offer from GitLab and found pricing to be above fair market value (FMV) for the combined spend.  BNYM?s demand is significant, as the vendor does not have an excessive amount of accounts with 10,000 or more users, and especially not many of those under a 3-year commitment.  GitLab has decent margins on this product even if support call volumes are high, and the long-term agreement would see good incentives passed to the sales team.  The vendor appears to be pushing hard for a decision on this agreement before their fiscal quarter end this month, and terms indicate that this includes a full prepayment of the term.  Even with a limited timeline for negotiations, NPI recommends BNYM create doubt in the sales team?s mind that this deal can proceed in its current form.  NPI sees the DevOps market as fiercely competitive at the moment, and if GitLab?s deal team believes the deal?s health is in question, they will bring their case before the executives in the sales organization for consideration.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: No financials because this was a review of 3-vendors....   Hi Lucy,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.   I can appreciate the urgency and we tried to get you some information as quickly as we can.  We get a number of requests from Intuit and based on NPI?s contract with Intuit, our turnaround times are typically 4 to 5 business days.  We always strive to respond quicker, but 4 to 5 days is where most reviews will end up.  If we get too many urgent requests that jump the line, it can affect the turnaround times on other reviews we are doing for Intuit and other clients.  For future reviews, it would be best to prepare for a 4 - 5 day turnaround time for feedback from NPI.  This is a bit different than the type of reviews NPI typically does.  Intuit is seeking guidance to subscribe to licensing as an MSP or distributor, rather than as the consumer of a product or service themselves. While this is not the 1st time that we have done such a review for Intuit, and specifically for one of these three vendors, Symantec, this is not a type of transaction that we see often.  We have looked at this review in terms of the pure numbers, but the pricing model may be slightly different, so Intuit should keep that in mind as you review the information below.  Almost a year ago, Intuit asked NPI to review a renewal of Quick Online Backup Services. At that time, Intuit was comparing numerous vendors, including Symantec, for the sole purpose of Intuit buying online backup service wholesale from Norton (Symantec) and selling it to users of Intuit Online.   At the time, NPI offered Intuit the following advice, beyond the hard data surrounding market information on storage pricing:     Fast forward to this moment in time and again Norton (Symantec) is in the mix, this time pitted against Bitdefender and McAfee. While Bitdefender has been in business for 15 years, they have not had much success penetrating NPI?s client base and NPI has relatively small data by comparison to our Symantec and McAfee experience.  NPI was a bit surprised by McAfee?s attempt by to bolster their proposal with 5 pages of data that is all immediately accessible on their website:     In fact, the only truly compelling information provided, unless Intuit is strongly considering becoming a reseller or distributor for McAfee, is found on page 7. On page 7, we find the pricing information that shows that the offer from McAfee, based on a one year model represents an 89% discount from their MSRP for a single instance of their software. The 3 year annually paid offer improves this position to 91% off of MSRP and finally the 3 year pre-paid offer is almost 94% off of MSRP.  Comparing these price points from Symantec and McAfee, to those of the MSP model Bitdefender proposal, we find a mixed bag of higher and lower positions, based on time committed to and consumed licenses.  Both the offers from Bitdefender and McAfee appear to be far more competitively priced by comparison to the Symantec offer at a minimum of $13.99 per subscription, however, Symantec already has a presence within Intuit and Intuit?s Quickbook offering and, as such is probably expected to perform more favorably. At an 86% discount from list, Symantec?s discount is aggressive, but if compared to similarly sized transactions from Symantec, it falls a bit short of the 94% best-in-class discounting that NPI has seen in the past. If we take the simplest of views, NPI could apply the 100K licensing model to Symantec?s pricing, and produce a list price of $9.99M and a discounted price of $1.39M, or 86%. The target discount of 94% would result in net price of $600,000 or a reduction of almost $700K and furthermore, would bring the per license costs in-line with the other two provider proposals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pricing Analysis ?	NPI combined both proposals to provide a consolidated view of the Brocade hardware renewal.    SEE FMV for details.  The NPI analysis of the Brocade proposals finds the various discounting on the models to be unusual for a Brocade renewal.   The majority of the HW in this renewal is less than 5 years old as stated by Morgan Stanley.  As HW increases in age, hardware manufacturers will often begin a steady increase in maintenance costs to ?encourage? a hardware refresh.    Data shows the typical 5% Y/Y increase on many of the items yet tied to the unusual discounting, NPI is also seeing some unusual increases and decreases (which appear to be tied to a reduction in support levels). It makes for a lot of moving parts year over year.  NPI calculated a blended discount rate of 30.9% and finds discount to be below our FMV range.  NPI will often see discounts in the 40% - 45% range for renewals near the $1M range.  NPI does not see any particular rationale as to why discounting should vary between hardware models and recommends a FMV target of a straight 47% on all SKUs.  In this exercise, NPI actually reduced discounts on some SKUs (that NPI believed to be unusually high) to the same 47%.  Achieving this target will result in a savings of $180K.  The FMV target of 47% on all renewal SKUs would be considered ?best-in-classs? pricing.  NPI is targeting this level of pricing because of the potential sales opportunities that MS is considering in the near future.  Premier Onsite Support Engineer (OSE) is currently discounted at 33%.  NPI targets $192,000 or a 40% discount as FMV.  This FMV target will land the OSE at $96/hr.   Achieving this target will result in $24,000 in additional savings.  Targets and negotiation bullets in FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Got this from MS in Aug 2018: On the distributed side we did not meet NPI?s 47% target. We landed at 36% on the hw and 33% on the OSE.  Brocade was not flexible on this.
deal_metadata.description: Ok ? this deal is twofold but Tom and I will negotiate w/ Brocade by treating the spend holistically.    Tom?s side (First Quote):  Brocade DCX Director out of warranty support devices are entering 5th year of service ? we are receiving a 37% discount from list. Does this seem too low and normally what do you see?  Christina?s side (Second Quote): Includes all of our kit for distributed systems.  Anything highlighted in Orange is Next Day Onsite as this kit is located in our labs.  All other line items are Premier support. I inserted columns Q-T as part of my own analysis but that should provide insight for you too.  We have potential new spend of up to $1.5M between now and Q2 (~ $600K now, and $600K in each Q1 and Q2), though we run this through a reseller.    We are looking for a % discount off list for each item ? e.g. X% off List for DCX Director, X% off List for 6510?s.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: See email attached for cleaner view of feedback:  Hi Johan,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of Checkmarx deals, in fact, we?ve seen a few from Intuit, so we know that Intuit has spent a few million dollars with Checkmarx over the past couple of years.  In our write-up below, you will see that NPI believes this pricing is ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) based on a) projected usage and, b) Intuit?s overall spend with Checkmarx over the past 12 ? 24 months.  It is difficult to benchmark this Codebashing quote because all of Codebashing?s developer modules are available to every developer, so the true market value will depend heavily on the actual consumption of training modules.  ? The proposal from Checkmarx?s Codebashing is offering 4,500 users access to all lessons and languages for a discounted price of $133/user/year.  Currently, Codebashing offers a total of 164 modules over 9 different languages (as per their website), effectively placing the annual cost per module at $0.81/user/year. o While pricing at $0.81/user/year is certainly considered FMV, NPI recommends an internal review as to the realistic expectations of actual consumption.   ? On average, there are ~22 courses for each of the 9 programming languages.   ? If developers focus their coding to a smaller subset of the offered programming languages, will the developers complete the training modules for languages they do not focus on?  Is the realistic consumption of the modules at 100%, 80%, 20%?  Actual consumption will potentially drive cost/user significantly higher (and likely above FMV). o Due to our believe that actual consumption will be significantly lower than 100%, NPI considers the pricing in this quote to be ABOVE (FMV). ? NPI suggests the creation of a matrix, similar to the sample below, be used as a negotiating data point as to why Intuit pricing overall needs to be further reduced.  The two primary variables that will need to be researched by Intuit are the developer #s and estimated use by each developer.  SAMPLE Projection of Value           Language # of Courses Developer #s List Price/Module List Per Language Price Est. Use Adj. List Price Java 22 3500 $ 2.13  $ 164,010  40% $65,604  .net 22 1000 $ 2.13  $ 46,860  40% $18,744  php 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  node.js 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Ruby on Rails 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Python 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  C++ 16 1000 $ 2.13  $ 34,080  40% $13,632  Android 8 1200 $ 2.13  $ 20,448  40% $8,179  iOS 8 1400 $ 2.13  $ 23,856  40% $9,542  Total 164   $ 804,714   $321,886         ? Once Intuit has calculated the Adjusted List Price, remember it is just that? LIST price, and a nominal 15% - 25% reduction should still be applied to that adjusted LIST price. ? NPI expects that there will be a number of developers that are well-versed in multiple languages.  We recommend that Intuit recognize that developer ?burn-out? is likely if they are asked to review modules from multiple categories.  This argument can be used to defend the lower estimated use figure. ? Checkmarx will typically offer deeper discounts to get the total contract pricing closer to the projected pricing that reflects Intuit?s calculations.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Continued from deal: 36602, several related docs in that deal.  Feedback was high-level.. didn't really recommend savings:  Thanks for letting NPI review this and provide feedback.  Overall, NPI considers the pricing on these NEW devices to be within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  We recommend that Springfield should consider refurbished equipment because it would be priced significantly lower and in this market, refurbished equipment often comes with the same warranties, etc.  Attached is a spreadsheet comparing 2 quotes for 2 different sites from 2 vendors, Consolidated and ConvergeOne. It appears both represent upgrades to R7.x CM's, with multiple Gateway sites remote to each Core.  Consolidated has 10, Springfield has 8.  Both sites are adding 600 9608 sets to each location, several port cards for end users and T'1's. It appears that the Springfield site had a co-term support contract quote for SA, while the Mattoon site has a 3 year annual SA UA quote.  We attempted to line up like for like material codes, or similar codes based on the target support outcome, so when you look at SS you will see side by side. We ignored a few small items like cables etc.  Additional Notes: 1.	There are minor price differences between the vendors, however, if the intent is to choose one vendor for both sites, we recommend that Springfield get quotes for each site from both vendors, including installation, support, upgrade protection. 2.	Springfield will want to require the same Project manager for both sites, and if appropriate an SPOC on the client end. Really a pain to deal with different PM's, waste a lot of time reviewing. 3.	Require a test plan for failover testing out of hours for GW site 4.	Verify VMware software compatibility with the Avaya load, should have been tested; so trust but verify. 5.	Ask for references for similar upgrades, paying particular attention to the Gateway sites. Not a recommendation, I know from personal experience C1 has a track record for this kind of upgrade. 6.	It was mentioned that Springfield intends to have a spare 8300 processor to use as you upgrade the individual sites....that works very well, saves a lot of time and hassle. 7.	On both designs , Springfield should look at refurbished pricing for the MM circuit cards. Quote totals are about $7700 for the 5 cards. We believe these can get the total below $4000 refurbished cards are available.  C1 will offer a one year warranty. On the phone sets it looks like C1 is offering a 3 year warranty on the 9608's. As you can see from the totals, there is very little difference in pricing.  C1 install costs are higher, but other costs offset the difference, however, support costs are only 8 months, while the Consolidated quote represents annual costs for 12 months. On Avaya proposals, TCO is greatly affected by support and upgrade costs, so this would give the slightest edge to the Consolidated pricing.

As this project was a "QSE Event" no savings calculations will be measured.  2/9/18 - no additional communications from Paola.  2/2/18 - Paola intends to finalize agreements by end of day today.  We have not seen any updates from MSFT but have offered help.  1/26/18 - no update from Flowserve.  Will cancel Monday meeting at end of day on 1/26 if we have not heard from them.   1/19/18 - no update since last week - will cancel meeting on 1/22 - works well as Cindy will be traveling and unavailable at meeting time.  1/12/18 - met with client on 1/9/18 and provided feedback for next steps - 2 prong approach with both account team as well as escalation to Microsoft Regional VP. 1/4/18 - received MSFT quote from client and held call with Paola and Earl.  Provided assessment of SCE and EAS CPS.   These were only docs provided.   Client has undergone numerous reiterations and communications w/MSFT without NPI involvement per their request to structure the project to best suit their needs vs. NPI methodology.  12/29/17 - reached out to client on 12/28, no response yet. Sent email to check in with client on 12/21.  12/8/17 - awaiting quotes from MSFT and scaling back discovery at client's request.   12/1/17 - Flowserve has delayed their request to MSFT to provide updated quotes.  We have requested that they please move forward in at least requesting from LAR.  Awaiting these and MLS as well. Held an initial discovery meeting with 4 product areas/topics that require follow up.  11/22/17 - primary contact has returned but was unable to meet with NPI week of 11/20.  Cindy sent details on specifics that we need to discuss and request for Flowserve to sent quotes and MLS as soon as they are available.  Reminded client to please folllow up with MSFT and Software One to get these ASAP. 11/17/17 -primary contact out through 11/20.  Met with Gabriel from IT to discuss E4 plans and cloud vs. on-prem.  Need additional interviews scheduled to keep project on track. Quote due back on 11/17.  11/10/17 - kick off call held 11/7 and project plan meeting on 11/8.  We made our way through a good list of action items but more to go and key contact Jennifer is now out until 11/20,  Shooting for a few interviews the week of 11/13.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Jim, Here?s our thinking. This required more creative analysis mixed with some benchmarking.  In sum, I don?t think this pricing is good enough considering your expansion.  When checking our data it was clear that basically all of our prior Flexera reviews were for perpetual license deals.  We had some data points on 2012 list pricing and 2014 list pricing.  Neither price list had a Suite price but there were some interesting learnings that may apply.  ?	In the perpetual license reviews the total quantity always applied to FlexNet Manager Platform.  The total for all the ?connector? licenses e.g., for Servicenow, or for Adobe would then sum to that same Platform count.  While I?m not sure how this works in the Cloud it would lead me to conclude MetLife really has 62,500 platform (or suite) licenses and you can use them for 62,500 various connectors and you don?t have 62,500 connectors to Adobe and 62,500 connectors to Microsoft.  Is that the case and how you interpret that?  ?	While there?s clearly value in having the flexibility of the Suite which is noted in this attached article - http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/flexera-software-enhances-flexnet-manager-suite-on-demand-providing-broadest-software-1875394.htm this was a key observation as NPI did some creative analysis ?	Flexera doesn?t publish a list price but NPI has two sets of price lists.  One from a detailed GSA document in 2012 and some abbreviated pricing from a client?s 2014 offer.  One key observation was it appeared that Flexera had some HUGE price increases between 2012 and 2014.  NPI decided to use our view of 2014 list pricing to analyze your current pricing.  This fits because you executed your current deal around that time. ?	To note again, we don?t have Cloud list pricing now or from 2014.  Flexera has a number of tiers based on volume for all the perpetual licenses. o	There?s a number of ways to cut it but from a perpetual license POV for these volumes I estimate the list price for the Platform and one connector (of which you have 62,500) is $18.50.  o	At these volumes we?d expect a discount near 40% for a net price of around $11.   o	There?s likely five ways to think about how you can compare a perpetual license cost to a Cloud option.  For example with Splunk if a perpetual license costs $100, then a term license is 40% of that or $40 and a Cloud license is 1.33 times that or about $53.  So the Cloud works out to 50% of the perpetual cost.  The inflection point is often at 2.5-3.5 years where the TCOs intersect.  Perpetual will have annual support as well. o	To simplify, if the net target for the perpetual license is $11 then if that?s 2.5 the cost of a Cloud option the target would be $4.50.   o	MetLife?s current contract works out to $11.80. That?s the $2.95M all-in total which is $737.5K a year divided by 62,500. o	If you allow for a bit lower discounts since Cloud usually experiences that vs. perpetual, and if I round up wherever I could in my analysis then maybe I end up at $7-8. ?	In sum, I don?t have a perfect benchmark for the cost of Cloud FlexNet Manager Suite at your volumes but using the data at hand and analyzing a perpetual license purchase and using a reasonable conversion approach I conclude there?s a good amount of room to improve this price as you seek a global footprint. ?	Consider asking them for a quote with list pricing for both perpetual and Cloud.  Let them know you are aware there are significant reductions to list price based on tiers and review those.   In perpetual license model the tiers at the high end have been 50000-74999; 75000-99999; 100000-149999; 150000-199999; 200000-249999 and they keep going.  Sometime we don?t see tiers with Cloud but if you surface your knowledge of tiers with perpetual licenses then you can raise the expectation that as Cloud tiers increase the price should go down.  In the high volumes each tier has a 3-8% drop in the respective list price.  Can talk you through this more but this should get the general message across. What I can offer amounts to 9% additional discount for the 15k endpoints with a confirmation it will close by EOY.  Budgetary Estimate:  Contractually ? 15k endpoints for one year at $11.80 or $177,700 Concession for EOY - 15k endpoints for one year at $10.74 or $161,100  Know this is not what you were looking for yet what I could get approved.  and then Jim said: "FYI.. don?t think I will be able to further reduce the fees."

At the time, NPI offered Intuit the following advice, beyond the hard data surrounding market information on storage pricing:     Fast forward to this moment in time and again Norton (Symantec) is in the mix, this time pitted against Bitdefender and McAfee. While Bitdefender has been in business for 15 years, they have not had much success penetrating NPI?s client base and NPI has relatively small data by comparison to our Symantec and McAfee experience.  NPI was a bit surprised by McAfee?s attempt by to bolster their proposal with 5 pages of data that is all immediately accessible on their website:     In fact, the only truly compelling information provided, unless Intuit is strongly considering becoming a reseller or distributor for McAfee, is found on page 7. On page 7, we find the pricing information that shows that the offer from McAfee, based on a one year model represents an 89% discount from their MSRP for a single instance of their software. The 3 year annually paid offer improves this position to 91% off of MSRP and finally the 3 year pre-paid offer is almost 94% off of MSRP.  Comparing these price points from Symantec and McAfee, to those of the MSP model Bitdefender proposal, we find a mixed bag of higher and lower positions, based on time committed to and consumed licenses.  Both the offers from Bitdefender and McAfee appear to be far more competitively priced by comparison to the Symantec offer at a minimum of $13.99 per subscription, however, Symantec already has a presence within Intuit and Intuit?s Quickbook offering and, as such is probably expected to perform more favorably. At an 86% discount from list, Symantec?s discount is aggressive, but if compared to similarly sized transactions from Symantec, it falls a bit short of the 94% best-in-class discounting that NPI has seen in the past. If we take the simplest of views, NPI could apply the 100K licensing model to Symantec?s pricing, and produce a list price of $9.99M and a discounted price of $1.39M, or 86%. The target discount of 94% would result in net price of $600,000 or a reduction of almost $700K and furthermore, would bring the per license costs in-line with the other two provider proposals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: See email attached for cleaner view of feedback:  Hi Johan,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of Checkmarx deals, in fact, we?ve seen a few from Intuit, so we know that Intuit has spent a few million dollars with Checkmarx over the past couple of years.  In our write-up below, you will see that NPI believes this pricing is ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) based on a) projected usage and, b) Intuit?s overall spend with Checkmarx over the past 12 ? 24 months.  It is difficult to benchmark this Codebashing quote because all of Codebashing?s developer modules are available to every developer, so the true market value will depend heavily on the actual consumption of training modules.  ? The proposal from Checkmarx?s Codebashing is offering 4,500 users access to all lessons and languages for a discounted price of $133/user/year.  Currently, Codebashing offers a total of 164 modules over 9 different languages (as per their website), effectively placing the annual cost per module at $0.81/user/year. o While pricing at $0.81/user/year is certainly considered FMV, NPI recommends an internal review as to the realistic expectations of actual consumption.   ? On average, there are ~22 courses for each of the 9 programming languages.   ? If developers focus their coding to a smaller subset of the offered programming languages, will the developers complete the training modules for languages they do not focus on?  Is the realistic consumption of the modules at 100%, 80%, 20%?  Actual consumption will potentially drive cost/user significantly higher (and likely above FMV). o Due to our believe that actual consumption will be significantly lower than 100%, NPI considers the pricing in this quote to be ABOVE (FMV). ? NPI suggests the creation of a matrix, similar to the sample below, be used as a negotiating data point as to why Intuit pricing overall needs to be further reduced.  The two primary variables that will need to be researched by Intuit are the developer #s and estimated use by each developer.  SAMPLE Projection of Value           Language # of Courses Developer #s List Price/Module List Per Language Price Est. Use Adj. List Price Java 22 3500 $ 2.13  $ 164,010  40% $65,604  .net 22 1000 $ 2.13  $ 46,860  40% $18,744  php 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  node.js 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Ruby on Rails 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Python 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  C++ 16 1000 $ 2.13  $ 34,080  40% $13,632  Android 8 1200 $ 2.13  $ 20,448  40% $8,179  iOS 8 1400 $ 2.13  $ 23,856  40% $9,542  Total 164   $ 804,714   $321,886         ? Once Intuit has calculated the Adjusted List Price, remember it is just that? LIST price, and a nominal 15% - 25% reduction should still be applied to that adjusted LIST price. ? NPI expects that there will be a number of developers that are well-versed in multiple languages.  We recommend that Intuit recognize that developer ?burn-out? is likely if they are asked to review modules from multiple categories.  This argument can be used to defend the lower estimated use figure. ? Checkmarx will typically offer deeper discounts to get the total contract pricing closer to the projected pricing that reflects Intuit?s calculations.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Continued from deal: 36602, several related docs in that deal.  Feedback was high-level.. didn't really recommend savings:  Thanks for letting NPI review this and provide feedback.  Overall, NPI considers the pricing on these NEW devices to be within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  We recommend that Springfield should consider refurbished equipment because it would be priced significantly lower and in this market, refurbished equipment often comes with the same warranties, etc.  Attached is a spreadsheet comparing 2 quotes for 2 different sites from 2 vendors, Consolidated and ConvergeOne. It appears both represent upgrades to R7.x CM's, with multiple Gateway sites remote to each Core.  Consolidated has 10, Springfield has 8.  Both sites are adding 600 9608 sets to each location, several port cards for end users and T'1's. It appears that the Springfield site had a co-term support contract quote for SA, while the Mattoon site has a 3 year annual SA UA quote.  We attempted to line up like for like material codes, or similar codes based on the target support outcome, so when you look at SS you will see side by side. We ignored a few small items like cables etc.  Additional Notes: 1.	There are minor price differences between the vendors, however, if the intent is to choose one vendor for both sites, we recommend that Springfield get quotes for each site from both vendors, including installation, support, upgrade protection. 2.	Springfield will want to require the same Project manager for both sites, and if appropriate an SPOC on the client end. Really a pain to deal with different PM's, waste a lot of time reviewing. 3.	Require a test plan for failover testing out of hours for GW site 4.	Verify VMware software compatibility with the Avaya load, should have been tested; so trust but verify. 5.	Ask for references for similar upgrades, paying particular attention to the Gateway sites. Not a recommendation, I know from personal experience C1 has a track record for this kind of upgrade. 6.	It was mentioned that Springfield intends to have a spare 8300 processor to use as you upgrade the individual sites....that works very well, saves a lot of time and hassle. 7.	On both designs , Springfield should look at refurbished pricing for the MM circuit cards. Quote totals are about $7700 for the 5 cards. We believe these can get the total below $4000 refurbished cards are available.  C1 will offer a one year warranty. On the phone sets it looks like C1 is offering a 3 year warranty on the 9608's. As you can see from the totals, there is very little difference in pricing.  C1 install costs are higher, but other costs offset the difference, however, support costs are only 8 months, while the Consolidated quote represents annual costs for 12 months. On Avaya proposals, TCO is greatly affected by support and upgrade costs, so this would give the slightest edge to the Consolidated pricing.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: We reviewed the NS1 (Managed DNS) proposal from Intuit and here is our feedback: ?	Managed DNS providers offer similar services, yet offerings are all slightly different and the structural buildout of Intuit?s infrastructure may typically overcome any shortcomings (if any) from the various providers. ?	NPI performed a high-level review of how NS1 compares in key measurement metrics for a DNS Managed Services provider at www.dnsperf.com and finds no problematic issues of concern.  NPI recommends that Intuit periodically review measurement sites to ensure company performance is functioning at expectations. ?	NS1 offering allows for 10B queries / month for $17,500/year or $1,458/mo.  At this price point, the cost/M querries is $0.14583.  NPI finds this pricing to be at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	NSONE or NS1 is a provider of intelligent DNS and traffic management services. The company is headquartered in New York, and has offices in San Francisco and in Singapore. Founded in 2013 by a team with first-hand experience in building content delivery networks (CDNs), infrastructure APIs and cloud platforms, NSONE came about to enable and improve present day?s dynamic infrastructures. ?	NS1 leverages infrastructure, network and real time user data to allow customers on their platform to create customized routing setups for a wide variety of applications. They offer data driven traffic management, managed DNS and dedicated DNS. Their product Pulsar is designed for real-time performance-based traffic routing, and offers fully automated traffic management functionality that can be used in a multi-CDN solution. ?	NPI?s enterprise clients will typically have two DNS providers to ensure a high availability network design.  And the previously reviewed Verisign analysis for Intuit in December 2016 is in line with this dual vendor strategy for Managed DNS services.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Jive Software renewal and move to Cloud
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Clarification email back and her answers:  Hi Meaghan, Sorry for my delayed response.  My key Jive analyst has been out this week and it took me a little effort to think about my reply.  This may be a tough one to review but let?s dig in a bit first.  When you say Jive 8 that tells me you?re one version behind the latest Jive 9 release.  That?s not uncommon for clients with perpetual licenses especially if you have a number of customizations that can be tough to upgrade.  That leads to several questions that I?ll note below.  I understand Intel can?t share your vendor contracts but the general understanding is you?d make a best effort at still providing enough detail on your commercial arrangement to allow NPI to provide a benchmark.  Our focus is generally around evaluating actual offered pricing and less around trying to come up with an expected scenario for a price.  Sometimes this is because vendors don?t publish a list price (that?s the case with Jive) or there?s so many feature and ways Jive can package up their offering that NPI can?t accurately perform that task but our database is set up to analyze an actual offer.  Here's some questions that will allow NPI to determine if we can provide a benchmark. ?	What Product(s) from Jive are you using?  They?ve changed names quite a bit and now call their Internal Collaboration product Jive-n and their external one Jive-x for customers and partners.  o	I believe Jive-n now has Select, Premier and Premier + plans.  We are using Jive-n and have a Platinum plan o	Jive-x has Basic and Advanced Packages  o	NPI would need to know this granular detail about your products. ?	While they often say the number of licensed users is UNLIMITED in reality there?s typically an Authorized number of users.  Please share that for each product. Unlimited, truly ?	What?s the current run rate for each product?  I?m assuming you bought perpetual licenses and your recurring expense is Software Support.  Please confirm.  Knowing the original license price can also be helpful because with any upgrade it?s not just about the benchmark as there?s the art of the deal and how are they compensating you (if at all) for past license purchases. We renew annually for the license and support is included ?	How long have you had each Product?  5 years ?	Are you considering a 3 year term in the Cloud? We would like to have a 1 yr agreement, potential for more if a large enough discount ?	Why are you changing?  This adds a dynamic to your pricing as you convert.  For example, is Intel?s board forcing a switch to the cloud across the enterprise?  Is there a defined business criteria?  Is Jive forcing this?  The reasons can determine leverage points and expected pricing flexibility.  If it is being forced upon Intel then it really is all about price.  If it is to obtain different features or not continue to battle keeping customizations when you upgrade then there?s more about payback and value.  Intel has an overall move to cloud strategy.  We would also like the new features that come with the cloud version with minimal internal IT support ?	Is this a like for like move? Yes, would expect the same services/support after the move ?	What are Intel?s Use Cases for either/or the Internal or External products?  What sort of communities do you have set up? We have 3 major classes of communities: Existing organizational units, Project teams, & Social interaction communities ?	What are the cost elements offered for the transition? Services? New SaaS cost?  You should expect to pay more for SaaS than you have been for ongoing software support renewals.  Better services, less internal cost to Intel to maintain/update servers  I know this is a number of items but in the absence of seeing actually contracts this is the information required to make an NPI benchmark possible and worthwhile to Intel.  Felt had enough to say to agree to FMV.

And can you tell me how many data points you have for a purchase similar to ours?

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pricing Analysis ?	NPI combined both proposals to provide a consolidated view of the Brocade hardware renewal.    SEE FMV for details.  The NPI analysis of the Brocade proposals finds the various discounting on the models to be unusual for a Brocade renewal.   The majority of the HW in this renewal is less than 5 years old as stated by Morgan Stanley.  As HW increases in age, hardware manufacturers will often begin a steady increase in maintenance costs to ?encourage? a hardware refresh.    Data shows the typical 5% Y/Y increase on many of the items yet tied to the unusual discounting, NPI is also seeing some unusual increases and decreases (which appear to be tied to a reduction in support levels). It makes for a lot of moving parts year over year.  NPI calculated a blended discount rate of 30.9% and finds discount to be below our FMV range.  NPI will often see discounts in the 40% - 45% range for renewals near the $1M range.  NPI does not see any particular rationale as to why discounting should vary between hardware models and recommends a FMV target of a straight 47% on all SKUs.  In this exercise, NPI actually reduced discounts on some SKUs (that NPI believed to be unusually high) to the same 47%.  Achieving this target will result in a savings of $180K.  The FMV target of 47% on all renewal SKUs would be considered ?best-in-classs? pricing.  NPI is targeting this level of pricing because of the potential sales opportunities that MS is considering in the near future.  Premier Onsite Support Engineer (OSE) is currently discounted at 33%.  NPI targets $192,000 or a 40% discount as FMV.  This FMV target will land the OSE at $96/hr.   Achieving this target will result in $24,000 in additional savings.  Targets and negotiation bullets in FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Got this from MS in Aug 2018: On the distributed side we did not meet NPI?s 47% target. We landed at 36% on the hw and 33% on the OSE.  Brocade was not flexible on this.
deal_metadata.description: Ok ? this deal is twofold but Tom and I will negotiate w/ Brocade by treating the spend holistically.    Tom?s side (First Quote):  Brocade DCX Director out of warranty support devices are entering 5th year of service ? we are receiving a 37% discount from list. Does this seem too low and normally what do you see?  Christina?s side (Second Quote): Includes all of our kit for distributed systems.  Anything highlighted in Orange is Next Day Onsite as this kit is located in our labs.  All other line items are Premier support. I inserted columns Q-T as part of my own analysis but that should provide insight for you too.  We have potential new spend of up to $1.5M between now and Q2 (~ $600K now, and $600K in each Q1 and Q2), though we run this through a reseller.    We are looking for a % discount off list for each item ? e.g. X% off List for DCX Director, X% off List for 6510?s.

file_info.name: SOW - Main Site 600 migration from NT - SO-000303457 - dm10-5.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Continued from deal: 36602, several related docs in that deal.  Feedback was high-level.. didn't really recommend savings:  Thanks for letting NPI review this and provide feedback.  Overall, NPI considers the pricing on these NEW devices to be within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  We recommend that Springfield should consider refurbished equipment because it would be priced significantly lower and in this market, refurbished equipment often comes with the same warranties, etc.  Attached is a spreadsheet comparing 2 quotes for 2 different sites from 2 vendors, Consolidated and ConvergeOne. It appears both represent upgrades to R7.x CM's, with multiple Gateway sites remote to each Core.  Consolidated has 10, Springfield has 8.  Both sites are adding 600 9608 sets to each location, several port cards for end users and T'1's. It appears that the Springfield site had a co-term support contract quote for SA, while the Mattoon site has a 3 year annual SA UA quote.  We attempted to line up like for like material codes, or similar codes based on the target support outcome, so when you look at SS you will see side by side. We ignored a few small items like cables etc.  Additional Notes: 1.	There are minor price differences between the vendors, however, if the intent is to choose one vendor for both sites, we recommend that Springfield get quotes for each site from both vendors, including installation, support, upgrade protection. 2.	Springfield will want to require the same Project manager for both sites, and if appropriate an SPOC on the client end. Really a pain to deal with different PM's, waste a lot of time reviewing. 3.	Require a test plan for failover testing out of hours for GW site 4.	Verify VMware software compatibility with the Avaya load, should have been tested; so trust but verify. 5.	Ask for references for similar upgrades, paying particular attention to the Gateway sites. Not a recommendation, I know from personal experience C1 has a track record for this kind of upgrade. 6.	It was mentioned that Springfield intends to have a spare 8300 processor to use as you upgrade the individual sites....that works very well, saves a lot of time and hassle. 7.	On both designs , Springfield should look at refurbished pricing for the MM circuit cards. Quote totals are about $7700 for the 5 cards. We believe these can get the total below $4000 refurbished cards are available.  C1 will offer a one year warranty. On the phone sets it looks like C1 is offering a 3 year warranty on the 9608's. As you can see from the totals, there is very little difference in pricing.  C1 install costs are higher, but other costs offset the difference, however, support costs are only 8 months, while the Consolidated quote represents annual costs for 12 months. On Avaya proposals, TCO is greatly affected by support and upgrade costs, so this would give the slightest edge to the Consolidated pricing.

deal_metadata.description: Msft EA Renewal, part of subscription.  We spent near a year working on Discovery, with many options and and a lot of planning.  We even uncovered numerous non-compliant situations and provided specific advice on how to rectify.  The customer was very interested in O365 as a potential option, but getting the right discount and pricing was very important.  Of course, they were very concerned with security as well, but once they got past that concern it was a solid decision to move forward with an O365 option.  Unfortunately Grace was waiting in the wings to take over and pull NPI out for the final rounds.  She was frustrated with MSFT's resistance to her strategy, but her boss ended up coming back to us, along with John Ngyuen, and seeking our advice and benchmarking for the final rounds.  Ultimately they got a good deal, it could have been better if they would have followed our advice, but as we found out, Grace wanted to discontinue our relationship and even went as far as to say that they know as much as NPI and don't need any of our benchmarking any longer.  Also that they are premier negotiators now.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Slalom rates for Phase 2 of the SQL Server Consolidation and TED Migration
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI believes there is room for improvement of about 16% in the SOW price as shown in the table below. NPI has seen Trinity being overcharged by Slalom for a SharePoint architect as well when we reviewed another SOW, and this trend follows into the SQL server consolidation SOW.  The barrier to achieving savings here is that this is phase 2 so Trinity does not have much leverage to lower rates since it is a continuation of the migration and Trinity will want to retain the same resources.  Trinity?s strategy here may be to ask for a volume discount based on increasing spend with Slalom.
