deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Kronos and found the pricing for the core SaaS bundle to be above Fair Market Value (FMV) with room for improvement of up to 24% based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the other add-on software subscriptions are at FMV.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions. ?	The core SaaS bundle is priced at $2.74 per employee, per month (PEPM). The list pricing for this bundle is $7 PEPM, which is an increase from the previous list price of $5 PEPM.  o	For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $1.82 PEPM. This translates to savings of $13,800 per month. ?	The Workforce Activities software is priced at $0.45 PEPM. This price is at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	The Workforce Accruals software is priced at $0.26, which is also at FMV. ?	 The Workforce Record Manager is priced at $0.15. For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $0.11 PEPM. This translates to savings of $600 per month. ?	WF Analytics is priced at $0.86 PEPM. This price is FMV. ?	The overall savings based on NPI?s recommended target price translates to $14,400 per month and $358,560 for the 36-month period with a 24-month ramp up.  Other considerations: ?	NPI has not seen Kronos insist on prepayment for the subscriptions. This is certainly negotiable. ?	However, NPI has also not seen Kronos concede to a ramp up pricing, which reduces the revenue in years 1 and 2.  o	Most SaaS vendors prefer an even annual or front-loaded pricing/revenue model and a 3-5 year commitment.  A ramp up licensing scenario inevitably results in higher pricing per license for the customer and higher TCO over 5 years. However, if a customer has strong leverage (for example, if the customer already has perpetual licenses and does not need the licenses since they don?t require upgrades, and therefore would not be likely to make the purchase at all, or if there is competition in the mix), the vendor will concede to these terms. ?	A target of $2 per employee per month for Time and Accruals for 15,000 employees is achievable. The motivation by Kronos to provide a larger incentive for a large employee base is in line with their marketing approach, which highly touts the number of users/employees that use or are managed through KRONOS cloud. ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially on the add-on subscriptions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: They only went with Timekeeping, Accruals and Activities, so reflected that in the Financial Summary
deal_metadata.description: Flowserve is looking to purchase various Kronos SaaS subscriptions. they are looking at an 18 -24 month ramp-up.   don?t want to do any pre-payments to Kronos as is recommended in the Kronos pricing model. Our preference is to do a 20% tiered pricing model. The final cost that Doug wants to pay is $2.00 per employee per month for Time and Accruals. The final cost for activities (SFDC) is $0.40 per employee per month.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: See email attached for cleaner view of feedback:  Hi Johan,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of Checkmarx deals, in fact, we?ve seen a few from Intuit, so we know that Intuit has spent a few million dollars with Checkmarx over the past couple of years.  In our write-up below, you will see that NPI believes this pricing is ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) based on a) projected usage and, b) Intuit?s overall spend with Checkmarx over the past 12 ? 24 months.  It is difficult to benchmark this Codebashing quote because all of Codebashing?s developer modules are available to every developer, so the true market value will depend heavily on the actual consumption of training modules.  ? The proposal from Checkmarx?s Codebashing is offering 4,500 users access to all lessons and languages for a discounted price of $133/user/year.  Currently, Codebashing offers a total of 164 modules over 9 different languages (as per their website), effectively placing the annual cost per module at $0.81/user/year. o While pricing at $0.81/user/year is certainly considered FMV, NPI recommends an internal review as to the realistic expectations of actual consumption.   ? On average, there are ~22 courses for each of the 9 programming languages.   ? If developers focus their coding to a smaller subset of the offered programming languages, will the developers complete the training modules for languages they do not focus on?  Is the realistic consumption of the modules at 100%, 80%, 20%?  Actual consumption will potentially drive cost/user significantly higher (and likely above FMV). o Due to our believe that actual consumption will be significantly lower than 100%, NPI considers the pricing in this quote to be ABOVE (FMV). ? NPI suggests the creation of a matrix, similar to the sample below, be used as a negotiating data point as to why Intuit pricing overall needs to be further reduced.  The two primary variables that will need to be researched by Intuit are the developer #s and estimated use by each developer.  SAMPLE Projection of Value           Language # of Courses Developer #s List Price/Module List Per Language Price Est. Use Adj. List Price Java 22 3500 $ 2.13  $ 164,010  40% $65,604  .net 22 1000 $ 2.13  $ 46,860  40% $18,744  php 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  node.js 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Ruby on Rails 22 2500 $ 2.13  $ 117,150  40% $46,860  Python 22 3000 $ 2.13  $ 140,580  40% $56,232  C++ 16 1000 $ 2.13  $ 34,080  40% $13,632  Android 8 1200 $ 2.13  $ 20,448  40% $8,179  iOS 8 1400 $ 2.13  $ 23,856  40% $9,542  Total 164   $ 804,714   $321,886         ? Once Intuit has calculated the Adjusted List Price, remember it is just that? LIST price, and a nominal 15% - 25% reduction should still be applied to that adjusted LIST price. ? NPI expects that there will be a number of developers that are well-versed in multiple languages.  We recommend that Intuit recognize that developer ?burn-out? is likely if they are asked to review modules from multiple categories.  This argument can be used to defend the lower estimated use figure. ? Checkmarx will typically offer deeper discounts to get the total contract pricing closer to the projected pricing that reflects Intuit?s calculations.

It's also possible that they are getting a new account team - this is just speculation, but we can use this to help negotiation as well.  Client wants info on deployment of SQL subscriptions on SCE as potential licensing model for Performacare.  Cindy following up and initially believes this should be similar to EAS licensing and capable of on-prem deployment.  Client sent Citrix question to Josh on RDS - Cindy/Joshua to review.  7/21/17 - client has requested specific SQL modeling for an affiliate that was "missed" at last true up.  Wants all options - SQL is covered product family in SCE.   We review SCE including subscription.  7/14/17 - had status meeting on 7/13/17.  Client wants further analysis of options to license SQL cores on a majority owned affiliate, PerformCare  that hasn't been covered in SCE previously..  Client requested as is quotes from MSFT and is looking into MSDN oversubcriptions. Client will also be sending details on licensing requirements for virtualized apps on Large Citrix implementation. 7/7/17 - sent ghostwritten message to client for request of as-is quotes.   6/30 - Discovery meeting attended by John, Stephen and Anthony, which was a lighter audience than expected, but had very good dialogue and ran way over time. 6/23 - Confusion around the Discovery meeting, slated for next week now, however still awaiting final server information. 6/16: discovery mtg 6/29 - awaiting details fro client so we can perform calcs and analysis. 6/01/17 - Completed interviews and received final documents.  Still need final server numbers for Windows/Systems Center for Discovery Report and initial 'As Is' estimate and working to schedule Discovery meeting. 5/12/2017 - Same as last week, no material progress as of yet. 5/5/2017 - Had bi-weekly call and discussed project timeline, questionnaire deadline and next steps. deal_metadata.customer_comments: Subsequent overage
deal_metadata.description: Msft EA Renewal, part of subscription.  We spent near a year working on Discovery, with many options and and a lot of planning.  We even uncovered numerous non-compliant situations and provided specific advice on how to rectify.  The customer was very interested in O365 as a potential option, but getting the right discount and pricing was very important.  Of course, they were very concerned with security as well, but once they got past that concern it was a solid decision to move forward with an O365 option.  Unfortunately Grace was waiting in the wings to take over and pull NPI out for the final rounds.  She was frustrated with MSFT's resistance to her strategy, but her boss ended up coming back to us, along with John Ngyuen, and seeking our advice and benchmarking for the final rounds.  Ultimately they got a good deal, it could have been better if they would have followed our advice, but as we found out, Grace wanted to discontinue our relationship and even went as far as to say that they know as much as NPI and don't need any of our benchmarking any longer.  Also that they are premier negotiators now.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Slalom rates for Phase 2 of the SQL Server Consolidation and TED Migration
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI believes there is room for improvement of about 16% in the SOW price as shown in the table below. NPI has seen Trinity being overcharged by Slalom for a SharePoint architect as well when we reviewed another SOW, and this trend follows into the SQL server consolidation SOW.  The barrier to achieving savings here is that this is phase 2 so Trinity does not have much leverage to lower rates since it is a continuation of the migration and Trinity will want to retain the same resources.  Trinity?s strategy here may be to ask for a volume discount based on increasing spend with Slalom.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Client chose to move to Qualtrics as a solution.  Did not renew.  There's at leas 1 xActly quote in here as well.

Progressive is accustomed to receiving best-in-class pricing for Dell EMC products and this proposal falls slightly short, despite including some considerable concessions. However, the discounts provided by EMC are still higher than the majority of EMC purchases that NPI reviews, and attaining further discounts will require careful negotiation.   Pricing Analysis NPI?s analysis incorporates 15 separate proposals. The methodology for this analysis categorizes each proposed line item into a specific EMC product ?family? (Centera, Data Domain, VxRack, etc.) and category (HW, SW, PS, Maint.), as discounting levels between different storage families and categories vary within the Dell EMC environment.  Because NPI data revolves around EMC product families and  because the fair discount ranges for each of these families varies, the analysis discusses discounts by family and category and concludes with target recommendations per each individual quote.  CENTERA ?	Centera spend is 3% of the overall proposal spend, which is in line with industry observations of decreasing spend on this product family. o	NPI continues to see clients migrating from this platform to more current offerings from EMC and/or other vendors. ?	The current proposal is discounted at 68% off list price for HW. NPI finds this pricing to be at FMV with room for improvement.  A discount target of 72% off list pricing would place Progressive in the best-in-class range.   Achieving this target will result in a savings of $16,342. ?	NPI has seen some instances where it was difficult for clients to migrate from this platform.  Some migrations have been complex, and when issues arise, there are few Centera ?experts? remaining on the Dell EMC team to resolve problems. ?	NPI has observed ?creative? pricing solutions where clients can achieve extremely deep discounts when bundling a planned migration/retirement of the Centera platform to a newer EMC offering.  These types of ?solutions? allow for a win-win scenario where the client can upgrade the platform, EMC can migrate off an older platform which is increasingly more difficult to support, and the sales team can deepen the EMC relationship with new products.  NPI recommends a careful ROI analysis on any new solutions proposed.  DATA DOMAIN ?	EMC currently offers a 64% discount off list for both HW and Maintenance on the Data Domain (DD) family of products.  NPI finds this to be a low discount that places pricing above FMV. ?	The prior Data Domain purchase had a discount of 69% on a net price of $83K.  Current net pricing of $611K has a smaller, 64% discount off list.   ?	A target of 69% to match prior discounting levels for this family of product will result in a savings of $89K.  ELASTIC CLOUD STORAGE (ECS) ?	EMC offers discounts of 34.2% on their Elastic Cloud Storage (ECS) product.  NPI finds this discount level to be too low, and pricing therefore too high given the deep relationship that Progressive has with EMC.   ?	This appears to be the initial entry point for this product family, which focuses on Software Defined Storage (SDS) for a turnkey, hyperscale storage infrastructure.  The current buy represents 14%, or $700K, of the current spend and spend in this family will likely grow in the future. ?	NPI has seen discounts at the 40% level for a handful of clients.  As the Progressive relationship and spend continues to grow, NPI would expect nothing less than a discount of 40% in this area.  Achieving the 40% discount target will establish a solid discounting framework from which to baseline future purchases and will also result in savings of $62K on this purchase.  VBLOCK / VxBLOCK ?	VBlock spend in this proposal appears to be maintenance-related spend of $230K that is not discounted. ?	NPI finds that EMC maintenance spend is rarely discounted and pre-defined by EMC at the time of purchase (as it is based on the purchase price). ?	NPI finds pricing to be within FMV for this renewal. VMAX ?	NPI routinely observes Core VMAX purchases reach the high 70% and even low 80% discount ranges depending on size of purchase.  ?	VMAX is one of two ?flagship products for EMC that they built from the ground up, but the platform has existed for some time and EMC?s margins have steadily grown.  ?	NPI assumes that Progressive was able to reach (and exceed) the prior discount target of 80%, as prior discounting for Progressive was at 68% in December 2016.  Achieving that prior target of 80% would have yielded savings of $1.175M. ?	Progressive is currently at 81% and NPI is confident that the current discounting for this family is at best-in-class pricing.   ?	EMC traditionally applies discounts for all portions of software, hardware, and support at the same discount levels.  NPI typically finds elevated discounts in all areas Professional Services. ?	EMC Professional Services are custom and customer-specific; engagement prices are priced by teams per business units. There is also little to no continuity across business units.  NPI rarely sees pricing concessions in this area.    Hardware Support and Warranty Upgrade OPTIONS:  ?	While it is widely distributed and acknowledged that VMAX hardware comes with 3 years of support at the time of purchase, this support is Basic Support, or 24/7 remote support, with NBD delivery of replacements.  ?	Of course, there is an upgraded level of support or Premium Support and, depending on the size of the purchase, this ?upgrade support? will either carry the same level of discounting as the hardware that it is providing coverage for or include it entirely.  o	The little-known or unknown side of support is that the 4th year can be included at the basic level for ?free? and at the same discount level for upgrade support, with no penalty or commission knock to the EMC Enterprise AM or Sales Team selling it.  VRACK / VxRACK ?	Progressive had originally submitted two quote proposals to NPI for review.  Proposal P1112366 contained 2 sections, Prod and Non-Prod. Environments.  These two proposals were subsequently withdrawn. ?	Although quote 6001450691 may need to be removed from this analysis, the PS figures associated with this quote are still included in this report.  As all VxRack charges are specifically broken into categorical spend, it will be relatively simple to remove the PS amount of $751,273 if necessary.  XTREMIO ?	XtremIO is offered at a 64% discount for the majority of HW SKUs in this family.  Support is also offered at 64% off list pricing. This discount is too low and places pricing above FMV. NPI recommends a target discount of 72% to bring these items within FMV. o	A single SKU that stands out in the XtremIO analysis is the InfiniBand Switch.  This switch was only discounted at 48.7%.  NPI believes this hardware should be discounted to the same discount rate as all other XtremIO HW. ?	NPI has recently seen smaller deals achieve the 69% discount target at the $200K price point.  NPI believes that the significant spend with EMC should warrant best-in-class pricing and discounting for this product family. ?	As previously noted for the two maturing family lines above, the all-flash, high IO product offering by EMC is seen as a technology class that will continue to grow within the Progressive environment. Therefore, we strongly recommend that Progressive establish a solid discounting baseline for this product.  Achieving the targeted discount of 72% will result in savings of $230K. Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	It is NPI?s understanding that Progressive ?isn?t looking for ?deeper? discounting, but rather...for discounting that appreciates the deepening relationship that [they] have with EMC.? ?	NPI recommends that Progressive stress that, as the EMC / Progressive relationship continues to strengthen and grow, Progressive would like to see the same discounting as previously offered by EMC.   ?	Overall, targeted discounts are based on best-in-class pricing that Progressive has previously witnessed in prior purchases.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Karen,  I have four sets of quotes that I need NPI to review for November deals. Let me know if you need additional information or if you would like me to contact Greg directly on these.   These sets are all EMC deals for storage  and virtual computing infrastructure.   Project 1 ? HCI infrastructure for DSE project  Project 2 ? vBlock Lease Extension for Prod and Non-prod racks  Project 3 ? Centera Evaluation Units purchase  Project 4 ? Q4 Storage Purchase (multi-platform)    Hi Chris, We?ve got a lot going on and I just was able to take a first pass.  ?	The first two files are VCE quotes with the same look and feel and list prices includes.  Reviewing won?t be a problem.  ?	The third and fourth files are one line item quotes in a standard EMC file format.  Not big dollars but no list price and a generic SKU.  These can?t be benchmarked in this format.  Do they relate to the VCE quotes? ?	The fifth file is another EMC quote.  No list prices but not a lot of items and we can fill in the blanks. ?	The sixth file is the biggest dollar quote.  No list prices and many worksheets.  I think it makes the most sense to ask EMC to revise with list prices. There?s even a column for it that they left blank. On prior NPI reviews for Progressive for EMC they furnished it.  This is the most efficient and accurate way to proceed.  Can you request that?  Can you share any info on timeline and context?  We reviewed another sizable purchase in December.  Would be interesting to understand how this relates to that purchase.   Try these quotes. The timeframe for these transactions are all in the next three weeks. The context is: the storage transactions are mostly to replace end of life units for the big storage quote, additional emergency capacity for the Centera storage, lease extension on the vblock units, and a new development/ production environment for the Prod/Non-Prod racks.    OUTCOME EMAIL (NO DOCS): EMC tends to bundle product and services with the greater discounts coming on services and associated software, at least for Progressive. On the vxblock / vxRail deal there was no appreciable additional discount received for this deal. We did receive services discounts in the amount of $125k tied to this purchase. On the storage deal (XtemeIO, Vmax, Data Domain, Centera) we received a total of $549k in software discounts and software substitution rights on a total spend of $3.027M for this purchase.   As we look toward renegotiating our current ELA with Dell EMC we will be seeking more favorable discounts rates across the board for HW, SW, and Services for the next term. We are clear that we left money on the table in the prior contract.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: See attached email for cleaner view of feedback.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: NOTE: Scott provided final disposition in an email... they renewed 8000 users for $500K... "This deal was very atypical.  We had an alternative to OEL available to us that we estimated would cost us $500k for licenses and labor to switch.  We gave Oracle the option to match the price."  Not sure of what size the original ULA was based on... closing without completing financials and with status="Unknown Outcome"
deal_metadata.description: Can you let me know how this pricing looks for the Linux Premier Support?  Both are for unlimited usage but they are based on an estimate of servers we are using.  I haven?t nailed down the count of servers the original was based on, it was either 2000, 3000, or 6000,  The current quote is based on 8400.  We renewed the VM Premier support last year on a 1 year deal but the count was reduced from 385 to 325.  The cost for 1 year was $144k.

Client is engaging internal counsel on language - this is a must for this deal to close.  Otherwise we will push for "AS IS".   12/29/17 - status call with client 12/29.   Awaiting MSFT decision on downgrade amendment.  BATNA is As-Is.  12/22/17 - client's MDO is M365E3 - working on getting SCE and EA to 3.3m per year.  Still need downgrade language .  Will elect full M365 E3 full USL for contractors.  12/8/17 -started more frequent  coaching sessions with client to discuss upcoming negotiations. Still need VS information.  11/2/17 - client meeting with MSFT week of 11/6 and reviewing ME3/E5 and OE3/E5 solutions.  Still need Visual Studio details and another meeting to review Windows Server proc to core transition.  10/26/17 - Windows server details received on 10/25 and additional O365 meeting to be held afternoon of 10/26,  10/20/17 - onsite today for initial F&R.  10/13/17 - client has been sent MA but not agreed to it yet.  Plan to send 2 MPSA models to client to see options vs. renewing EA.  On site F&R scheduled on 10/20.  10/5/17 -call to discuss SAM was held on 10/5/17 and at client's request, status meeting to happen 10/6/17. Dino wanted NPI to perform SAM on MAP data (said it's 35 spreadsheets with 10s of 1000s or rows of raw data, there has been no hygeine on data, no correct allocation or assignment of licenses and no capturing of inactive users/devices).  Net is that this client doesn't think they will have numbers for us within the project term. Windows Server information provided 9/20.  We are also working to set the baseline for MA.  8/31/17 - customer has new info on Citrix/RDS.  Working on new user counts/devices.   8/25/18 - client received MSFT quote on 8/24 - we are in process of reviewing. XtremIO is offered at a 64% discount for the majority of HW SKUs in this family.  Support is also offered at 64% off list pricing. This discount is too low and places pricing above FMV. NPI recommends a target discount of 72% to bring these items within FMV. o	A single SKU that stands out in the XtremIO analysis is the InfiniBand Switch.  This switch was only discounted at 48.7%.  NPI believes this hardware should be discounted to the same discount rate as all other XtremIO HW. ?	NPI has recently seen smaller deals achieve the 69% discount target at the $200K price point.  NPI believes that the significant spend with EMC should warrant best-in-class pricing and discounting for this product family. ?	As previously noted for the two maturing family lines above, the all-flash, high IO product offering by EMC is seen as a technology class that will continue to grow within the Progressive environment. Therefore, we strongly recommend that Progressive establish a solid discounting baseline for this product.  Achieving the targeted discount of 72% will result in savings of $230K. Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	It is NPI?s understanding that Progressive ?isn?t looking for ?deeper? discounting, but rather...for discounting that appreciates the deepening relationship that [they] have with EMC.? ?	NPI recommends that Progressive stress that, as the EMC / Progressive relationship continues to strengthen and grow, Progressive would like to see the same discounting as previously offered by EMC.   ?	Overall, targeted discounts are based on best-in-class pricing that Progressive has previously witnessed in prior purchases.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Karen,  I have four sets of quotes that I need NPI to review for November deals. Let me know if you need additional information or if you would like me to contact Greg directly on these.   These sets are all EMC deals for storage  and virtual computing infrastructure.   Project 1 ? HCI infrastructure for DSE project  Project 2 ? vBlock Lease Extension for Prod and Non-prod racks  Project 3 ? Centera Evaluation Units purchase  Project 4 ? Q4 Storage Purchase (multi-platform)    Hi Chris, We?ve got a lot going on and I just was able to take a first pass.  ?	The first two files are VCE quotes with the same look and feel and list prices includes.  Reviewing won?t be a problem.  ?	The third and fourth files are one line item quotes in a standard EMC file format.  Not big dollars but no list price and a generic SKU.  These can?t be benchmarked in this format.  Do they relate to the VCE quotes? ?	The fifth file is another EMC quote.  No list prices but not a lot of items and we can fill in the blanks. ?	The sixth file is the biggest dollar quote.  No list prices and many worksheets.  I think it makes the most sense to ask EMC to revise with list prices. There?s even a column for it that they left blank. On prior NPI reviews for Progressive for EMC they furnished it.  This is the most efficient and accurate way to proceed.  Can you request that?  Can you share any info on timeline and context?  We reviewed another sizable purchase in December.  Would be interesting to understand how this relates to that purchase.   Try these quotes. The timeframe for these transactions are all in the next three weeks. The context is: the storage transactions are mostly to replace end of life units for the big storage quote, additional emergency capacity for the Centera storage, lease extension on the vblock units, and a new development/ production environment for the Prod/Non-Prod racks.    OUTCOME EMAIL (NO DOCS): EMC tends to bundle product and services with the greater discounts coming on services and associated software, at least for Progressive. On the vxblock / vxRail deal there was no appreciable additional discount received for this deal. We did receive services discounts in the amount of $125k tied to this purchase. On the storage deal (XtemeIO, Vmax, Data Domain, Centera) we received a total of $549k in software discounts and software substitution rights on a total spend of $3.027M for this purchase.   As we look toward renegotiating our current ELA with Dell EMC we will be seeking more favorable discounts rates across the board for HW, SW, and Services for the next term. We are clear that we left money on the table in the prior contract.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: 4/12: Final MA sent yesterday. 4/06: Completing final MA today. 3/9/18 - client to send final docs for MA.   2/23/18 - client got average of 16% off  M365 E3 and 20% off SCE.  Paperwork in finalized state.  2/16/18 - call with Grace, John, Chad to discuss MSFT's unwillingness to provide deal discount to true up table and future pricing.  NPI advice to hold firm, fall back to as -is if needed.  2/9/18- CTM received with custom language that allows downgrades of older versions for Office and specifically says customer will not deploy click to run.   Client received updated CPSs 2/8/18 and called to review.  We've returned calls and sent advice via email but have not heard from them as of the end of the day 2/8/18. 2/2/18 - client is receiving updated paperwork and language today/tomorrow.  They will let us know if they need anything else.  1/26/18 - AmierHealth legal is still awaiting response from MSFT legal regarding downgrade language.  1/19/18 - no update this week.  1/12/18 - sent email to client to advise that we make it clear to MSFT that delay in getting deal completed is due to MSFT's silence on request for final docs.   (language amendment and final CPS) 1/4/18 - client (Grace) called today to update NPI.  AmeriHealth trued up all call center employees and is going with MSFT Option 2 (one profile M365 E3 from SA).  Client is engaging internal counsel on language - this is a must for this deal to close.  Otherwise we will push for "AS IS".   12/29/17 - status call with client 12/29.   Awaiting MSFT decision on downgrade amendment.  BATNA is As-Is.  12/22/17 - client's MDO is M365E3 - working on getting SCE and EA to 3.3m per year.  Still need downgrade language .  Will elect full M365 E3 full USL for contractors.  12/8/17 -started more frequent  coaching sessions with client to discuss upcoming negotiations.  Client has 3 quotes - 0% as is, 7% M365 E3 and 14%-31% on M365E5.   12/1/17 - updated quotes due today.   Client is making nice progress on product decisions/reductions/migrations to EA from Select Plus.  John Nguygen agreed to talk to Chad Goodwin re: MA.  11/22/17 - checked in with client to get updated quotes from MSFT.  Client postponed meeting with them until we have these docs.  Meeting scheduled on 11/30 to discuss Server model change and proc to core results.  11/17/17 - Met with client to review project, plan, discuss MDO and request to MSFT for updated quotes and to review negotiation tactics for meeting with MSFT next week.  M365E3 is desired solution! Quote promised from MSFT today.  11/10/17 - met with client this week to discuss request for quotes and true up.   Client is making good progress on technical decisions although have not shared their ultimate MDO with us yet.   We are getting closer.  Still need VS information.  11/2/17 - client meeting with MSFT week of 11/6 and reviewing ME3/E5 and OE3/E5 solutions.  Still need Visual Studio details and another meeting to review Windows Server proc to core transition.  10/26/17 - Windows server details received on 10/25 and additional O365 meeting to be held afternoon of 10/26,  10/20/17 - onsite today for initial F&R.  10/13/17 - client has been sent MA but not agreed to it yet.  Plan to send 2 MPSA models to client to see options vs. renewing EA.  On site F&R scheduled on 10/20.  10/5/17 -call to discuss SAM was held on 10/5/17 and at client's request, status meeting to happen 10/6/17.  No new updates on counts or profiles, MDO, LAA, BATNA.  9/29/17 - client has new consultant on status calls, Dino, who formerly worked for them in IT and knows the rounds on MSFT.  Dino wanted NPI to perform SAM on MAP data (said it's 35 spreadsheets with 10s of 1000s or rows of raw data, there has been no hygeine on data, no correct allocation or assignment of licenses and no capturing of inactive users/devices).  Net is that this client doesn't think they will have numbers for us within the project term. Once dates provided by client, Cindy/Joshua to determine best time to go in person to "work through" F&R together with client.  9/21/17 - customer is working to finalize counts.  Windows Server information provided 9/20.  We are also working to set the baseline for MA.  8/31/17 - customer has new info on Citrix/RDS.  Working on new user counts/devices.   8/25/18 - client received MSFT quote on 8/24 - we are in process of reviewing.  Part 3 of infrastructure meeting on 8/28.  8/18/17 - held part one of infrastructure call this week, part 2 on Monday 8/21.  Wrote ghost written letter requesting quote from MSFT. 8/10/17 - new quotes received since last week.  Review of these is in process.  NPI setting up meeting with IT mgr responsible for Citrix to review environment and ensure licensing is correct.  SHI sent 3 year EA quotes vs. annual pricing and at LEVEL A!  Still need to talk through their basket of goods so we can  model out their most desired outcome.  8/4/17 - Joshua sent RDS/Citrix details to John/Stephen.  We are still awaiting quote - will follow up today if still no word.  7/28/17 - client received completely incorrect quote from SHI .  LSP quoted Select Plus. We will develop an MA. 3 years remaining.  Cindy advised going back and requesting correction as line items referenced "select plus".  AmeriHealth found out from LSP that they no longer qualifyt for Level D pricing as MSFT will no longer allow their inclusion in the "association".  Need to understand this - likely the shake up of the healthcare vertical with MSFT internally is causing this.  It's also possible that they are getting a new account team - this is just speculation, but we can use this to help negotiation as well.  Client wants info on deployment of SQL subscriptions on SCE as potential licensing model for Performacare.  Cindy following up and initially believes this should be similar to EAS licensing and capable of on-prem deployment.  Client sent Citrix question to Josh on RDS - Cindy/Joshua to review.  7/21/17 - client has requested specific SQL modeling for an affiliate that was "missed" at last true up.  Wants all options - SQL is covered product family in SCE.   We review SCE including subscription.  7/14/17 - had status meeting on 7/13/17.  Client wants further analysis of options to license SQL cores on a majority owned affiliate, PerformCare  that hasn't been covered in SCE previously..  Client requested as is quotes from MSFT and is looking into MSDN oversubcriptions. Client will also be sending details on licensing requirements for virtualized apps on Large Citrix implementation. 7/7/17 - sent ghostwritten message to client for request of as-is quotes.   6/30 - Discovery meeting attended by John, Stephen and Anthony, which was a lighter audience than expected, but had very good dialogue and ran way over time. 6/23 - Confusion around the Discovery meeting, slated for next week now, however still awaiting final server information. 6/16: discovery mtg 6/29 - awaiting details fro client so we can perform calcs and analysis. 6/01/17 - Completed interviews and received final documents.  Still need final server numbers for Windows/Systems Center for Discovery Report and initial 'As Is' estimate and working to schedule Discovery meeting. 5/12/2017 - Same as last week, no material progress as of yet. 5/5/2017 - Had bi-weekly call and discussed project timeline, questionnaire deadline and next steps.  Also lots of Q&A and coaching on preparation. 4/28:  Client happy. Meeting was a waste.  Really wanted a meet and greet with the team.  Better to have tied it to a deliverable event.  4/21:  On-site on Tuesday for strategy discussion and planning the approach to MSFT.  4/7:  Surprised that their executive was trying to close 9 mos. before expiration.  Trying to delay on-site so not to disrupt other deals. 3/31:  Held kickoff.  Good start, especially with John Ng.  3/24:  Kickoff next week.  3/17/2017 - Official kickoff being scheduled for next week or the week after. 3/10/2017 - No major update to report, working on kickoff date once John is back. 3/3/17 - Drafted project plan for John Nguyen, hoping to have kickoff next week or week after.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Subsequent overage
deal_metadata.description: Msft EA Renewal, part of subscription.  We spent near a year working on Discovery, with many options and and a lot of planning.  We even uncovered numerous non-compliant situations and provided specific advice on how to rectify.  The customer was very interested in O365 as a potential option, but getting the right discount and pricing was very important.  Of course, they were very concerned with security as well, but once they got past that concern it was a solid decision to move forward with an O365 option.  Unfortunately Grace was waiting in the wings to take over and pull NPI out for the final rounds.  She was frustrated with MSFT's resistance to her strategy, but her boss ended up coming back to us, along with John Ngyuen, and seeking our advice and benchmarking for the final rounds.  Ultimately they got a good deal, it could have been better if they would have followed our advice, but as we found out, Grace wanted to discontinue our relationship and even went as far as to say that they know as much as NPI and don't need any of our benchmarking any longer.  Also that they are premier negotiators now.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAS expansion purchase in support of client front end to Ignite
deal_metadata.current_narrative: SAS came in with high costs. a bit better terms if they prepay for 10 clients.  Seems odd for Equifax to be taking on risk since they're bringing customers to SAS.  Found a SME. His data indicated (through a buddy) that the core items were actually being offered above list.  Wild card is ELA seems to lock in a 66% discount on future purchases during ELA term. Final ELA was at 80%+ as well. See attached email with feedback and Steve's reply about progress to date.  Response when I sent feedback: Thank you, this is insightful and scary.. Charles and I will review, while we are waiting on a response from SAS on MLA discount terms we believe we have locked in as we discussed. SAS promised yesterday, Bob Mann reached out again this morning, still nothing.   Lastly, I reached out to BU with EM questions, and he is traveling and did not have access to some data in order to answer. Expecting a response there as well. I?m pretty comfortable it?s for 16 core, but not sure if it?s per client..
deal_metadata.description: Steve called back in to help.  2016 ELA included free proof of concept.  Prospects interested in Equifax's Ignite product could play with the data and use SAS front end for now charge.  If they want to buy ignite they are likely to want to buy SAS as well.  Equifax is negotiating the cost for reselling SAS front end.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pricing Analysis ?	NPI combined both proposals to provide a consolidated view of the Brocade hardware renewal.    SEE FMV for details.  The NPI analysis of the Brocade proposals finds the various discounting on the models to be unusual for a Brocade renewal.   The majority of the HW in this renewal is less than 5 years old as stated by Morgan Stanley.  As HW increases in age, hardware manufacturers will often begin a steady increase in maintenance costs to ?encourage? a hardware refresh.    Data shows the typical 5% Y/Y increase on many of the items yet tied to the unusual discounting, NPI is also seeing some unusual increases and decreases (which appear to be tied to a reduction in support levels). It makes for a lot of moving parts year over year.  NPI calculated a blended discount rate of 30.9% and finds discount to be below our FMV range.  NPI will often see discounts in the 40% - 45% range for renewals near the $1M range.  NPI does not see any particular rationale as to why discounting should vary between hardware models and recommends a FMV target of a straight 47% on all SKUs.  In this exercise, NPI actually reduced discounts on some SKUs (that NPI believed to be unusually high) to the same 47%.  Achieving this target will result in a savings of $180K.  The FMV target of 47% on all renewal SKUs would be considered ?best-in-classs? pricing.  NPI is targeting this level of pricing because of the potential sales opportunities that MS is considering in the near future.  Premier Onsite Support Engineer (OSE) is currently discounted at 33%.  NPI targets $192,000 or a 40% discount as FMV.  This FMV target will land the OSE at $96/hr.   Achieving this target will result in $24,000 in additional savings.  Targets and negotiation bullets in FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Got this from MS in Aug 2018: On the distributed side we did not meet NPI?s 47% target. We landed at 36% on the hw and 33% on the OSE.  Brocade was not flexible on this.
deal_metadata.description: Ok ? this deal is twofold but Tom and I will negotiate w/ Brocade by treating the spend holistically.    Tom?s side (First Quote):  Brocade DCX Director out of warranty support devices are entering 5th year of service ? we are receiving a 37% discount from list. Does this seem too low and normally what do you see?  Christina?s side (Second Quote): Includes all of our kit for distributed systems.  Anything highlighted in Orange is Next Day Onsite as this kit is located in our labs.  All other line items are Premier support. I inserted columns Q-T as part of my own analysis but that should provide insight for you too.  We have potential new spend of up to $1.5M between now and Q2 (~ $600K now, and $600K in each Q1 and Q2), though we run this through a reseller.    We are looking for a % discount off list for each item ? e.g. X% off List for DCX Director, X% off List for 6510?s.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Client chose to move to Qualtrics as a solution.  Did not renew.  There's at leas 1 xActly quote in here as well.

file_info.name: Copy of VBLOCK MAINT BW Customer Proposal 6001570745.xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Progressive is accustomed to receiving best-in-class pricing for Dell EMC products and this proposal falls slightly short, despite including some considerable concessions. However, the discounts provided by EMC are still higher than the majority of EMC purchases that NPI reviews, and attaining further discounts will require careful negotiation.   Pricing Analysis NPI?s analysis incorporates 15 separate proposals. The methodology for this analysis categorizes each proposed line item into a specific EMC product ?family? (Centera, Data Domain, VxRack, etc.) and category (HW, SW, PS, Maint.), as discounting levels between different storage families and categories vary within the Dell EMC environment.  Because NPI data revolves around EMC product families and  because the fair discount ranges for each of these families varies, the analysis discusses discounts by family and category and concludes with target recommendations per each individual quote.  CENTERA ?	Centera spend is 3% of the overall proposal spend, which is in line with industry observations of decreasing spend on this product family. o	NPI continues to see clients migrating from this platform to more current offerings from EMC and/or other vendors. ?	The current proposal is discounted at 68% off list price for HW. NPI finds this pricing to be at FMV with room for improvement.  A discount target of 72% off list pricing would place Progressive in the best-in-class range.   Achieving this target will result in a savings of $16,342. ?	NPI has seen some instances where it was difficult for clients to migrate from this platform.  Some migrations have been complex, and when issues arise, there are few Centera ?experts? remaining on the Dell EMC team to resolve problems. ?	NPI has observed ?creative? pricing solutions where clients can achieve extremely deep discounts when bundling a planned migration/retirement of the Centera platform to a newer EMC offering.  These types of ?solutions? allow for a win-win scenario where the client can upgrade the platform, EMC can migrate off an older platform which is increasingly more difficult to support, and the sales team can deepen the EMC relationship with new products.  NPI recommends a careful ROI analysis on any new solutions proposed.  DATA DOMAIN ?	EMC currently offers a 64% discount off list for both HW and Maintenance on the Data Domain (DD) family of products.  NPI finds this to be a low discount that places pricing above FMV. ?	The prior Data Domain purchase had a discount of 69% on a net price of $83K.  Current net pricing of $611K has a smaller, 64% discount off list.   ?	A target of 69% to match prior discounting levels for this family of product will result in a savings of $89K.  ELASTIC CLOUD STORAGE (ECS) ?	EMC offers discounts of 34.2% on their Elastic Cloud Storage (ECS) product.  NPI finds this discount level to be too low, and pricing therefore too high given the deep relationship that Progressive has with EMC.   ?	This appears to be the initial entry point for this product family, which focuses on Software Defined Storage (SDS) for a turnkey, hyperscale storage infrastructure.  The current buy represents 14%, or $700K, of the current spend and spend in this family will likely grow in the future. ?	NPI has seen discounts at the 40% level for a handful of clients.  As the Progressive relationship and spend continues to grow, NPI would expect nothing less than a discount of 40% in this area.  Achieving the 40% discount target will establish a solid discounting framework from which to baseline future purchases and will also result in savings of $62K on this purchase.  VBLOCK / VxBLOCK ?	VBlock spend in this proposal appears to be maintenance-related spend of $230K that is not discounted. ?	NPI finds that EMC maintenance spend is rarely discounted and pre-defined by EMC at the time of purchase (as it is based on the purchase price). ?	NPI finds pricing to be within FMV for this renewal. VMAX ?	NPI routinely observes Core VMAX purchases reach the high 70% and even low 80% discount ranges depending on size of purchase.  ?	VMAX is one of two ?flagship products for EMC that they built from the ground up, but the platform has existed for some time and EMC?s margins have steadily grown.  ?	NPI assumes that Progressive was able to reach (and exceed) the prior discount target of 80%, as prior discounting for Progressive was at 68% in December 2016.  Achieving that prior target of 80% would have yielded savings of $1.175M. ?	Progressive is currently at 81% and NPI is confident that the current discounting for this family is at best-in-class pricing.   ?	EMC traditionally applies discounts for all portions of software, hardware, and support at the same discount levels.  NPI typically finds elevated discounts in all areas Professional Services. ?	EMC Professional Services are custom and customer-specific; engagement prices are priced by teams per business units. There is also little to no continuity across business units.  NPI rarely sees pricing concessions in this area.    Hardware Support and Warranty Upgrade OPTIONS:  ?	While it is widely distributed and acknowledged that VMAX hardware comes with 3 years of support at the time of purchase, this support is Basic Support, or 24/7 remote support, with NBD delivery of replacements.  ?	Of course, there is an upgraded level of support or Premium Support and, depending on the size of the purchase, this ?upgrade support? will either carry the same level of discounting as the hardware that it is providing coverage for or include it entirely.  o	The little-known or unknown side of support is that the 4th year can be included at the basic level for ?free? and at the same discount level for upgrade support, with no penalty or commission knock to the EMC Enterprise AM or Sales Team selling it.  VRACK / VxRACK ?	Progressive had originally submitted two quote proposals to NPI for review.  Proposal P1112366 contained 2 sections, Prod and Non-Prod. Environments.  These two proposals were subsequently withdrawn. ?	Although quote 6001450691 may need to be removed from this analysis, the PS figures associated with this quote are still included in this report.  As all VxRack charges are specifically broken into categorical spend, it will be relatively simple to remove the PS amount of $751,273 if necessary.  XTREMIO ?	XtremIO is offered at a 64% discount for the majority of HW SKUs in this family.  Support is also offered at 64% off list pricing. This discount is too low and places pricing above FMV. NPI recommends a target discount of 72% to bring these items within FMV. o	A single SKU that stands out in the XtremIO analysis is the InfiniBand Switch.  This switch was only discounted at 48.7%.  NPI believes this hardware should be discounted to the same discount rate as all other XtremIO HW. ?	NPI has recently seen smaller deals achieve the 69% discount target at the $200K price point.  NPI believes that the significant spend with EMC should warrant best-in-class pricing and discounting for this product family. ?	As previously noted for the two maturing family lines above, the all-flash, high IO product offering by EMC is seen as a technology class that will continue to grow within the Progressive environment. Therefore, we strongly recommend that Progressive establish a solid discounting baseline for this product.  Achieving the targeted discount of 72% will result in savings of $230K. Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	It is NPI?s understanding that Progressive ?isn?t looking for ?deeper? discounting, but rather...for discounting that appreciates the deepening relationship that [they] have with EMC.? ?	NPI recommends that Progressive stress that, as the EMC / Progressive relationship continues to strengthen and grow, Progressive would like to see the same discounting as previously offered by EMC.   ?	Overall, targeted discounts are based on best-in-class pricing that Progressive has previously witnessed in prior purchases.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Renewal of something NPI hasnt seen before, Gnip owned buy Twitter, performed research and provided feedback via email. see attached
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from Pam:  Gregg ?   With this email I would like to introduce you to a colleague of mine who supports the Marketing Division at American Family Insurance.  She is working on an agreement with Networked Insights and it appears Twitter has more than doubled the price with very little notice (and tactics that are legal, but definitely not friendly).  Would NPI have any insight as to how we can help Network Insights with Twitter,  and what we could predict for future price increases.   The data they get from the Twitter Decahose is crucial to their business and we have a deadline to get a new agreement signed by 3/31 or we will be shut off. We are definitely short on leverage in the situation, so trying to find anything I can to help us out!  Kristin?s contact information is as follows:

deal_metadata.description: Msft EA Renewal, part of subscription.  We spent near a year working on Discovery, with many options and and a lot of planning.  We even uncovered numerous non-compliant situations and provided specific advice on how to rectify.  The customer was very interested in O365 as a potential option, but getting the right discount and pricing was very important.  Of course, they were very concerned with security as well, but once they got past that concern it was a solid decision to move forward with an O365 option.  Unfortunately Grace was waiting in the wings to take over and pull NPI out for the final rounds.  She was frustrated with MSFT's resistance to her strategy, but her boss ended up coming back to us, along with John Ngyuen, and seeking our advice and benchmarking for the final rounds.  Ultimately they got a good deal, it could have been better if they would have followed our advice, but as we found out, Grace wanted to discontinue our relationship and even went as far as to say that they know as much as NPI and don't need any of our benchmarking any longer.  Also that they are premier negotiators now.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAS expansion purchase in support of client front end to Ignite
deal_metadata.current_narrative: SAS came in with high costs. a bit better terms if they prepay for 10 clients.  Seems odd for Equifax to be taking on risk since they're bringing customers to SAS.  Found a SME. His data indicated (through a buddy) that the core items were actually being offered above list.  Wild card is ELA seems to lock in a 66% discount on future purchases during ELA term. Final ELA was at 80%+ as well. See attached email with feedback and Steve's reply about progress to date.  Response when I sent feedback: Thank you, this is insightful and scary.. Charles and I will review, while we are waiting on a response from SAS on MLA discount terms we believe we have locked in as we discussed. SAS promised yesterday, Bob Mann reached out again this morning, still nothing.   Lastly, I reached out to BU with EM questions, and he is traveling and did not have access to some data in order to answer. Expecting a response there as well. I?m pretty comfortable it?s for 16 core, but not sure if it?s per client..
deal_metadata.description: Steve called back in to help.  2016 ELA included free proof of concept.  Prospects interested in Equifax's Ignite product could play with the data and use SAS front end for now charge.  If they want to buy ignite they are likely to want to buy SAS as well.  Equifax is negotiating the cost for reselling SAS front end.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Kronos and found the pricing for the core SaaS bundle to be above Fair Market Value (FMV) with room for improvement of up to 24% based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the other add-on software subscriptions are at FMV.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions. ?	The core SaaS bundle is priced at $2.74 per employee, per month (PEPM). The list pricing for this bundle is $7 PEPM, which is an increase from the previous list price of $5 PEPM.  o	For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $1.82 PEPM. This translates to savings of $13,800 per month. ?	The Workforce Activities software is priced at $0.45 PEPM. This price is at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	The Workforce Accruals software is priced at $0.26, which is also at FMV. ?	 The Workforce Record Manager is priced at $0.15. For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $0.11 PEPM. This translates to savings of $600 per month. ?	WF Analytics is priced at $0.86 PEPM. This price is FMV. ?	The overall savings based on NPI?s recommended target price translates to $14,400 per month and $358,560 for the 36-month period with a 24-month ramp up.  Other considerations: ?	NPI has not seen Kronos insist on prepayment for the subscriptions. This is certainly negotiable. ?	However, NPI has also not seen Kronos concede to a ramp up pricing, which reduces the revenue in years 1 and 2.  o	Most SaaS vendors prefer an even annual or front-loaded pricing/revenue model and a 3-5 year commitment.  A ramp up licensing scenario inevitably results in higher pricing per license for the customer and higher TCO over 5 years. However, if a customer has strong leverage (for example, if the customer already has perpetual licenses and does not need the licenses since they don?t require upgrades, and therefore would not be likely to make the purchase at all, or if there is competition in the mix), the vendor will concede to these terms. ?	A target of $2 per employee per month for Time and Accruals for 15,000 employees is achievable. The motivation by Kronos to provide a larger incentive for a large employee base is in line with their marketing approach, which highly touts the number of users/employees that use or are managed through KRONOS cloud. ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially on the add-on subscriptions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: They only went with Timekeeping, Accruals and Activities, so reflected that in the Financial Summary
deal_metadata.description: Flowserve is looking to purchase various Kronos SaaS subscriptions. they are looking at an 18 -24 month ramp-up.   don?t want to do any pre-payments to Kronos as is recommended in the Kronos pricing model. Our preference is to do a 20% tiered pricing model. The final cost that Doug wants to pay is $2.00 per employee per month for Time and Accruals. The final cost for activities (SFDC) is $0.40 per employee per month.

file_info.name: Copy of VBLOCK MAINT BE Customer Proposal 6001570689.xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Progressive is accustomed to receiving best-in-class pricing for Dell EMC products and this proposal falls slightly short, despite including some considerable concessions. However, the discounts provided by EMC are still higher than the majority of EMC purchases that NPI reviews, and attaining further discounts will require careful negotiation.   Pricing Analysis NPI?s analysis incorporates 15 separate proposals. The methodology for this analysis categorizes each proposed line item into a specific EMC product ?family? (Centera, Data Domain, VxRack, etc.) and category (HW, SW, PS, Maint.), as discounting levels between different storage families and categories vary within the Dell EMC environment.  Because NPI data revolves around EMC product families and  because the fair discount ranges for each of these families varies, the analysis discusses discounts by family and category and concludes with target recommendations per each individual quote.  CENTERA ?	Centera spend is 3% of the overall proposal spend, which is in line with industry observations of decreasing spend on this product family. o	NPI continues to see clients migrating from this platform to more current offerings from EMC and/or other vendors. ?	The current proposal is discounted at 68% off list price for HW. NPI finds this pricing to be at FMV with room for improvement.  A discount target of 72% off list pricing would place Progressive in the best-in-class range.   Achieving this target will result in a savings of $16,342. ?	NPI has seen some instances where it was difficult for clients to migrate from this platform.  Some migrations have been complex, and when issues arise, there are few Centera ?experts? remaining on the Dell EMC team to resolve problems. ?	NPI has observed ?creative? pricing solutions where clients can achieve extremely deep discounts when bundling a planned migration/retirement of the Centera platform to a newer EMC offering.  These types of ?solutions? allow for a win-win scenario where the client can upgrade the platform, EMC can migrate off an older platform which is increasingly more difficult to support, and the sales team can deepen the EMC relationship with new products.  NPI recommends a careful ROI analysis on any new solutions proposed.  DATA DOMAIN ?	EMC currently offers a 64% discount off list for both HW and Maintenance on the Data Domain (DD) family of products.  NPI finds this to be a low discount that places pricing above FMV. ?	The prior Data Domain purchase had a discount of 69% on a net price of $83K.  Current net pricing of $611K has a smaller, 64% discount off list.   ?	A target of 69% to match prior discounting levels for this family of product will result in a savings of $89K.  ELASTIC CLOUD STORAGE (ECS) ?	EMC offers discounts of 34.2% on their Elastic Cloud Storage (ECS) product.  NPI finds this discount level to be too low, and pricing therefore too high given the deep relationship that Progressive has with EMC.   ?	This appears to be the initial entry point for this product family, which focuses on Software Defined Storage (SDS) for a turnkey, hyperscale storage infrastructure.  The current buy represents 14%, or $700K, of the current spend and spend in this family will likely grow in the future. ?	NPI has seen discounts at the 40% level for a handful of clients.  As the Progressive relationship and spend continues to grow, NPI would expect nothing less than a discount of 40% in this area.  Achieving the 40% discount target will establish a solid discounting framework from which to baseline future purchases and will also result in savings of $62K on this purchase.  VBLOCK / VxBLOCK ?	VBlock spend in this proposal appears to be maintenance-related spend of $230K that is not discounted. ?	NPI finds that EMC maintenance spend is rarely discounted and pre-defined by EMC at the time of purchase (as it is based on the purchase price). ?	NPI finds pricing to be within FMV for this renewal. VMAX ?	NPI routinely observes Core VMAX purchases reach the high 70% and even low 80% discount ranges depending on size of purchase.  ?	VMAX is one of two ?flagship products for EMC that they built from the ground up, but the platform has existed for some time and EMC?s margins have steadily grown.  ?	NPI assumes that Progressive was able to reach (and exceed) the prior discount target of 80%, as prior discounting for Progressive was at 68% in December 2016.  Achieving that prior target of 80% would have yielded savings of $1.175M. ?	Progressive is currently at 81% and NPI is confident that the current discounting for this family is at best-in-class pricing.   ?	EMC traditionally applies discounts for all portions of software, hardware, and support at the same discount levels.  NPI typically finds elevated discounts in all areas Professional Services. ?	EMC Professional Services are custom and customer-specific; engagement prices are priced by teams per business units. There is also little to no continuity across business units.  NPI rarely sees pricing concessions in this area.    Hardware Support and Warranty Upgrade OPTIONS:  ?	While it is widely distributed and acknowledged that VMAX hardware comes with 3 years of support at the time of purchase, this support is Basic Support, or 24/7 remote support, with NBD delivery of replacements.  ?	Of course, there is an upgraded level of support or Premium Support and, depending on the size of the purchase, this ?upgrade support? will either carry the same level of discounting as the hardware that it is providing coverage for or include it entirely.  o	The little-known or unknown side of support is that the 4th year can be included at the basic level for ?free? and at the same discount level for upgrade support, with no penalty or commission knock to the EMC Enterprise AM or Sales Team selling it.  VRACK / VxRACK ?	Progressive had originally submitted two quote proposals to NPI for review.  Proposal P1112366 contained 2 sections, Prod and Non-Prod. Environments.  These two proposals were subsequently withdrawn. ?	Although quote 6001450691 may need to be removed from this analysis, the PS figures associated with this quote are still included in this report.  As all VxRack charges are specifically broken into categorical spend, it will be relatively simple to remove the PS amount of $751,273 if necessary.  XTREMIO ?	XtremIO is offered at a 64% discount for the majority of HW SKUs in this family.  Support is also offered at 64% off list pricing. This discount is too low and places pricing above FMV. NPI recommends a target discount of 72% to bring these items within FMV. o	A single SKU that stands out in the XtremIO analysis is the InfiniBand Switch.  This switch was only discounted at 48.7%.  NPI believes this hardware should be discounted to the same discount rate as all other XtremIO HW. ?	NPI has recently seen smaller deals achieve the 69% discount target at the $200K price point.  NPI believes that the significant spend with EMC should warrant best-in-class pricing and discounting for this product family. ?	As previously noted for the two maturing family lines above, the all-flash, high IO product offering by EMC is seen as a technology class that will continue to grow within the Progressive environment. Therefore, we strongly recommend that Progressive establish a solid discounting baseline for this product.  Achieving the targeted discount of 72% will result in savings of $230K. Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	It is NPI?s understanding that Progressive ?isn?t looking for ?deeper? discounting, but rather...for discounting that appreciates the deepening relationship that [they] have with EMC.? ?	NPI recommends that Progressive stress that, as the EMC / Progressive relationship continues to strengthen and grow, Progressive would like to see the same discounting as previously offered by EMC.   ?	Overall, targeted discounts are based on best-in-class pricing that Progressive has previously witnessed in prior purchases.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Karen,  I have four sets of quotes that I need NPI to review for November deals. Let me know if you need additional information or if you would like me to contact Greg directly on these.   These sets are all EMC deals for storage  and virtual computing infrastructure.   Project 1 ? HCI infrastructure for DSE project  Project 2 ? vBlock Lease Extension for Prod and Non-prod racks  Project 3 ? Centera Evaluation Units purchase  Project 4 ? Q4 Storage Purchase (multi-platform)    Hi Chris, We?ve got a lot going on and I just was able to take a first pass.  ?	The first two files are VCE quotes with the same look and feel and list prices includes.  Reviewing won?t be a problem.  ?	The third and fourth files are one line item quotes in a standard EMC file format.  Not big dollars but no list price and a generic SKU.  These can?t be benchmarked in this format.  Do they relate to the VCE quotes? ?	The fifth file is another EMC quote.  No list prices but not a lot of items and we can fill in the blanks. ?	The sixth file is the biggest dollar quote.  No list prices and many worksheets.  I think it makes the most sense to ask EMC to revise with list prices. There?s even a column for it that they left blank. On prior NPI reviews for Progressive for EMC they furnished it.  This is the most efficient and accurate way to proceed.  Can you request that?  Can you share any info on timeline and context?  We reviewed another sizable purchase in December.  Would be interesting to understand how this relates to that purchase.   Try these quotes. The timeframe for these transactions are all in the next three weeks. The context is: the storage transactions are mostly to replace end of life units for the big storage quote, additional emergency capacity for the Centera storage, lease extension on the vblock units, and a new development/ production environment for the Prod/Non-Prod racks.    OUTCOME EMAIL (NO DOCS): EMC tends to bundle product and services with the greater discounts coming on services and associated software, at least for Progressive. On the vxblock / vxRail deal there was no appreciable additional discount received for this deal. We did receive services discounts in the amount of $125k tied to this purchase. On the storage deal (XtemeIO, Vmax, Data Domain, Centera) we received a total of $549k in software discounts and software substitution rights on a total spend of $3.027M for this purchase.   As we look toward renegotiating our current ELA with Dell EMC we will be seeking more favorable discounts rates across the board for HW, SW, and Services for the next term. We are clear that we left money on the table in the prior contract.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email. see attached.   Standard support which is included in the Node Pricing vs Premium $0 line item as seen on other quotes.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Based on existing discounts and outcomes that we?ve seen with other clients, NPI finds the FMV range for this purchase is 65% - 68%.  With a current blended discount of 65.7%, VSP is within FMV, but we have seen slightly better discounting and we believe VSP should target 68% for 2,000 Nodes, returning an additional ~$6K in savings.   The message to Chef should focus on dollar figures vs discount percentages.  It is a more convincing argument to explain to Chef that you are trying to reach a budgetary number of $82,250 (using a specific number makes it seem more realistic).  You may be able to rob from Peter to pay Paul and add some additional dollars to the budget for this project, but we are unlikely to get to $94K.  If Chef can meet us in the middle around $85K, approval will likely happen quicker.  NPI is interested in the negotiations that have occurred to this point with Chef?  What has VSP done & said to reach the current 65.7% blended discount?  In sum, NPI feels this pricing is within FMV as is, but 68% is achievable and would be closer to best-in-class.

Based on this understanding, the target rates we provided are not best-in-class rates but Fair Market Value rates.  For example, for a junior developer in the CA Sunnyvale area, we have seen rates as low as $60 for resources with 0-2 years. However, this may not be a realistic target for Intuit.  NPI recommended a $75 target for IT services - Jr. Developer assuming the resource has 3-6 years of experience and higher skill set and a $80 target for Product development Jr. Developer which requires special product related knowledge.

file_info.name: HR Block - FMV - Oracle Cloud - March 2018 - V3.docx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the Oracle Fusion Financials Cloud subscription pricing and found the pricing to be within the range of Fair Market Value with room for improvement.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Oracle has offered a blended discount of 54.4% for various Oracle Financial Cloud Services.  o	In the past year, NPI has seen a large discount variance for Oracle Cloud products in general and particularly for the EPM and Financial stacks. o	 NPI has seen discounts vary between 20% and 86%.  o	The typical expected discount range for transactions of this size is 45% - 64.8%.   ?	While the offered discount of 54.4% is within this market range, there is room for improvement in discounting of up to 10%.  Oracle Cloud discounts and pricing are based on factors such as:  ?	Quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customer prior to purchasing the cloud subscription (Oracle provides big incentives when customers are moving from perpetual to cloud licenses, including shelving credits, credits for prepaid maintenance and larger discounts on the cloud products) ?	Customer requirements and negotiation leverage ?	Presence of competitors ?	Senior Management/CXO level connects/escalations  ?	Volume and total spend with Oracle  Oracle?s Cloud Strategy  Oracle is in a full-court press to move as many customers to the Cloud as possible, even though over 70% of their revenue is still from their on-premise install base.  They are "all-in" on the Cloud and are paying their field reps (ASMs) on cloud-only revenue.  Last year, they gave their field ASMs a small SPIFF for on-premise software sales and have moved all of their on-premise sales efforts over to their inside sales group, OracleDirect.   Oracle Pricing/discounting Strategy on Cloud Products  As mentioned earlier, NPI has observed large variances in discounting for Oracle cloud products, but overall, Oracle has been much more conservative from a discount perspective on their SaaS offerings. Typically, any discount for a SaaS tool that is over 65% must be personally reviewed by the SVP of Sales for North America         through a deal review call; historically, very few transactions over 65% have been approved.  There are exceptions to this, of course, but exceptions must be a monster deal and very strategic, an ELA or otherwise.  This is one of the reasons H&R Block has previously received discount quotes for 64%.  It's unlikely that Oracle will go any higher than a 64.9% discount, even if you threaten to walk from the deal (although that may get them to consider).

Plus plan has a list price of $150 per user when paid annually. Your current offer reflects a discount of 0% where anything would be an improvement. o	NPI recommends targeting a 10% - 15% discount based on the size of spend, netting $4,500 - $6,750 in savings. o	SaaS companies are sometimes stingy with discounting but with the right leverage and messaging, NPI believes additional savings are achievable.   Service	Order Term	Qty	Unit Price	Total	Discount	Target Discount	Target Price	Target Savings Plus Plan	12	300	$150	$45,000	0%	10% - 15%	$39,375	$4,500 - $6,750  ?	One added benefit worth noting and is unique to Slack is their ?Fair Billing Policy?. As stated on their website, ?At Slack, you only get billed for the people who use it each month. And if someone you?ve already paid for becomes inactive, we?ll add a prorated credit to your account for the unused time?. o	Seeing this is a first time purchase, VSP will be able to gauge adoption rate and not be penalized for those not using it.  ?	Slack is the fastest company to reach a $2B valuation ($5B as of September 2017), so they are very proud of themselves; but, they need to continue demonstrating profitability to justify the valuation.  ?	Slack?s fiscal year is the calendar year, therefore, 3/31 is quarter end. This will provide further negotiation leverage if VSP can pull the trigger quickly.  o	VSP?s message should be: ?The budget for this project has been cut to $40K.
