deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pat My advisor believes the Equinix offers are at list price for both Chicago and DC.   The DC 2 data center is their main hub and there?s not much remaining space there which makes them less negotiable.  Chicago is another story.  List pricing is above FMV.  Target 25-30% off all MRCs and settling on anything about 20% is solid plus target no installation costs in Chicago.  While you may want to push for that in DC it?ll be tougher.  You may want to consider indicating you know DC is their hub and your intel suggests has limited capacity and because of that you can live with minimal discounting BUT 0% across the board is not going to work.  Then push for 10% on DC and the targets I noted for Chicago.  This is new business for Equinix with cheaper options so they can flex if pushed.  A few other thoughts:  There are two power models in the industry.  Measured Use (pay by amp used) and flat rated to a limit.  AmFam has chosen kVA based power which has flat rated AC power to a 3 KVa limit per term. There are significant penalties if you exceed the kVa limit during the 36 month term.  AmFam needs to understand the initial consumption of the equipment going in to the cabinet and its future growth.  See below on contractual items.  The NRC cost for each AC circuit is $500.  Power is primary and redundant so a total of 4 circuits.    Power                   NRC                       MRC (primary & redundant) Chicago                $500.00                 $362.50/cabinet                                $1,087.50/cage Ashburn               $500.00                 $300.00/cabinet                                $900.00/cage                        Interconnection Each cage will be configured with a 10 gb port accessible to the public internet/cloud.  NRC is $3,000 per port.  This a bundled offer including the port and cross-connect and cable.   There is no mention of redundancy in the port.    Potential Risks  1]            Make sure 3 cabinets and 3 kVa is sufficient for the 36 month term of the contract.    2]            Make sure the interconnection port is redundant. We assume one IBX location is primary and the other DR.  3]            This is not a fixed price contract.  There is a 5% annual price escalator on all prices.     TCO Summary                                 NRC                       36 months          Total  Chicago                 $5,500                   $89,846                 $95,346  Ashburn               $5,500                   $75,660                 $81,160  Total                      $11,000                 $165,506              $176,506   Here are three other ideas for AmFam to consider:  1]           Reduce the 5% fixed annual escalator:   Eliminate/reduce the escalator on the cage MRC of $300 (Ashburn) and $362 (Chicago).  Equinix space costs are fixed (investment in the building is sunk).  Plus, they keep adding cabinets so they cover their costs at the marginal rate of another cabinet.  This is very similar to another software license?no increase in underlying cost but increased revenue.   Second, on the other hand, power is an external variable not completely under their control.   In that case, I would index the power to a third party index.  I used the CPI index.   BLS publishes CPI values on urban basis and both Chicago and Washington have their own index.  Equinix will have language available for indexing and AmFam should ask for it and compare 5% to what they propose as an index.   National CPI over the last 3 years is much lower than 5% annually.    2]           Up front $3000 interconnection fee:  The old model was a monthly interconnect charge which has been replaced through competition to a NRC.  A interconnection MRC was ?frustrating? as it was viewed by the customer as a charge for a 50 foot piece of cable (I?m exaggerating here).  Amortized over the 36 month term, this works out to $83 MRC for a 10 gb port with no traffic charge.  This is a good price but AmFam needs to ask what the charge will be to use Equinix services to interconnect with cloud providers (say Azure, AWS, etc) or a third party ISP (say AT&T, VZ) for internet access.   So, make sure the port is redundant and make sure you understand third party external interconnect costs.  The port is a gate to the outside world?..charges for what goes through the gate may be additional.  3]           Hedge for growth:  Three cabinets/cage seems small, but maybe that?s all AmFam can forecast right now.   Consider including a hedge this way.  Reserve on a no-cost basis 2 additional cabinets per cage (build the cage larger).  If they grow past the initial 3 cabinets anytime during the term, they can draw down on the 2 reserved cabinets.  All cabinets will then have a reduction in MRC by some negotiated MRC.  AmFam is working with a small requirement so Equinix probably will not want to negotiate this (if they don?t grow, Equinix has 2 stranded cabinet spaces).   AmFam nevertheless should reserve and hedge now to the best you can.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Cognizant?s rates 3 years ago in 2015 and achieved savings at the time. During the review process, NPI came to understand that many of these resources have a higher/niche/product specific skill set.  Based on this understanding, the target rates we provided are not best-in-class rates but Fair Market Value rates.  For example, for a junior developer in the CA Sunnyvale area, we have seen rates as low as $60 for resources with 0-2 years. However, this may not be a realistic target for Intuit.  NPI recommended a $75 target for IT services - Jr. Developer assuming the resource has 3-6 years of experience and higher skill set and a $80 target for Product development Jr. Developer which requires special product related knowledge.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Freddie Mac?s SCE pricing and found it to be above fair market value (FMV) based on comparable Microsoft spends. Discounting is poor in each category for a $2M+ annual spend, and the 0% discount on subscription items is consistent with a 0% rate on subscriptions in Freddie Mac?s larger EAS. The SCE does provide some automatic discounting on perpetual licensing, but at this size of a net spend across multiple agreements, those discounts do not push pricing into the range of FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts off the Level C reference pricing.  Microsoft is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the larger 3-year TCO plus address the financial exposure risks of the SCE?s encompassing licensing rules. ?	NPI recommends getting Microsoft to focus on an even budgetary goal of getting the spend under a $6.75M target for the term ($2.25M annual) in exchange for an expedited deal approval that preserves a March signature timeline. ?	NPI notes that these targets are more conservative to reflect the smaller timeframe available for this deal.  o	More aggressive targets would be appropriate with multiple months available for negotiations, but NPI has seen success even within shorter periods.  o	If Freddie Mac feels the sales team is especially nervous about landing this deal, it is feasible to pursue a more aggressive price target.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: Even with a short month-long timeline, Microsoft upped L/SA, SA, and Subs discounts 6%, 6.5%, and 7% respectively.  Financials and savings reflect the full 3-year spend.    Freddie Mac is reviewing a Microsoft Server and Cloud Enrollment (SCE) proposal set to commence in April 2018.

deal_metadata.description: Please review and provide your input as to the value of the attached quotes.    1.	Cisco Meraki (Pomeroy) 2.	HP Aruba-SD Branch (AE Business Solutions) 3.	Fortinet (Verizon)  Background/Scope of work: AmFam would like to procure an innovative and creative solution that will meet secure WAN, wireless LAN, and network access control (NAC) needs for our sales agency environment.  We will be selecting a technology solution to replace the existing Cisco 891 router, the ASR1004 head end gear, and the existing inline NAC solution.  In addition, we will be deploying wireless LAN to all of the Agent offices.  AmFam will be selecting a vendor to procure the equipment and deploy the technology solution.  At the conclusion of the RFP process we will award a contract.  Additional Information: AmFam has 3,000 agent offices throughout 19 states that will be affected.  We desire to implement a reasonable security protection capability within each office, however, we would like to retain the current Netgear FS728 switches deployed in each office.  Long term, we expect the Netgear will be phased out as we move to a predominantly wireless office.  Use of Aruba ClearPass is desired as the back end authentication system. We want to use a client or dissolvable agent to provide AmFam device posture checks.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: In summary, the proposed pricing from Adobe is at the low end of the range of Fair Market Value as compared to similar market transactions.  NPI reviewed the original Adobe Analytics purchase for Intuit (In June 2016).  Adobe had proposed pricing of $28 for 90 Billion server calls and $25 for 100 Billion server calls per year. NPI had recommended targets of $25 for 90 billion server calls and $23 for 100 billion server calls which targets Intuit achieved at the time resulting in savings of $233K for 1 year.  In a subsequent renewal early last year, the pricing has remained flat at $23 for 100 Billion server calls.  Adobe Analytics Changes   Adobe previously offered Analytics in two editions, standard and premium.  ?	Adobe has repackaged the Analytics Cloud (announced March 2017) and now offers three editions: Select, Prime and Ultimate. The license metric continues to be Million SERVER CALLS Per Month. Each product increases in functionality and price from Select to Prime to Ultimate. ?	Previously, secondary calls cost 50% of Primary server calls, but that is no longer the case. Now, both primary and secondary calls have the same cost and count towards the total calls. ?	Adobe increased the price for all of their analytics solutions this year when they introduced the three new analytics products. ?	Based on Intuit's usage of Adobe Analytics and price point, Intuit has been offered the Prime product for this renewal.  Price Breakdown     ?	It is common for Adobe to offer pricing tiers like the offered table for companies to project their spend as they grow.  Typically Adobe will offer 3 options - they have offered seven options in this proposal, which is generous.   ?	Intuit is being offered great pricing on Adobe Analytics Prime. This pricing is likely to have had not only management exception approval but also executive approval. Intuit?s Adobe rep likely had to fight a battle internally to get this pricing approved.    Recommendation ?	Overall, NPI believes that Intuit has received great pricing from Adobe for the Analytics Prime and the pricing has remained flat since 2016/2017.  ?	The Sitecat Data Feed is priced at $1,350 CPMM. NPI recommends a pricing of $1250 CPMM which translates to savings of $14,400 per year. ?	At this level of spend, Intuit can request free training and free passes to Adobe Summit.  FINAL UPDATE: Great news, we were able to negotiate our pricing further to 21.25 for 120B primary server calls (price intended for 150B) and continue to pay 11.50 for secondary postponing the increase in price for secondary. Thank you!

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed CRL?s proposed quantities and is providing guidelines around fair market value (FMV) and best practices. ServiceNow customers face many challenges that are common with enterprise SaaS providers. The solution can grow rapidly and the vendor is notorious for levying heavy automatic price hikes if left unchecked.  ServiceNow continues to develop new offerings, and although CRL only anticipates the two license types, NPI expects the vendor will try to upsell different areas of your organization. If CRL considers adding any products to this proposal, NPI suggests using that additional demand as a point of leverage by positioning them as ?nice-to-haves? that could be left off due to cost considerations. ServiceNow?s next fiscal quarter end is this month (March), and CRL?s offer to ServiceNow could provide key incentives to sales team quotas.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts.  ServiceNow is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the long-term solution TCO, especially as it relates to pricing allowing for growth and new products.   ?	NPI recommends getting ServiceNow to focus on getting the combined spend under an even $325K target annually in exchange for an expedited deal approval that can accommodate a March signature timeline.  A fallback of $350k (a flat 45% discount) is appropriate.
deal_metadata.description: Closing: client didn't share results    CRL is preparing to ask ServiceNow for a quote of ITSM and Approver users.  There is no current quote and the vendor has not been approached.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Findings and Recommendations NPI reviewed REI?s Kronos proposal and found the pricing for the add-on software subscriptions to be Fair Market Value (FMV) based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the ?Professional and Educational Services? were noted to be Above FMV.  Pricing Analysis ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions.   Workforce Budgeting & Analytics Kronos has a large footprint at REI, but even in the context of larger spend the pricing is very good and appears historical pricing has carried to the current proposal before contract consolidation next year. ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be FMV.  o	While Kronos does not publish list pricing, NPI has numerous deals in our database providing the ability to make comparisons, and by our estimates, your quote is discounted at ~80%+ which NPI considers to be solidly FMV. ?	Market range is typically between $.8 and $1.5 so clearly REI is getting solid pricing given these are add-on purchases.   License Type	Qty	Monthly Unit List	List Extended	Quote Unit Price	Quote Extended	Discount Workforce Budgeting	11,500	$5.42	$62,215	$0.50	$5,750 	91% Workforce Analytics for Retail	11,500	$6.66	$57,500	$0.77	$8,855 	88%  Professional Services Kronos itself bills its consultants in the range of $165 - $215 per hour. Kronos rack rates start at $200 per hour (blended). ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be Above FMV. ?	Currently, your blended hourly rate stands at ~$213, which we would expect for someone with far less of a landscape than what REI has. o	NPI provided target discounts as shown in the table below, returning a nominal additional savings of $1,078 (blended rate of ~$180).  SOW - Role	Hours	Rate	Extended	Discount	Target Discount	Target Price	Target Savings Project Manager	4	$200	$800	0%	10%	$720	$80 Technical Consultant	29	$215	$6,235	0%	16%	$5,237	$998 			$7,035		15%		$1,078  Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	NPI recommends REI to express disappointment with these rates. Indicate that you have done your market research (talking to colleagues, or a new REI executive who has experience with Kronos consulting), and you were expecting a blended rate closer to $175 - $180 per hour and to match prior contracts.  ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially for the add-on subscriptions. While that is evident in the subscription add-on, there is room for improvement on hourly rates.   Determined licenses were FMV but install rates were above FMV with targets provided
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from REI:  Have a quote for your review.  We are going to add two modules to our Kronos SaaS contract.  These are Analytics and Budgeting.  The second quote combines both and the total costs are listed as monthly fees.  We are looking for a one year contract that will be rolled up in our SaaS agreement next year.  During that time we will look at some multi-year options to see where we can leverage some cost saving.  The first quote is to install Analytics only.  In conjunction with this purchase we are using Axsium to provide professional services to roll out these two modules.  Let me know what you think.

file_info.name: RE  FMV Benchmarking on Workfront Sales Order.msg

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Provided feedback via email (see attached)  Thanks for sending over the quote for our review. NPI has provided general feedback as well as specific price targets for your 3-year renewal.  They changed the company name from AtTask to Workfront (http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/attask-changes-its-name-to-workfront-inc-300023764.html) in 2015 to rebrand and grow. Workfront has been aggressive, raising prices significantly over the past several years.  ?	Workfront acquired ProofHQ in 2015 (https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/workfront-acquires-proofhq-300116669.html)  While Workfront does not publish list pricing, they have provided it in Shaw?s quote (see table below for math).  Workfront Flex License ?  ?	The ?Flex? License allows for Workfront customers to seamlessly transfer access within an organization, not always offered by account executives as it is a cross between the highest tier ?Plan? license (all inclusive) and lower tier ?Work? license (less inclusive). This indicates Shaw?s need for licenses to change hands as people may leave/change departments as they no longer require access to Workfront. The Flex license is also flexible in capabilities as changing employees may not need the full use of a certain license type but is still available. Flex licenses are offered at a lower list price but with limited discounting ? most likely due to customers not always leveraging the full benefits of the higher tier (?Work? is half the cost of ?Plan? license).  o	Does Shaw need the flexibility? As it does come at a cost - it can makes sense to use Flex if you have more Work licenses than Plan. It is to Shaw?s advantage if you are able to make full use of the Flex license.  o	If this is not the case for Shaw?s Workfront landscape, you could inquire for a quote using one license type or the other to see how pricing compares. ?	NPI calculated a current flat discount of 14% on your proposal, identifying an opportunity for further discounting especially considering the three-year term. Many reviews completed by NPI are for one and two year terms. We believe this longer commitment should be rewarded. o	For this deal size and term NPIs FMV target is 30%. FYI, we would expect a one-year term to top out at 10% and a two-year near 20%. o	Achieving a target discount of 30% returns an additional savings of $10,560.  ProofHQ Premium License ?  ?	NPI calculated a current discount of 20% on your proposal, identifying an opportunity for further discounting driven by the same reasoning as the Flex license.  We often see both types of licenses discounted similarly. o	Achieving a target discount of 30% returns an additional savings of a modest $1,700. ?	NPI provided a comparison of Premium vs Standard below, where if Shaw does not require the Premium benefits you could consider the lower cost Standard or Select offerings. Shaw could consider the threat or really consider a less expensive license. o	See ?Pricing? section (no pricing provided, but compares license types) ? https://www.merchantmaverick.com/reviews/workfront-review/   The Premium offering includes:  ?	Their highest level of license and security  ?	Encryption-at-rest  ?	Option to review data center audits performed to maintain SaS70 compliance  ?	Unlimited access to providing Requests, Dashboards and Reports ? users beyond the licensed ?Power users?  ?	Highest level of support, 7X24X365  ?	Provides for data storage of 25GB per user ?	Highest level of SLA at 30 Min ? 4 hours  The Standard offering by comparison:  ?	Does not include their highest security, Encryption-at-rest (EAR)  ?	Provides for their lowest level of SLA?s (2 hours - 2 business days for support response)  ?	Provides their lowest level of support offering 12 hours per day, 5 days per week (12X5)  ?	Provides for data storage of 1.5GB per user  ?	Somewhat limited where non-power users are unable to submit requests to a queue.  QTY	Part	Description	List Price	Customer Price	Discount	Target Discount	Target Price	Target Savings 55	WF-PRM-LF	Workfront Flex License	$66,000	$56,760	14%	30%	$46,200	$10,560 20	PHQ-PRM-FL	ProofHQ Premium License	$17,000	$13,600	20%	30%	$11,900	$1,700 		Totals	$83,000	$70,360	15%	30%	$58,100	$12,260  NPI has more frequently reviewed 1-year and 2-year Workfront quotes, all seeing improvement when pushed for better pricing. Given your spend and 3-year commitment, NPI sees 30% across the board being achievable to realize total additional savings of $12,260.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ***Updated proposal received with new feedback provided. See the attached files labeled 'UPDATED...' deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed CRL?s proposed quantities and is providing guidelines around fair market value (FMV) and best practices. ServiceNow customers face many challenges that are common with enterprise SaaS providers. The solution can grow rapidly and the vendor is notorious for levying heavy automatic price hikes if left unchecked.  ServiceNow continues to develop new offerings, and although CRL only anticipates the two license types, NPI expects the vendor will try to upsell different areas of your organization. If CRL considers adding any products to this proposal, NPI suggests using that additional demand as a point of leverage by positioning them as ?nice-to-haves? that could be left off due to cost considerations. ServiceNow?s next fiscal quarter end is this month (March), and CRL?s offer to ServiceNow could provide key incentives to sales team quotas.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts.  ServiceNow is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the long-term solution TCO, especially as it relates to pricing allowing for growth and new products.   ?	NPI recommends getting ServiceNow to focus on getting the combined spend under an even $325K target annually in exchange for an expedited deal approval that can accommodate a March signature timeline.  A fallback of $350k (a flat 45% discount) is appropriate.
deal_metadata.description: Closing: client didn't share results    CRL is preparing to ask ServiceNow for a quote of ITSM and Approver users.  There is no current quote and the vendor has not been approached.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the SOW from ImplementHIT and found the pricing to be well within Fair Market Value.  A Jimenez MD MSED is the CEO of ImplementHIT and a $250 per hour rate for a senior consulting role is well within FMV. Market range is between $200/hour and $315/per hour.  The other resources are priced at $140 per hour which is also at Fair Market Value. Typical market range is $125 - $150 per hour. Furthermore, ImplementHIT has provided a discount of 20% on the consulting fees which makes the cost very competitive.  Overall, based on comparisons to market rates, Springfield Clinic is good to go with this purchase.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: ?	Each Instance subscription from WSO2 has a list price of $10,000.   ?	Last year, AFI was at $8,742 for each of the six instances, a 12.5% discount.   ?	This year, at $9004 per license, you are at 10% off. ?	NPI?s guidance was to push for 20%, however, we were unsuccessful even moving the needle slightly. ?	This is essentially a subscription, so the idea of a year over year increase is not uncommon, however, the question falls back to what has the experience for AFI been with the product and has AFI seen enough growth in the product to justify the increase, no matter how small. If the answer is no, they AFI can always push back to last year?s pricing, however, the $1,600 savings may not be worth the effort. ?	NPI did advise that committing to longer subscription cycle (3 years) ? for longer terms WSO2 has done 25-30% discounts  ?	WSO2?s consulting rack rate is $200/hr so the $150 (bulk rate) is solid and within FMV.   ?	In the services case as well, NPI did advise to push for an additional discount, down to 37.5% off, however, WSO2 must have been resistant to giving any ground there as well. ?	If the services work fell short of expectations, that might provide some leverage. Failing that occurrence, the cost of labor has certainly not been reduced in the last 12 months.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Essentially FMV
deal_metadata.description: Can you give me a price assessment on the attached WSO2 proposal.  They are providing an instance at $9,004 which is a 3% YoY on last year's fees.  Total Production Support fee would be $54,024. With the 200 hours of Development Support, the total would come up to $84,024.  Thanks

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this BrightEdge pricing over for NPI to review.  We have only seen a handful of BrightEdge transactions, but I was able to do some comparative analysis on the discount percentage.  Overall, last year?s purchase at 40% discounting is well within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV) for a BrightEdge purchase of this size.  We have actually seen a few larger BrightEdge deals that have maxed out in the mid- 40%?s discounting, so we consider 40% for a $60K list price purchase to be FMV.  Since BrightEdge has held the pricing flat AND included additional Domains and Google Analytics connects, NPI continues to believe that this pricing is well within FMV.  VSP can move forward with confidence on this one.
deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarking on BrightEdge? Supplier raised the price by 8% and is offering the same price as last year if we close this month.  They added 2 free domains on this order.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Robert, Hey there.  Must be something about this space and how their vendors conceal their list prices.  I guess as security companies they are practicing what they preach ?.  While we?ve seen several Vormetric deals the SKUs often vary across our reviews and they don?t always show list pricing.  However, they do at times so we know they will provide it if asked.  Again, we got resourceful and tried to work through this and also leverage some public data.  I just got to a point where I think we are better off asking Trace3 to show add more transparency in their quote.  I think the SKUs are correct so that?s some good news.  The attached Excel file shows the work in progress.  I haven?t suggested targets yet since there?s too many open items.  Of note:  ?	VOR-TE ? listed for $6K about 12 months ago.  Let?s confirm this.  You may also want to take this time and ask about the bundled list price (and even net) that includes the Transparent Encryption Agent, Application Encryption and Tokenization. Another client bought the bundle (at MUCH bigger volumes ? 1,500) but paid $1K for each bundle. Webster is at $3,150 for just TE. You?re at less than 2% of their volume but I?m curious what they?d offer and it may be good to know if that?s on your roadmap.  If only two of these are of interest I don?t think they have a bundle for that but you could ask.  This other client didn?t have the Tokenization Client license so perhaps they?re configuring their solution differently than Webster. o	The quantity of 25 for VOR-TE and VOR-VTE-LTD brings up another topic to push for clarity on. From the limited pricing I?ve seen there?s a clear example on their Data Encryption Agent license where the first one is $6K, ten cost $45K (or $4500 each) and 25 cost $100K or $4K each).  I think now is the time to make sure they show you what all these tiers look like to ensure you?re getting both the programmatic volume discount and the additional discount you?d get on a first-time competitive buy. ?	VOR-VTE-LTD ? the one item I had no traction finding list pricing for ?	VOR-TOKEN ? educated guess is this is also at $6K list ?	The DSM Enterprise Parts I believe have the same list and they just discount non-prod more than prod.  The list could be $30K or something north of $40K.  That reflects quite a swing in discounting so it is a key item to validate.  I?d be appreciative if you could also ask them for the list price of the physical DSM Enterprise equivalent. Perhaps you could say someone asked about that option and you wanted to understand it more.  I think it lists for at least $5K more. ?	On the Support side, Standard is always 18% of net and Premium is 22%.  We?ve never seen Premium+ which is what?s reflected on your quote.  Below is a picture of the comparison of these two in their SW Lic Agreement.  They?re offering the + at 23% of the total hardware and software net.  Doesn?t sound like a bad uplift over Premium assuming you?re getting something more.  Consider your options there.  ?	Some services details are shown. o	Vormetric?s rack rate is $2,500/day. VOR-PRO-SERV is the SKU.  We?ve seen it not discounted typically.   o	Program Review and Roadmap Dev seems like it?ll be work done by Trace3 for a fixed fee of $51,800. They mention a Security Architect and PM. No hours are mentioned.   We?d expect this to reflect some hourly estimate applied against the rates and then a 10-20% uplift for the risk involved with a fixed fee engagement.  Maybe ask about a T&M to get exposure to the rates and effort. o	Product Install appears to be Vormetric people.  Offered at $12,500 that?s 5 days at their $2,500 rack rate.  That number of days doesn?t seem bloated.  In a competitive environment feels like that could be something to push for free. o	Tech Design and Impl - $67,500 for 6 weeks. That?s $11,250 a week or $2,250 a day if one resource which is exactly 10% off the Vormetric daily rack rate of $2500. It includes an Architect, Engineer and PM but again is offered at a fixed amount so no effort/hours noted.  Push for some clarity around this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric. On the one hand you?d expect a lower rate with Trace3 but oftentimes partners bring more senior resources to bear than the OEM/Publisher. o	Roadmap and Mentoring is offered at $51,800 and is T&M. It is largely an architect at $300.  We can benchmark this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric.  We?ll work on what we can but let me know if you expect to reach out to Trace3 for this additional detail.  Now is the time and no reason to spend this money if there?s any questions about the transparency of the offer.  Also, do you expect future growth.  Getting transparency now sets you up for that.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.  Final quote increased in size largely due to Token Server Client item growing from 1 to 18.  The only reductions appear to be on the DSM units as both the Prod and non prod had reductions.  Maintenance also dropped from 23% to 20%.   The initial quotes didn't clear show all the non prod info that was shown in the final.  Estimating savings and new baseline but not overthinking it.  Future folks should use the final docs (also some list pricing in XLS) and new SME.
deal_metadata.description: Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.  Reply to first offer: We?ll take a look.  From my first pass I can tell you the Trace3 (Vormetric) SOW is too light on details.  There?s a lot ($530K+) of services with no resources, rates and hours so it can?t be benchmarked.  There?s also a sizable placeholder for hardware, licenses and support for $501K with no detail.  Trace3 needs to provide a Vormetric quote showing all the usual details (SKUs, list, net, quantities).  Webster came back on 3/13 with a revised spreadsheet showing list pricing.  Some sizable increases. Sent a second round of feedback on 3/14. see email.

We believe this longer commitment should be rewarded. o	Achieving a target discount of 35% returns an additional savings of ~$20K. o	Achieving a target discount of 25% returns an additional savings of ~$10K. Albeit a different license type (less expensive & non-flex), Shaw?s quantity does fall into the same quantity pricing tier (shown below) on a much longer term.  ?	< 25 ?	25 ? 49 ?	50 ? 74* ?	75 ? 99  Our analysis supports targeting total spend of ~$65K - ~$75K and would land Shaw?s pricing where NPI considers to be solidly FMV.  ? deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Jennifer,  Can you please clarify a couple of questions highlighted below? Thanks, I will try to get you a response back today.  To upgrade to Bot Manager Premier + Mobile SDK + Rapid Response + Client Reputation with increase in bandwidth from 75TB to 100TB = another $24K per month + a one-time $25K implementation fee. This is to cover all in scope sites (not just the current 2). How many sites total?  To increase Ion and Kona from 75TB to 100TB =  another $10K per month (with $.50 per GB overage fee) backdated to January 1. Is this $10,000 each Ion and Kona ($20,000 total)? I assume the increase is needed to cover traffic.  What is monthly traffic?  Hi Matt -   The $10K / month for extra 25TB bandwidth covers both Ion and Kona. January was about 83TB and February was also on target to exceed our 75TB entitlement. Our overage fees for January are just shy of $10K, so they will back date.  Since Digital released more products there has been an uptick in online activity (coupled with recent market volatility). We have been steadily increasing the last several months. Additionally they agreed to increase our Global Traffic Management by 30 properties at no additional cost as we exceeded those entitlements too.   (see attached email for table).  The offer for increased bandwidth on ION Premier and KSD is solid.  The push to migrate MS to Bot Manager Premier includes all of the extras that they normally throw in at no additional cost (Mobile SDK, Rapid Response, Client Reputation).  There is nothing special about this offer.  If I pulled it all together, they are proposing 100GB bandwidth and 7 sites for $46,500/month plus a $25,000 implementation fee.  A good target MRC for this arrangement anything $40,000/MRC or below.  Do you know of anyone that was able to get Akamai to agree to carry over unused bandwidth or measure overage only if over for the year or term?   For instance if I have 75TB per month, over 1 year that is 900TB. If I?m under for 9 months and go over the next, I would only pay if at end of year if I exceed 900TB.   I got them agree to count prof hours this way on our last renewal but not bandwidth.   No. I have been pushing for a more equitable equation on bandwidth usage for years.  I assume they are reluctant to do it because they lease bandwidth based on the aggregate of what they have sold and so they have a sunk cost either way.  If you are under utilizing the network, they still pay.  If you are over your commitment, they have to buy extra capacity. I?d like to get them to go on a straight metered rate.  Pay a platform fee, but then pay by the GB for actual consumption.  MS is a very large customer and has been successful in getting a lot of special terms, so you just might be the one that pushes them to a new model.  They have a sunk cost in professional hours also, but if they are sitting around idle, there are plenty of other customers to use those resources ? so in that case, there is no under utilization.
deal_metadata.description: Hi Gregg,  NPI provided Akamai data last year before our May renewal. We?re now upgrading Bot Manager to Bot Manager Premier which we?ve been evaluating, including a Mobile SDK, Rapid Response, Client Reputation and adding Visitor Prioritization. In addition, despite all the padding we negotiated to increase bandwidth from 50TB to 75K last year, we are now exceeding our bandwidth projections and have to upgrade to 100TB. Lastly, we have to extend Session Accelerator another year as we were not able to migrate the last site to ION.   Can you provide any current data related to these services (if any)? Aside from increasing bandwidth, many of these are somewhat newer offerings.  Currently: Bot Manager Standard = Started with just MS Online @ $14K per month in Jul 2017 and added another site in Oct for a total of $22,500 per month To upgrade to Bot Manager Premier + Mobile SDK + Rapid Response + Client Reputation with increase in bandwidth from 75TB to 100TB = another $24K per month + a one-time $25K implementation fee. This is to cover all in scope sites (not just the current 2). To add Visitor Prioritization = $3800 per month To increase Ion and Kona from $75TB to $100TB =  another $10K per month (with $.50 per GB overage fee) backdated to January 1. To extend Session Accelerator another year, they will reduce monthly cost from $14K to $7,250 since it is for 1 site only and backdate it to January 1.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Kronos and found the pricing for the core SaaS bundle to be above Fair Market Value (FMV) with room for improvement of up to 24% based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the other add-on software subscriptions are at FMV.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions. ?	The core SaaS bundle is priced at $2.74 per employee, per month (PEPM). The list pricing for this bundle is $7 PEPM, which is an increase from the previous list price of $5 PEPM.  o	For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $1.82 PEPM. This translates to savings of $13,800 per month. ?	The Workforce Activities software is priced at $0.45 PEPM. This price is at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	The Workforce Accruals software is priced at $0.26, which is also at FMV. ?	 The Workforce Record Manager is priced at $0.15. For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $0.11 PEPM. This translates to savings of $600 per month. ?	WF Analytics is priced at $0.86 PEPM. This price is FMV. ?	The overall savings based on NPI?s recommended target price translates to $14,400 per month and $358,560 for the 36-month period with a 24-month ramp up.  Other considerations: ?	NPI has not seen Kronos insist on prepayment for the subscriptions. This is certainly negotiable. ?	However, NPI has also not seen Kronos concede to a ramp up pricing, which reduces the revenue in years 1 and 2.  o	Most SaaS vendors prefer an even annual or front-loaded pricing/revenue model and a 3-5 year commitment.  A ramp up licensing scenario inevitably results in higher pricing per license for the customer and higher TCO over 5 years. However, if a customer has strong leverage (for example, if the customer already has perpetual licenses and does not need the licenses since they don?t require upgrades, and therefore would not be likely to make the purchase at all, or if there is competition in the mix), the vendor will concede to these terms. ?	A target of $2 per employee per month for Time and Accruals for 15,000 employees is achievable. The motivation by Kronos to provide a larger incentive for a large employee base is in line with their marketing approach, which highly touts the number of users/employees that use or are managed through KRONOS cloud. ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially on the add-on subscriptions.

file_info.name: Webster Vormetric Token Server Client 1YR Quote - #50555 v1[2].pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Robert, Hey there.  Must be something about this space and how their vendors conceal their list prices.  I guess as security companies they are practicing what they preach ?.  While we?ve seen several Vormetric deals the SKUs often vary across our reviews and they don?t always show list pricing.  However, they do at times so we know they will provide it if asked.  Again, we got resourceful and tried to work through this and also leverage some public data.  I just got to a point where I think we are better off asking Trace3 to show add more transparency in their quote.  I think the SKUs are correct so that?s some good news.  The attached Excel file shows the work in progress.  I haven?t suggested targets yet since there?s too many open items.  Of note:  ?	VOR-TE ? listed for $6K about 12 months ago.  Let?s confirm this.  You may also want to take this time and ask about the bundled list price (and even net) that includes the Transparent Encryption Agent, Application Encryption and Tokenization. Another client bought the bundle (at MUCH bigger volumes ? 1,500) but paid $1K for each bundle. Webster is at $3,150 for just TE. You?re at less than 2% of their volume but I?m curious what they?d offer and it may be good to know if that?s on your roadmap.  If only two of these are of interest I don?t think they have a bundle for that but you could ask.  This other client didn?t have the Tokenization Client license so perhaps they?re configuring their solution differently than Webster. o	The quantity of 25 for VOR-TE and VOR-VTE-LTD brings up another topic to push for clarity on. From the limited pricing I?ve seen there?s a clear example on their Data Encryption Agent license where the first one is $6K, ten cost $45K (or $4500 each) and 25 cost $100K or $4K each).  I think now is the time to make sure they show you what all these tiers look like to ensure you?re getting both the programmatic volume discount and the additional discount you?d get on a first-time competitive buy. ?	VOR-VTE-LTD ? the one item I had no traction finding list pricing for ?	VOR-TOKEN ? educated guess is this is also at $6K list ?	The DSM Enterprise Parts I believe have the same list and they just discount non-prod more than prod.  The list could be $30K or something north of $40K.  That reflects quite a swing in discounting so it is a key item to validate.  I?d be appreciative if you could also ask them for the list price of the physical DSM Enterprise equivalent. Perhaps you could say someone asked about that option and you wanted to understand it more.  I think it lists for at least $5K more. ?	On the Support side, Standard is always 18% of net and Premium is 22%.  We?ve never seen Premium+ which is what?s reflected on your quote.  Below is a picture of the comparison of these two in their SW Lic Agreement.  They?re offering the + at 23% of the total hardware and software net.  Doesn?t sound like a bad uplift over Premium assuming you?re getting something more.  Consider your options there.  ?	Some services details are shown. o	Vormetric?s rack rate is $2,500/day. VOR-PRO-SERV is the SKU.  We?ve seen it not discounted typically.   o	Program Review and Roadmap Dev seems like it?ll be work done by Trace3 for a fixed fee of $51,800. They mention a Security Architect and PM. No hours are mentioned.   We?d expect this to reflect some hourly estimate applied against the rates and then a 10-20% uplift for the risk involved with a fixed fee engagement.  Maybe ask about a T&M to get exposure to the rates and effort. o	Product Install appears to be Vormetric people.  Offered at $12,500 that?s 5 days at their $2,500 rack rate.  That number of days doesn?t seem bloated.  In a competitive environment feels like that could be something to push for free. o	Tech Design and Impl - $67,500 for 6 weeks. That?s $11,250 a week or $2,250 a day if one resource which is exactly 10% off the Vormetric daily rack rate of $2500. It includes an Architect, Engineer and PM but again is offered at a fixed amount so no effort/hours noted.  Push for some clarity around this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric. On the one hand you?d expect a lower rate with Trace3 but oftentimes partners bring more senior resources to bear than the OEM/Publisher. o	Roadmap and Mentoring is offered at $51,800 and is T&M. It is largely an architect at $300.  We can benchmark this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric.  We?ll work on what we can but let me know if you expect to reach out to Trace3 for this additional detail.  Now is the time and no reason to spend this money if there?s any questions about the transparency of the offer.  Also, do you expect future growth.  Getting transparency now sets you up for that.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.  Final quote increased in size largely due to Token Server Client item growing from 1 to 18.  The only reductions appear to be on the DSM units as both the Prod and non prod had reductions.  Maintenance also dropped from 23% to 20%.   The initial quotes didn't clear show all the non prod info that was shown in the final.  Estimating savings and new baseline but not overthinking it.  Future folks should use the final docs (also some list pricing in XLS) and new SME.
deal_metadata.description: Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.  Reply to first offer: We?ll take a look.  From my first pass I can tell you the Trace3 (Vormetric) SOW is too light on details.  There?s a lot ($530K+) of services with no resources, rates and hours so it can?t be benchmarked.  There?s also a sizable placeholder for hardware, licenses and support for $501K with no detail.  Trace3 needs to provide a Vormetric quote showing all the usual details (SKUs, list, net, quantities).  Webster came back on 3/13 with a revised spreadsheet showing list pricing.  Some sizable increases. Sent a second round of feedback on 3/14. see email.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Aspect Software WCM expansion - J. Dudash
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Jennifer, Thanks for sending your add-on license purchase for review.  I see Aspect is using the same negotiation tactic as they did in 2016 where they started with a 30% discount and ended with 40%.  That purchase had an extended list price of $300K for licenses while this purchase is at $235K.  The 5% uplift is possible as our last review for Aspect was right at the end of 2017 and Aspect doesn?t publish a price list.  That 2017 review had list prices that matched the ones being shown/offered to Progressive.   They hadn?t raised their prices in a couple of years and my guess is just before your last purchase in 2016 there had been a recent 10% increase.  The Aspect story has changed little: they?ve moved from leader to niche player in the latest Gartner report (Feb 2018), mainly focused on existing clients.  Progressive in effect are investing dollars into the enhancement of a SaaS solution you don't own.  My SME advises postponing the buy if possible (maybe not feasible) and survey the market for better solution and a lower TCO.  Of course, this is a mouthful and easier said than done.  However, it could generate some talking points in support of your negotiation.  Ask about the R&D into the perpetual license solution.  The talent on the R&D and Support side can?t be focused on Progressive?s solution.  Push hard for specifics.  Has the release schedule slowed down?  Less in each release?  Any more major releases expected?  While leverage may not be on your side, this allows you to push for better pricing on this as you double your footprint.  It just makes common sense.  If they indicate less R&D and fewer releases then why are they trying to raise prices.  Feels like they are milking the old product while they furiously work on their SaaS offering.   Focusing back on the commercial terms, we continue to expect to see Mission Critical Maintenance at 22% and Business Day Maintenance at 20%.  This is where Progressive landed in 2016 and that?s the current offer.  It is small dollars but you?d kind of expect the gap to be bigger i.e., Business Day to be 18% vs. MC at 22%; however, they?ve been consistent.  Along the same negotiation points noted above, if Progressive feels as though support is deteriorating and software releases are less robust and fewer and far between that is reason enough to push for a lower percentage.  Maintenance costs are comprised of phone support and software releases and patches so if any aspect is weakening then customers have the right to push for relief.  During our last review we noted that they just emerged from bankruptcy and were struggling to rollout  a cloud offering.  We suggested a 50%+ target but the leverage worked against Progressive and you topped off at 40%.  This feels like a rinse-and-repeat scenario.  40% feels a bit low in light of market conditions and the 2x growth.  NPI suggests targeting a 50% final discount which typically requires pushing for more than that to allow for the compromise.  Achieving a 50% discount drives $23,500 out of license spend and about $3,500 out of support. Driving Mission Critical support to 20% would save an additional $2500.
deal_metadata.description: I am working on the attached deal I hope you can benchmark to ensure this is a good deal for 400 license and the associated maintenance.  I was able to negotiate them down from 30% to 40% off list price. This also appears to be the same purchase price we paid at the end of 2016, even though they noted an increase of 5% in 2018. I am not seeing that represented in the pricing.  Note from Karen: Savings achieved $28,450.40.  NO FINAL DOCS OR SPECIFICS.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAS renewal and Prof. Services Rates
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Here are some thoughts on the SAS renewal:  NPI has observed that SAS is a vendor who likes to keep customers in the dark about their pricing.  They have different list pricing depending on the volume of spend and they are very inconsistent in the pricing they will agree to.  What this does tell us is that SAS pricing is highly negotiable.  We know that test environments are typically 25% of the production costs and list prices for Dev and Test are based on a percentage of the list price for the production environment.  There doesn?t seem to be quite enough information in this proposal (email) for NPI to provide a detailed benchmark.  Below are some thoughts and recommendations that VSP will want to consider.  ?	At first blush, the descriptions in the email you attached aren?t detailed enough for us to be able to calculate list price.  Additionally, there are no productions fees in the email description, so we are not able to determine list price and discount percentages for the Dev and Test environments.  If we have better descriptions of the licenses or - better still - if we have SKUs we can usually figure out list price and discount percentages for FYFs.  Having said that, Dev and Test environments list pricing tends to be a percentage of the production costs.  NOTE: NPI strongly recommends that you ask for list price on the FYFs so we can be sure we have the correct discount percentage.  SAS will share list price if pushed. ?	We like to see the first-RYF to be between 27-35% of the FYF.  VSP is at 28% for both the Dev and Test licenses, so that is good, however:   o	We still want to gauge the discount of the FYF fees even though we like 28% for the RYF. Often we see that a good RYF percentage is due to the first year fee is not well discounted. ?	We also like to see the third year fee to be 3% over the second year fee.  SAS has offered 5%.  That?s a standard starting offer.  Target 3%. ?	How big is VSPs overall footprint with SAS?  Can you provide financial details around your production environment?  That helps us adjust our targeted discount for this particular transaction.  It is largely handled standalone by SAS but the big picture should be considered especially if it benefits VSPs. ?	The professional services rates are actually very good in the SOW.  We usually don?t see large market variances in SAS professional services rates. o	The technical consultant is billed at $195. We see market rates between $195 - $200 per hour. o	Technical architects typically bill at $225 per hour. o	The Project Manager is billed at $180. We typically see this at $200 per hour.  If you can provide a bit more detail, I am confident that we can offer more detailed analysis of your SAS pricing.
deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarking on SAS professional services?  This is the same price we paid for the same service previously on supplement 5.  We have received an email quote last winter with the attached pricing range.    UPDATE 4/8/2018: SAS is still on-going and has been delayed.   The professional services are at your market rate stated below at $195. The biggest movement is that I negotiated free development and test licenses. A savings of about $338K.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hey Robert, Prior to you sending the revised Safenet offer we had taken some time to try and find all the list prices as they weren?t provided in the quote.  That history can be helpful as you continue negotiations. The prior two offers were at poor discounts of 0-2%.  We couldn?t validate a couple of items.  They have a crazy number of SKUs complicated by a series of acquisitions (Aladdin, Safenet, Gemalto, and Thales (who also own competitor Vormetric)).  I?m attaching our efforts which can be found in the first worksheet.  The feedback was going to be this looks to be budgetary (we hope) and Webster should insist that list prices be provided and also ask for list prices for tiers below and above the quantities you are buying for the Tokenization Manager licenses.  The ?2? at the end of the SKU refers to the second volume tier 11-20.    The recent quote had different SKUs.  Again, I think we figured out the list prices but it requires some art and science.  The two prior quotes totaled about $300K.  The latest is around $700K.  The discount appears to have increased to just under 12%.  See the second worksheet in the Excel file.  I believe all the three-year maintenance items list for 24% of the hw/sw list cost each year and are discounted the same 12% (so they remain at 24% of the NET cost).  Plus Maintenance is priced at 24% and Extended Maintenance (not what Webster is buying) is priced at 18%.  I suggest Webster ask for list prices to validate NPIs figures.  If NPIs list prices are incorrect we?ll want to revisit this review.  At this spend level and in a competitive environment, 30% would be the minimum discount NPI suggests Webster should target and 40%-50% is not an unrealistic goal.  NPI hasn?t seen a ton of SafeNet deals but have seen several smaller ones that landed in the mid to high 20s making 30% our floor.  We have fewer data points on the top end.  We?ve seen a million plus purchase comprised largely of subscriptions at over 60%.  This purchase has a different dollar profile and product mix but it helped to form our ceiling.  NPI can?t provide a narrower target than 35-50% as our estimate of FMV.  With confidence we believe anything under 30% is NOT FMV.  Anything into the 50s at this dollar size feels stellar and a great outcome.  That leaves the wide swath of 30-50%.  Based on our data and this sizable purchase I bumped up the bottom of the range to 35%.  The goal would be to keep Maintenance at the same 24% of the net spend with a best case outcome of 22%.  NPI has seen SafeNet discount hw/sw considerably more than Maintenance.  I?ve included the math supporting our low and high targets in the second worksheet.  If we get any more late-breaking data points I?ll share that info.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.
deal_metadata.description: Gregg,  Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.     High Level Requirements:   ?	Generating keys for different cryptographic systems and different applications.  ?	Generating and obtaining public keys.  ?	Distributing keys to intended users, including how keys should be activated when received.  ?	Storing keys, including how authorized users obtain access to keys.  ?	Changing or updating keys, including rules on when and how keys should be changed.  ?	Addressing compromised keys.  ?	Archiving, revoking, and specifying how keys should be withdrawn or deactivated.  ?	Recovering keys that are lost or corrupted as part of business continuity management.  ?	Reporting and logging the auditing of key management-related activities.  ?	Instituting defined activation and deactivation dates, and limiting the usage period of keys. ?	Integrates with Netapp, Sales Force and has a rest API to program with Webster custom applications.  I have attached the two proposals we received.  Would you please review and come back to us with feedback?  If you can turn this around quickly, it would be appreciated.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BJC?s combined hardware and software maintenance and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV) for the overall spend.  The majority of the spend falls under XIV storage, with XIV hardware (26%) and software (39%) comprising the majority of the spend (65%).  That ratio goes up further (71%) if Technical Advisors related to XIV are included (6%).  Analyzing hardware in this space requires greater granular configuration data for the equipment covered and can be an exacting process.  BJC?s configuration data may sway FMV analysis slightly, but there are sufficient commoditized hardware, software, and service items in the provided spreadsheet to complete a more exacting assessment.  Current price increases over the previous 5-Year term are within FMV guidelines that target anything lower than 5% annual, with BJC?s totals at nearly 4% when comparing previous and current 5-year totals.  While the overall spend is within FMV guidelines, XIV and Pseries hardware are ripe for third-party maintainers once assets are off initial support, and as a result IBM faces pricing pressure in the current market.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	BJC?s pricing is at FMV for bottom-line costs, even with increase over previous annual rates.  Addressing cost increases that did exceed 20% is the first recommended savings target, as FMV rate increase of 15% (3% per year of the previous term) are more in line with this sizable operating cost.   ?	Equipment nearly end of life or items that may otherwise be covered by SMS can be targeted as areas for most aggressive savings expectations.  Got final doc.  Did a serial number search and compared final cost to the three year offer.  The spreadsheet had a bunch of scenarios.  Seemed like the right comparison.  Shown in Excel.  Changed contract to 8908 since we didn't get to show this in prior year and was so close. likely didn't get acted on til after new contract started.
deal_metadata.description: BJC is renewing a 5-year maintenance agreement with IBM around hardware and associated software titles.

Upon review, we determined your current pricing to be FMV as you should feel confident in moving forward.   ?	As it stands, your quantity of 8,450 puts you in 8th pricing group (5,001 ? 10,000).  o	Pricing does get better as you move up groups but there is an obvious increased multiplier making the overall cost higher. o	Since your initial TAPADS purchase in 2016, your YoY increase has consistently remained at ~1%.  Year	Total	Increase 2016	$105,158	N/A 2017	$106,629	1.4% 2018	$107,830	1.1%  ?	Platinum Support is at ~10% of license spend and is considered FMV. o	Proofpoint will include Platinum Support at no charge when bought as SaaS, but not otherwise. This is the case with the current quote and past reviews performed by NPI. This is something to consider as it could result in significant savings across your current landscape.  Description	Part #	QTY	Unit Price	Ext Price Proofpoint Targeted Attack Protection Attachment Defense Virtual Edition	PP-M-TAPADS-V-D-108	8450	$11.60	$98,020 Proofpoint Platinum Support - technical support - 1 year	PP-SUP-PS-12	1	$9,810	$9,810 				$107,830  It is worth considering a consolidation of current contracts under one to allow for more consistent discounting, transparency, and prevent negotiating as frequently. If CAMC really wants to gain the attention of Proofpoint, you should consider a multi-year agreement. In NPI?s experience, CAMC could reduce the year over year costs by as much as 35% with a multi-year commitment with the right messaging and timing.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Kronos and found the pricing for the core SaaS bundle to be above Fair Market Value (FMV) with room for improvement of up to 24% based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the other add-on software subscriptions are at FMV.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions. ?	The core SaaS bundle is priced at $2.74 per employee, per month (PEPM). The list pricing for this bundle is $7 PEPM, which is an increase from the previous list price of $5 PEPM.  o	For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $1.82 PEPM. This translates to savings of $13,800 per month. ?	The Workforce Activities software is priced at $0.45 PEPM. This price is at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	The Workforce Accruals software is priced at $0.26, which is also at FMV. ?	 The Workforce Record Manager is priced at $0.15. For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $0.11 PEPM. This translates to savings of $600 per month. ?	WF Analytics is priced at $0.86 PEPM. This price is FMV. ?	The overall savings based on NPI?s recommended target price translates to $14,400 per month and $358,560 for the 36-month period with a 24-month ramp up.  Other considerations: ?	NPI has not seen Kronos insist on prepayment for the subscriptions. This is certainly negotiable. ?	However, NPI has also not seen Kronos concede to a ramp up pricing, which reduces the revenue in years 1 and 2.  o	Most SaaS vendors prefer an even annual or front-loaded pricing/revenue model and a 3-5 year commitment.  A ramp up licensing scenario inevitably results in higher pricing per license for the customer and higher TCO over 5 years. However, if a customer has strong leverage (for example, if the customer already has perpetual licenses and does not need the licenses since they don?t require upgrades, and therefore would not be likely to make the purchase at all, or if there is competition in the mix), the vendor will concede to these terms. ?	A target of $2 per employee per month for Time and Accruals for 15,000 employees is achievable. The motivation by Kronos to provide a larger incentive for a large employee base is in line with their marketing approach, which highly touts the number of users/employees that use or are managed through KRONOS cloud. ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially on the add-on subscriptions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: They only went with Timekeeping, Accruals and Activities, so reflected that in the Financial Summary
deal_metadata.description: Flowserve is looking to purchase various Kronos SaaS subscriptions. they are looking at an 18 -24 month ramp-up.   don?t want to do any pre-payments to Kronos as is recommended in the Kronos pricing model. Our preference is to do a 20% tiered pricing model. The final cost that Doug wants to pay is $2.00 per employee per month for Time and Accruals. The final cost for activities (SFDC) is $0.40 per employee per month.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAS renewal and Prof. Services Rates
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Here are some thoughts on the SAS renewal:  NPI has observed that SAS is a vendor who likes to keep customers in the dark about their pricing.  They have different list pricing depending on the volume of spend and they are very inconsistent in the pricing they will agree to.  What this does tell us is that SAS pricing is highly negotiable.  We know that test environments are typically 25% of the production costs and list prices for Dev and Test are based on a percentage of the list price for the production environment.  There doesn?t seem to be quite enough information in this proposal (email) for NPI to provide a detailed benchmark.  Below are some thoughts and recommendations that VSP will want to consider.  ?	At first blush, the descriptions in the email you attached aren?t detailed enough for us to be able to calculate list price.  Additionally, there are no productions fees in the email description, so we are not able to determine list price and discount percentages for the Dev and Test environments.  If we have better descriptions of the licenses or - better still - if we have SKUs we can usually figure out list price and discount percentages for FYFs.  Having said that, Dev and Test environments list pricing tends to be a percentage of the production costs.  NOTE: NPI strongly recommends that you ask for list price on the FYFs so we can be sure we have the correct discount percentage.  SAS will share list price if pushed. ?	We like to see the first-RYF to be between 27-35% of the FYF.  VSP is at 28% for both the Dev and Test licenses, so that is good, however:   o	We still want to gauge the discount of the FYF fees even though we like 28% for the RYF. Often we see that a good RYF percentage is due to the first year fee is not well discounted. ?	We also like to see the third year fee to be 3% over the second year fee.  SAS has offered 5%.  That?s a standard starting offer.  Target 3%. ?	How big is VSPs overall footprint with SAS?  Can you provide financial details around your production environment?  That helps us adjust our targeted discount for this particular transaction.  It is largely handled standalone by SAS but the big picture should be considered especially if it benefits VSPs. ?	The professional services rates are actually very good in the SOW.  We usually don?t see large market variances in SAS professional services rates. o	The technical consultant is billed at $195. We see market rates between $195 - $200 per hour. o	Technical architects typically bill at $225 per hour. o	The Project Manager is billed at $180. We typically see this at $200 per hour.  If you can provide a bit more detail, I am confident that we can offer more detailed analysis of your SAS pricing.
deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarking on SAS professional services?  This is the same price we paid for the same service previously on supplement 5.  We have received an email quote last winter with the attached pricing range.    UPDATE 4/8/2018: SAS is still on-going and has been delayed.   The professional services are at your market rate stated below at $195. The biggest movement is that I negotiated free development and test licenses. A savings of about $338K.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Initial feedback delivered on 3/9.  NPI identified significant cost differences in power.  Suggested Shelter focus on rationalizing power costs before moving on.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: IBM, their path was $2.4, 5 years. Went back to other companies. Looked at all the incidental charges. IBM simplified down to $1.2 and threw in Z13 (were on 196). They are leasing.
deal_metadata.description: Customer submitted an overview (Excel) evaluation on 2/27 but NPI stated that was incomplete and asked for supporting documents.  Supporting documents were sent on 3/5/2018.  Shelter has existing DR data center with IBM in Boulder, CO.  DR costs include both data center cost and mainframe rental.  Shelter solicited bids from IBM for the following: renew and upgrade or bring their own.  Shelter also sought bids from Iron Mountain and Cavern Technologies in Kansas area for data center space only.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: In summary, the proposed pricing from Adobe is at the low end of the range of Fair Market Value as compared to similar market transactions.  NPI reviewed the original Adobe Analytics purchase for Intuit (In June 2016).  Adobe had proposed pricing of $28 for 90 Billion server calls and $25 for 100 Billion server calls per year. NPI had recommended targets of $25 for 90 billion server calls and $23 for 100 billion server calls which targets Intuit achieved at the time resulting in savings of $233K for 1 year.  In a subsequent renewal early last year, the pricing has remained flat at $23 for 100 Billion server calls.  Adobe Analytics Changes   Adobe previously offered Analytics in two editions, standard and premium.  ?	Adobe has repackaged the Analytics Cloud (announced March 2017) and now offers three editions: Select, Prime and Ultimate. The license metric continues to be Million SERVER CALLS Per Month. Each product increases in functionality and price from Select to Prime to Ultimate. ?	Previously, secondary calls cost 50% of Primary server calls, but that is no longer the case. Now, both primary and secondary calls have the same cost and count towards the total calls. ?	Adobe increased the price for all of their analytics solutions this year when they introduced the three new analytics products. ?	Based on Intuit's usage of Adobe Analytics and price point, Intuit has been offered the Prime product for this renewal.  Price Breakdown     ?	It is common for Adobe to offer pricing tiers like the offered table for companies to project their spend as they grow.  Typically Adobe will offer 3 options - they have offered seven options in this proposal, which is generous.   ?	Intuit is being offered great pricing on Adobe Analytics Prime. This pricing is likely to have had not only management exception approval but also executive approval. Intuit?s Adobe rep likely had to fight a battle internally to get this pricing approved.    Recommendation ?	Overall, NPI believes that Intuit has received great pricing from Adobe for the Analytics Prime and the pricing has remained flat since 2016/2017.  ?	The Sitecat Data Feed is priced at $1,350 CPMM. NPI recommends a pricing of $1250 CPMM which translates to savings of $14,400 per year. ?	At this level of spend, Intuit can request free training and free passes to Adobe Summit.  FINAL UPDATE: Great news, we were able to negotiate our pricing further to 21.25 for 120B primary server calls (price intended for 150B) and continue to pay 11.50 for secondary postponing the increase in price for secondary. Thank you!
deal_metadata.description: NPI reviewed the original Adobe Analytics purchase for Intuit (In June 2016). Adobe had proposed pricing of $28 for 90 Billion server calls and $25 for 100 Billion server calls per year. NPI had recommended targets of $25 for 90 billion server calls and $23 for 100 billion server calls which targets Intuit achieved at the time resulting in savings of $233K for 1 year.  In a subsequent renewal early last year, the pricing has remained flat at $23 for 100 Billion server calls.

NPI has seen SafeNet discount hw/sw considerably more than Maintenance.  I?ve included the math supporting our low and high targets in the second worksheet.  If we get any more late-breaking data points I?ll share that info.

Changing or updating keys, including rules on when and how keys should be changed.  ?	Addressing compromised keys.  ?	Archiving, revoking, and specifying how keys should be withdrawn or deactivated.  ?	Recovering keys that are lost or corrupted as part of business continuity management.  ? Would you please review and come back to us with feedback?  If you can turn this around quickly, it would be appreciated.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for checking in, and thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  I ran this past our Microsoft team and we have a bit of feedback for you.  This did not lend itself to a full FMV document, but if you need a more formal document, I can put something together for you.  ?	Overall, the discounting on years 1 & 2, at ~39% is some of the best discounting we?ve seen.  This is a Corporate VP level discount within Microsoft. o	We have other, larger Microsoft clients that are not able to get to that discount level. o	We suspect that a combination of a) your relatively low dollar commit, b) only purchasing Core CAL?s, and c) Chico?s next big purchase will be in 2-years with the EA renewal, makes Chico?s a ?target for opportunity? within Microsoft.  Microsoft will be looking to significantly increase the revenue they get from Chico?s, either by adding on new products, or significantly reducing your discount levels at the time of the EA renewal. ?	It is common that Microsoft is trying to ramp down the 3rd year discount to 20%.  NPI recommends that you push hard for consistency across all 3-years. ?	You will want to be sure to have a ?Not to Exceed? (NTE) clause added to this contract so that the renewal cost does not exceed either CPI or CAGR.  We recommend that you target a NTE 3% increase (over 3-years), but Microsoft will most likely settle on 6% - 10%. ?	Chico?s is receiving solid additional funding in Deployment Funds, CSM, and Fast Track, etc.  There may be even more funding available, but Chico?s would have to tie it to some specific project.  So, overall, Year 1 & 2 pricing are very good.  We recommend that you push for 3rd year consistency and add the NTE.  At that point, Chico?s could move forward with confidence on this purchase.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hey Robert, Prior to you sending the revised Safenet offer we had taken some time to try and find all the list prices as they weren?t provided in the quote.  That history can be helpful as you continue negotiations. The prior two offers were at poor discounts of 0-2%.  We couldn?t validate a couple of items.  They have a crazy number of SKUs complicated by a series of acquisitions (Aladdin, Safenet, Gemalto, and Thales (who also own competitor Vormetric)).  I?m attaching our efforts which can be found in the first worksheet.  The feedback was going to be this looks to be budgetary (we hope) and Webster should insist that list prices be provided and also ask for list prices for tiers below and above the quantities you are buying for the Tokenization Manager licenses.  The ?2? at the end of the SKU refers to the second volume tier 11-20.    The recent quote had different SKUs.  Again, I think we figured out the list prices but it requires some art and science.  The two prior quotes totaled about $300K.  The latest is around $700K.  The discount appears to have increased to just under 12%.  See the second worksheet in the Excel file.  I believe all the three-year maintenance items list for 24% of the hw/sw list cost each year and are discounted the same 12% (so they remain at 24% of the NET cost).  Plus Maintenance is priced at 24% and Extended Maintenance (not what Webster is buying) is priced at 18%.  I suggest Webster ask for list prices to validate NPIs figures.  If NPIs list prices are incorrect we?ll want to revisit this review.  At this spend level and in a competitive environment, 30% would be the minimum discount NPI suggests Webster should target and 40%-50% is not an unrealistic goal.  NPI hasn?t seen a ton of SafeNet deals but have seen several smaller ones that landed in the mid to high 20s making 30% our floor.  We have fewer data points on the top end.  We?ve seen a million plus purchase comprised largely of subscriptions at over 60%.  This purchase has a different dollar profile and product mix but it helped to form our ceiling.  NPI can?t provide a narrower target than 35-50% as our estimate of FMV.  With confidence we believe anything under 30% is NOT FMV.  Anything into the 50s at this dollar size feels stellar and a great outcome.  That leaves the wide swath of 30-50%.  Based on our data and this sizable purchase I bumped up the bottom of the range to 35%.  The goal would be to keep Maintenance at the same 24% of the net spend with a best case outcome of 22%.  NPI has seen SafeNet discount hw/sw considerably more than Maintenance.  I?ve included the math supporting our low and high targets in the second worksheet.  If we get any more late-breaking data points I?ll share that info.
