deal_metadata.current_narrative: Smita has some data that shows the daily rate is slightly less than what we have seen from Verint before.  However, the overall blended rate for this project is $244 / hour.  This is largely because the lowest cost resource is at $225/hour.  From their input, it appear they have a lot of business with Verint and use them either extensively or exclusively for professional services.  Asking for a 10% loyalty discount across the board is not unwarranted.  Other observation.  The resources on this project are a bit skewed.  The PM represents 25.8% of the time, the Solution Delivery Architect represents 22.6%.  This seems very high for both.  We would expect a project like this might only have 10 ? 15% participation by these two resources and the balance divided between the application consultant and systems engineer.  Re-juggling the balance of resources doesn?t really impact the overall cost though since the sdev of rates is only $24/hour.   To Client: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of Verint proposals, many that include professional services so I was able to do some comparative analysis.  The information below did not lend itself to a full FMV report, but if you need this info in a more formal document, I can put that together for you, just let me know.  The feedback on this consultant pricing is mixed: ?	From a high-level perspective looking at the daily rates, this is in line with what we have seen from Verint.  So at a high-level, this pricing is within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  However, ?. ?	Based on your description of the amount of work that VSP has done with Verint, NPI is also looking at the breakdown of hourly rates for this SOW: o	The overall blended hourly rate for this project is $240/hr, which NPI considers to be a little higher than FMV.  A portion of the ?higher than FMV? determination may have something to do with the number of hours for some of the resources ? more on that below. o	The App Consultant and System Engineer are both at $225/hr.  With the amount of spend that VSP has with Verint, NPI believes these rates are a bit high.  We recommend targeting an hourly rate closer to $200/hr, $1600/day. o	The hourly rate for the Project Manager is $237.50, which NPI considers to be a bit higher than FMV.  The hourly rate for the PM should be reduced a bit to $220 - $225 per hour or $1800/day. o	The Solution Architect is priced at $275/hr which NPI also considers to be above FMV for a company with VSP?s Verint spend.  A rate closer to $240 - $250 ($2K/day) would be more in line with market rate. o	Using the target hourly rates above, with the same number of days for each resource, the total price tag would be closer to $54K for this SOW. ?	Another observation that NPI found is that the resources on this project seem to be a bit skewed, based on the resource make-up that we have seen on similar projects for other clients.   o	The PM represents 25.4% of the time, the Solution Delivery Architect represents 23.8%.  This seems very high for both.  We would expect a project like this might only have 10 ? 15% participation by these two resources and the balance divided between the application consultant and systems engineer.  NPI recommends that VSP inquire with Verint on this and verify the need for this level of effort for these resources (at these prices).  If it makes sense to reduce the hours for these 2 resources, it could affect overall pricing since these are the most expensive resources.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: We reviewed Mavenlink and Workfront together... VSP went with Workfront - achieves small savings there.    NPI provided feedback via email, see attached.  Not a lot of previous exposure to Mavenlink as it appears more costly than Workfront. Suggested targeting lower cost license (premier) to see $20K reduction in quoted license (enterprise) pricing or even choosing the lower cost item.  NPI recommends that VSP approach Mavenlink with dollar figures instead of discount percentages.  The message to Mavenlink could be something along these lines, ?We had an expectation ? and set our budget accordingly ? that we would see a charge more like $30/user/month, or $360/year.  The current offer of $60/user/month is really a non-starter.  This is a competitive bid situation and for the most part, the remaining solutions are technically similar.  So it has come down to a pricing conversation, and Mavenlink is losing ? badly.  We may be able to rob Peter to pay Paul and move some additional money into the budget for this project, but we won?t be able to get near $72K.?  Please let me know if you have any other questions or if you would like to discuss further on a call.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: After our conversation yesterday re: Workfront & Mavenlink, I wanted to follow-up with the feedback on Mavenlink (Workfront feedback sent in different email).  We?ve discussed everything below, but wanted to get it to you in written form so you have it.  Originally, NPI reviewed a 36-month term for Mavenlink Enterprise for 200 users.  In our discussion yesterday, we see that Mavenlink is now offering a 24% discount for 100 users, for a total license cost of $72K.  While NPI has seen fewer Mavenlink deals than we have seen for Workfront, we have enough data points to provide some general market analysis.  NPI believes the target discount for this size deal is closer to 30% - 35% discounting which would result in a total annual license cost of ~$60K.  Regarding the professional services, these are offered with 0% discounting.  It is not unusual that professional services have no discount, but on a deal of this size and term length, it is also reasonable to seek a nominal 5% - 15% discount on these services.  See the table below for an illustration of NPI?s recommended targets:

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the Oracle Fusion Financials Cloud subscription pricing and found the pricing to be within the range of Fair Market Value with room for improvement.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Oracle has offered a blended discount of 54.4% for various Oracle Financial Cloud Services.  o	In the past year, NPI has seen a large discount variance for Oracle Cloud products in general and particularly for the EPM and Financial stacks. o	 NPI has seen discounts vary between 20% and 86%.  o	The typical expected discount range for transactions of this size is 45% - 64.8%.   ?	While the offered discount of 54.4% is within this market range, there is room for improvement in discounting of up to 10%.  Oracle Cloud discounts and pricing are based on factors such as:  ?	Quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customer prior to purchasing the cloud subscription (Oracle provides big incentives when customers are moving from perpetual to cloud licenses, including shelving credits, credits for prepaid maintenance and larger discounts on the cloud products) ?	Customer requirements and negotiation leverage ?	Presence of competitors ?	Senior Management/CXO level connects/escalations  ?	Volume and total spend with Oracle  Oracle?s Cloud Strategy  Oracle is in a full-court press to move as many customers to the Cloud as possible, even though over 70% of their revenue is still from their on-premise install base.  They are "all-in" on the Cloud and are paying their field reps (ASMs) on cloud-only revenue.  Last year, they gave their field ASMs a small SPIFF for on-premise software sales and have moved all of their on-premise sales efforts over to their inside sales group, OracleDirect.   Oracle Pricing/discounting Strategy on Cloud Products  As mentioned earlier, NPI has observed large variances in discounting for Oracle cloud products, but overall, Oracle has been much more conservative from a discount perspective on their SaaS offerings. Typically, any discount for a SaaS tool that is over 65% must be personally reviewed by the SVP of Sales for North America         through a deal review call; historically, very few transactions over 65% have been approved.  There are exceptions to this, of course, but exceptions must be a monster deal and very strategic, an ELA or otherwise.  This is one of the reasons H&R Block has previously received discount quotes for 64%.  It's unlikely that Oracle will go any higher than a 64.9% discount, even if you threaten to walk from the deal (although that may get them to consider).
deal_metadata.description: Oracle Fusion financial purchase. Initial discount of 64.25% for the financial subscription for 5 years. Now 54.4% for 36 month term.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Cindy and Dan chimed in a bit.  Cindy on pricing and Dan on the agreement.  Largely got feedback from Dean who worked their original EA.  Email back: Hi Deidre,- I had a few folks scan and chime in.  Our collective observations: ?	The Product Number for QC5-00002 has not changed since last year but the description has.  The price continues to be $1.50 so no change since last year or from this Feb to March.   The new name is AzureInfoProtPremP1 ShrdSvr ALNG SubsVL MVL PerUsr.  It appears they don?t sell Rights Management as an individual SKU any longer. ?	Level D List is $1.50 under EA and $1.70 under Select.  It can also be bought under their CSP (Cloud Solutions Program) but NPI doesn?t have that Level d list price. ?	The 3R2-00002 product hasn?t changed and is still $4.49.  Perhaps they quoted that if it is on your current EA and the QC5 was overlooked due to the name change. ?	I?m attaching the file you sent with Level D list prices confirmed.  ?	Please note the Windows Skus are PER YEAR vs. the others on here that are per month.  I provided both the platform and non-platform option but the price they listed of 37.92 is the platform price. ?	You will run up against some challenges since each country is buying in their own currency o	Each country has a different price list and you can?t take the US price list and use the latest exchange rate to come up with the right list price for a given country. This is because pricing is set at some point in the past based on an historical exchange rate.  Some will work in Metlife?s favor and some will not. o	They will each have their respective Level D pricing so there?s a common goal.  As you suggest 1,500 is too small of a commitment to expect a discount. NPIs FMV expectation is 0% off. If Metlife commits to some rollout up to around 5,000 agents we could see up to a 10% discount being possible.  Also, 20,000 agents + would have a 20-30% discount target.  o	We don?t think the Japan O365 rollout will help the non-captive agents piece.  I?m assuming you were talking about that vs. Japan buying non-captive agent licenses.  We believe MS will point to rev rec limitations and balk at reducing any set pricing that?s been negotiated for Japan.   o	In some countries Microsoft abstracts themselves from the customer. A partner negotiates with a customer and then negotiated with Microsoft. There?s a disconnect and MS expects to get a certain amount and partners are given some pricing latitude.  Japan, Brazil and Mexico are indirect countries. In these countries you have moving parts of the exchange rate and the indirectness. o	For direct countries, the goal is Level D in their currency.  ?	Also, one of our MS folks shared this: the participation agreement permits the entity that signed the agreement to include non-affiliated entities in their enterprise device/user counts.  A participation agreement is typically used when the parent entity (the ?enrolled affiliate?) has the ability to direct standards for the participants/franchisees/etc.  The enrolled affiliate is responsible both for placing orders for the participant (commonly outsourced to the reseller), and they are responsible for paying the bill.  Microsoft does not invoice the individual participants.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the pricing from Kronos and found the pricing for the core SaaS bundle to be above Fair Market Value (FMV) with room for improvement of up to 24% based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the other add-on software subscriptions are at FMV.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions. ?	The core SaaS bundle is priced at $2.74 per employee, per month (PEPM). The list pricing for this bundle is $7 PEPM, which is an increase from the previous list price of $5 PEPM.  o	For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $1.82 PEPM. This translates to savings of $13,800 per month. ?	The Workforce Activities software is priced at $0.45 PEPM. This price is at Fair Market Value (FMV). ?	The Workforce Accruals software is priced at $0.26, which is also at FMV. ?	 The Workforce Record Manager is priced at $0.15. For 15,000 employees, NPI recommends a target price of $0.11 PEPM. This translates to savings of $600 per month. ?	WF Analytics is priced at $0.86 PEPM. This price is FMV. ?	The overall savings based on NPI?s recommended target price translates to $14,400 per month and $358,560 for the 36-month period with a 24-month ramp up.  Other considerations: ?	NPI has not seen Kronos insist on prepayment for the subscriptions. This is certainly negotiable. ?	However, NPI has also not seen Kronos concede to a ramp up pricing, which reduces the revenue in years 1 and 2.  o	Most SaaS vendors prefer an even annual or front-loaded pricing/revenue model and a 3-5 year commitment.  A ramp up licensing scenario inevitably results in higher pricing per license for the customer and higher TCO over 5 years. However, if a customer has strong leverage (for example, if the customer already has perpetual licenses and does not need the licenses since they don?t require upgrades, and therefore would not be likely to make the purchase at all, or if there is competition in the mix), the vendor will concede to these terms. ?	A target of $2 per employee per month for Time and Accruals for 15,000 employees is achievable. The motivation by Kronos to provide a larger incentive for a large employee base is in line with their marketing approach, which highly touts the number of users/employees that use or are managed through KRONOS cloud. ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially on the add-on subscriptions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: They only went with Timekeeping, Accruals and Activities, so reflected that in the Financial Summary
deal_metadata.description: Flowserve is looking to purchase various Kronos SaaS subscriptions. they are looking at an 18 -24 month ramp-up.   don?t want to do any pre-payments to Kronos as is recommended in the Kronos pricing model. Our preference is to do a 20% tiered pricing model. The final cost that Doug wants to pay is $2.00 per employee per month for Time and Accruals. The final cost for activities (SFDC) is $0.40 per employee per month.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the Oracle Fusion Financials Cloud subscription pricing and found the pricing to be within the range of Fair Market Value with room for improvement.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Oracle has offered a blended discount of 54.4% for various Oracle Financial Cloud Services.  o	In the past year, NPI has seen a large discount variance for Oracle Cloud products in general and particularly for the EPM and Financial stacks. o	 NPI has seen discounts vary between 20% and 86%.  o	The typical expected discount range for transactions of this size is 45% - 64.8%.   ?	While the offered discount of 54.4% is within this market range, there is room for improvement in discounting of up to 10%.  Oracle Cloud discounts and pricing are based on factors such as:  ?	Quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customer prior to purchasing the cloud subscription (Oracle provides big incentives when customers are moving from perpetual to cloud licenses, including shelving credits, credits for prepaid maintenance and larger discounts on the cloud products) ?	Customer requirements and negotiation leverage ?	Presence of competitors ?	Senior Management/CXO level connects/escalations  ?	Volume and total spend with Oracle  Oracle?s Cloud Strategy  Oracle is in a full-court press to move as many customers to the Cloud as possible, even though over 70% of their revenue is still from their on-premise install base.  They are "all-in" on the Cloud and are paying their field reps (ASMs) on cloud-only revenue.  Last year, they gave their field ASMs a small SPIFF for on-premise software sales and have moved all of their on-premise sales efforts over to their inside sales group, OracleDirect.   Oracle Pricing/discounting Strategy on Cloud Products  As mentioned earlier, NPI has observed large variances in discounting for Oracle cloud products, but overall, Oracle has been much more conservative from a discount perspective on their SaaS offerings. Typically, any discount for a SaaS tool that is over 65% must be personally reviewed by the SVP of Sales for North America         through a deal review call; historically, very few transactions over 65% have been approved.  There are exceptions to this, of course, but exceptions must be a monster deal and very strategic, an ELA or otherwise.  This is one of the reasons H&R Block has previously received discount quotes for 64%.  It's unlikely that Oracle will go any higher than a 64.9% discount, even if you threaten to walk from the deal (although that may get them to consider).
deal_metadata.description: Oracle Fusion financial purchase. Initial discount of 64.25% for the financial subscription for 5 years. Now 54.4% for 36 month term.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Cindy and Dan chimed in a bit.  Cindy on pricing and Dan on the agreement.  Largely got feedback from Dean who worked their original EA.  Email back: Hi Deidre,- I had a few folks scan and chime in.  Our collective observations: ?	The Product Number for QC5-00002 has not changed since last year but the description has.  The price continues to be $1.50 so no change since last year or from this Feb to March.   The new name is AzureInfoProtPremP1 ShrdSvr ALNG SubsVL MVL PerUsr.  It appears they don?t sell Rights Management as an individual SKU any longer. ?	Level D List is $1.50 under EA and $1.70 under Select.  It can also be bought under their CSP (Cloud Solutions Program) but NPI doesn?t have that Level d list price. ?	The 3R2-00002 product hasn?t changed and is still $4.49.  Perhaps they quoted that if it is on your current EA and the QC5 was overlooked due to the name change. ?	I?m attaching the file you sent with Level D list prices confirmed.  ?	Please note the Windows Skus are PER YEAR vs. the others on here that are per month.  I provided both the platform and non-platform option but the price they listed of 37.92 is the platform price. ?	You will run up against some challenges since each country is buying in their own currency o	Each country has a different price list and you can?t take the US price list and use the latest exchange rate to come up with the right list price for a given country. This is because pricing is set at some point in the past based on an historical exchange rate.  Some will work in Metlife?s favor and some will not. o	They will each have their respective Level D pricing so there?s a common goal.  As you suggest 1,500 is too small of a commitment to expect a discount. NPIs FMV expectation is 0% off. If Metlife commits to some rollout up to around 5,000 agents we could see up to a 10% discount being possible.  Also, 20,000 agents + would have a 20-30% discount target.  o	We don?t think the Japan O365 rollout will help the non-captive agents piece.  I?m assuming you were talking about that vs. Japan buying non-captive agent licenses.  We believe MS will point to rev rec limitations and balk at reducing any set pricing that?s been negotiated for Japan.   o	In some countries Microsoft abstracts themselves from the customer. A partner negotiates with a customer and then negotiated with Microsoft. There?s a disconnect and MS expects to get a certain amount and partners are given some pricing latitude.  Japan, Brazil and Mexico are indirect countries. In these countries you have moving parts of the exchange rate and the indirectness. o	For direct countries, the goal is Level D in their currency.  ?	Also, one of our MS folks shared this: the participation agreement permits the entity that signed the agreement to include non-affiliated entities in their enterprise device/user counts.  A participation agreement is typically used when the parent entity (the ?enrolled affiliate?) has the ability to direct standards for the participants/franchisees/etc.  The enrolled affiliate is responsible both for placing orders for the participant (commonly outsourced to the reseller), and they are responsible for paying the bill.  Microsoft does not invoice the individual participants.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Microsoft NCA ?  That has been bifurcated into two separate work-streams now with Direct being eminent (Please let it be soo) and still figuring out Indirect   Just going to close with Unknown outcome. will revisit as necessary
deal_metadata.description: Hey Gregg!  We are signing a separate Global Enterprise Agreement Enrollment for what we call our Non-Captive Agents (folks that sell MetLife and other insurance).     1.	Each country will execute a Participation agreement; cut a PO in-country, pay in-country in local currency 2.	We have the US, Iberia (Spain/Portugal), Brazil and Poland are the only countries with approval so far 3.	In nearly a year since we started we haven?t truly grown the numbers some of that was due to MSFT feet dragging in getting a Pilot and Metlife resource commitment to project 4.	MSFT is agreeing to look at the cost as MetLife grows foot print in good faith ? wording to be negotiated  Thoughts? Hey Gregg,   Can you also provide the price increase history for the the Azure Active Directory sku?    Below is the pricing Dean provided last February?.  See emails for a couple tables Deirdre included

deal_metadata.current_narrative: When it comes to Verint (or NICE or Aceyus or any other major IVR player), you have two opportunities to get your pricing right, new purchases, and significant upgrades, and that is it. During normal renewal cycles, these companies historically do not move and typically raise prices that are not locked in, anywhere from 3-8% year over year.  In fact, I just finished a review, for a large Midwest Bank, that has been a customer of NICE Systems for some 8 years, , and with the exception of last year, when they did a major upgrade, and the first two renewals, where they had contractually agreed to maintenance, NICE raised their rates every year. Why not last year, because they did a major upgrade. Fast forward 365 days to this renewal, absolutely no love what so ever, 3% increase, across the board, that was the extent of their favoritism.  I have reviewed both your prior and current offers. The original offer at 60% was actually not a bad starting position, considering the size of your environment, although, the 3% increase on maintenance right out of the gate and the maintenance rate based on an initial 22% were both above FMV for certain. The 2nd iteration, at 63% discount and a flat maintenance rate, is definitely a step in the right direction. Keep it up.   The goal here should be to get closer to 70%, but that is not going to happen now and it is most likely not going to happen quickly. AFI missed the end of Q2, so you may have to hold 60-70 days to get all the way to 69-70% and it is going to take competition. Even if NICE has been eliminated, they have to be played up. Aceyus is another vendor that you can work into the conversation as is Cisco.   We can help you brainstorm and set this in motion if you need assistance.
deal_metadata.description: We are evaluating On-Premise and Saas WFM solutions with Verint and Nice.  Is this an area you could benchmark?  A month later got this:  We opted for Verints? On Premise model and have been through a few rounds of pricing.  Attached is a breakdown of where we ended up.  Can you benchmark the ?Current? pricing.  They came down on licensing, Professional Services and of course Support and Maintenance from the first pricing breakdown also included on the attached.  Thanks for your help.  No interest in SaaS. Asked about that discount to capture it   Seemed to say he had a verbal for 70% on perpetual but Mike did review and landed at 63%.  From Pat: Revised quote is forthcoming but the one you posted is the latest.   The difference will be a license fees drop from $400K to $367, Support and Maintenance drops from $264K over 3 years to $220,200 and Professional Services drops from $125K (estimated) to $112.5  Yes, this is the key stuff; perpetual current state.  We did look at SaaS and it is cost prohibitive mostly because both Verint and Nices? solution are not true SaaS.  They both essentially are hosted in their own environment.  Got a revised quote (mike excel). Quantities changed a little and support was uplifted but generally ended as-is.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  I have had this one for a while and I owe you some feedback.  Since this was a smaller deal and you were out of the office, it got moved a little lower on the priority list.  Typically Oracle renewals are not very exciting.  Often, the best case scenario for a standard Oracle renewal is to have pricing remain flat from the previous year, which is what Oracle is offering in the 18-month proposal.  So NPI considers the 18-month renewal cost to be Fair Market Value (FMV).  In the 24-month and 36-month renewals, Oracle is offering additional discounting on the Multi-tenant service, but the Java CS is maintained at a 30% discount.  NPI sees no reason that the Java service should not also see moderate reductions (or increased discounting) if CNL is going to make a longer-term commitment.  NPI recommends targeting 35% discounting on the Java CS service for the 24-month renewal ? a reduction of ~$2K.  And we recommend targeting 40% discounting on the Java CS service for the 36-month renewal ? a reduction of ~$5K.  The messaging to Oracle is fairly simple, if CNL is going to make a longer-term commitment, it will need to be worth-your-while.  If there is no reduction in the largest cost of this renewal when we make a longer-term commitment, then we may as well just renew for 1-year and see if we will still need these services each year.   UPDATE: Closing as CNL no longer a client.
deal_metadata.description: This is the PAAS which is expiring and is separate from the Oracle Fusion SAAS renewal.    I am OOO until 11/13.  Let me know if you have someone I can work with for these.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Although the initial discounts offered by Dell EMC are respectable, NPI considers other external factors when classifying pricing and those areas should be considered in this negotiation.  NPI would typically expect to see both Hardware and Software discounted at 70% - 72% for deal of this size. Discounting at 69.5% places this pricing in the high range (and almost above FMV). ? Due to the timing of this fiscal year-end opportunity, NPI has increased the FMV target discount an additional percentage point, up to 73%. Achieving this target will result in approximately $51K in savings. ? Support is typically 20% of net HW/SW pricing for THREE years. In this offer, NPI finds that the support pricing is at 21% of HW/SW pricing, but only covers TWO years. ©2017 NPI, LLC. All Rights Reserved. NPI Confidential Information. May Not Be Disclosed to 3rd Parties. Page 3 ? NPI adjusted for this anomaly and increases the target discount to 82% of list for support. This discount results in a number that extrapolates out to 21% for the typical three-year term. Successfully negotiating this topic will result in approximately $39K in savings. ? Professional services is a rarely discounted line item and NPI finds that the small discounts that are seen are typically found in large deployments with large amounts of professional services. o NPI believes that these funds ARE somewhat flexible and because of the small dollar amount, NPI is applying the 23% discount that we periodically find in larger deployments to this proposal. Although this equates to a small $2K in savings, NPI mentions it as another negotiation point for Michael Kors.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: With the close tie to 4 days on site this equates to $2500/day or (if standard not to exceed 10 hour days) $250/hour.  This is not bad for this type of work, especially on a small engagement. Is $8K better, of course.  Agreeing with your comment below, if this is a successful pilot, what is the next iteration? How many days? How many sites? And can this expense be applied to add-on work.  We?ve seen that before and that?s not unreasonable.  Even applying 50% as a compromise.
deal_metadata.description: Gregg, chance to read attached?  $10k?...heard of them before?  Thanks?just if anything pops out, does the cost make sense ? I?d ask that we refund the $10k if we progress with the purchase, etc.  Still open as of 4/9  closed on 11/26. Too small to worry about

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Gentleman, I?ve gotten smarter on this and hope to impart that wisdom to you all.  NPI hasn?t seen this very much but it is an interesting area.  I think understanding what this does is almost as important to the negotiation as understanding your pricing specifically.   I?m hoping this is just round one of feedback and that you have a bit of time to allow me to get smarter on the pricing.  Pardon the informality of bullets but it is the quickest way to share thoughts based on my two SME conversations. Also, this is heavily Pega-focused.  Pega has several product lines.  Their traditional BPM line has been their flagship product.  Individual sales of this are routinely seven figures.  This is a value-driven product and the Account Executives that sell this product are actually somewhat distanced from how it is priced.  Pega attempts to determine the value they will drive (clients should be coached not to let them from a negotiation point of view) and then is fairly challenging to negotiate with. Everything is purpose-based and licensed for a specific use.  The negotiation can be about how to get this as broad as possible.  An average AE has only five named accounts and they land and expand.  18 months ago they bought a company called OpenSpan and this is the RPA stuff that AmFam is looking at now.  It?s being integrated into Pega of course but there?s still remnants of how OpenSpan sold this.  NPI believes this part of their business, unlike the core BPM, is more negotiable.  I?m pretty certain a list price exists for the Robotics products (RPA, RDA and Workforce Intelligence) and it can be benchmarked like most software companies.  This is unlike the core BPM offering from Pega where the value-based approach distances any offer from any of their secretive price lists.  So that?s a bit of a tease as I indicate I think this can be benchmarked but I?m not able to yet.  It does mean it is more negotiable I believe especially since you?re involving competition.  ?	Even though it is the third license mentioned Workforce Intelligence (WI) is likely the first license you?ll use.  You don?t know what you need to fix until you use WI.  This is a small piece of software that Pega wants you to run continuously on everyone?s desk.  It?ll monitor all keystrokes, idle time and system transactions.  Are folks doing a lot of cutting and pasting between applications, for example.  You learn people in call centers are spending x% of time not doing anything, x% copying/pasting...then Pega can figure out dollar amounts you can say if you automate/improve the use of people?s time.   Pega will tell you that as you soon as you do this and things change you will want to keep improving and so you need to keep monitoring.  So WI runs out of the gate and tells you where you can automate. o	This is some key messaging that you will hear from Pega and will need to determine how you want to counter it.  It?ll make a ton of sense when you think about the value of continually monitoring and improving.  Who can question that, right?  However, how comprehensive does the monitoring need to be to find ongoing improvements when you?re paying for a license for each  person being monitored.  You almost have to counter with you don?t want to be overwhelmed with too much intelligence out of WI. o	How comprehensive you are can depend on how diverse or uniform your workforce is.  If you monitor 10 to 20 people per user group that may be enough.  Do you have 3, 7 or 15 groups that seem distinct enough in what they do so that each needs monitoring?   o	Pega will push for very comprehensive coverage during the whole 24 or 36 month term.  There are plenty of customers who will do as much as they can possible do within 18 months.  Every customer is different of course.  Is there so much anticipated improvement from Robotics that 36 months is needed.  My SME told me that EVERYONE overbuys this stuff.  Both in signing up for a term and in the number of licenses since they make you buy them in blocks.  They condition you to buy a year at a time in blocks of at least 200. Just be cognizant of that and consider being more conservative knowing the tendency. o	I gave some thought to how long the RPA/RDA term should be (offered for 24 and 36 months) compared to WI which is offered at 12 and 24 months.  Intuitively it makes sense that you could stop monitoring at some point and start automating. It also makes sense that you could start automating your first round of recommendations (coming out of WI) and then expect to keep monitoring and get additional recommendations. AmFam needs to think about how this may play out.  If you think you only need 12 months of WI or 18 months or maybe you want to run it for 6 months and turn it off for 6 and then back on for 6, this is stuff I?m told you can broach and try to negotiate.  o	NPI is trying to determine list price but I did find some GSA pricing. One month of Cloud, 12 month commit and 100 users was $32/month. AmFam?s offer for 200 users for 12 months is $45.50 (totals $109,200 for a year).  This should tell you there?s sizable room for improvement. Anyone can find this price list. I?m attaching for your convenience.  Real list is not published on their website but consider asking for it.  AmFam doesn?t approach GSA pricing until you buy 1000 users for 24 months. At 200 users for 12 months, achieving GSA pricing saves $36K a year.  Push for increments of 100 users as well. ?	The ratio of 7:1 being allowed using Robotic Units is standard and a nice ?concession?.  I have a GSA price list for Pega and saw that when comparing their RPA and RDA pricing (they are separate products being combined for AmFam) their price ratio was exactly 7:1. o	The flexibility to switch is nice since you don?t know what you don?t know.  Slide 4 gives a good description of RDA vs RPA.  RPA is basically automating processes that don?t have any human intervention.  RDA is adding automation to more people-driven processes.  Using WF helps you understand where you improvements are and these will then require some mix of RPA and RDA licenses. o	NPI prefers to know list price and offer up benchmarks comparing client pricing to other observed market prices.  Since this isn?t an option yet we offer up another GSA comparison.   ?	GSA pricing per RPA for a 1 mo. Term and 12 month commitment is $316.   AmFam?s offer for 50 RPA for 24 months is $368.75 per month.  Again, not a great comparison to GSA.  At 100 units that drops to $287.25 and to $213 for 200 units and a 36 month commitment.  The GSA price didn?t have a volume commitment and was for 12 months.   ?	AmFam?s negotiation will pivot on the term and volume of course.  NPI believes there?s room to leverage competition to push back for a 10-25% improvement depending on the term/quantity mix. ?	Slides 5 and 6 mention a Purpose based license of Pega Platform is included at no charge and there?s no requirement to purchase it.  This is an interesting piece.  The whole reason why they bought OpenSpan is to get these smaller opportunities in front of clients, then they can get you to taste the power of the big Platform and then sell you the $1M+ BPM offering.  Robotics improves existing processes but doesn?t outright transform them.  That?s BPM in a simplistic way.  The Robotics Studio is also included and that?s what?s used to build the Bots.  ?	Here?s a couple interesting links to read about Robotics on their site and the acquisition o	https://www.pega.com/products/pega-7-platform/robotic-automation o	https://www.pega.com/about/news/media-coverage/pegasystems-acquires-robotic-automation-software-provider-openspan  I wanted to share as much as I could today and hope the above helps.  My SMEs didn?t know much about Automation Anywhere.  They did feel it was a less robust platform and if the prices are similar then Pega is the way to go.  We talked about it a bit and since they call stuff differently it is a little hard to know if they?re apples to apples.  None of the different counts/quantities seems to align but a lot of the functionality seemed to overlap.  Analytics Platform sounds a bit like WI. Task Bot and Meta Bot sound like RPA and RDA.  Sample year one totals $225K and there?s a level of RPA/RDA combined with WI that is close to this as well.  My SME thought it was a bit less advanced and AA wants to have someone on site to oversee all this.  He compared this to Pega who offer up free training through 12/31 for one item and other free training online as they want you to be self sufficient  and believe clients can use WI, Robotics Studio and RPA/RDA to be self sufficient.  He didn?t say this exactly but that?s my interpretation.  He said Pega is less klugy.  AA?s attitude is we?ll have someone on site to fix this for you.  You can look at that two ways.  It is nice to have a helping hand but Pega doesn?t think you?ll need it. I need to dig into this comparison a bit more.  Consider asking each vendor to talk about the differences in laymen?s terms.  Increasingly Robotics is going to take on the personality of core Pega BPM. They believe they?re the best and don?t want to leave any money on the table. They will be tough to negotiate with.  Don?t show favoritism.  Get internally aligned so there are no leaks.  Be firm that it doesn?t make sense to monitor the whole population continually, push back on some of the chunkiness of having to buy licenses in blocks, and even indicate aside from budget and competitive elements you found some GSA pricing and AmFam compares unfavorably to it.  ?There?s no way our CIO or CFO are going to approve any offer where that?s the case?
deal_metadata.description: AmFam is looking for guidance on two quotes for RPA ? Robotic Process Automation.    Attached are quotes form the two vendors that are finalists.  See round two.  20% reduction. Free training. WFI  10 month free trial.

I?m pretty certain a list price exists for the Robotics products (RPA, RDA and Workforce Intelligence) and it can be benchmarked like most software companies.  This is unlike the core BPM offering from Pega where the value-based approach distances any offer from any of their secretive price lists.  So that?s a bit of a tease as I indicate I think this can be benchmarked but I?m not able to yet.  It does mean it is more negotiable I believe especially since you?re involving competition.  ?	Even though it is the third license mentioned Workforce Intelligence (WI) is likely the first license you?ll use.  You don?t know what you need to fix until you use WI.  This is a small piece of software that Pega wants you to run continuously on everyone?s desk.  It?ll monitor all keystrokes, idle time and system transactions.  Are folks doing a lot of cutting and pasting between applications, for example.  You learn people in call centers are spending x% of time not doing anything, x% copying/pasting...then Pega can figure out dollar amounts you can say if you automate/improve the use of people?s time.   Pega will tell you that as you soon as you do this and things change you will want to keep improving and so you need to keep monitoring.  So WI runs out of the gate and tells you where you can automate. o	This is some key messaging that you will hear from Pega and will need to determine how you want to counter it.  It?ll make a ton of sense when you think about the value of continually monitoring and improving.  Who can question that, right?  However, how comprehensive does the monitoring need to be to find ongoing improvements when you?re paying for a license for each  person being monitored.  You almost have to counter with you don?t want to be overwhelmed with too much intelligence out of WI. o	How comprehensive you are can depend on how diverse or uniform your workforce is.  If you monitor 10 to 20 people per user group that may be enough.  Do you have 3, 7 or 15 groups that seem distinct enough in what they do so that each needs monitoring?   o	Pega will push for very comprehensive coverage during the whole 24 or 36 month term.  There are plenty of customers who will do as much as they can possible do within 18 months.  Every customer is different of course.  Is there so much anticipated improvement from Robotics that 36 months is needed.  My SME told me that EVERYONE overbuys this stuff.  Both in signing up for a term and in the number of licenses since they make you buy them in blocks.  They condition you to buy a year at a time in blocks of at least 200. Just be cognizant of that and consider being more conservative knowing the tendency. o	I gave some thought to how long the RPA/RDA term should be (offered for 24 and 36 months) compared to WI which is offered at 12 and 24 months.  Intuitively it makes sense that you could stop monitoring at some point and start automating. It also makes sense that you could start automating your first round of recommendations (coming out of WI) and then expect to keep monitoring and get additional recommendations. AmFam needs to think about how this may play out.  If you think you only need 12 months of WI or 18 months or maybe you want to run it for 6 months and turn it off for 6 and then back on for 6, this is stuff I?m told you can broach and try to negotiate.  o	NPI is trying to determine list price but I did find some GSA pricing. One month of Cloud, 12 month commit and 100 users was $32/month. AmFam?s offer for 200 users for 12 months is $45.50 (totals $109,200 for a year).  This should tell you there?s sizable room for improvement. Anyone can find this price list. I?m attaching for your convenience.  Real list is not published on their website but consider asking for it.  AmFam doesn?t approach GSA pricing until you buy 1000 users for 24 months. At 200 users for 12 months, achieving GSA pricing saves $36K a year.  Push for increments of 100 users as well. ?	The ratio of 7:1 being allowed using Robotic Units is standard and a nice ?concession?.  I have a GSA price list for Pega and saw that when comparing their RPA and RDA pricing (they are separate products being combined for AmFam) their price ratio was exactly 7:1. o	The flexibility to switch is nice since you don?t know what you don?t know.  Slide 4 gives a good description of RDA vs RPA.  RPA is basically automating processes that don?t have any human intervention.  RDA is adding automation to more people-driven processes.  Using WF helps you understand where you improvements are and these will then require some mix of RPA and RDA licenses. o	NPI prefers to know list price and offer up benchmarks comparing client pricing to other observed market prices.  Since this isn?t an option yet we offer up another GSA comparison.   ?	GSA pricing per RPA for a 1 mo. Term and 12 month commitment is $316.   AmFam?s offer for 50 RPA for 24 months is $368.75 per month.  Again, not a great comparison to GSA.  At 100 units that drops to $287.25 and to $213 for 200 units and a 36 month commitment.  The GSA price didn?t have a volume commitment and was for 12 months.   ?	AmFam?s negotiation will pivot on the term and volume of course.  NPI believes there?s room to leverage competition to push back for a 10-25% improvement depending on the term/quantity mix. ?	Slides 5 and 6 mention a Purpose based license of Pega Platform is included at no charge and there?s no requirement to purchase it.  This is an interesting piece.  The whole reason why they bought OpenSpan is to get these smaller opportunities in front of clients, then they can get you to taste the power of the big Platform and then sell you the $1M+ BPM offering.  Robotics improves existing processes but doesn?t outright transform them.  That?s BPM in a simplistic way.  The Robotics Studio is also included and that?s what?s used to build the Bots.  ?	Here?s a couple interesting links to read about Robotics on their site and the acquisition o	https://www.pega.com/products/pega-7-platform/robotic-automation o	https://www.pega.com/about/news/media-coverage/pegasystems-acquires-robotic-automation-software-provider-openspan  I wanted to share as much as I could today and hope the above helps.  My SMEs didn?t know much about Automation Anywhere.  They did feel it was a less robust platform and if the prices are similar then Pega is the way to go.  We talked about it a bit and since they call stuff differently it is a little hard to know if they?re apples to apples.  None of the different counts/quantities seems to align but a lot of the functionality seemed to overlap.  Analytics Platform sounds a bit like WI. Task Bot and Meta Bot sound like RPA and RDA.  Sample year one totals $225K and there?s a level of RPA/RDA combined with WI that is close to this as well.  My SME thought it was a bit less advanced and AA wants to have someone on site to oversee all this.  He compared this to Pega who offer up free training through 12/31 for one item and other free training online as they want you to be self sufficient  and believe clients can use WI, Robotics Studio and RPA/RDA to be self sufficient.  He didn?t say this exactly but that?s my interpretation.  He said Pega is less klugy.  AA?s attitude is we?ll have someone on site to fix this for you.  You can look at that two ways.  It is nice to have a helping hand but Pega doesn?t think you?ll need it. I need to dig into this comparison a bit more.  Consider asking each vendor to talk about the differences in laymen?s terms.  Increasingly Robotics is going to take on the personality of core Pega BPM. They believe they?re the best and don?t want to leave any money on the table. They will be tough to negotiate with.  Don?t show favoritism.  Get internally aligned so there are no leaks.  Be firm that it doesn?t make sense to monitor the whole population continually, push back on some of the chunkiness of having to buy licenses in blocks, and even indicate aside from budget and competitive elements you found some GSA pricing and AmFam compares unfavorably to it.  ?There?s no way our CIO or CFO are going to approve any offer where that?s the case?
deal_metadata.description: AmFam is looking for guidance on two quotes for RPA ? Robotic Process Automation.    Attached are quotes form the two vendors that are finalists.  See round two.  20% reduction. Free training. WFI  10 month free trial.

file_info.name: ISG SOW #25 - Bank of America IBM Benchmark Report - FE.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  As I mentioned, NPI has good amount of data on Coupa, as well as a SME in our Advisor Network who also helps with reviews.  In the interest of a quick turnaround, please see notes below in lieu of a more formal document.    It appears that the document you sent over is a 2-year agreement that you signed last year.  It is not unusual that you are looking to discuss the subscription fees mid-contract because NPI has seen that many SaaS vendors are willing to discuss subscription costs off-cycle.  Sometimes, they will require an extension to the term of the contract, but they will typically agree to discuss the subscription rates.  Price Analysis and Negotiation Strategy First, a bit of history that NPI has seen with Coupa.  Prior to their IPO in October 2016, Coupa?s pricing was truly the wild-wild-west.  It was not uncommon that they would manipulate list pricing to show whatever discount percentage they wanted.  Since the IPO, as a public company with more scrutiny, they have tamed their pricing practices a bit, but NPI would not call it ?stable? pricing.  In September of 2016, Coupa hired Steve Winter, former SAP executive, as their CRO.  Steve has brought SAP?s ?keep?em guessing? pricing methodologies to Coupa.  That is, Coupa will change their pricing roughly every 90-days? maybe not wholesale changes, but name changes and moving ?bundles? around so it is difficult for the market to get a bead on their pricing.  In looking at Chico?s pricing in this 2-year agreement, using list prices that we have seen in other Coupa proposals for the 4 included applications, we believe this proposal is discounted between 35% - 50%.  NPI considers this level of discounting to be in the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  Chico?s may want to ask Coupa for list pricing for this proposal to see what they are claiming is the discount percentage.  Coupa will often push back on providing list price and if they provide it, it will need to be taken with a grain of salt ? see notes above about constant changes in pricing.  Having said the above we would also add that, based on the competitive landscape of the market, NPI believes there may be at least some small savings on this contract.  There are literally hundreds of  vendors that will do ?3-bids and a buy? functionality that Coupa sees as competitors to their S2P environment.  Even though many are not as robust as Coupa, they are credible enough to be a threat.  A message along the lines of, ?Verian (now part of Basware) has been courting us and as we?ve been evaluating their product, it appears it will satisfy most of our requirements at nearly half the cost.?, will get Coupa?s attention.  Other competitors worth mentioning: Jagger (formerly Sciquest), Zycus, Determine, GEP.  If Coupa asks for a target reduction, NPI recommends setting a target of a 20% reduction, but any improvement at all on this pricing is really icing on the cake.  Closing as FMV ... significant scope change - cut user count in half and paying more than initial quote.  Coupa recently (May 2017) acquired a company called Trade Extensions.  Trade Extensions is a top-of-the-line trading platform and significantly improves on the ?3-bids and a buy? functionality.  If Coupa offers to throw Trade Extensions in, NPI considers that a big concession.
deal_metadata.description: Could you review the attached order form for our P2P Coupa Subscription, could you assist in providing a FMV analysis by tomorrow?

file_info.name: BrightEdge Order Form - Vision Service Plan - 7-Mar-2018 - Q037937.1.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this BrightEdge pricing over for NPI to review.  We have only seen a handful of BrightEdge transactions, but I was able to do some comparative analysis on the discount percentage.  Overall, last year?s purchase at 40% discounting is well within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV) for a BrightEdge purchase of this size.  We have actually seen a few larger BrightEdge deals that have maxed out in the mid- 40%?s discounting, so we consider 40% for a $60K list price purchase to be FMV.  Since BrightEdge has held the pricing flat AND included additional Domains and Google Analytics connects, NPI continues to believe that this pricing is well within FMV.  VSP can move forward with confidence on this one.
deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarking on BrightEdge? Supplier raised the price by 8% and is offering the same price as last year if we close this month.  They added 2 free domains on this order.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Findings and Recommendations NPI reviewed REI?s Kronos proposal and found the pricing for the add-on software subscriptions to be Fair Market Value (FMV) based on comparisons to similar transactions. The pricing for the ?Professional and Educational Services? were noted to be Above FMV.  Pricing Analysis ?	Kronos, having successfully transitioned to a pure software-as-a-service (SaaS) provider, delivered strong growth in the Kronos Cloud last year, with their subscription revenue increasing 45 percent.  ?	Kronos is continuing to add hundreds of customers to the Kronos Cloud (both existing customers with Kronos perpetual licenses as well as new customers).  ?	Kronos also appears to have raised the list pricing for a few products.  ?	As is the case with many other SaaS vendors, Kronos has been re-bundling and renaming several products, as well as adding new features and functionality.  ?	Pricing varies based on factors such as total spend, volume, customer requirements and negotiation leverage, and quantity of perpetual licenses owned by the customers prior to signing up for the SaaS subscriptions.   Workforce Budgeting & Analytics Kronos has a large footprint at REI, but even in the context of larger spend the pricing is very good and appears historical pricing has carried to the current proposal before contract consolidation next year. ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be FMV.  o	While Kronos does not publish list pricing, NPI has numerous deals in our database providing the ability to make comparisons, and by our estimates, your quote is discounted at ~80%+ which NPI considers to be solidly FMV. ?	Market range is typically between $.8 and $1.5 so clearly REI is getting solid pricing given these are add-on purchases.   License Type	Qty	Monthly Unit List	List Extended	Quote Unit Price	Quote Extended	Discount Workforce Budgeting	11,500	$5.42	$62,215	$0.50	$5,750 	91% Workforce Analytics for Retail	11,500	$6.66	$57,500	$0.77	$8,855 	88%  Professional Services Kronos itself bills its consultants in the range of $165 - $215 per hour. Kronos rack rates start at $200 per hour (blended). ?	NPI reviewed current pricing as proposed and determined it to be Above FMV. ?	Currently, your blended hourly rate stands at ~$213, which we would expect for someone with far less of a landscape than what REI has. o	NPI provided target discounts as shown in the table below, returning a nominal additional savings of $1,078 (blended rate of ~$180).  SOW - Role	Hours	Rate	Extended	Discount	Target Discount	Target Price	Target Savings Project Manager	4	$200	$800	0%	10%	$720	$80 Technical Consultant	29	$215	$6,235	0%	16%	$5,237	$998 			$7,035		15%		$1,078  Negotiation Leverage and Strategy ?	NPI recommends REI to express disappointment with these rates. Indicate that you have done your market research (talking to colleagues, or a new REI executive who has experience with Kronos consulting), and you were expecting a blended rate closer to $175 - $180 per hour and to match prior contracts.  ?	Kronos rewards customers for buying add-on software and typically offers better pricing and discounts initially for the add-on subscriptions. While that is evident in the subscription add-on, there is room for improvement on hourly rates.   Determined licenses were FMV but install rates were above FMV with targets provided
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from REI:  Have a quote for your review.  We are going to add two modules to our Kronos SaaS contract.  These are Analytics and Budgeting.  The second quote combines both and the total costs are listed as monthly fees.  We are looking for a one year contract that will be rolled up in our SaaS agreement next year.  During that time we will look at some multi-year options to see where we can leverage some cost saving.  The first quote is to install Analytics only.  In conjunction with this purchase we are using Axsium to provide professional services to roll out these two modules.  Let me know what you think.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for checking in, and thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  I ran this past our Microsoft team and we have a bit of feedback for you.  This did not lend itself to a full FMV document, but if you need a more formal document, I can put something together for you.  ?	Overall, the discounting on years 1 & 2, at ~39% is some of the best discounting we?ve seen.  This is a Corporate VP level discount within Microsoft. o	We have other, larger Microsoft clients that are not able to get to that discount level. o	We suspect that a combination of a) your relatively low dollar commit, b) only purchasing Core CAL?s, and c) Chico?s next big purchase will be in 2-years with the EA renewal, makes Chico?s a ?target for opportunity? within Microsoft.  Microsoft will be looking to significantly increase the revenue they get from Chico?s, either by adding on new products, or significantly reducing your discount levels at the time of the EA renewal. ?	It is common that Microsoft is trying to ramp down the 3rd year discount to 20%.  NPI recommends that you push hard for consistency across all 3-years. ?	You will want to be sure to have a ?Not to Exceed? (NTE) clause added to this contract so that the renewal cost does not exceed either CPI or CAGR.  We recommend that you target a NTE 3% increase (over 3-years), but Microsoft will most likely settle on 6% - 10%. ?	Chico?s is receiving solid additional funding in Deployment Funds, CSM, and Fast Track, etc.  There may be even more funding available, but Chico?s would have to tie it to some specific project.  So, overall, Year 1 & 2 pricing are very good.  We recommend that you push for 3rd year consistency and add the NTE.  At that point, Chico?s could move forward with confidence on this purchase.
deal_metadata.description: It has been a while but we have something I would like for you to help provide a FMV analysis on our Microsoft 365 purchase. We are planning on migrating away from Google and to M365 by the end of this year.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Although the initial discounts offered by Dell EMC are respectable, NPI considers other external factors when classifying pricing and those areas should be considered in this negotiation.  NPI would typically expect to see both Hardware and Software discounted at 70% - 72% for deal of this size. Discounting at 69.5% places this pricing in the high range (and almost above FMV). ? Due to the timing of this fiscal year-end opportunity, NPI has increased the FMV target discount an additional percentage point, up to 73%. Achieving this target will result in approximately $51K in savings. ? Support is typically 20% of net HW/SW pricing for THREE years. In this offer, NPI finds that the support pricing is at 21% of HW/SW pricing, but only covers TWO years. ©2017 NPI, LLC. All Rights Reserved. NPI Confidential Information. May Not Be Disclosed to 3rd Parties. Page 3 ? NPI adjusted for this anomaly and increases the target discount to 82% of list for support. This discount results in a number that extrapolates out to 21% for the typical three-year term. Successfully negotiating this topic will result in approximately $39K in savings. ? Professional services is a rarely discounted line item and NPI finds that the small discounts that are seen are typically found in large deployments with large amounts of professional services. o NPI believes that these funds ARE somewhat flexible and because of the small dollar amount, NPI is applying the 23% discount that we periodically find in larger deployments to this proposal. Although this equates to a small $2K in savings, NPI mentions it as another negotiation point for Michael Kors.
deal_metadata.description: They just gave a "Special discount" not broken out by type

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Freddie Mac?s SCE pricing and found it to be above fair market value (FMV) based on comparable Microsoft spends. Discounting is poor in each category for a $2M+ annual spend, and the 0% discount on subscription items is consistent with a 0% rate on subscriptions in Freddie Mac?s larger EAS. The SCE does provide some automatic discounting on perpetual licensing, but at this size of a net spend across multiple agreements, those discounts do not push pricing into the range of FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts off the Level C reference pricing.  Microsoft is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the larger 3-year TCO plus address the financial exposure risks of the SCE?s encompassing licensing rules. ?	NPI recommends getting Microsoft to focus on an even budgetary goal of getting the spend under a $6.75M target for the term ($2.25M annual) in exchange for an expedited deal approval that preserves a March signature timeline. ?	NPI notes that these targets are more conservative to reflect the smaller timeframe available for this deal.  o	More aggressive targets would be appropriate with multiple months available for negotiations, but NPI has seen success even within shorter periods.  o	If Freddie Mac feels the sales team is especially nervous about landing this deal, it is feasible to pursue a more aggressive price target.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: Even with a short month-long timeline, Microsoft upped L/SA, SA, and Subs discounts 6%, 6.5%, and 7% respectively.  Financials and savings reflect the full 3-year spend.    Freddie Mac is reviewing a Microsoft Server and Cloud Enrollment (SCE) proposal set to commence in April 2018.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: It appeared CNMC was getting a 43% discount and we have seen from 51-57%  I negotiated with Cisco directly and they informed me that he List price had gone up substantially.  Trying to find out if that is true.  They also wanted to couple this with a Wireless project that we had not seen.  CNMC was not happy that they tried to couple any additional concessions with that project and do not think they will award Cisco that deal.  The did ultimately come down another 15K for a month end deal.  Waiting to hear if CNMC moved forward with it.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Subsequent overage
deal_metadata.description: This ended up getting negotiated with a Wireless deal and more was given on that.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BJC?s combined hardware and software maintenance and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV) for the overall spend.  The majority of the spend falls under XIV storage, with XIV hardware (26%) and software (39%) comprising the majority of the spend (65%).  That ratio goes up further (71%) if Technical Advisors related to XIV are included (6%).  Analyzing hardware in this space requires greater granular configuration data for the equipment covered and can be an exacting process.  BJC?s configuration data may sway FMV analysis slightly, but there are sufficient commoditized hardware, software, and service items in the provided spreadsheet to complete a more exacting assessment.  Current price increases over the previous 5-Year term are within FMV guidelines that target anything lower than 5% annual, with BJC?s totals at nearly 4% when comparing previous and current 5-year totals.  While the overall spend is within FMV guidelines, XIV and Pseries hardware are ripe for third-party maintainers once assets are off initial support, and as a result IBM faces pricing pressure in the current market.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	BJC?s pricing is at FMV for bottom-line costs, even with increase over previous annual rates.  Addressing cost increases that did exceed 20% is the first recommended savings target, as FMV rate increase of 15% (3% per year of the previous term) are more in line with this sizable operating cost.   ?	Equipment nearly end of life or items that may otherwise be covered by SMS can be targeted as areas for most aggressive savings expectations.  Got final doc.  Did a serial number search and compared final cost to the three year offer.  The spreadsheet had a bunch of scenarios.  Seemed like the right comparison.  Shown in Excel.  Changed contract to 8908 since we didn't get to show this in prior year and was so close. likely didn't get acted on til after new contract started.
deal_metadata.description: BJC is renewing a 5-year maintenance agreement with IBM around hardware and associated software titles.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Initial feedback delivered on 3/9.  NPI identified significant cost differences in power.  Suggested Shelter focus on rationalizing power costs before moving on.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: IBM, their path was $2.4, 5 years. Went back to other companies. Looked at all the incidental charges. IBM simplified down to $1.2 and threw in Z13 (were on 196). They are leasing.
deal_metadata.description: Customer submitted an overview (Excel) evaluation on 2/27 but NPI stated that was incomplete and asked for supporting documents.  Supporting documents were sent on 3/5/2018.  Shelter has existing DR data center with IBM in Boulder, CO.  DR costs include both data center cost and mainframe rental.  Shelter solicited bids from IBM for the following: renew and upgrade or bring their own.  Shelter also sought bids from Iron Mountain and Cavern Technologies in Kansas area for data center space only.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Aspect Software WCM expansion - J. Dudash
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Jennifer, Thanks for sending your add-on license purchase for review.  I see Aspect is using the same negotiation tactic as they did in 2016 where they started with a 30% discount and ended with 40%.  That purchase had an extended list price of $300K for licenses while this purchase is at $235K.  The 5% uplift is possible as our last review for Aspect was right at the end of 2017 and Aspect doesn?t publish a price list.  That 2017 review had list prices that matched the ones being shown/offered to Progressive.   They hadn?t raised their prices in a couple of years and my guess is just before your last purchase in 2016 there had been a recent 10% increase.  The Aspect story has changed little: they?ve moved from leader to niche player in the latest Gartner report (Feb 2018), mainly focused on existing clients.  Progressive in effect are investing dollars into the enhancement of a SaaS solution you don't own.  My SME advises postponing the buy if possible (maybe not feasible) and survey the market for better solution and a lower TCO.  Of course, this is a mouthful and easier said than done.  However, it could generate some talking points in support of your negotiation.  Ask about the R&D into the perpetual license solution.  The talent on the R&D and Support side can?t be focused on Progressive?s solution.  Push hard for specifics.  Has the release schedule slowed down?  Less in each release?  Any more major releases expected?  While leverage may not be on your side, this allows you to push for better pricing on this as you double your footprint.  It just makes common sense.  If they indicate less R&D and fewer releases then why are they trying to raise prices.  Feels like they are milking the old product while they furiously work on their SaaS offering.   Focusing back on the commercial terms, we continue to expect to see Mission Critical Maintenance at 22% and Business Day Maintenance at 20%.  This is where Progressive landed in 2016 and that?s the current offer.  It is small dollars but you?d kind of expect the gap to be bigger i.e., Business Day to be 18% vs. MC at 22%; however, they?ve been consistent.  Along the same negotiation points noted above, if Progressive feels as though support is deteriorating and software releases are less robust and fewer and far between that is reason enough to push for a lower percentage.  Maintenance costs are comprised of phone support and software releases and patches so if any aspect is weakening then customers have the right to push for relief.  During our last review we noted that they just emerged from bankruptcy and were struggling to rollout  a cloud offering.  We suggested a 50%+ target but the leverage worked against Progressive and you topped off at 40%.  This feels like a rinse-and-repeat scenario.  40% feels a bit low in light of market conditions and the 2x growth.  NPI suggests targeting a 50% final discount which typically requires pushing for more than that to allow for the compromise.  Achieving a 50% discount drives $23,500 out of license spend and about $3,500 out of support. Driving Mission Critical support to 20% would save an additional $2500.
deal_metadata.description: I am working on the attached deal I hope you can benchmark to ensure this is a good deal for 400 license and the associated maintenance.  I was able to negotiate them down from 30% to 40% off list price. This also appears to be the same purchase price we paid at the end of 2016, even though they noted an increase of 5% in 2018. I am not seeing that represented in the pricing.  Note from Karen: Savings achieved $28,450.40.  NO FINAL DOCS OR SPECIFICS.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Although the initial discounts offered by Dell EMC are respectable, NPI considers other external factors when classifying pricing and those areas should be considered in this negotiation.  NPI would typically expect to see both Hardware and Software discounted at 70% - 72% for deal of this size. Discounting at 69.5% places this pricing in the high range (and almost above FMV). ? Due to the timing of this fiscal year-end opportunity, NPI has increased the FMV target discount an additional percentage point, up to 73%. Achieving this target will result in approximately $51K in savings. ? Support is typically 20% of net HW/SW pricing for THREE years. In this offer, NPI finds that the support pricing is at 21% of HW/SW pricing, but only covers TWO years. ©2017 NPI, LLC. All Rights Reserved. NPI Confidential Information. May Not Be Disclosed to 3rd Parties. Page 3 ? NPI adjusted for this anomaly and increases the target discount to 82% of list for support. This discount results in a number that extrapolates out to 21% for the typical three-year term. Successfully negotiating this topic will result in approximately $39K in savings. ? Professional services is a rarely discounted line item and NPI finds that the small discounts that are seen are typically found in large deployments with large amounts of professional services. o NPI believes that these funds ARE somewhat flexible and because of the small dollar amount, NPI is applying the 23% discount that we periodically find in larger deployments to this proposal. Although this equates to a small $2K in savings, NPI mentions it as another negotiation point for Michael Kors.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed both proposed renewal options and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV).  Should BJC pursue the B2C option and shift the licensing structure for portions of the spend, NPI notes that more aggressive FMV pricing targets would exist compared to similar transformational agreements.  BJC?s precedent pricing in this space holds a good foundation and does not support much targeted cost savings on the BAU renewal, especially considering concessions made around costs for existing Spectrum licenses.  New demand around Watson, DashDB, Cloud subscriptions and other analytics items are the main area where pricing came in above FMV, holding the greatest area of savings opportunity in either option.  Given the limited timeframe, savings targets for the BAU renewal remain conservative.  The B2C proposal as offered is not as aggressive compared to other NPI reviews of this like, and if BJC pursues this option, utilizing an even $1.5M budgetary figure would move the spend further into FMV ranges.  IBM?s fiscal year end in December means that any lingering business without definite indications of a close will have teams at Sirius and the vendor under pressure from executives, especially if they believe budgetary restrictions jeopardize the deal.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: BJC?s BAU renewal option holds some FMV savings targets, but with a short timeframe you should feel confident executing.  Aggressive targets around B2C are shown as that current offer does lag behind similar conversions NPI reviews in this space.    ?	Targeting a $1.8M and $1.5M for the BAU and B2C offers, respectively, matches FMV discounting and may be tied to even budgetary amounts, enhancing the credibility of messaging.    o	Leading with these net targets as amounts to hit in order to facilitate a quick signature will utilize existing pressure around the fiscal quarter ends in December.
deal_metadata.description: BJC is renewing an existing 1-year term of an IBM PPA through reseller Sirius.  In addition to a BAU renewal proposal, Sirius is proposing a Business to Cloud (B2C) solution as an alternative option.  Went with B2C SaaS.  As-is outcome.  Changed contract to 8908 since we didn't get to show this in prior year and was so close. likely didn't get acted on til after new contract started.
