deal_metadata.current_narrative: When it comes to Verint (or NICE or Aceyus or any other major IVR player), you have two opportunities to get your pricing right, new purchases, and significant upgrades, and that is it. During normal renewal cycles, these companies historically do not move and typically raise prices that are not locked in, anywhere from 3-8% year over year.  In fact, I just finished a review, for a large Midwest Bank, that has been a customer of NICE Systems for some 8 years, , and with the exception of last year, when they did a major upgrade, and the first two renewals, where they had contractually agreed to maintenance, NICE raised their rates every year. Why not last year, because they did a major upgrade. Fast forward 365 days to this renewal, absolutely no love what so ever, 3% increase, across the board, that was the extent of their favoritism.  I have reviewed both your prior and current offers. The original offer at 60% was actually not a bad starting position, considering the size of your environment, although, the 3% increase on maintenance right out of the gate and the maintenance rate based on an initial 22% were both above FMV for certain. The 2nd iteration, at 63% discount and a flat maintenance rate, is definitely a step in the right direction. Keep it up.   The goal here should be to get closer to 70%, but that is not going to happen now and it is most likely not going to happen quickly. AFI missed the end of Q2, so you may have to hold 60-70 days to get all the way to 69-70% and it is going to take competition. Even if NICE has been eliminated, they have to be played up. Aceyus is another vendor that you can work into the conversation as is Cisco.   We can help you brainstorm and set this in motion if you need assistance.
deal_metadata.description: We are evaluating On-Premise and Saas WFM solutions with Verint and Nice.  Is this an area you could benchmark?  A month later got this:  We opted for Verints? On Premise model and have been through a few rounds of pricing.  Attached is a breakdown of where we ended up.  Can you benchmark the ?Current? pricing.  They came down on licensing, Professional Services and of course Support and Maintenance from the first pricing breakdown also included on the attached.  Thanks for your help.  No interest in SaaS. Asked about that discount to capture it   Seemed to say he had a verbal for 70% on perpetual but Mike did review and landed at 63%.  From Pat: Revised quote is forthcoming but the one you posted is the latest.   The difference will be a license fees drop from $400K to $367, Support and Maintenance drops from $264K over 3 years to $220,200 and Professional Services drops from $125K (estimated) to $112.5  Yes, this is the key stuff; perpetual current state.  We did look at SaaS and it is cost prohibitive mostly because both Verint and Nices? solution are not true SaaS.  They both essentially are hosted in their own environment.  Got a revised quote (mike excel). Quantities changed a little and support was uplifted but generally ended as-is.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Gentleman, I?ve gotten smarter on this and hope to impart that wisdom to you all.  NPI hasn?t seen this very much but it is an interesting area.  I think understanding what this does is almost as important to the negotiation as understanding your pricing specifically.   I?m hoping this is just round one of feedback and that you have a bit of time to allow me to get smarter on the pricing.  Pardon the informality of bullets but it is the quickest way to share thoughts based on my two SME conversations. Also, this is heavily Pega-focused.  Pega has several product lines.  Their traditional BPM line has been their flagship product.  Individual sales of this are routinely seven figures.  This is a value-driven product and the Account Executives that sell this product are actually somewhat distanced from how it is priced.  Pega attempts to determine the value they will drive (clients should be coached not to let them from a negotiation point of view) and then is fairly challenging to negotiate with. Everything is purpose-based and licensed for a specific use.  The negotiation can be about how to get this as broad as possible.  An average AE has only five named accounts and they land and expand.  18 months ago they bought a company called OpenSpan and this is the RPA stuff that AmFam is looking at now.  It?s being integrated into Pega of course but there?s still remnants of how OpenSpan sold this.  NPI believes this part of their business, unlike the core BPM, is more negotiable.  I?m pretty certain a list price exists for the Robotics products (RPA, RDA and Workforce Intelligence) and it can be benchmarked like most software companies.  This is unlike the core BPM offering from Pega where the value-based approach distances any offer from any of their secretive price lists.  So that?s a bit of a tease as I indicate I think this can be benchmarked but I?m not able to yet.  It does mean it is more negotiable I believe especially since you?re involving competition.  ?	Even though it is the third license mentioned Workforce Intelligence (WI) is likely the first license you?ll use.  You don?t know what you need to fix until you use WI.  This is a small piece of software that Pega wants you to run continuously on everyone?s desk.  It?ll monitor all keystrokes, idle time and system transactions.  Are folks doing a lot of cutting and pasting between applications, for example.  You learn people in call centers are spending x% of time not doing anything, x% copying/pasting...then Pega can figure out dollar amounts you can say if you automate/improve the use of people?s time.   Pega will tell you that as you soon as you do this and things change you will want to keep improving and so you need to keep monitoring.  So WI runs out of the gate and tells you where you can automate. o	This is some key messaging that you will hear from Pega and will need to determine how you want to counter it.  It?ll make a ton of sense when you think about the value of continually monitoring and improving.  Who can question that, right?  However, how comprehensive does the monitoring need to be to find ongoing improvements when you?re paying for a license for each  person being monitored.  You almost have to counter with you don?t want to be overwhelmed with too much intelligence out of WI. o	How comprehensive you are can depend on how diverse or uniform your workforce is.  If you monitor 10 to 20 people per user group that may be enough.  Do you have 3, 7 or 15 groups that seem distinct enough in what they do so that each needs monitoring?   o	Pega will push for very comprehensive coverage during the whole 24 or 36 month term.  There are plenty of customers who will do as much as they can possible do within 18 months.  Every customer is different of course.  Is there so much anticipated improvement from Robotics that 36 months is needed.  My SME told me that EVERYONE overbuys this stuff.  Both in signing up for a term and in the number of licenses since they make you buy them in blocks.  They condition you to buy a year at a time in blocks of at least 200. Just be cognizant of that and consider being more conservative knowing the tendency. o	I gave some thought to how long the RPA/RDA term should be (offered for 24 and 36 months) compared to WI which is offered at 12 and 24 months.  Intuitively it makes sense that you could stop monitoring at some point and start automating. It also makes sense that you could start automating your first round of recommendations (coming out of WI) and then expect to keep monitoring and get additional recommendations. AmFam needs to think about how this may play out.  If you think you only need 12 months of WI or 18 months or maybe you want to run it for 6 months and turn it off for 6 and then back on for 6, this is stuff I?m told you can broach and try to negotiate.  o	NPI is trying to determine list price but I did find some GSA pricing. One month of Cloud, 12 month commit and 100 users was $32/month. AmFam?s offer for 200 users for 12 months is $45.50 (totals $109,200 for a year).  This should tell you there?s sizable room for improvement. Anyone can find this price list. I?m attaching for your convenience.  Real list is not published on their website but consider asking for it.  AmFam doesn?t approach GSA pricing until you buy 1000 users for 24 months. At 200 users for 12 months, achieving GSA pricing saves $36K a year.  Push for increments of 100 users as well. ?	The ratio of 7:1 being allowed using Robotic Units is standard and a nice ?concession?.  I have a GSA price list for Pega and saw that when comparing their RPA and RDA pricing (they are separate products being combined for AmFam) their price ratio was exactly 7:1. o	The flexibility to switch is nice since you don?t know what you don?t know.  Slide 4 gives a good description of RDA vs RPA.  RPA is basically automating processes that don?t have any human intervention.  RDA is adding automation to more people-driven processes.  Using WF helps you understand where you improvements are and these will then require some mix of RPA and RDA licenses. o	NPI prefers to know list price and offer up benchmarks comparing client pricing to other observed market prices.  Since this isn?t an option yet we offer up another GSA comparison.   ?	GSA pricing per RPA for a 1 mo. Term and 12 month commitment is $316.   AmFam?s offer for 50 RPA for 24 months is $368.75 per month.  Again, not a great comparison to GSA.  At 100 units that drops to $287.25 and to $213 for 200 units and a 36 month commitment.  The GSA price didn?t have a volume commitment and was for 12 months.   ?	AmFam?s negotiation will pivot on the term and volume of course.  NPI believes there?s room to leverage competition to push back for a 10-25% improvement depending on the term/quantity mix. ?	Slides 5 and 6 mention a Purpose based license of Pega Platform is included at no charge and there?s no requirement to purchase it.  This is an interesting piece.  The whole reason why they bought OpenSpan is to get these smaller opportunities in front of clients, then they can get you to taste the power of the big Platform and then sell you the $1M+ BPM offering.  Robotics improves existing processes but doesn?t outright transform them.  That?s BPM in a simplistic way.  The Robotics Studio is also included and that?s what?s used to build the Bots.  ?	Here?s a couple interesting links to read about Robotics on their site and the acquisition o	https://www.pega.com/products/pega-7-platform/robotic-automation o	https://www.pega.com/about/news/media-coverage/pegasystems-acquires-robotic-automation-software-provider-openspan  I wanted to share as much as I could today and hope the above helps.  My SMEs didn?t know much about Automation Anywhere.  They did feel it was a less robust platform and if the prices are similar then Pega is the way to go.  We talked about it a bit and since they call stuff differently it is a little hard to know if they?re apples to apples.  None of the different counts/quantities seems to align but a lot of the functionality seemed to overlap.  Analytics Platform sounds a bit like WI. Task Bot and Meta Bot sound like RPA and RDA.  Sample year one totals $225K and there?s a level of RPA/RDA combined with WI that is close to this as well.  My SME thought it was a bit less advanced and AA wants to have someone on site to oversee all this.  He compared this to Pega who offer up free training through 12/31 for one item and other free training online as they want you to be self sufficient  and believe clients can use WI, Robotics Studio and RPA/RDA to be self sufficient.  He didn?t say this exactly but that?s my interpretation.  He said Pega is less klugy.  AA?s attitude is we?ll have someone on site to fix this for you.  You can look at that two ways.  It is nice to have a helping hand but Pega doesn?t think you?ll need it. I need to dig into this comparison a bit more.  Consider asking each vendor to talk about the differences in laymen?s terms.  Increasingly Robotics is going to take on the personality of core Pega BPM. They believe they?re the best and don?t want to leave any money on the table. They will be tough to negotiate with.  Don?t show favoritism.  Get internally aligned so there are no leaks.  Be firm that it doesn?t make sense to monitor the whole population continually, push back on some of the chunkiness of having to buy licenses in blocks, and even indicate aside from budget and competitive elements you found some GSA pricing and AmFam compares unfavorably to it.  ?There?s no way our CIO or CFO are going to approve any offer where that?s the case?
deal_metadata.description: AmFam is looking for guidance on two quotes for RPA ? Robotic Process Automation.    Attached are quotes form the two vendors that are finalists.  See round two.  20% reduction. Free training. WFI  10 month free trial.

I would also like to note that our team paid for Storefront services in 2017 for all brands (carved out by the vendor in the amount of $60k). We are not incorporating Storefront in 2018 but have requested the vendor to offer a recoup of those paid costs with the knowledge that we were not using the services in 2017.   I have attached our former agreement along with a renewal proposal for your reference.   Are you able to assist? If so, what is your expected turn around on the request?   Update - we have decided to opt for a one year deal with the assumption that our business will change over the next year. With that, we may not engage your services on this one. Due to the substantial savings we obtained on the prior agreement I don't anticipate, nor do I expect, they will be in a position offer additional savings for a one year renewal. Let me converse with Mark Wheeler first and I will get back to you.

file_info.name: Freddie Mac - FMV - Microsoft SCE March 2018 - V2 Redline.docx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed Freddie Mac?s SCE pricing and found it to be above fair market value (FMV) based on comparable Microsoft spends. Discounting is poor in each category for a $2M+ annual spend, and the 0% discount on subscription items is consistent with a 0% rate on subscriptions in Freddie Mac?s larger EAS. The SCE does provide some automatic discounting on perpetual licensing, but at this size of a net spend across multiple agreements, those discounts do not push pricing into the range of FMV.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts off the Level C reference pricing.  Microsoft is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the larger 3-year TCO plus address the financial exposure risks of the SCE?s encompassing licensing rules. ?	NPI recommends getting Microsoft to focus on an even budgetary goal of getting the spend under a $6.75M target for the term ($2.25M annual) in exchange for an expedited deal approval that preserves a March signature timeline. ?	NPI notes that these targets are more conservative to reflect the smaller timeframe available for this deal.  o	More aggressive targets would be appropriate with multiple months available for negotiations, but NPI has seen success even within shorter periods.  o	If Freddie Mac feels the sales team is especially nervous about landing this deal, it is feasible to pursue a more aggressive price target.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: Even with a short month-long timeline, Microsoft upped L/SA, SA, and Subs discounts 6%, 6.5%, and 7% respectively.  Financials and savings reflect the full 3-year spend.    Freddie Mac is reviewing a Microsoft Server and Cloud Enrollment (SCE) proposal set to commence in April 2018.

file_info.name: Trace3 Solution Proposal Encryption and Key MGT Services_v02.3.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Robert, Hey there.  Must be something about this space and how their vendors conceal their list prices.  I guess as security companies they are practicing what they preach ?.  While we?ve seen several Vormetric deals the SKUs often vary across our reviews and they don?t always show list pricing.  However, they do at times so we know they will provide it if asked.  Again, we got resourceful and tried to work through this and also leverage some public data.  I just got to a point where I think we are better off asking Trace3 to show add more transparency in their quote.  I think the SKUs are correct so that?s some good news.  The attached Excel file shows the work in progress.  I haven?t suggested targets yet since there?s too many open items.  Of note:  ?	VOR-TE ? listed for $6K about 12 months ago.  Let?s confirm this.  You may also want to take this time and ask about the bundled list price (and even net) that includes the Transparent Encryption Agent, Application Encryption and Tokenization. Another client bought the bundle (at MUCH bigger volumes ? 1,500) but paid $1K for each bundle. Webster is at $3,150 for just TE. You?re at less than 2% of their volume but I?m curious what they?d offer and it may be good to know if that?s on your roadmap.  If only two of these are of interest I don?t think they have a bundle for that but you could ask.  This other client didn?t have the Tokenization Client license so perhaps they?re configuring their solution differently than Webster. o	The quantity of 25 for VOR-TE and VOR-VTE-LTD brings up another topic to push for clarity on. From the limited pricing I?ve seen there?s a clear example on their Data Encryption Agent license where the first one is $6K, ten cost $45K (or $4500 each) and 25 cost $100K or $4K each).  I think now is the time to make sure they show you what all these tiers look like to ensure you?re getting both the programmatic volume discount and the additional discount you?d get on a first-time competitive buy. ?	VOR-VTE-LTD ? the one item I had no traction finding list pricing for ?	VOR-TOKEN ? educated guess is this is also at $6K list ?	The DSM Enterprise Parts I believe have the same list and they just discount non-prod more than prod.  The list could be $30K or something north of $40K.  That reflects quite a swing in discounting so it is a key item to validate.  I?d be appreciative if you could also ask them for the list price of the physical DSM Enterprise equivalent. Perhaps you could say someone asked about that option and you wanted to understand it more.  I think it lists for at least $5K more. ?	On the Support side, Standard is always 18% of net and Premium is 22%.  We?ve never seen Premium+ which is what?s reflected on your quote.  Below is a picture of the comparison of these two in their SW Lic Agreement.  They?re offering the + at 23% of the total hardware and software net.  Doesn?t sound like a bad uplift over Premium assuming you?re getting something more.  Consider your options there.  ?	Some services details are shown. o	Vormetric?s rack rate is $2,500/day. VOR-PRO-SERV is the SKU.  We?ve seen it not discounted typically.   o	Program Review and Roadmap Dev seems like it?ll be work done by Trace3 for a fixed fee of $51,800. They mention a Security Architect and PM. No hours are mentioned.   We?d expect this to reflect some hourly estimate applied against the rates and then a 10-20% uplift for the risk involved with a fixed fee engagement.  Maybe ask about a T&M to get exposure to the rates and effort. o	Product Install appears to be Vormetric people.  Offered at $12,500 that?s 5 days at their $2,500 rack rate.  That number of days doesn?t seem bloated.  In a competitive environment feels like that could be something to push for free. o	Tech Design and Impl - $67,500 for 6 weeks. That?s $11,250 a week or $2,250 a day if one resource which is exactly 10% off the Vormetric daily rack rate of $2500. It includes an Architect, Engineer and PM but again is offered at a fixed amount so no effort/hours noted.  Push for some clarity around this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric. On the one hand you?d expect a lower rate with Trace3 but oftentimes partners bring more senior resources to bear than the OEM/Publisher. o	Roadmap and Mentoring is offered at $51,800 and is T&M. It is largely an architect at $300.  We can benchmark this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric.  We?ll work on what we can but let me know if you expect to reach out to Trace3 for this additional detail.  Now is the time and no reason to spend this money if there?s any questions about the transparency of the offer.  Also, do you expect future growth.  Getting transparency now sets you up for that.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.  Final quote increased in size largely due to Token Server Client item growing from 1 to 18.  The only reductions appear to be on the DSM units as both the Prod and non prod had reductions.  Maintenance also dropped from 23% to 20%.   The initial quotes didn't clear show all the non prod info that was shown in the final.  Estimating savings and new baseline but not overthinking it.  Future folks should use the final docs (also some list pricing in XLS) and new SME.
deal_metadata.description: Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.  Reply to first offer: We?ll take a look.  From my first pass I can tell you the Trace3 (Vormetric) SOW is too light on details.  There?s a lot ($530K+) of services with no resources, rates and hours so it can?t be benchmarked.  There?s also a sizable placeholder for hardware, licenses and support for $501K with no detail.  Trace3 needs to provide a Vormetric quote showing all the usual details (SKUs, list, net, quantities).  Webster came back on 3/13 with a revised spreadsheet showing list pricing.  Some sizable increases. Sent a second round of feedback on 3/14. see email.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Matt and Jon, Here?s what I can tell you upon first blush. ?	A five year term is kind of rare to see.  Typically is three years and have heard WD has balked at five years as that doesn?t allow for increases after the typical three year term.  That?s a plus. ?	NPI interprets the 63 month term as that is WDs approach to handling the usual customer objection about doublepaying i.e., paying for Workday while still on the current solution.  While we don?t see six months free granted too often this is a case where we?d suggest pushing for that i.e., 66 month term for same cost.  This is a two year project at least.  This is likely one of the first hospitals to be going all-in (HCM plus Financials) with Workday.  HIPAA concerns and capital intensive nature of hospitals have not been a great proving ground in the past for WD and SaaS.  They?re likely pushing for this to be a referenceable account. The comprehensiveness of this purchase should make the case that you need six months at no cost.  Adding term to the end is how WD addresses that. ?	WD is increasing bundling their subscriptions making it difficult to benchmark without doing some reverse engineering.  CHOP should consider pushing for each subscription to have its own cost.  What if you want to grow (or keep) only 4 of the 6 bundled items in the third subscription? ?	To try and evaluate NPI viewed this as a five year term. That?s $2.4M a year for 5 years.  NPI also took the blended FSE average since there?s some growth forecast after month 15. ?	The FSE conversion table on p.3 is the typical table they use.  ?	NPI then applied our typical analysis to see if using the FSE averages ( first table below) and our pricing expectations we could back into your $2.4M annual cost.  One key assumption we often make when trying to unbundle when there?s no line item aggregate pricing is that the Additional Subscription Fee table on P.1 reflects the same price for add-on FSEs as offered for the initial FSEs. This is generally a safe assumption. ?	At 13,000+ FSEs a price of $38.18 (again assuming this add?l FSE cost is the same as the original cost) is VERY strong for the core HCM subscription.  We?d generally expect that FSE level to land between $40-50 and maybe a bit higher if WD was feeling confident.  We would say this is toward the low end of our fair market value (FMV) range. ?	When NPI evaluates Workday we first form an opinion on HCM and then all other modules are generally priced as a percentage of HCM.  o	CCB and USP are combined.  We generally expect CCB to be at 25-30% of HCM and USP to be at 65-75% of HCM.  Using 25% and 75%, you?d then expect the combined bundle to equal the HCM cost.  It is close as HCM is $38.18 and CCB/USP is $40.61. This passes the sniff test but has some room for improvement.  o	NPI would target HCM to stay flat; CCB at 25% and USP at 75%.  That would put CCB at $9.55 and USP at $28.64. This totals $38.18.  Achieving $38.18 drives $25-30K out of the annualized expense. o	The last part is a super SKU with 6 items bundled in.  Again, tough to reverse engineer.  The cost is 275% of the HCM SKU ($104.99 vs. $34.18). o	NPI encourages CHOP to get this unbundled.  WD can be weird about it but will if pushed hard enough. o	Historically CCB was included with HCM. Here?s where there?s some art and science with a benchmark.  CCB is carved out largely to make HCM look smaller but historically something like FIN was priced at about 100% of HCM (when it included CCB).  That?s the approach NPI took with this review.  ?	We would expect FIN to be 100% of the combined HCM and CCB per FSE costs or $47.73 ($38.18 + $9.55) ?	We?ve never seen Grants before but newer subscriptions are generally at 25% of HCM to start ?	We?ve seen Projects bundled often with HCM ?	WD has done a good job making it murkier to determine the right percentages ?	Using 100% for FIN and 25% for all the others (knowing a couple are likely a bit higher) and basing our expected costs as a percentage of HCM + CCB yields the second table below. deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed CRL?s proposed quantities and is providing guidelines around fair market value (FMV) and best practices. ServiceNow customers face many challenges that are common with enterprise SaaS providers. The solution can grow rapidly and the vendor is notorious for levying heavy automatic price hikes if left unchecked.  ServiceNow continues to develop new offerings, and although CRL only anticipates the two license types, NPI expects the vendor will try to upsell different areas of your organization. If CRL considers adding any products to this proposal, NPI suggests using that additional demand as a point of leverage by positioning them as ?nice-to-haves? that could be left off due to cost considerations. ServiceNow?s next fiscal quarter end is this month (March), and CRL?s offer to ServiceNow could provide key incentives to sales team quotas.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI strongly recommends not mentioning specific discounts.  ServiceNow is notorious for standing up to requests that solely revolve around discounts; they are typically much more receptive when clients speak to the long-term solution TCO, especially as it relates to pricing allowing for growth and new products.   ?	NPI recommends getting ServiceNow to focus on getting the combined spend under an even $325K target annually in exchange for an expedited deal approval that can accommodate a March signature timeline.  A fallback of $350k (a flat 45% discount) is appropriate.
deal_metadata.description: Closing: client didn't share results    CRL is preparing to ask ServiceNow for a quote of ITSM and Approver users.  There is no current quote and the vendor has not been approached.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s Kofax pricing and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV). Software pricing is solidly within the range of FMV, but maintenance costs have room for improvement based on NPI?s data and similar reviews.  NPI sees the greatest factors of leverage in similarly-sized Kofax spends to be timing pressure and the degree of open competition involved.  Without both of those factors, it is difficult but still feasible to achieve savings targets. If Kofax already knows they?re the preferred vendor and/or no credible threat exists, NPI recommends manifesting uncertainty around this decision point.  Ideally, BNYM should float a high-level net target to the reseller and follow this with a short break in communication to make the vendors nervous about this forecasted deal.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI suggests using a rounded net amount of $800k as a talking point with the reseller and vendor, and to avoid mentioning any specific discounting. Say that this is the target needed to keep this within the March timeframe. o	Messaging can focus on attaining a slight relief on capital costs, but also emphasize that high relative operational expenses are the main factor causing BNYM to pause before proceeding with this purchase.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: BNYM did not give a true indication as to closing costs, but did indicate they had prorated maintenance reduced which would imply at least a $6.6k save.  We indicated this was mostly FMV with opportunity, but client is trying not to count this as a report   BNYM is reviewing a proposal from reseller Document Imaging Group for Kofax?s TotalAgility platform.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: ?	NPI reviewed Intuit?s pricing for both upfront purchases and hardware subscriptions for the Rhombus R1 camera solution and found pricing to be above fair market value (FMV) for all of the options.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	A 5 ? 10% discount on cameras and subscription services is far below an expected 20% watermark for FMV.  This is separate of the 200 quantity total potential demand, which further reinforces the need for competitive pricing to accommodate a full deployment.  When looking at the total demand, a 20 ? 30% target range realistically exists.   o	Note that this only addresses the 1-year options for the purchase and subscription options.  There are no additional incentives for the 2 ? 3-year subscription terms, and without at least a 5 ? 10% additional incentive for the respective lengths, it?s difficult to see any value in them at current costs. ?	NPI does note that while the subscription model for this purchase offers lower net costs by more than 20%, there are risks with a subscription based model that does not provide ownership of the actual units.  Most importantly, Intuit should ensure understanding of any additional fees that may be incurred when going with the subscription model, such as if accessing or downloading content may cost extra.   NOTE: Closing for data cleanup.
deal_metadata.description: Review of several upfront or subscription options for physical security cameras and attached software.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Matt and Jon, Here?s what I can tell you upon first blush. ?	A five year term is kind of rare to see.  Typically is three years and have heard WD has balked at five years as that doesn?t allow for increases after the typical three year term.  That?s a plus. ?	NPI interprets the 63 month term as that is WDs approach to handling the usual customer objection about doublepaying i.e., paying for Workday while still on the current solution.  While we don?t see six months free granted too often this is a case where we?d suggest pushing for that i.e., 66 month term for same cost.  This is a two year project at least.  This is likely one of the first hospitals to be going all-in (HCM plus Financials) with Workday.  HIPAA concerns and capital intensive nature of hospitals have not been a great proving ground in the past for WD and SaaS.  They?re likely pushing for this to be a referenceable account. The comprehensiveness of this purchase should make the case that you need six months at no cost.  Adding term to the end is how WD addresses that. ?	WD is increasing bundling their subscriptions making it difficult to benchmark without doing some reverse engineering.  CHOP should consider pushing for each subscription to have its own cost.  What if you want to grow (or keep) only 4 of the 6 bundled items in the third subscription? ?	To try and evaluate NPI viewed this as a five year term. That?s $2.4M a year for 5 years.  NPI also took the blended FSE average since there?s some growth forecast after month 15. ?	The FSE conversion table on p.3 is the typical table they use.  ?	NPI then applied our typical analysis to see if using the FSE averages ( first table below) and our pricing expectations we could back into your $2.4M annual cost.  One key assumption we often make when trying to unbundle when there?s no line item aggregate pricing is that the Additional Subscription Fee table on P.1 reflects the same price for add-on FSEs as offered for the initial FSEs. This is generally a safe assumption. ?	At 13,000+ FSEs a price of $38.18 (again assuming this add?l FSE cost is the same as the original cost) is VERY strong for the core HCM subscription.  We?d generally expect that FSE level to land between $40-50 and maybe a bit higher if WD was feeling confident.  We would say this is toward the low end of our fair market value (FMV) range. ?	When NPI evaluates Workday we first form an opinion on HCM and then all other modules are generally priced as a percentage of HCM.  o	CCB and USP are combined.  We generally expect CCB to be at 25-30% of HCM and USP to be at 65-75% of HCM.  Using 25% and 75%, you?d then expect the combined bundle to equal the HCM cost.  It is close as HCM is $38.18 and CCB/USP is $40.61. This passes the sniff test but has some room for improvement.  o	NPI would target HCM to stay flat; CCB at 25% and USP at 75%.  That would put CCB at $9.55 and USP at $28.64. This totals $38.18.  Achieving $38.18 drives $25-30K out of the annualized expense. o	The last part is a super SKU with 6 items bundled in.  Again, tough to reverse engineer.  The cost is 275% of the HCM SKU ($104.99 vs. $34.18). o	NPI encourages CHOP to get this unbundled.  WD can be weird about it but will if pushed hard enough. o	Historically CCB was included with HCM. Here?s where there?s some art and science with a benchmark.  CCB is carved out largely to make HCM look smaller but historically something like FIN was priced at about 100% of HCM (when it included CCB).  That?s the approach NPI took with this review.  ?	We would expect FIN to be 100% of the combined HCM and CCB per FSE costs or $47.73 ($38.18 + $9.55) ?	We?ve never seen Grants before but newer subscriptions are generally at 25% of HCM to start ?	We?ve seen Projects bundled often with HCM ?	WD has done a good job making it murkier to determine the right percentages ?	Using 100% for FIN and 25% for all the others (knowing a couple are likely a bit higher) and basing our expected costs as a percentage of HCM + CCB yields the second table below.  With more time NPI could likely vet these percentages of HCM further (but push WD to provide).   o	Our calculation tallies $2.34M a year ($11.7M over the term).  This provides a nice sanity check that the $2.4M is in the ballpark of fair market value. It would be great to fine tune the percentages against line item pricing from WD.   o	Hopefully NPIs assumptions make sense. o	This is a lot to implement. CHOP should argue that without the deal of the century why should you prebuy all this stuff.  This is really comprehensive. o	Target 6 months free (i.e., 66 month term). o	Target $11.3 -11.5M as the annual cost but at this 5000 foot dive analysis $11.5-11.7M would be a solid landing spot. o	Execute knowing $38.18 for HCM is stout at this FSE level.  TABLES IN EMAIL FEEDBACK.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email. see attached.   Standard support which is included in the Node Pricing vs Premium $0 line item as seen on other quotes.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Based on existing discounts and outcomes that we?ve seen with other clients, NPI finds the FMV range for this purchase is 65% - 68%.  With a current blended discount of 65.7%, VSP is within FMV, but we have seen slightly better discounting and we believe VSP should target 68% for 2,000 Nodes, returning an additional ~$6K in savings.   The message to Chef should focus on dollar figures vs discount percentages.  It is a more convincing argument to explain to Chef that you are trying to reach a budgetary number of $82,250 (using a specific number makes it seem more realistic).  You may be able to rob from Peter to pay Paul and add some additional dollars to the budget for this project, but we are unlikely to get to $94K.  If Chef can meet us in the middle around $85K, approval will likely happen quicker.  NPI is interested in the negotiations that have occurred to this point with Chef?  What has VSP done & said to reach the current 65.7% blended discount?  In sum, NPI feels this pricing is within FMV as is, but 68% is achievable and would be closer to best-in-class.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via e-mail (see attached):  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  Please see our feedback below:  ?	Chef Automate has a list price of $137/year per node, including some level of support (12x5). If you follow this link you?ll see that confirmed. https://www.chef.io/pricing/ ?	In 2015, Equifax bought 2,000 licenses of their prior subscription (Private Chef) which listed for $81 a year and received a 40% discount.  Somewhere over the past 2+ years you?ve upgraded to Chef Automate and got a slight uptick in your discount.  In 2015 we felt 50% was a stretch target and 45% was a good landing spot.  The outcome was 40%.  It helps to quickly review the background. ?	The core list price for what Equifax is buying is higher than the indicated quote list price because of the Premier Support upgrade which is ~20% of the $137.  The all-in list price is = $164 ($137 + $27).  NPIs gut feel is this is a bit of salesmanship as it appears Automate comes with 24x7 support (i.e., Premier).  NPI has a few suggestions related to this: o	Equifax could consider asking Chef to provide a quote with Base/Standard Support. You can ask under the guise of trying to gauge if Premium is worth it. Even though they are ?including? Premium, there is a high probability these costs have been worked into overall pricing or more realistically are always included at no charge. Evaluating Base/Standard vs Premier will shake Chef up as vendors do not typically give anything away for free ? especially with a list price over $100K? o	All the support levels are via a web-based ticketing system.  Premium just puts you ahead in the queue and doesn?t get you a dedicated person or even a live person which supports the thinking that they include this at no charge. Chef is generally not the license that breaks your environment. If Chef is down the supporting applications won?t be down. The biggest difference across all three support levels is the handling of Sev 1 tickets. Base is a 12x5 two-hour response time, Standard is a 12x5 one-hour response time and Premium is a 24x7 30-minute response time.  o	NPI found a few articles that seemed to state the $137 came with Premium Support. Just another reason to confirm and get further transparency. ?	https://reviews.financesonline.com/p/chef/ (excerpted below) ?	https://www.getapp.com/it-management-software/a/chef/pricing/     ?	NPI used the list price of $137 per node and total node usage of 3,000 to 4,000 in the table below: o	NPI believes all the subscriptions should be priced at the same level i.e., the original 2,000 subscriptions should be grandfathered into any discount improvement due to the expansion. o	Based on existing discounts, our prior Equifax targets and other client outcomes, NPI has an FMV range of 40-50%.  We believe Equifax should target 50% for 4,000 subscriptions and 45% for 3,000 subscriptions.  Clearly, hitting +/- 5% on any of the scenarios is within FMV so the good news is you?re at a good point currently.   Equifax should be comfortable striving to achieve these targets based on Chef?s attempt to muddy the water with a $0 dollar line item on what NPI concludes is included plus this is certainly an industry with high margins that can flex on pricing to land some sizable growth.   Additionally, Chef will often be more willing to bump up their discount if customers agree to serve as a "tier 1" media reference if that is something Equifax would consider.
deal_metadata.description: Initial ask from Equifax:  \We?ve had 2000 licenses for several years at the price below?. We need to bump up to 3 or 4K nodes.. they?ve given us the pricing below.

deal_metadata.savings_achieved: N - Did not act on advice
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the rates from Accenture and found the overall blended rate of $159.65 to be in the range of FMV with room for improvement. While some of the individual rates are within FMV, other are at the high end of the range with room for improvement. In summary, NPI believes that there is potential for savings of about 5% of the total proposed cost of the project.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Typical blended rates for the SFDC implementation (including offshore and onsite roles) vary between $150 per hour and $250 per hour based on the vendor and resource mix. Accenture?s blended rate is $159 per hour. ?	SFDC?s stance in general is not to do implementations unless they have to.  They prefer to leave it to their partners.   o	SFDC?s rates are typically in the $225-$250/hr range, so customers generally save money using service partners.   ?	Adding to the conversation is the presence of India-based consultancies who often provide staff augmentation for some of the roles and leverage offshore resources.  NPI typically sees architect-level SFDC resources at rates around $120 - $150/hr from vendors like HCL, Infosys, and Cognizant. ?	Typically, we see a phased approach where the Big 4/Accenture are involved in the initial assessment, strategy, change management, etc., and the ensuing implementation phases are bid out separately to other vendors, including mid-tier consulting firms and India-based consulting firms (who sometimes work in conjunction with the Big 4 on the implementation phases). ?	NPI observed that 54% of the effort is offshore (in terms of the number of hours) and 46% is onsite. This is slightly higher than the typical range that NPI observes on SFDC implementation projects where 25% - 45% of the effort is offshore. This contributes to a lower blended rate. The high offshore utilization may be due to a larger offshore COE (Center of Excellence) for the SFDC practice. ?	While the offshore rates seem extremely high (ranging between $35 and $105), NPI has observed that SFDC resource rates are much higher than the typical offshore rates that we see for other implementation and development projects (between $21 and $55). The same is true for onshore rates as well. ?	NPI noted that there is a large difference between the hourly rates for the two change management content developer line items. Assuming one developer to be more senior, NPI has recommended a rate of $225 vs. $300 for the senior resource. At $185, the junior resource rate is FMV.	 ?	The tables below depict Accenture?s rates, NPI?s target rates and potential savings.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Pressed Rob but he held fast. Correct, the hourly figures did not change. Given that it was T&M and we needed to start quickly since we purchased software sooner than we thought, we just decided not to pursue.  It's possible that I may have to extend SOWs, so at that point I may reach out to you well in advance and push much harder related to the implementation resource cost.
deal_metadata.description: Accenture's $7M proposal to implement SFDC

deal_metadata.description: Accenture's $7M proposal to implement SFDC

deal_metadata.savings_achieved: N - Did not act on advice
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the rates from Accenture and found the overall blended rate of $159.65 to be in the range of FMV with room for improvement. While some of the individual rates are within FMV, other are at the high end of the range with room for improvement. In summary, NPI believes that there is potential for savings of about 5% of the total proposed cost of the project.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Typical blended rates for the SFDC implementation (including offshore and onsite roles) vary between $150 per hour and $250 per hour based on the vendor and resource mix. Accenture?s blended rate is $159 per hour. ?	SFDC?s stance in general is not to do implementations unless they have to.  They prefer to leave it to their partners.   o	SFDC?s rates are typically in the $225-$250/hr range, so customers generally save money using service partners.   ?	Adding to the conversation is the presence of India-based consultancies who often provide staff augmentation for some of the roles and leverage offshore resources.  NPI typically sees architect-level SFDC resources at rates around $120 - $150/hr from vendors like HCL, Infosys, and Cognizant. ?	Typically, we see a phased approach where the Big 4/Accenture are involved in the initial assessment, strategy, change management, etc., and the ensuing implementation phases are bid out separately to other vendors, including mid-tier consulting firms and India-based consulting firms (who sometimes work in conjunction with the Big 4 on the implementation phases). ?	NPI observed that 54% of the effort is offshore (in terms of the number of hours) and 46% is onsite. This is slightly higher than the typical range that NPI observes on SFDC implementation projects where 25% - 45% of the effort is offshore. This contributes to a lower blended rate. The high offshore utilization may be due to a larger offshore COE (Center of Excellence) for the SFDC practice. ?	While the offshore rates seem extremely high (ranging between $35 and $105), NPI has observed that SFDC resource rates are much higher than the typical offshore rates that we see for other implementation and development projects (between $21 and $55). The same is true for onshore rates as well. ?	NPI noted that there is a large difference between the hourly rates for the two change management content developer line items. Assuming one developer to be more senior, NPI has recommended a rate of $225 vs. $300 for the senior resource. At $185, the junior resource rate is FMV.	 ?	The tables below depict Accenture?s rates, NPI?s target rates and potential savings.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Matt and Jon, Here?s what I can tell you upon first blush. ?	A five year term is kind of rare to see.  Typically is three years and have heard WD has balked at five years as that doesn?t allow for increases after the typical three year term.  That?s a plus. ?	NPI interprets the 63 month term as that is WDs approach to handling the usual customer objection about doublepaying i.e., paying for Workday while still on the current solution.  While we don?t see six months free granted too often this is a case where we?d suggest pushing for that i.e., 66 month term for same cost.  This is a two year project at least.  This is likely one of the first hospitals to be going all-in (HCM plus Financials) with Workday.  HIPAA concerns and capital intensive nature of hospitals have not been a great proving ground in the past for WD and SaaS.  They?re likely pushing for this to be a referenceable account. The comprehensiveness of this purchase should make the case that you need six months at no cost.  Adding term to the end is how WD addresses that. ?	WD is increasing bundling their subscriptions making it difficult to benchmark without doing some reverse engineering.  CHOP should consider pushing for each subscription to have its own cost.  What if you want to grow (or keep) only 4 of the 6 bundled items in the third subscription? ?	To try and evaluate NPI viewed this as a five year term. That?s $2.4M a year for 5 years.  NPI also took the blended FSE average since there?s some growth forecast after month 15. ?	The FSE conversion table on p.3 is the typical table they use.  ?	NPI then applied our typical analysis to see if using the FSE averages ( first table below) and our pricing expectations we could back into your $2.4M annual cost.  One key assumption we often make when trying to unbundle when there?s no line item aggregate pricing is that the Additional Subscription Fee table on P.1 reflects the same price for add-on FSEs as offered for the initial FSEs. This is generally a safe assumption. ?	At 13,000+ FSEs a price of $38.18 (again assuming this add?l FSE cost is the same as the original cost) is VERY strong for the core HCM subscription.  We?d generally expect that FSE level to land between $40-50 and maybe a bit higher if WD was feeling confident.  We would say this is toward the low end of our fair market value (FMV) range. ?	When NPI evaluates Workday we first form an opinion on HCM and then all other modules are generally priced as a percentage of HCM.  o	CCB and USP are combined.  We generally expect CCB to be at 25-30% of HCM and USP to be at 65-75% of HCM.  Using 25% and 75%, you?d then expect the combined bundle to equal the HCM cost.  It is close as HCM is $38.18 and CCB/USP is $40.61. This passes the sniff test but has some room for improvement.  o	NPI would target HCM to stay flat; CCB at 25% and USP at 75%.  That would put CCB at $9.55 and USP at $28.64. This totals $38.18.  Achieving $38.18 drives $25-30K out of the annualized expense. o	The last part is a super SKU with 6 items bundled in.  Again, tough to reverse engineer.  The cost is 275% of the HCM SKU ($104.99 vs. $34.18). o	NPI encourages CHOP to get this unbundled.  WD can be weird about it but will if pushed hard enough. o	Historically CCB was included with HCM. Here?s where there?s some art and science with a benchmark.  CCB is carved out largely to make HCM look smaller but historically something like FIN was priced at about 100% of HCM (when it included CCB).  That?s the approach NPI took with this review.  ?	We would expect FIN to be 100% of the combined HCM and CCB per FSE costs or $47.73 ($38.18 + $9.55) ?	We?ve never seen Grants before but newer subscriptions are generally at 25% of HCM to start ?	We?ve seen Projects bundled often with HCM ?	WD has done a good job making it murkier to determine the right percentages ?	Using 100% for FIN and 25% for all the others (knowing a couple are likely a bit higher) and basing our expected costs as a percentage of HCM + CCB yields the second table below.  With more time NPI could likely vet these percentages of HCM further (but push WD to provide).   o	Our calculation tallies $2.34M a year ($11.7M over the term).  This provides a nice sanity check that the $2.4M is in the ballpark of fair market value. It would be great to fine tune the percentages against line item pricing from WD.   o	Hopefully NPIs assumptions make sense. o	This is a lot to implement. CHOP should argue that without the deal of the century why should you prebuy all this stuff.  This is really comprehensive. o	Target 6 months free (i.e., 66 month term). o	Target $11.3 -11.5M as the annual cost but at this 5000 foot dive analysis $11.5-11.7M would be a solid landing spot. o	Execute knowing $38.18 for HCM is stout at this FSE level.  TABLES IN EMAIL FEEDBACK.

FMV range for renewals of this size would be a 40-55% discount

file_info.name: MI-INTUIT CMC FY18 H2 Marketing Automation Retainer v2.0[1].pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  NPI has not seen a ton of services deals in the marketing automation area, even though we frequently benchmark marketing automation software.  We also have several SME?s in our Advisor Network who were able to provide some thoughts on your professional services pricing.  Massive Insights has offered a blended rate of $105 per hour. This is within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV). The market range for similar projects range widely between $90 and $150 per hour based on the actual resource mix.  While the offered $105 per hour is within the range of fair market value, there may be room for improvement of up to 14% on the cost of the SOW. A blended rate of $90 translates to savings of $121K for the SOW.  In terms of negotiating levers, Intuit is certainly in a position of strength.  Intuit is one of Massive Insight?s key vendors and Intuit?s name is displayed on their web page as a key client partner.  Intuit?s increasing spend with them also forms a strong lever.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: NOTE: Closing for data cleanup
deal_metadata.description: I hope you?re doing well!  Julie and I are working on an agreement with Massive Insights to help us with marketing automation.  For some background, we have spent ~ $900k with them this past fiscal and this SOW would be doubling our engagement with them.  We are hoping you can help us with benchmarking the attached SOW and give guidance on any levers we can pull to help strengthen our negotiating power.

file_info.name: Springfield Clinic - Citrix NetScaler Training - Quote v1.0.pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for checking in on this one.  We would agree that 5% discounting is well ABOVE Fair Market Value (FMV) (for clarity, discounting is low, pricing is high).  We have several deals in our database with this exact training SKU (2000761) so I can validate that the list price is $5K.  We have often seen this priced at $4000 - $4200 per class, which equates to a 16% - 20%.  Based on NPI?s knowledge of Springfield?s annual Citrix spend, we absolutely believe that 20% - 25% discounting is the correct target discount for this $20K list price quote.  The total for this training should fall between $15K - $17K.  The message to Citrix should start with a bit of frustration, ?Springfield clinic has been a good customer and we?ve continued to grow and expand our spend with Citrix.  A 5% discount on training, that is more of a benefit for Citrix than Springfield because it will allow us to continue to grow the solution (and spend more with Citrix), is very disappointing.  Unless the cost for this training can?t get to a more acceptable $3 - $4K per class, then we may need to back down to only 1 or 2 of these courses at this time.?
deal_metadata.description: . I know this is under your threshold but what kind of discounting should I expect on Citrix training? Five percent feels insulting.

Founded in 2010, they are a fledgling company in the Security Risk Management Solution software space. They have a small, very dedicated team, with very little turnover, but are also very private about their company.  The only real competitor to Threatmodeler that shows up is TMT. (other tools are available in the ?open source? space). ?Threatmodeler was specifically identify by Gartner in their Hype Cycle for Application Security, 2017, for automating ?security requirements definition, risk assessment and threat modeling,? with SDLC integration, which ?can dynamically highlight potential security ramifications of functional requirements.? (NBC)  TM also recently hired the former Global Director of Fortify ( https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/12/globe-newswire-david-nester-joins-threatmodeler-software-as-chief-security-officer.html ). Combine that with a recent announcement of a partnership with Wipro to sell and deploy their solution and you get a sense for the trajectory that this company could be on.  NPI has only a couple of data points for them, and are honestly surprised to see that your offer for 200 threat models topped out at 40%. Our data would support an offer closer to the 50% that your rec?d for your unlimited proposal.  That being said, NPI expects that a proposal for only 50 or 100 threat models will be in the 30-40% discount range and Intuit will have to present a very complete case to push them higher than that.   Intuit could certainly offer the publicity angle as a way to leverage further discount, through reference calls or a case study if this proves successful for Intuit.   The bottom line is this, you don?t have to look that hard to find DevOps, SecOps or DevSec companies, but to find a company that puts it all together as TM claims with their ?automated? DevSecOps solution is pretty incredible, and TM knows it. TM still needs revenue to get their company off the ground and into the mainstream. Once Intuit determines how many threat models are truly required, the hard press will work with TM.

Lucy Cheng Sourcing Specialist, Technology (858) 215-7781 | lucy_cheng@intuit.com

file_info.name: WFM HCM vendor cost breakdown 3 12 2018 CERIDIAN DAYFORCE (1).xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hey Michael,  Thanks for sending these over for NPI to review.  We have seen a number of both SAP and Ceridian deals so I have good data for comparative analysis.  In the interest of trying to get this back to you quickly, see our feedback below.  If you would like this in a more formal FMV report, I can put that together for you.  SAP SFSF ?	Overall discount provided on the software is 91%. This is within the range of FMV, but we have seen on large deals of this size that SAP will reach 92%. Achieving a discount of 92% translates to savings of $311K per year on the software subscription. ?	Cost of Professional services is $2,998,900. NPI will need a bit more details around the specific resource rates to be able to benchmark this. SAP has a standard set of rates and list prices and NPI will be able to benchmark the associated discounts and share targets.  o	Individual rates vary from $245 to $400 per hour for onshore effort. Offshore rates vary between $55 and $75.  Blended rate for Success Factors implementation projects vary between $200 and $250 per hour based on resource mix, offshore utilization etc. ?	The travel cost associated with the services is estimated at 15% which is in the middle of the range of FMV. NPI has seen this vary between 10% and 25% based on project requirement. This is billed based on actuals.  Ceridian ?	The actual discount provided is not as well defined as in the SAP proposal. The cost per employee is $9.75 as compared to SAP?s proposed cost of $8.58 PEPM.  ?	While the individual cost of the software is within FMV as compared to similar market transactions, NPI has seen that Ceridian is very cost competitive and will match SFSF?s pricing to win the business.  They will typically not lose a deal based on price. ?	The cost of implementation services is low as compared to SFSF at $860,600. Clearly, SAP and Ceridian?s effort estimate and approach to implementation is different. Once again, if Chico?s shares the details on these services (resource rates and effort), NPI will be able to benchmark the same.  o	PS rates vary between $175 and $200 for onshore resources, although data conversion rates are lower and dashboard consulting rates are higher. ?	Estimated Travel and Expense is 10% of implementation cost which is at the low end of the range of FMV.
deal_metadata.description: As always we have an urgent one. We are looking at 2 vendors to replace our current HR and WFM applications, switching from ADP and JDA. Attached are 2 quotes from SAP Success Factors and Ceridian which we are looking at both.   Could you please provide a FMV analysis on both of these and let me know timing wise how long that would take to get back?

file_info.name: BNYM - FMV - Oracle February 2018 - V2 Redline.docx

deal_metadata.savings_achieved: Y - Savings but no NPI credit
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s offer from Oracle and found pricing to be at FMV (fair market value).  While price points are competitive (the main ASO piece?s rates are below FMV), the total deal?s actual value will vary depending on true utilization during the term.  Timing pressure is elevated for both sides, but depending on the sales team?s eagerness, this deal could be key to quotas.  BNYM has also indicated that the RAT components would be nice to add under the ULA, but may not be a necessarily part of this.  Adding these products to the ULA also adds the risks associated with variable deployment schedules.  Positioning these doubts as the reason BNYM is holding off on a purchase decision could edge out some final savings in the final hours. However, NPI considers this pricing to be strong as is.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends leading with a $1.775M target amount as the amount needed in exchange for the expedited approval of the final amount.  Starting with that figure without commentary will have the greatest effect, and if pressed, BNYM can then offer explanation behind the rationale.  As credibly as is possible, this target figure should be linked to budgetary concerns.   ?	NPI highly recommends tying this to a simple budgetary goal needed for the quickest approval, and not mentioning any specific discounting or benchmarks.
deal_metadata.description: Closing: Savings of $256k affected in last day but limited credit to NPI.  BNYM is reviewing an Amendment to add licenses on an existing ULA.  The deal?s incentives are tied to the vendor?s impending fiscal quarter end.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Shauna,  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We have seen quite a few VMWare purchases and renewals, so we have a lot of data for comparative analysis.  Unfortunately low, or zero, discounting is not uncommon for VMWare renewals.  Most VMWare renewals we review begin with 0% discounting.  VMWare renewals do not see very large discounts but 0% discounting, especially on a renewal of this size, is ABOVE FMV.    10% discounting on a VMWare renewal is about as high as we?ve seen.  We recommend targeting 10% - 12%, with an acceptable fallback to 6% - 8%.  Probably not the news you wanted to hear, but VMWare just doesn?t play ball very well on their renewals.  Let me know if you have any questions or if you would like to discuss on a call.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Pricing Analysis The majority of NPI?s clients renew Nuance software for 1-3 years. ?	One-year renewals rarely offer any form of reprieve from the prior year ?	NPI has observed Nuance offering discounts of up to 15% for prepaid 3-year agreements. ?	Nuance maintenance costs are typically based on 18% of the price of the license pool. ?	At 20% of net, NPI estimates Swedish? license pool value @ $290K.  Targets The clear path to pricing improvements for Swedish Covenant are to extend renewal cycles from 6 months to 1 or 3 years ?	NPI expects that one a year renewal, Swedish would witness minimal discount improvement ?	NPI further anticipates that if a 3-year renewal were pursued, that a 10-15% discount per year is attainable ?	Based on best in class pricing from other clients, NPI estimates that Swedish Covenant is above FMV by as much as $4K every 6 months or $8K annually

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI Reviewed the invoices and agreement amendment provided by Swedish Covenant and finds the PEPM (Per Employee Per Month) pricing of $11.81 to be within the range of FMV for an HCM solution. Solutions from competitive providers can often come in 2-3x this price.  The HCM solution from Ultimate is made of several components: Core, Talent Acquisition, Recruiting, Onboarding, Performance Management, and Compensation Management among others, all of which it appears SC is subscribing to.  SC committed in 2013 to a fee structure of $5.04 PEPM  NPI has not had another client pay for HCM services on a quarterly basis with monthly true-ups, the way that SC currently is, and would like to hear more about how that evolved?  NPI has not been provided any further change orders or amendments that reflect all of the other modules, nor do we have access to the original agreement, however, based on the invoices provided we were able to create the following data table of Quarterly and Annual pricing for each module and ultimately arrive at the aggregated PEPM number just under $12 PEPM.  Competitors in the space, such as Workday, SuccessFactors, Infor and others for sub 10K user environments will charge a far heavier PEPM than what SC is receiving, so making a competitive play will likely not bear any fruit for SC. Based on the original agreement(s) and agreed to pricing, if SCs pricing has crept up dramatically over the years, NPI could help SC structure a negotiation platform to perhaps reduce pricing to earlier levels, however, additional documentation would be required to support an effort such as that.
deal_metadata.description: Agreement sent as from 2013 with auto-renew.

file_info.name: BNYM - FMV - NetAPP OCI + Maint. March 2018 V2 Redline.docx

deal_metadata.savings_achieved: Y - Savings but no NPI credit
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s combined NetApp offer and found pricing to be just above fair market value (FMV). While the main maintenance renewals hold strong discounting, there?s opportunity around the OCI licensing due to  alignment with NetApp?s quarter-end. NetApp has greater flexibility on the capital side of this purchase, but NPI recommends BNYM approach them with an even net target and let the vendor determine a way to relieve cost concerns. Offering this in exchange for an expedient signature before open deals begin drawing scrutiny and pressure across the sales organization as it gets later in April.  NPI hears many complaints about the high costs of NetApp?s OCI software, and it?s possible BNYM holds better precedent pricing from previous transactions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Targets ?	NPI recommends offering a $2.4M net total as the focal point NetApp needs to hit to maintain momentum that could lead to a signature before April.   o	NPI recognizes that this transaction is needed and BNYM is under some extra timing pressure due to expired agreements in this deal, but NetApp commonly faces cost concerns with OCI?s rising outlays in environments. The sales team will be wary of any sign that the deal or any of its components could be put on hold to fit BNYM?s own internal cost goals.    ?	NPI highly recommends not addressing specific discount amounts and approaching NetApp with the bottom-line figure. BNYM can address specific discounting around the OCI License True-up or other parts if better precedent discounting exists, but NetApp will not be responsive to anything tied to benchmarks or requests for better raw discounting. o	Similarly, the StorageX spend would best be approached with a $250k net target if this is a net new investment. Without that confirmation, NPI cannot recommend a more aggressive target.    ?	The range of FMV includes discounts more aggressive than the 72% on the OCI software, but NPI?s target remains conservative due to prevailing factors driving the transaction.  If some other leverage exists, for example another upcoming capital spend or a recent lapse in SLAs, NPI would target discounts in the higher 70s for the OCI capacity.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: frustrating.  BNY indicated they did get savings but used "other" market intel that laid out more aggressive targets than those we furnished.  Another report they tried not to count.  No specifics on close, so safe assumption they at least hit our FMV targets.   BNYM has an upcoming true-up purchase of NetApp?s OnCommand Insight as well as several maintenance renewals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Robert, Hey there.  Must be something about this space and how their vendors conceal their list prices.  I guess as security companies they are practicing what they preach ?.  While we?ve seen several Vormetric deals the SKUs often vary across our reviews and they don?t always show list pricing.  However, they do at times so we know they will provide it if asked.  Again, we got resourceful and tried to work through this and also leverage some public data.  I just got to a point where I think we are better off asking Trace3 to show add more transparency in their quote.  I think the SKUs are correct so that?s some good news.  The attached Excel file shows the work in progress.  I haven?t suggested targets yet since there?s too many open items.  Of note:  ?	VOR-TE ? listed for $6K about 12 months ago.  Let?s confirm this.  You may also want to take this time and ask about the bundled list price (and even net) that includes the Transparent Encryption Agent, Application Encryption and Tokenization. Another client bought the bundle (at MUCH bigger volumes ? 1,500) but paid $1K for each bundle. Webster is at $3,150 for just TE. You?re at less than 2% of their volume but I?m curious what they?d offer and it may be good to know if that?s on your roadmap.  If only two of these are of interest I don?t think they have a bundle for that but you could ask.  This other client didn?t have the Tokenization Client license so perhaps they?re configuring their solution differently than Webster. o	The quantity of 25 for VOR-TE and VOR-VTE-LTD brings up another topic to push for clarity on. From the limited pricing I?ve seen there?s a clear example on their Data Encryption Agent license where the first one is $6K, ten cost $45K (or $4500 each) and 25 cost $100K or $4K each).  I think now is the time to make sure they show you what all these tiers look like to ensure you?re getting both the programmatic volume discount and the additional discount you?d get on a first-time competitive buy. ?	VOR-VTE-LTD ? the one item I had no traction finding list pricing for ?	VOR-TOKEN ? educated guess is this is also at $6K list ?	The DSM Enterprise Parts I believe have the same list and they just discount non-prod more than prod.  The list could be $30K or something north of $40K.  That reflects quite a swing in discounting so it is a key item to validate.  I?d be appreciative if you could also ask them for the list price of the physical DSM Enterprise equivalent. Perhaps you could say someone asked about that option and you wanted to understand it more.  I think it lists for at least $5K more. ?	On the Support side, Standard is always 18% of net and Premium is 22%.  We?ve never seen Premium+ which is what?s reflected on your quote.  Below is a picture of the comparison of these two in their SW Lic Agreement.  They?re offering the + at 23% of the total hardware and software net.  Doesn?t sound like a bad uplift over Premium assuming you?re getting something more.  Consider your options there.  ?	Some services details are shown. o	Vormetric?s rack rate is $2,500/day. VOR-PRO-SERV is the SKU.  We?ve seen it not discounted typically.   o	Program Review and Roadmap Dev seems like it?ll be work done by Trace3 for a fixed fee of $51,800. They mention a Security Architect and PM. No hours are mentioned.   We?d expect this to reflect some hourly estimate applied against the rates and then a 10-20% uplift for the risk involved with a fixed fee engagement.  Maybe ask about a T&M to get exposure to the rates and effort. o	Product Install appears to be Vormetric people.  Offered at $12,500 that?s 5 days at their $2,500 rack rate.  That number of days doesn?t seem bloated.  In a competitive environment feels like that could be something to push for free. o	Tech Design and Impl - $67,500 for 6 weeks. That?s $11,250 a week or $2,250 a day if one resource which is exactly 10% off the Vormetric daily rack rate of $2500. It includes an Architect, Engineer and PM but again is offered at a fixed amount so no effort/hours noted.  Push for some clarity around this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric. On the one hand you?d expect a lower rate with Trace3 but oftentimes partners bring more senior resources to bear than the OEM/Publisher. o	Roadmap and Mentoring is offered at $51,800 and is T&M. It is largely an architect at $300.  We can benchmark this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric.  We?ll work on what we can but let me know if you expect to reach out to Trace3 for this additional detail.  Now is the time and no reason to spend this money if there?s any questions about the transparency of the offer.  Also, do you expect future growth.  Getting transparency now sets you up for that.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.  Final quote increased in size largely due to Token Server Client item growing from 1 to 18.  The only reductions appear to be on the DSM units as both the Prod and non prod had reductions.  Maintenance also dropped from 23% to 20%.   The initial quotes didn't clear show all the non prod info that was shown in the final.  Estimating savings and new baseline but not overthinking it.  Future folks should use the final docs (also some list pricing in XLS) and new SME.
deal_metadata.description: Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.  Reply to first offer: We?ll take a look.  From my first pass I can tell you the Trace3 (Vormetric) SOW is too light on details.  There?s a lot ($530K+) of services with no resources, rates and hours so it can?t be benchmarked.  There?s also a sizable placeholder for hardware, licenses and support for $501K with no detail.  Trace3 needs to provide a Vormetric quote showing all the usual details (SKUs, list, net, quantities).  Webster came back on 3/13 with a revised spreadsheet showing list pricing.  Some sizable increases. Sent a second round of feedback on 3/14. see email.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Founded in 2010, they are a fledgling company in the Security Risk Management Solution software space. They have a small, very dedicated team, with very little turnover, but are also very private about their company.  The only real competitor to Threatmodeler that shows up is TMT. (other tools are available in the ?open source? space). ?Threatmodeler was specifically identify by Gartner in their Hype Cycle for Application Security, 2017, for automating ?security requirements definition, risk assessment and threat modeling,? with SDLC integration, which ?can dynamically highlight potential security ramifications of functional requirements.? (NBC)  TM also recently hired the former Global Director of Fortify ( https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/12/globe-newswire-david-nester-joins-threatmodeler-software-as-chief-security-officer.html ). Combine that with a recent announcement of a partnership with Wipro to sell and deploy their solution and you get a sense for the trajectory that this company could be on.  NPI has only a couple of data points for them, and are honestly surprised to see that your offer for 200 threat models topped out at 40%. Our data would support an offer closer to the 50% that your rec?d for your unlimited proposal.  That being said, NPI expects that a proposal for only 50 or 100 threat models will be in the 30-40% discount range and Intuit will have to present a very complete case to push them higher than that.   Intuit could certainly offer the publicity angle as a way to leverage further discount, through reference calls or a case study if this proves successful for Intuit.   The bottom line is this, you don?t have to look that hard to find DevOps, SecOps or DevSec companies, but to find a company that puts it all together as TM claims with their ?automated? DevSecOps solution is pretty incredible, and TM knows it. TM still needs revenue to get their company off the ground and into the mainstream. Once Intuit determines how many threat models are truly required, the hard press will work with TM.

deal_metadata.description: Hi Chris,  I need a price benchmark on the attached quotes from Threatmodeler.  This seems to be a pretty niche market, but the vendor is being super difficult and I want to make sure we get fair pricing.  Hopefully you guys can help us.  These are quotes they provided last year, we will be looking at quotes for 50 and 100 threats when they send them over.   Thanks!  Lucy Cheng Sourcing Specialist, Technology (858) 215-7781 | lucy_cheng@intuit.com
