file_info.name: MetLife 2018 Draft Workbook (for 2-20-18 presentation) - MetLife Workbook 3-1-2018.xlsx

deal_metadata.current_narrative: There?s a variety of info to report back.    For starters in the Draft Workbook worksheet ?Software Buyback-Destruct CTR? I added columns H-K to show the cost to upgrade the 3 items we discussed. I extended out the costs and applied a 65% discount. I also added in 3 years of SnS at 20% of the net license spend.  I included totals in row 20.  I had to estimate the vSOM upgrade but my figure is likely a little on the high side.  The two main upgrade SKUs are listed below.  I?m not exactly sure if you still want to calculate some sort of upgrade and renew SnS vs. do the ELA but this will be an input into that.  ?	VS6-STD-EPL-UG-C - Upgrade: VMware vSphere 6 Standard to vSphere 6 Enterprise Plus for 1 Processor - $2,750  ?	VS6-ENT-EPL-UG-C - Upgrade: VMware vSphere 6 Enterprise to vSphere 6 Enterprise Plus for 1 Processor - $682  The FMV range for the token-based discount is 65-75%.  I think the 64.28% is just below the FMV range.  I think getting well into the mid-70s will be a challenge but low 70s is a fair expectation given the size.  As discussed, push for 75% to allow the compromise to 72% or so.  A 2016 ELA that I reviewed (and believe was cancelled) had license discounts at 50% (NPI suggested 60% as a target) and that only had $2.2M in list license value.  This blows that away.  You also had SnS at 19% of the net license spend so that would be our target here (vs. 20% offer).  Remind me to chat with you about the topic of handling SnS costs when you cash in tokens which must be used for both the license AND the prorated SnS.  The three-year list price for Mission Critical Support is $1,320,000 or $440K a year. The Global one year SKU is MCS-GLOBAL-SUP-C with a list of $500K.  The three-year SKU is MCS-GLOBAL-3SUP-C which has a programmatic 12% list price reduction to $440K.  The SKU clearly states to get this you need to be paying for Production SnS and a TAM to qualify for MCS.  Interestingly, their price list describes the product as ?VMware Mission Critical Support - Global Option - non-ELA, 3 Year?.  The key words are non-ELA. When I see this I think ?what?s the price if I have an ELA??.  I checked an old price list and the non-ELA used to be A LOT more.  I think they just haven?t fixed the description yet.  A 10% discount should be expected.  The show this already at a 12% discount but that is overstated.  It is a programmatic reduction in their list price and not a concession on this deal.  Additionally, I saw one client doing a sizable ELA that focused largely on vCloud Suite (upgrades and new).  As part of their deal they got their Production Support upgraded to Mission Critical for two years at no charge so we know that type of creativity is possible. They also got one full time Tier 3 TAM (list is $300K) at no charge and paid for one as well.  The TAM being offered (actually it isn?t the offer but it is a list price shown on the last worksheet) indicates the SKU is TAM-TIER-2.  Typically I see this have a list of $154,995 but it can have multiple personalities as evidenced by the description NPI has seen as follows:  1. A single (1) TAM SKU includes 1 business days worth of time each week delivered by a VMware TAM for a duration of one year.   2. A single (1) STAM SKU includes a half-week (2.5 business days) of a single TAM resource delivered for one year. 3. A single (1) Dedicated STAM SKU includes a week (5 business days) delivered by a single TAM resource for one year.  Note, only full SKUs may be ordered no partial amounts, half-SKUs, or changes to the published fees on the order will be honored without prior sign-off from the VP of PSO for the geography.   Multiple quantities of the TAM SKUs may be included on an order.  See the TAM FAQ for more information (TAM.VMware.COM)  The $154,995 applies to the one-day a week item.  MetLife is getting ?Enterprise Technical Account Manager - 2.5 days/week? so it does make intuitive sense that your list price is about 33% higher at $206K.  That passes our sniff test.  Actually, that?s the list price shown but in the one-page ELA summary there?s a Tier-1 TAM noted with a list of $87,445.  This must be Global.  NPI has seen list of $64,955 about 24 months ago.  A year ago we saw the non-Global at $71,495 and MetLIfe in 2016 had a Global TAM one-year offer of $76,995 (reflecting the Global upcharge).  The current $87,445 reflects an almost 14% increase from the $76,995.  That?s sizable.  I?d point that out and push for 10-20% discounting.   The Education and PSO credits are priced exactly as you?d expect. At volumes over 1,200 the programmatic list price drops from $100 to $80.  Not a real concession in my mind. The BS about all these credits being required to justify the discounts is pure salesmanship.  No discounts on TAM or MCS and the token discount is pedestrian at this spend level.  Credits often expire in a year, if you buy push to ensure they can be used throughout the three year term.  I reflected targets in columns I and J in the attached one page ELA summary.  NPI has not seen a lot of MCS purchased. I found 4 attached PDFs that talk about the differences between MCS and BCS.   FINAL FEEDBACK: Hey Jim, Hope the week is going well.  We went back and continued to think on your VMWare situation.  It definitely has a few wrinkles: ?	Not really net new license spend although it can seemingly look like it is ?	Challenged with the knowledge that there?s already a contractual obligation of $10.8M in installed base SnS over the next four years (three year $8.1M obligation extended to four years) ?	Reflects a 12% reduction from the $10.8M and includes lots of upgrades needed for the COE and creates an SnS run rate reduction of about $1.6M a year ($2.7M to an NPI estimated $1.1M)  ?	Could include upside of using functionality included in upgrade to replace Turbonomics spend  So in light of these wrinkles and the tokens not being net new I do think it makes sense to reconsider FMV and BIC targets.  The last offer was a 66% discount. This improved and entered into NPIs initial FMV range of 65 to 75% where we indicated exceeding 72% would be very challenging.  Many clients with smaller spend struggle to hit NPIs 50% discount target.   After revisiting past reviews and figuring out how to reflect the unique situation (noted above), NPI revised FMV range and BIC discount are: ?	62-68% is our best estimate of an FMV range.  ?	Above 68% for this situation feels equivalent to a BIC discount
deal_metadata.customer_comments: we went back and forth.  This got pretty focused on the token discount.  He also was concerned that the token buy really wasn't net new so we may not want to hold it to the typical new license buy discount standard. Also made a strong case that VMware knew they had locked rev from IB SNS and so why do an ELA for less than that.  FInal baseline required adjustments as tokens changed and relief on past support changed.  Also took a bit of a leap of faith that discount should be considered higher due to relief issue even though the figure shown was a list price which isn't reality.
deal_metadata.description: Weird situation.  Many vsphere licenses are on extended support.  Lots of upgrades needed plus VMware doesn't sell standard and enterprise editions anymore.  VMWare clearly getting creative to recognize software revenue.  They're offering to buy back a bunch of software and then Metlife to buy tokens to buy the upgraded software.  Really just need vsphere E+ but we think for rev rec reasons they're saying they need vSOM (vsphere operations mgt).  Really odd. Offered to buy at 80% of list. Now at 95%.  Weird since they bought at a discount.  Saw once before with ADP-CDK where the buyback quantity was WAY more than the licenses owned.  It's clear financial engineering of some sort.  Lots of tokens included to buy VSOM.  We did an exercise to see the cost if they just upgraded a bunch of licenses. Many licenses are already e+ and are fine.  They included a bunch of services as well.  It wasn't a typical analysis since the buyback and the spreadsheet are quite odd.  Turns out to support a center of excellence (COE) they need to get on same versions so the threat of doing a few upgrades only weakened.  Jim asked for some set things and we acted as a sounding board.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: There?s a variety of info to report back.    For starters in the Draft Workbook worksheet ?Software Buyback-Destruct CTR? I added columns H-K to show the cost to upgrade the 3 items we discussed. I extended out the costs and applied a 65% discount. I also added in 3 years of SnS at 20% of the net license spend.  I included totals in row 20.  I had to estimate the vSOM upgrade but my figure is likely a little on the high side.  The two main upgrade SKUs are listed below.  I?m not exactly sure if you still want to calculate some sort of upgrade and renew SnS vs. do the ELA but this will be an input into that.  ?	VS6-STD-EPL-UG-C - Upgrade: VMware vSphere 6 Standard to vSphere 6 Enterprise Plus for 1 Processor - $2,750  ?	VS6-ENT-EPL-UG-C - Upgrade: VMware vSphere 6 Enterprise to vSphere 6 Enterprise Plus for 1 Processor - $682  The FMV range for the token-based discount is 65-75%.  I think the 64.28% is just below the FMV range.  I think getting well into the mid-70s will be a challenge but low 70s is a fair expectation given the size.  As discussed, push for 75% to allow the compromise to 72% or so.  A 2016 ELA that I reviewed (and believe was cancelled) had license discounts at 50% (NPI suggested 60% as a target) and that only had $2.2M in list license value.  This blows that away.  You also had SnS at 19% of the net license spend so that would be our target here (vs. 20% offer).  Remind me to chat with you about the topic of handling SnS costs when you cash in tokens which must be used for both the license AND the prorated SnS.  The three-year list price for Mission Critical Support is $1,320,000 or $440K a year. The Global one year SKU is MCS-GLOBAL-SUP-C with a list of $500K.  The three-year SKU is MCS-GLOBAL-3SUP-C which has a programmatic 12% list price reduction to $440K.  The SKU clearly states to get this you need to be paying for Production SnS and a TAM to qualify for MCS.  Interestingly, their price list describes the product as ?VMware Mission Critical Support - Global Option - non-ELA, 3 Year?.  The key words are non-ELA. When I see this I think ?what?s the price if I have an ELA??.  I checked an old price list and the non-ELA used to be A LOT more.  I think they just haven?t fixed the description yet.  A 10% discount should be expected.  The show this already at a 12% discount but that is overstated.  It is a programmatic reduction in their list price and not a concession on this deal.  Additionally, I saw one client doing a sizable ELA that focused largely on vCloud Suite (upgrades and new).  As part of their deal they got their Production Support upgraded to Mission Critical for two years at no charge so we know that type of creativity is possible. They also got one full time Tier 3 TAM (list is $300K) at no charge and paid for one as well.  The TAM being offered (actually it isn?t the offer but it is a list price shown on the last worksheet) indicates the SKU is TAM-TIER-2.  Typically I see this have a list of $154,995 but it can have multiple personalities as evidenced by the description NPI has seen as follows:  1. A single (1) TAM SKU includes 1 business days worth of time each week delivered by a VMware TAM for a duration of one year.   2. A single (1) STAM SKU includes a half-week (2.5 business days) of a single TAM resource delivered for one year. 3. A single (1) Dedicated STAM SKU includes a week (5 business days) delivered by a single TAM resource for one year.  Note, only full SKUs may be ordered no partial amounts, half-SKUs, or changes to the published fees on the order will be honored without prior sign-off from the VP of PSO for the geography.   Multiple quantities of the TAM SKUs may be included on an order.  See the TAM FAQ for more information (TAM.VMware.COM)  The $154,995 applies to the one-day a week item.  MetLife is getting ?Enterprise Technical Account Manager - 2.5 days/week? so it does make intuitive sense that your list price is about 33% higher at $206K.  That passes our sniff test.  Actually, that?s the list price shown but in the one-page ELA summary there?s a Tier-1 TAM noted with a list of $87,445.  This must be Global.  NPI has seen list of $64,955 about 24 months ago. deal_metadata.current_narrative: SC has accepted 5% uplift for several years which has inflated the pricing over time.    They may end up looking into DMO, but it hasn't made sense for them financially to do so yet.    We recommended they push back based on the increases over the years (25% in total from 2013)  Waiting on next renewal in August
deal_metadata.description: Received the Aug 2017 renewal for review - so 5 months early for next renewal

file_info.name: FW  Chef renewal for NPI review.msg

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI provided feedback via email. see attached.   Standard support which is included in the Node Pricing vs Premium $0 line item as seen on other quotes.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Based on existing discounts and outcomes that we?ve seen with other clients, NPI finds the FMV range for this purchase is 65% - 68%.  With a current blended discount of 65.7%, VSP is within FMV, but we have seen slightly better discounting and we believe VSP should target 68% for 2,000 Nodes, returning an additional ~$6K in savings.   The message to Chef should focus on dollar figures vs discount percentages.  It is a more convincing argument to explain to Chef that you are trying to reach a budgetary number of $82,250 (using a specific number makes it seem more realistic).  You may be able to rob from Peter to pay Paul and add some additional dollars to the budget for this project, but we are unlikely to get to $94K.  If Chef can meet us in the middle around $85K, approval will likely happen quicker.  NPI is interested in the negotiations that have occurred to this point with Chef?  What has VSP done & said to reach the current 65.7% blended discount?  In sum, NPI feels this pricing is within FMV as is, but 68% is achievable and would be closer to best-in-class.
deal_metadata.description: Hi,  Can you review the quote attached and let me know there is room for price improvement? We already pay $46 for the licenses that we already own and $50 for new licenses.   NOTE from Client: You can close the request for Chef. Another CM was working on that and closed the deal. He appreciated the feedback.  I don't know what that means... closing with "unknown status"

deal_metadata.current_narrative: We reviewed Mavenlink and Workfront together... VSP went with Workfront - achieves small savings there.    NPI provided feedback via email, see attached.  Not a lot of previous exposure to Mavenlink as it appears more costly than Workfront. Suggested targeting lower cost license (premier) to see $20K reduction in quoted license (enterprise) pricing or even choosing the lower cost item.  NPI recommends that VSP approach Mavenlink with dollar figures instead of discount percentages.  The message to Mavenlink could be something along these lines, ?We had an expectation ? and set our budget accordingly ? that we would see a charge more like $30/user/month, or $360/year.  The current offer of $60/user/month is really a non-starter.  This is a competitive bid situation and for the most part, the remaining solutions are technically similar.  So it has come down to a pricing conversation, and Mavenlink is losing ? badly.  We may be able to rob Peter to pay Paul and move some additional money into the budget for this project, but we won?t be able to get near $72K.?  Please let me know if you have any other questions or if you would like to discuss further on a call.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: After our conversation yesterday re: Workfront & Mavenlink, I wanted to follow-up with the feedback on Mavenlink (Workfront feedback sent in different email).  We?ve discussed everything below, but wanted to get it to you in written form so you have it.  Originally, NPI reviewed a 36-month term for Mavenlink Enterprise for 200 users.  In our discussion yesterday, we see that Mavenlink is now offering a 24% discount for 100 users, for a total license cost of $72K.  While NPI has seen fewer Mavenlink deals than we have seen for Workfront, we have enough data points to provide some general market analysis.  NPI believes the target discount for this size deal is closer to 30% - 35% discounting which would result in a total annual license cost of ~$60K.  Regarding the professional services, these are offered with 0% discounting.  It is not unusual that professional services have no discount, but on a deal of this size and term length, it is also reasonable to seek a nominal 5% - 15% discount on these services.  See the table below for an illustration of NPI?s recommended targets:
deal_metadata.description: Chris,  Would you please provide your benchmarks for Mavenlink?

deal_metadata.deal_subject: Oracle Fusion Sales Cloud - Incentive Compensation Cloud Service
deal_metadata.current_narrative: ?	Oracle has offered a discount of 52% for various Oracle Cloud Services.  o	In the past year, NPI has seen a large discount variance for Oracle Cloud product. o	 NPI has seen discounts vary between 20% and 86%.  o	The typical expected discount range for transactions of this size is 45% - 64%.   ?	While the offered discount of 52% is within this market range, there is room for improvement in discounting of up to 12%. However, Oracle may balk at this purchase going below $2M making 61% discount an achievable target. ?	Previously, Equifax has received a discount of 38% for this product: B67272 - Oracle Fusion Incentive Compensation Cloud Service - Hosted Compensated Individual for a smaller number of users ( 300 vs the current proposed 1950).   We are moving forward with a new subscription contract for ?Oracle Fusion Incentive Compensation?. This is the first review you and Smita provided.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Here are the details:  Term of Agreement: 5 years 56% Discount No increases during term; 2% Annual Increase Cap thereafter Price hold for additional capacity during the agreement term
deal_metadata.customer_comments: NO FINAL DOCS

deal_metadata.current_narrative: ?	Oracle has offered a discount of 52% for various Oracle Cloud Services.  o	In the past year, NPI has seen a large discount variance for Oracle Cloud product. o	 NPI has seen discounts vary between 20% and 86%.  o	The typical expected discount range for transactions of this size is 45% - 64%.   ?	While the offered discount of 52% is within this market range, there is room for improvement in discounting of up to 12%. However, Oracle may balk at this purchase going below $2M making 61% discount an achievable target. ?	Previously, Equifax has received a discount of 38% for this product: B67272 - Oracle Fusion Incentive Compensation Cloud Service - Hosted Compensated Individual for a smaller number of users ( 300 vs the current proposed 1950).   We are moving forward with a new subscription contract for ?Oracle Fusion Incentive Compensation?. This is the first review you and Smita provided.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Here are the details:  Term of Agreement: 5 years 56% Discount No increases during term; 2% Annual Increase Cap thereafter Price hold for additional capacity during the agreement term

deal_metadata.current_narrative: REI requested feedback on a Parasoft Pilot Program totalling $71K  No comparable data within SFDC, provided general feedback as the pricing should be great given that it is a pilot/test trial.   NPI provided feedback via email, see attached.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: We were hoping to get a positive hit on the product SKUs but could not find any matches.  We have typically seen the perpetual licenses at a much higher cost than that of your subscription pricing.  Parasoft may have also created a custom SKU/product for REI that is not in the usual product catalog offered to all customers ? especially since this reflects a 9 month pilot with option to credit toward unlimited ELA solutions prior to 12/31/2018.   As NPI will do for niche vendors that we do not have frequent exposure to, we will look toward LinkedIn to identify potential SMEs to gain company insight. Without having much luck in the process, we did note flat/declining LinkedIn hiring activity over the last year which likely means Parasoft is hungry for new business and logos on their website. This would support low initial pricing in hopes to lure REI onto the platform.   NPI suggests gaining further clarity of the ?REI may choose to leverage the already incurred costs of the Pilot as credit?? (found at the bottom of the first quote you provided) to confirm full understanding of what the 2nd year total costs would be should REI decide to retain Parasoft. Identifying this early in the process protects REI from overexposing to unforeseen ?sticker shock? and can play part in ultimately determining whether it is worth embarking on the pilot program. This will also provide additional detail of ?how good a deal? the pilot is and how you may be able to leverage that information to lock in pricing.   As for ?Consulting Services?, NPI see the current fees as their typical rack rate and would target 8% - 10% in discounting. Achieving these savings results in an additional $2,400 - $3,000 in savings.
deal_metadata.description: Initial request from REI:  Morning Jonathan  Have another one for ya.  We are looking to run a pilot from Parasoft so we can test out their masking software.  The proposal include a total of 96 hours of professional services.  56 would be to setup the pilot and 40 would be used for training.  Combined the hourly rate is $312 which seems high but don?t know if that is common for this type of engagement.  The $41,000 is a one year license.  The QU team is looking at other providers but wanted to test Parasoft to see what they can provide.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s combined NetApp offer and found pricing to be just above fair market value (FMV). While the main maintenance renewals hold strong discounting, there?s opportunity around the OCI licensing due to  alignment with NetApp?s quarter-end. NetApp has greater flexibility on the capital side of this purchase, but NPI recommends BNYM approach them with an even net target and let the vendor determine a way to relieve cost concerns. Offering this in exchange for an expedient signature before open deals begin drawing scrutiny and pressure across the sales organization as it gets later in April.  NPI hears many complaints about the high costs of NetApp?s OCI software, and it?s possible BNYM holds better precedent pricing from previous transactions.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Targets ?	NPI recommends offering a $2.4M net total as the focal point NetApp needs to hit to maintain momentum that could lead to a signature before April.   o	NPI recognizes that this transaction is needed and BNYM is under some extra timing pressure due to expired agreements in this deal, but NetApp commonly faces cost concerns with OCI?s rising outlays in environments. The sales team will be wary of any sign that the deal or any of its components could be put on hold to fit BNYM?s own internal cost goals.    ?	NPI highly recommends not addressing specific discount amounts and approaching NetApp with the bottom-line figure. BNYM can address specific discounting around the OCI License True-up or other parts if better precedent discounting exists, but NetApp will not be responsive to anything tied to benchmarks or requests for better raw discounting. o	Similarly, the StorageX spend would best be approached with a $250k net target if this is a net new investment. Without that confirmation, NPI cannot recommend a more aggressive target.    ?	The range of FMV includes discounts more aggressive than the 72% on the OCI software, but NPI?s target remains conservative due to prevailing factors driving the transaction.  If some other leverage exists, for example another upcoming capital spend or a recent lapse in SLAs, NPI would target discounts in the higher 70s for the OCI capacity.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: frustrating.  BNY indicated they did get savings but used "other" market intel that laid out more aggressive targets than those we furnished.  Another report they tried not to count.  No specifics on close, so safe assumption they at least hit our FMV targets.   BNYM has an upcoming true-up purchase of NetApp?s OnCommand Insight as well as several maintenance renewals.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Asked for additional info... see attached email for cleaner view...  Never received additional info... got word that they closed as is.  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  We?ve seen a number of Unicom purchases and renewals so I do have data to compare, but I may need additional information.  Unicom maintenance for these 2 products is typically 18% of net license cost, and depending on the size, we have seen that get down as low as 15% of net license cost.  This renewal quote doesn?t provide quite enough detail to figure out the pricing on this.  Ideally, you would go back to the original purchase and insure that your maintenance costs are still in the 15% - 20% of net license cost.   If you don?t know original costs, then you could try to back in to it using specific products and # of MIPS.    The 2 graphics below shows list price for specific products based on # of MIPs.  Again, this is the list price for the license, maintenance would be 18% of the net license fee.  There are several pages within the price list that NPI has for each of these products for ?Assembler support?, ?Batch Support?, ?CICS support?, ?DB2 Support?, etc.  Let me know if you can find your original purchase for these licenses or if you can provide the additional details for us to back in to the license costs so that we can calculate the maintenance fees.
deal_metadata.description: Are you able to review this?  Please let me know what questions you have.  Thank you.   On the quote, that is preliminary numbers. The updated #?s are below:   Sorry I missed that part of your email about the dates.  The renewal period starts on 3/29/2018 so for the sake of the license keys being delivered in time to replace the expiring ones we would ask that payment be sent 30 days prior to the start of the term (around 2/28/2018).    I see that last year we were able to offer a 5% discount on the 1 year renewal. I can offer a similar discount for the 2018 term. We also have 3 and 5 year maintenance agreements, paid annually, which I?ve outlined below along with the 2018 discounted rates for all 3 options.    Duration	2018 Maintenance	Maintenance Cap 1 year	$177,913 ($9,364 discount)	10% cap 3 year	$173,061 ($14,261 discount)	5% cap 5 year	$169,827 ($17,450 discount)	3% cap

deal_metadata.current_narrative: This is a service subject to tariff regulations and there is always some vagueness around when a carrier can discount and how they discount.  The most recent tariff covering this service is attached.  The pricing covering this service begins at the bottom of page 130.  From that pricing, NPI determined that Progressive is getting a 17% discount on nodes and a 45% discount on channel mileage (see below).  Tariff Element	Tariff Rate	Contract Rate	Savings  Node	$3690	$3050	$640 or 17% Mileage (per mile)	$150	$82.50	$67.50 or 45%   The total is $10,800 per month, $129,600 per year or $259,200 over the term.  Incremental discounts may be available to Progressive depending on the overall spend with Centurylink.  If the service has already been installed for 60 months or more, Progressive may push for a 25% discount on the Node.  Doing so would save $10,170  per year ($20,340/term).  The messaging around this is simply that you are being asked to scrutinize every expense.  You are simply asking if they can find any way to apply a 25% discount to the cost of nodes.  Progressive can realize a more significant savings with either a technology migration or migration to alternative suppliers.  Most of NPI's clients have migrated away from these types of rings in favor of redundant point-to-point diverse fiber connections.  Please let me know if you have any questions or want additional support.
deal_metadata.description: Just wanted to request a NPI report for this deal. This is a SHNS(Self-Healing Network Service) we are using for Phoenix. The pricing has remained constant the past few years. We just want to ensure that we are paying the right amount and prices for these haven?t gone down.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Fred, Hey there. So we see Hortonworks a couple times a year.  Most are HDP but certainly some HDF.  We?ve seen the same discounting approach for both.  Generally quite stingy. NPI was only able to focus on the Term offer.  I?ve got a SME who resells for IBM and is able to validate list pricing.  Even though MetLife is an SVP Level J IBM customer that isn?t impacting your Hortonworks (HW) pricing at all.  Generally, the base price for an IBM license is level BL (Baseline). I think of that as the absolute highest list price.  Depending on your spend you earn an SVP level with IBM.  Most clients are H, I or J.  For many IBM items Level I introduces a revised MSRP that is 15% lower than BL.  Level J is generally about 20% lower.  There are some products where there?s no difference i.e., BL = SVP H = SVP J.  On our own, we also validated these are list prices by comparing to a few other client reviews.  With the HW products I wasn?t surprised to learn there?s no programmatical reduction in the list price even if you?re SVP J.  Here?s an insider?s view below of the first two products in your quote from IBM.  You can see BL = each SVP price.  For many Level J clients we?d expect some sizable discounts off of that price (50%+); however, it appears (and it is not surprising) that MetLIfe is being offered only a 20% discount.  I would?ve guessed IBM would be constrained by the same pricing approach HW offers themselves.  Do you know your current discounts on your HDP support subscriptions?  If it works to your favor I?d be leveraging that.  So MetLife is being offered a 20% discount of list. Again, there?s no inherent pricing advantage being a Level J IBM Customer so don?t let them tell you otherwise.  NPIs FMV range on a one-year HW subscription with an extended list price of $554,000 is 28-35%.  The offer feels a bit on the low side for an initial purchase and such a sizable expansion beyond HDP into HDF.  Exceeding 40% would be considered best-in-class.  In the past, clients have been told multi-year deals (the example was 3 years) received 6% more i.e., a one year offer at 20% became three years each at 26%.  NPI is not sure if IBM can offer this or if MetLife is interested in this term.  We?ve also seen clients stagger their growth and receive increases in their discounting (2-4 points) as they bump up their volume each year.  In sum, the offer feels a bit light.  A 30% outcome would lower the current $443K offer to $388K for a $55K reduction.  A 40% outcome drops the net to $360K or an $83K reduction.  Reviewed revised; Thanks. Everything in terms of term, products and quantities remains unchanged.  Discount went from 20 to 25%.  Definitely right up against FMV in my estimation. They are getting increasingly stingy and you are seeing that.  Plus there?s the added twist of IBM being involved and taking their cut which certainly has to impact your end discount.  30% would still be the target.  Open to a longer term?  I know there?s not much in terms of competition for the Flow/Streaming products so that makes it tougher.  Glad to see the improvement for sure.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: From Fred: Hortonworks ? Died a slow death because of the pricing offered.  Added HDF to the IBM ELA agreement completed at the end of June.
deal_metadata.description: New purchase through IBM.  Focused on term option not odd perpetual license  I have another odd request to have you look at and see if you can offer any guidance.  Attached are two quotes from IBM for support subscriptions of Hortonworks DataFlow products.  One is a term support subscription and the other is something they are calling a perpetual ?license?.  I am focused on the term support agreement.  Do you have any fair market value information on Hortonworks DataFlow support subscriptions? Target pricing for a deal of this size?  The perpetual model is a convoluted point systems devised by IBM, Hortonworks doesn?t have anything like it. In the perpetual model we would buy the ?license? and it comes with 12 months of support.    After that, we would pay annual maintenance, estimated to be 20% of the ?license? cost. I put ?license? in quotes because they are not selling a software license, but a support license. All of the Hortonworks DataFlow products are some different flavor of Apache open source products, Hortonworks just provides support for them.  I?ve attached the two IBM quotes, I wouldn?t expect you to have anything like the IBM perpetual but if you can locate Hortonworks DataFlow subscription pricing, that should compare to the IBM term quote.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI recommendations take into consideration the overall MetLife relationship with Cisco has been in the ~$17M range for 2017.   Pricing Analysis ?	MetLife?s software discount is in line with historic pricing for MetLife at a 60% discount off List.  ?	NPI added a new layer of analysis and also benchmarked this SKU against a competitive product and provides some additional negotiating points below.  Targets  Type of Spend	Net Price	Discount	Target Discount	Net Target	Target Savings Software	$298,480 	60%	60%	$298,480 	$0  Support (1 Year Option)	$107,452 	28%	28%	$107,452 	$0  Support (3 Year Option)	$299,972 	33%	33% - 35%	$291,018 	$8,954  Support (5 Year Option)	$462,644 	38%	38% - 40%	$447,720 	$14,924   Negotiation Leverage and Strategy  NPI is providing some additional background on Denodo, a primary competitor to Cisco?s DV product suite.  We are providing this information to add some additional insight and potential negotiating points in the discussion on pricing with Cisco.  Denodo has multiple Licensing Models based on Customer requirements. Their claim is to attempt to offer the Licensing Model which best fits the customer?s need. Denodo licenses the Platform according to the number of cores, with all features included out of the box (Connectors, etc?). The amount of processing cores required is dependent on the Use Cases and the complexities of the queries, transformations, number of concurrent queries, etc.   Denodo offers the product in three different modalities:  ?	Perpetual Single Server  ?	Perpetual Multi server  ?	Annual Subscription   Perpetual Multi-Server  ?	Pricing is typically sold at ~$100,000 per Prod Core with Unlimited Non-Prod (see notes) with full flexibility to configure cores in multiple servers as needed.   o	Cisco pricing is offered at $298,500 for 4 Prod and 1 Non-Prod Cores with additional charges for staging/backup servers. o	Depending on the system landscape, scenarios with a large Non-Prod (Dev/Test/Stage) environment may require additional spend for additional non-prod licenses under the Cisco offer, where an unlimited scenario under a Denodo model would include these licenses for no cost.  (For Example.  4 Prod cores with 4 Dev cores under the Cisco model would require MetLife to purchase 3 additional Non-Prod cores as the SKU only included 4 Prod and 1 Non-Prod core.  The Denodo model would allow 4 Prod cores AND up to the same number of Non-Prod cores (which would be 4).  ?	All Non-Production licenses are included at No Charge so long as the quantity of cores deployed in any one non-Production server does not exceed the quantity of cores deployed in the Production server., i.e., 8 Production Cores are purchased, customer can deploy as many non-production servers so long as no one non-production server exceeds 8 cores so this is a standard offer from Denodo.   Perpetual support pricing - Annual Support and Maintenance for Perpetual Licenses  ?	Standard Support - 20% Of Net Price  ?	Premium Support - 25% Of Net Price o	Cisco pricing is offered at 31% (5 Year), 34% (3 Year), or 36% (1 Year) of Net Price  Single Server Subscription  ?	Annual subscriptions start at $10k/month/per Quad Core Server, including annual support and maintenance (5 day x 8 hr.), $11k month/Quad Core Server, including annual support and maintenance (7 day x 24 hr.).  ?	Non-Production Servers are not included and would be priced using the same ratio as in the Single Server Model. A minimum commitment of one year is required. Customers with budget constraints might chose the subscription model. The subscription model is less cost effective in the long term than the perpetual model.  ?	One quad core at Premium Support for the production environment is 12 months  x $11K = $132K   ?	NPI finds that Cisco pricing is within FMV yet if a convincing argument can be made on competitive product lines, favorable support options may be able to be negotiated into today?s contract to ensure support costs remain favorable to MetLife.   ?	NPI recommends that MetLife ask if a more favorable Dev/Test/Stage licensing model can be crafted to avoid future increases tied to this area.  (Point to the unlimited offer of the competitor). ?	Overall, the offer, as it currently stands, is within a reasonable FMV range and MetLife can proceed with confidence as the negotiated target discounts are small figures that may not justify further negotiations.
deal_metadata.description: Gregg ? attached are 1, 3 and 5 year proposals/BOM?s from Cisco. It does contain the part number. Is it typical for Cisco to provide support in this manner, discount a maintenance list cost?

deal_metadata.current_narrative: SEE EMAIL BELOW IN "EMAIL" SECTION FOR CLEANER VIEW OF FEEDBACK.  Hi Steve,  Thanks again for sending this over for NPI to review.  I have been able to speak to my Oracle SME to gain some clarity on your pricing.  In the interest of a faster turnaround, please find NPI?s analysis below.  If you need this in a more formal document, I can put that together for you, just let me know.  The majority of the HW on the quote is discounted at 23.0%.  NPI considers this to be within the range of Fair Market Value (FMV), but we have seen that, on a purchase of this size, Oracle will reach 25% - 26%.  At 25% discounting, this proposal would total ~$160K per site, a savings of ~$5K per site.  Support is priced at exactly 12.0% of the net HW cost, this is very standard for Oracle and they will not move off of that number.  However, if JCI is successful in reducing the HW cost, you will want to make sure that support remains at 12% of the new cost.  See the table below for an illustration of NPI?s recommended targets: Part Number Hardware Desc Qty Net Fee List Price Discount Target Disc Target 7117458 Oracle Database Appliance  X7-2-HA with 2 servers 1 $32,609.5 $42,350.0 23% 25% $31,762.5 333V-20-15-C14  Power cord: Sun Rack jumper, straight, 2 meters, C14 plug, C13 connector, 15 A (for factory installation) 4 $77.0 $100.0 23% 25% $75.0 333V-20-15-C14  Power cord: Sun Rack jumper, straight, 2 meters, C14 plug, C13 connector, 15 A (for factory installation) 2 $38.5 $50.0 23% 25% $37.5 7117465 Oracle Database Appliance  X7-2-HA storage enclosure fully populated with twenty 3.2 TB SSDs and four 800 GB SSDs 1 $84,315.0 $109,500.0 23% 25% $82,125.0 B74194  Oracle Standard System Installation Service, Site Audit: Engineered Systems - Group II  1 $4,050.7 $4,050.7     $4,050.7   Oracle Premier Support for Systems   $42,134.4       $41,041.1 X2129A-N  Dual rate transceiver: SFP+ SR. Support 1 Gb/sec and 10 Gb/sec dual rate Total: 1,784.32 4 $1,312.0 $1,312.0 0% 25% $984.0   Oracle Premier Support for Systems   $472.3       $472.3   Total $165,009.4    $160,548.09   2 sites-> $330,018.82   2 sites-> $321,096.18  Please let me know if you have any questions or if you would like to discuss on a call.

?	NPI validated pricing for each of the 2 major SKUs and they are being quoted with the proper discounting level ? Level 5 ? with the next price break occurring at the 10K level. ?	Review of the past CAMC purchases from 2015 show that pricing has been consistently increased on an annual basis.   ?	A deeper dive into some recent, additional LanDesk deals illustrates their ability to offer even deeper discounting from the original purchase.  Although it would be uncommon for LanDesk to grant a significant reduction in pricing without a justifiable reason, such as an increase in licensing or a multi-year contract, NPI encourages the CAMC team to push for a price reduction ?level-set?.  ?	NPI ran a scenario that has a more reasonable 2% annual increase.  This increase is much more reflective of a typical CPI-U increase that NPI would expect to see for a subscription such as LanDesk.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s offer from Oracle and found pricing to be at FMV (fair market value).  While price points are competitive (the main ASO piece?s rates are below FMV), the total deal?s actual value will vary depending on true utilization during the term.  Timing pressure is elevated for both sides, but depending on the sales team?s eagerness, this deal could be key to quotas.  BNYM has also indicated that the RAT components would be nice to add under the ULA, but may not be a necessarily part of this.  Adding these products to the ULA also adds the risks associated with variable deployment schedules.  Positioning these doubts as the reason BNYM is holding off on a purchase decision could edge out some final savings in the final hours. However, NPI considers this pricing to be strong as is.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI recommends leading with a $1.775M target amount as the amount needed in exchange for the expedited approval of the final amount.  Starting with that figure without commentary will have the greatest effect, and if pressed, BNYM can then offer explanation behind the rationale.  As credibly as is possible, this target figure should be linked to budgetary concerns.   ?	NPI highly recommends tying this to a simple budgetary goal needed for the quickest approval, and not mentioning any specific discounting or benchmarks.
deal_metadata.description: Closing: Savings of $256k affected in last day but limited credit to NPI.  BNYM is reviewing an Amendment to add licenses on an existing ULA.  The deal?s incentives are tied to the vendor?s impending fiscal quarter end.

Thanks for sending this over and thanks again, for your patience in getting this feedback.  NPI has seen SAP?s HEC services and we had a number of deals of similar size and scope for comparison.  NPI reviewed the proposed cost of HANA Enterprise Cloud for Projects and Enhanced Managed Services and found the proposal to be largely at Fair Market Value (FMV).  SAP?s HANA Enterprise Cloud is essentially an Infrastructure-as-a-Service managed services for SAP software where the customer can offload the management of their SAP footprint.  As with the large accompanying license purchase that NPI previously reviewed, the pricing for HEC is fairly custom and based on the SAP footprint. Since this purchase is being made on the heels of the large SAP purchase where Stericycle obtained very high discounts approaching best-in-class, not surprisingly, the pricing on this cloud services deal is also at the low (better) end of the range of FMV.  The SLAs and other terms and conditions are fairly standard and in line with the Ts and Cs that NPI has observed with comparable transactions. SAP Hana Enterprise Cloud is typically sold in two flavors, Projects and Production. The SLA for Projects is 95% as proposed in the order form and the SLA for Production is 99.5% (Stericycle is not purchasing this).   The pricing for HEC for projects is a consumption?based, weekly service fee. In this case it is priced at $20,556 per week. Based on Stericycle?s SAP footprint and sizing, this translates to an annual cost of a little over a $1M a year which is at FMV. NPI would expect this price to be between $1M and $1.2M based on comparisons to similarly sized deals.  EMS services are priced at $147 per hour which is also within Fair Market Value.
deal_metadata.description: I don?t believe the SAP HEC was sent over to you to analyze. The attached has the following agreements or documents:  ? SAP HEC Order Form; This holds the pricing per month and other rates. ? SAP HEC General Terms and Conditions for SAP Cloud Services.  ? SAP HEC Supplement Attachment ? SAP HEC SLA Attachment ? SAP HEC Data Processing Attachment  These agreements are still in Legal but wanted to send this over to you to get this reviewed as we need to finalize by February. So if you can send to us within 5 days that would be good.

NPI has seen SAP?s HEC services and we had a number of deals of similar size and scope for comparison.  NPI reviewed the proposed cost of HANA Enterprise Cloud for Projects and Enhanced Managed Services and found the proposal to be largely at Fair Market Value (FMV).  SAP?s HANA Enterprise Cloud is essentially an Infrastructure-as-a-Service managed services for SAP software where the customer can offload the management of their SAP footprint.  As with the large accompanying license purchase that NPI previously reviewed, the pricing for HEC is fairly custom and based on the SAP footprint. Since this purchase is being made on the heels of the large SAP purchase where Stericycle obtained very high discounts approaching best-in-class, not surprisingly, the pricing on this cloud services deal is also at the low (better) end of the range of FMV.  The SLAs and other terms and conditions are fairly standard and in line with the Ts and Cs that NPI has observed with comparable transactions. SAP Hana Enterprise Cloud is typically sold in two flavors, Projects and Production. The SLA for Projects is 95% as proposed in the order form and the SLA for Production is 99.5% (Stericycle is not purchasing this).   The pricing for HEC for projects is a consumption?based, weekly service fee. In this case it is priced at $20,556 per week. Based on Stericycle?s SAP footprint and sizing, this translates to an annual cost of a little over a $1M a year which is at FMV. NPI would expect this price to be between $1M and $1.2M based on comparisons to similarly sized deals.  EMS services are priced at $147 per hour which is also within Fair Market Value.
deal_metadata.description: I don?t believe the SAP HEC was sent over to you to analyze. The attached has the following agreements or documents:  ? SAP HEC Order Form; This holds the pricing per month and other rates. ? SAP HEC General Terms and Conditions for SAP Cloud Services.  ? SAP HEC Supplement Attachment ? SAP HEC SLA Attachment ? SAP HEC Data Processing Attachment  These agreements are still in Legal but wanted to send this over to you to get this reviewed as we need to finalize by February. So if you can send to us within 5 days that would be good.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI benchmarked pricing and found sizable discounts improvements were possible. NPI target a discount of 50 - 55%, resulting in ~$950k in savings. See formal FMV attached.   See the attached  FMV report for feedback on the three-year renewal offer.  On this size spend the discount is not considered to be within our FMV range.  As you noted in your email, we primarily focused on the three-year offer. However, we did a quick analysis of the one-year offer and calculated a blended discount of ~30%. Compared to the prior year blended discount of ~40%, there is an obvious discount erosion even with the higher dollar spend.  Last year, the one-year term NPI reviewed had a blended 38.4% discount that rose to 43.4% in the final version.  The disappointing pricing on the one-year is not a surprise based on the three-year offer.   Let us know if you want us to dig deeper on this or if the 3 year is your primary concern for feedback.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Hi Lorna,  Thanks for sending this over.  There isn?t quite enough detail to completely benchmark this pricing, but I have sent it over to NPI?s OutSystems SME to see if they can help decipher it.    This appears to be for professional services and they have outlined some of the hours that they expect for each role, but there is a 4-month window that just says ?weekly support? for a Customer Service Engineer and an Engagement Manager.  Using the time estimates they HAVE provided, I am able to account for about ~$115K: ? 144 hours ? Engagement Mangaer ? Estimating $250/hr = $36K ? 200 hours ? Technical Lead ? Estimating $220/hr = $44K ? 160 hours ? Developer ? Estimating $180/hr = $28800 ? 32 hours ? Customer Service Engineer ? Estimating $200/hr = $6,400  So it will depend on how many hours are expected in ?Weekly Support? from the EM and CSE as to whether that will make up the additional $25K.  NPI recommends that Stericycle ask for a bit more detail behind these costs.  Since this is professional services, it is acceptable (and expected) that you should know the hourly rates and estimated # of hours for each role.  A common response to a request like this is that OutSystems will say, ?it could be 2 or it could be 5, we don?t know.?  Be assured that they have put together estimates on the level of effort in order to create this pricing.  Stericycle will want to know the estimated work effort  because that will determine if this pricing is fair or not.  If the EM and CSE will average 2-hours per week during that 4-month period, then the total cost comes to about $130K and Stericycle should seek a reduction.  If they will average 4+ hours per week, then this cost will be approximately break-even.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: NOTE: Closing for data cleanup ... Not sure if Lorna is still with Stericycle.
deal_metadata.description: ADD SME INFO!  I received this proposal and SOW at the last minute. It?s for services from Outsystems to help us develop a Shredit Customer Portal.   I am not familiar with their ?packaged services? but they seem to be offering us support/enablement services vs. traditional professional services to help deliver this portal.   In any case, I?m planning to finalize this by Friday as there is already an MSA on file with this vendor but wanted to send over for you to review these packaged prices for future reference.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: As always, thank you for reaching out to NPI concerning the migration from CloudHealth to YotaScale. Apologies for not getting back you yesterday. I hope this information is still useful and relevant.  Unfortunately, for as much information as NPI has about cloud services in general and AWS services and other iAAS providers, we simply don?t have that much data when it comes to YotaScale.  This should not come as a surprise, considering that they have only 24 employees listed on LinkedIn, several of which are board members and advisors, and they have only been in business since 2015. In fact, YotaScale is largely still living on funding, not revenue, and is still largely a fledgling company:   YotaScale, Inc. is a Silicon Valley startup that is defining infrastructure performance management for the cloud. It is funded by Pelion Venture Partners and Engineering Capital.  YotaScale rec?d $3.6M in funding just over one year ago. From a late 2017 Diginomica article, I gleaned the following excerpt:   As public cloud use proliferates and grows more comprehensive among large enterprises, the difficulty of tracking resource usage, spending and performance is an opportunity for software intelligence and automation. Vendors have cost management services like AWS Cost Explorer. However, these can flood users with data and don?t do a solid job of summarizing it by application, project or department, nor do they provide much help in identifying usage anomalies or their cause. These are just the sorts of insights software from YotaScale, a quasi-stealth startup, seeks to provide by applying machine learning to cloud workload and cost analysis as part of what co-founder and CEO Asim Razzaq calls ?AI-enhanced Infrastructure Performance Management.?  One thing that I can tell you is that the Waterfall pricing method that they are offering is likely receiving push back from clients other than Intuit. This idea that your initial investment continues to be penalized borders on the absurd. There is little incentive to grow your consumption (which Intuit certainly will) under this model. Intuit should push back and either invite YotaScale to lower the cost per EC2 instance to the $1/per offered in the 40K tier, or to change the terms such that when Intuit reaches the next volume tier all of the consumption is repriced to the next tier up.   Intuit does not often prepay for services, but in this particular case, given the commitment of less than $0.5M/year, and the ability to offset the cost of this service, if Intuit offered the cash hungry YotaScale a 3-year prepayment, you could likely push the offer from 15% to 20% and then gain an add?l 5-10% as a referenceable account.  Has Intuit conducted a POC with YotaScale, and if so, NPI assumes it was successful?  In closing, if Intuit is committed to the start-up tech that YotaScale offers, offering a 3-year deal at $1M may carry a lot of weight to company that is certainly hungry for a notable win.

If we could get something back by Tuesday, it would be greatly appreciated.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the quote and found the pricing to be aggressive and within FMV.  Provided a formal FMV, see attached below.

deal_metadata.description: Cindy Sackett provided the following initial request on their upcoming 3 yr MongoDB renewal: We have another effort that we are working on and this one is more time sensitive as our renewal is due at the end of this month (01/31/2019). Attached is their current 3 yr proposal.   A little background: We currently have 82 licenses deployed and have been paying for 83 licenses the last few years. Note that this is the first time we have gotten this close to our previous years commitments of 83 servers. Our LOB has indicated that there is a potential for us to grow by 25 ? 35 licenses over the next 3 years.  Our contract has a server license price of $4,250 per server for 83+ servers and $5,395 for less than 83 servers. Production & DR servers are counted, non-production servers are not and the server metric is at 512GB. These server license prices are locked and ineligible for increase until 01/31/2019. Then it can be increased by 2% or CPI whichever is less annually thereafter.  We have requested that the date of 01/31/2019 be extended for 5 years and MongoDB has refused. They have not even countered with a revised expiration date as of yet. In addition, we have other TCs that we have sent to them to amend our contract with as well. i.e. True Up (annual reporting and true up of any licenses exceeding our entitlements, etc.).  Let me know if you have any questions and we look forward to your feedback.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: ?	A few key factors remain ?in play? within the HPE storage sector ? HPE/Nimble merger continues to affect internal HPE pricing as storage groups strive to validate their product lines and competition continues to drive pricing downwards.  NPI has seen discounts in the 75% - 80% range for new purchases and continues to believe that this pricing is reasonable with the competitive landscape that currently exists. ?	NPI reviewed the Anexinet proposal and takes into consideration the ?free? hardware and support that was bundled.   ?	Because discounts become skewed when ?free? items are included, NPI looks to blended discounts for a more accurate analysis.   ?	The blended discount for the proposal is 69.5%, up from a blended discount of 69.2% prior. ?	NPI also takes into consideration that a $115K discount was also applied to an existing 2018 maintenance proposal for existing hardware (as per Andrew O?Donnell 10/25/2017).  As NPI has not reviewed the aforementioned discount and/or proposal, NPI cannot validate the true ?value? of this discount. ?	Also unknown is the level of engineering support HPE/Anexinet may have provided in the build/design phase of this migration/upgrade.  As these services add ?value?, NPI would expect that the VAR would expect a fair compensation for services rendered (within their margins).  ?	Consideration of the already granted 2018 Maintenance Support Credit of $115K reduces the proposal?s $955K price to a normalized $840K.  At $840K, this proposal would calculate at a blended discount of 73.2%, slightly below where NPI would consider a superior price point. ?	Aggressively targeting an additional 3% discount on the 3Par system and an additional 5% discount on the corresponding support, the target price drops to $857K and with the $115K credit considered, ends at $743K or a blended 76.3%.
deal_metadata.description: OH HOLD per Steve 4/16/18

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  I have had this one for a while and I owe you some feedback.  Since this was a smaller deal and you were out of the office, it got moved a little lower on the priority list.  Typically Oracle renewals are not very exciting.  Often, the best case scenario for a standard Oracle renewal is to have pricing remain flat from the previous year, which is what Oracle is offering in the 18-month proposal.  So NPI considers the 18-month renewal cost to be Fair Market Value (FMV).  In the 24-month and 36-month renewals, Oracle is offering additional discounting on the Multi-tenant service, but the Java CS is maintained at a 30% discount.  NPI sees no reason that the Java service should not also see moderate reductions (or increased discounting) if CNL is going to make a longer-term commitment.  NPI recommends targeting 35% discounting on the Java CS service for the 24-month renewal ? a reduction of ~$2K.  And we recommend targeting 40% discounting on the Java CS service for the 36-month renewal ? a reduction of ~$5K.  The messaging to Oracle is fairly simple, if CNL is going to make a longer-term commitment, it will need to be worth-your-while.  If there is no reduction in the largest cost of this renewal when we make a longer-term commitment, then we may as well just renew for 1-year and see if we will still need these services each year.   UPDATE: Closing as CNL no longer a client.
deal_metadata.description: This is the PAAS which is expiring and is separate from the Oracle Fusion SAAS renewal.    I am OOO until 11/13.  Let me know if you have someone I can work with for these.

deal_metadata.savings_achieved: Y - Savings but no NPI credit
deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s Kofax pricing and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV). Software pricing is solidly within the range of FMV, but maintenance costs have room for improvement based on NPI?s data and similar reviews.  NPI sees the greatest factors of leverage in similarly-sized Kofax spends to be timing pressure and the degree of open competition involved.  Without both of those factors, it is difficult but still feasible to achieve savings targets. If Kofax already knows they?re the preferred vendor and/or no credible threat exists, NPI recommends manifesting uncertainty around this decision point.  Ideally, BNYM should float a high-level net target to the reseller and follow this with a short break in communication to make the vendors nervous about this forecasted deal.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI suggests using a rounded net amount of $800k as a talking point with the reseller and vendor, and to avoid mentioning any specific discounting. Say that this is the target needed to keep this within the March timeframe. o	Messaging can focus on attaining a slight relief on capital costs, but also emphasize that high relative operational expenses are the main factor causing BNYM to pause before proceeding with this purchase.

We indicated this was mostly FMV with opportunity, but client is trying not to count this as a report   BNYM is reviewing a proposal from reseller Document Imaging Group for Kofax?s TotalAgility platform.

deal_metadata.deal_subject: SAS renewal and Prof. Services Rates
deal_metadata.current_narrative: Here are some thoughts on the SAS renewal:  NPI has observed that SAS is a vendor who likes to keep customers in the dark about their pricing.  They have different list pricing depending on the volume of spend and they are very inconsistent in the pricing they will agree to.  What this does tell us is that SAS pricing is highly negotiable.  We know that test environments are typically 25% of the production costs and list prices for Dev and Test are based on a percentage of the list price for the production environment.  There doesn?t seem to be quite enough information in this proposal (email) for NPI to provide a detailed benchmark.  Below are some thoughts and recommendations that VSP will want to consider.  ?	At first blush, the descriptions in the email you attached aren?t detailed enough for us to be able to calculate list price.  Additionally, there are no productions fees in the email description, so we are not able to determine list price and discount percentages for the Dev and Test environments.  If we have better descriptions of the licenses or - better still - if we have SKUs we can usually figure out list price and discount percentages for FYFs.  Having said that, Dev and Test environments list pricing tends to be a percentage of the production costs.  NOTE: NPI strongly recommends that you ask for list price on the FYFs so we can be sure we have the correct discount percentage.  SAS will share list price if pushed. ?	We like to see the first-RYF to be between 27-35% of the FYF.  VSP is at 28% for both the Dev and Test licenses, so that is good, however:   o	We still want to gauge the discount of the FYF fees even though we like 28% for the RYF. Often we see that a good RYF percentage is due to the first year fee is not well discounted. ?	We also like to see the third year fee to be 3% over the second year fee.  SAS has offered 5%.  That?s a standard starting offer.  Target 3%. ?	How big is VSPs overall footprint with SAS?  Can you provide financial details around your production environment?  That helps us adjust our targeted discount for this particular transaction.  It is largely handled standalone by SAS but the big picture should be considered especially if it benefits VSPs. ?	The professional services rates are actually very good in the SOW.  We usually don?t see large market variances in SAS professional services rates. o	The technical consultant is billed at $195. We see market rates between $195 - $200 per hour. o	Technical architects typically bill at $225 per hour. o	The Project Manager is billed at $180. We typically see this at $200 per hour.  If you can provide a bit more detail, I am confident that we can offer more detailed analysis of your SAS pricing.
deal_metadata.description: Do you have benchmarking on SAS professional services?  This is the same price we paid for the same service previously on supplement 5.  We have received an email quote last winter with the attached pricing range.    UPDATE 4/8/2018: SAS is still on-going and has been delayed.   The professional services are at your market rate stated below at $195. The biggest movement is that I negotiated free development and test licenses. A savings of about $338K.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed the rates from Accenture and found the overall blended rate of $159.65 to be in the range of FMV with room for improvement. While some of the individual rates are within FMV, other are at the high end of the range with room for improvement. In summary, NPI believes that there is potential for savings of about 5% of the total proposed cost of the project.  Pricing Analysis  ?	Typical blended rates for the SFDC implementation (including offshore and onsite roles) vary between $150 per hour and $250 per hour based on the vendor and resource mix. Accenture?s blended rate is $159 per hour. ?	SFDC?s stance in general is not to do implementations unless they have to.  They prefer to leave it to their partners.   o	SFDC?s rates are typically in the $225-$250/hr range, so customers generally save money using service partners.   ?	Adding to the conversation is the presence of India-based consultancies who often provide staff augmentation for some of the roles and leverage offshore resources.  NPI typically sees architect-level SFDC resources at rates around $120 - $150/hr from vendors like HCL, Infosys, and Cognizant. ?	Typically, we see a phased approach where the Big 4/Accenture are involved in the initial assessment, strategy, change management, etc., and the ensuing implementation phases are bid out separately to other vendors, including mid-tier consulting firms and India-based consulting firms (who sometimes work in conjunction with the Big 4 on the implementation phases). ?	NPI observed that 54% of the effort is offshore (in terms of the number of hours) and 46% is onsite. This is slightly higher than the typical range that NPI observes on SFDC implementation projects where 25% - 45% of the effort is offshore. This contributes to a lower blended rate. The high offshore utilization may be due to a larger offshore COE (Center of Excellence) for the SFDC practice. ?	While the offshore rates seem extremely high (ranging between $35 and $105), NPI has observed that SFDC resource rates are much higher than the typical offshore rates that we see for other implementation and development projects (between $21 and $55). The same is true for onshore rates as well. ?	NPI noted that there is a large difference between the hourly rates for the two change management content developer line items. Assuming one developer to be more senior, NPI has recommended a rate of $225 vs. $300 for the senior resource. At $185, the junior resource rate is FMV.	 ?	The tables below depict Accenture?s rates, NPI?s target rates and potential savings.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Pressed Rob but he held fast. Correct, the hourly figures did not change. Given that it was T&M and we needed to start quickly since we purchased software sooner than we thought, we just decided not to pursue.  It's possible that I may have to extend SOWs, so at that point I may reach out to you well in advance and push much harder related to the implementation resource cost.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Although the initial discounts offered by Dell EMC are respectable, NPI considers other external factors when classifying pricing and those areas should be considered in this negotiation.  NPI would typically expect to see both Hardware and Software discounted at 70% - 72% for deal of this size. Discounting at 69.5% places this pricing in the high range (and almost above FMV). ? Due to the timing of this fiscal year-end opportunity, NPI has increased the FMV target discount an additional percentage point, up to 73%. Achieving this target will result in approximately $51K in savings. ? Support is typically 20% of net HW/SW pricing for THREE years. In this offer, NPI finds that the support pricing is at 21% of HW/SW pricing, but only covers TWO years. ©2017 NPI, LLC. All Rights Reserved. NPI Confidential Information. May Not Be Disclosed to 3rd Parties. Page 3 ? NPI adjusted for this anomaly and increases the target discount to 82% of list for support. This discount results in a number that extrapolates out to 21% for the typical three-year term. Successfully negotiating this topic will result in approximately $39K in savings. ? Professional services is a rarely discounted line item and NPI finds that the small discounts that are seen are typically found in large deployments with large amounts of professional services. o NPI believes that these funds ARE somewhat flexible and because of the small dollar amount, NPI is applying the 23% discount that we periodically find in larger deployments to this proposal. Although this equates to a small $2K in savings, NPI mentions it as another negotiation point for Michael Kors.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  As I mentioned, NPI has good amount of data on Coupa, as well as a SME in our Advisor Network who also helps with reviews.  In the interest of a quick turnaround, please see notes below in lieu of a more formal document.    It appears that the document you sent over is a 2-year agreement that you signed last year.  It is not unusual that you are looking to discuss the subscription fees mid-contract because NPI has seen that many SaaS vendors are willing to discuss subscription costs off-cycle.  Sometimes, they will require an extension to the term of the contract, but they will typically agree to discuss the subscription rates.  Price Analysis and Negotiation Strategy First, a bit of history that NPI has seen with Coupa.  Prior to their IPO in October 2016, Coupa?s pricing was truly the wild-wild-west.  It was not uncommon that they would manipulate list pricing to show whatever discount percentage they wanted.  Since the IPO, as a public company with more scrutiny, they have tamed their pricing practices a bit, but NPI would not call it ?stable? pricing.  In September of 2016, Coupa hired Steve Winter, former SAP executive, as their CRO.  Steve has brought SAP?s ?keep?em guessing? pricing methodologies to Coupa.  That is, Coupa will change their pricing roughly every 90-days? maybe not wholesale changes, but name changes and moving ?bundles? around so it is difficult for the market to get a bead on their pricing.  In looking at Chico?s pricing in this 2-year agreement, using list prices that we have seen in other Coupa proposals for the 4 included applications, we believe this proposal is discounted between 35% - 50%.  NPI considers this level of discounting to be in the range of Fair Market Value (FMV).  Chico?s may want to ask Coupa for list pricing for this proposal to see what they are claiming is the discount percentage.  Coupa will often push back on providing list price and if they provide it, it will need to be taken with a grain of salt ? see notes above about constant changes in pricing.  Having said the above we would also add that, based on the competitive landscape of the market, NPI believes there may be at least some small savings on this contract.  There are literally hundreds of  vendors that will do ?3-bids and a buy? functionality that Coupa sees as competitors to their S2P environment.  Even though many are not as robust as Coupa, they are credible enough to be a threat.  A message along the lines of, ?Verian (now part of Basware) has been courting us and as we?ve been evaluating their product, it appears it will satisfy most of our requirements at nearly half the cost.?, will get Coupa?s attention.  Other competitors worth mentioning: Jagger (formerly Sciquest), Zycus, Determine, GEP.  If Coupa asks for a target reduction, NPI recommends setting a target of a 20% reduction, but any improvement at all on this pricing is really icing on the cake.  Closing as FMV ... significant scope change - cut user count in half and paying more than initial quote.  Coupa recently (May 2017) acquired a company called Trade Extensions.  Trade Extensions is a top-of-the-line trading platform and significantly improves on the ?3-bids and a buy? functionality.  If Coupa offers to throw Trade Extensions in, NPI considers that a big concession.

file_info.name: Webster Vormetric Token Server Client 1YR Quote - #50555 v1[2].pdf

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Robert, Hey there.  Must be something about this space and how their vendors conceal their list prices.  I guess as security companies they are practicing what they preach ?.  While we?ve seen several Vormetric deals the SKUs often vary across our reviews and they don?t always show list pricing.  However, they do at times so we know they will provide it if asked.  Again, we got resourceful and tried to work through this and also leverage some public data.  I just got to a point where I think we are better off asking Trace3 to show add more transparency in their quote.  I think the SKUs are correct so that?s some good news.  The attached Excel file shows the work in progress.  I haven?t suggested targets yet since there?s too many open items.  Of note:  ?	VOR-TE ? listed for $6K about 12 months ago.  Let?s confirm this.  You may also want to take this time and ask about the bundled list price (and even net) that includes the Transparent Encryption Agent, Application Encryption and Tokenization. Another client bought the bundle (at MUCH bigger volumes ? 1,500) but paid $1K for each bundle. Webster is at $3,150 for just TE. You?re at less than 2% of their volume but I?m curious what they?d offer and it may be good to know if that?s on your roadmap.  If only two of these are of interest I don?t think they have a bundle for that but you could ask.  This other client didn?t have the Tokenization Client license so perhaps they?re configuring their solution differently than Webster. o	The quantity of 25 for VOR-TE and VOR-VTE-LTD brings up another topic to push for clarity on. From the limited pricing I?ve seen there?s a clear example on their Data Encryption Agent license where the first one is $6K, ten cost $45K (or $4500 each) and 25 cost $100K or $4K each).  I think now is the time to make sure they show you what all these tiers look like to ensure you?re getting both the programmatic volume discount and the additional discount you?d get on a first-time competitive buy. ?	VOR-VTE-LTD ? the one item I had no traction finding list pricing for ?	VOR-TOKEN ? educated guess is this is also at $6K list ?	The DSM Enterprise Parts I believe have the same list and they just discount non-prod more than prod.  The list could be $30K or something north of $40K.  That reflects quite a swing in discounting so it is a key item to validate.  I?d be appreciative if you could also ask them for the list price of the physical DSM Enterprise equivalent. Perhaps you could say someone asked about that option and you wanted to understand it more.  I think it lists for at least $5K more. ?	On the Support side, Standard is always 18% of net and Premium is 22%.  We?ve never seen Premium+ which is what?s reflected on your quote.  Below is a picture of the comparison of these two in their SW Lic Agreement.  They?re offering the + at 23% of the total hardware and software net.  Doesn?t sound like a bad uplift over Premium assuming you?re getting something more.  Consider your options there.  ?	Some services details are shown. o	Vormetric?s rack rate is $2,500/day. VOR-PRO-SERV is the SKU.  We?ve seen it not discounted typically.   o	Program Review and Roadmap Dev seems like it?ll be work done by Trace3 for a fixed fee of $51,800. They mention a Security Architect and PM. No hours are mentioned.   We?d expect this to reflect some hourly estimate applied against the rates and then a 10-20% uplift for the risk involved with a fixed fee engagement.  Maybe ask about a T&M to get exposure to the rates and effort. o	Product Install appears to be Vormetric people.  Offered at $12,500 that?s 5 days at their $2,500 rack rate.  That number of days doesn?t seem bloated.  In a competitive environment feels like that could be something to push for free. o	Tech Design and Impl - $67,500 for 6 weeks. That?s $11,250 a week or $2,250 a day if one resource which is exactly 10% off the Vormetric daily rack rate of $2500. It includes an Architect, Engineer and PM but again is offered at a fixed amount so no effort/hours noted.  Push for some clarity around this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric. On the one hand you?d expect a lower rate with Trace3 but oftentimes partners bring more senior resources to bear than the OEM/Publisher. o	Roadmap and Mentoring is offered at $51,800 and is T&M. It is largely an architect at $300.  We can benchmark this.  Is this Trace3 or Vormetric.  We?ll work on what we can but let me know if you expect to reach out to Trace3 for this additional detail.  Now is the time and no reason to spend this money if there?s any questions about the transparency of the offer.  Also, do you expect future growth.  Getting transparency now sets you up for that.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: Went with Vormetric.  Final quote increased in size largely due to Token Server Client item growing from 1 to 18.  The only reductions appear to be on the DSM units as both the Prod and non prod had reductions.  Maintenance also dropped from 23% to 20%.   The initial quotes didn't clear show all the non prod info that was shown in the final.  Estimating savings and new baseline but not overthinking it.  Future folks should use the final docs (also some list pricing in XLS) and new SME.
deal_metadata.description: Webster Bank is currently looking at a solution that can provide a solution that can provide enterprise key management across Webster?s applications on premise and in the cloud.  Currently key management at Webster Bank is not a cohesive process but maintained by the individual systems that use keys.  Reply to first offer: We?ll take a look.  From my first pass I can tell you the Trace3 (Vormetric) SOW is too light on details.  There?s a lot ($530K+) of services with no resources, rates and hours so it can?t be benchmarked.  There?s also a sizable placeholder for hardware, licenses and support for $501K with no detail.  Trace3 needs to provide a Vormetric quote showing all the usual details (SKUs, list, net, quantities).  Webster came back on 3/13 with a revised spreadsheet showing list pricing.  Some sizable increases. Sent a second round of feedback on 3/14. see email.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: NPI reviewed BNYM?s Kofax pricing and found pricing to be within fair market value (FMV). Software pricing is solidly within the range of FMV, but maintenance costs have room for improvement based on NPI?s data and similar reviews.  NPI sees the greatest factors of leverage in similarly-sized Kofax spends to be timing pressure and the degree of open competition involved.  Without both of those factors, it is difficult but still feasible to achieve savings targets. If Kofax already knows they?re the preferred vendor and/or no credible threat exists, NPI recommends manifesting uncertainty around this decision point.  Ideally, BNYM should float a high-level net target to the reseller and follow this with a short break in communication to make the vendors nervous about this forecasted deal.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: ?	NPI suggests using a rounded net amount of $800k as a talking point with the reseller and vendor, and to avoid mentioning any specific discounting. Say that this is the target needed to keep this within the March timeframe. o	Messaging can focus on attaining a slight relief on capital costs, but also emphasize that high relative operational expenses are the main factor causing BNYM to pause before proceeding with this purchase.
deal_metadata.description: Closing remarks: BNYM did not give a true indication as to closing costs, but did indicate they had prorated maintenance reduced which would imply at least a $6.6k save.  We indicated this was mostly FMV with opportunity, but client is trying not to count this as a report   BNYM is reviewing a proposal from reseller Document Imaging Group for Kofax?s TotalAgility platform.
